Women and men farmers’ labor use was quantified in Cote d’Ivoire and Madagascar (some results are available in this report on gender section).  Social impact indicators of SRP including Women empowerment and labor requirements were revised and shared with SRP members.SRP standard study in Nigeria assessed requirements for SRP standard, and the result showed that child labor and labor rights are major issues, followed by safety and health issues.

Achieved in two out of three target countries, in collaboration with CCAFS:•Philippines: Rejesus et al., 2017, Adoption and impact of alternate wetting and drying (AWD) water management for irrigated rice production in the Philippines), a final report submitted to the Standing Panel on Impact Assessment (SPIA). •Bangladesh: http://ccacoalition.org/en/news/farmers-northwestern-bangladesh-learn-grow-climate-friendly-rice •Vietnam: extended to 2018

A paper on farming systems analysis was published in Africa (Paresys et al., 2018) [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0308521X16303420]. Farming systems surveys were conducted in Madagascar, Rwanda, and Senegal. Preliminary study in Madagascar identified positive relationship on farm size, revenues and level of crop diversification, and key important crops for farm diversification in both lowlands and uplands.We could not finalize data collection and analysis in all the countries in Africa due to delayed implementation of farming systems survey. Thus, this milestone will be extended to 2018. The reasons for delayed implementation was due to the fact that AfricaRice and other partners (RTB, World Vegetable Center, WU) spent a lot of time discussing content of the survey and developing survey protocols.Baseline farming descriptions were completed for parts of India (Bihar, Eastern Uttar Pradesh), Bangladesh, and Myanmar.  Unlocking the production potential of “polder communities” in coastal Bangladesh through improved resource use efficiency and diversified cropping systems. Technical Report submitted to the Kansas State University, USA.Completed, and extended for more analyses

Expert survey was conducted in Africa, and data were analyzed. Key interventions that will help strengthening capacity on farming systems research were financial support, training, and information sharing. Partially complete (in Africa)

The draft protocol for the Antenna and Reference population was developed and shared with all the partners for their comments.Target sites in SA, SEA, China, Africa and LA are identified for the GRA panels.Zwart SJ et al. Future rice climates in Africa. Rice Today IRRI. June 10 2017 [http://books.irri.org/RT16_2_content.pdf]Van Oort and Zwart. Impacts of climate change on rice production in Africa and causes of simulated yield. Global Change Biology. DOI:10.1111/gcb.1396 [https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/gcb.13967]https://dataverse.harvard.edu/dataverse/AfricaRice?q=pepijnPublication of the baseline information underway (work funded by a consultancy for the European Commission).CIATPartly achieved (publication pending), importation of antenna panel underway

1. Antenna Panel is finalized through global consensus with participating institutions like IRRI, CIAT, AfricaRice, CIRAD and JIRCAS. 2. Seed import from contributing organizations is a big challenge but we have obtained seed of about 60 genotypes including those cleared by the IRRI Seed Health Unit (SHU) and the Philippine Bureau of Plant Industry (BPI).3. MAGIC – Indica population will be used as reference population but discussion is going on for future reference panel.4. Antenna panel shared with 7 locations for 2018 DS [IRRI-HQ (1), India (2), Myanmar (1), Vietnam (1), Bangladesh (1) and Burundi (1)].5. Some of the national partners are investing in the GRA (ICAR-India). Has procured 2 drones setup in India for HTP. Training on drone-based HTP is planned in 2018 by IRRI expert to support the project’s efficiency. Target sites are operational but due to limited funding no NARES site was included. Phenotyping/screening facilities are being upgraded in Mbe http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/pbi.12675/fullhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/pbi.12731/full; https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0924271617300357Partially complete: In process as formal seed importation, multiplication and dispatch take a long time. Testing sites would be fully functional in 2018.

Delay was due to the relocation from Cotonou to Bouake. Will be considered as a 2018 milestone- Design of VNTR primers for Burkholderia glumae typing, and validation on a collection of strains isolated in Colombia - Design of an MLVA scheme for Pantoea species - Development of multi-pathogen molecular detection tools - Intensive field work in six sites from southwestern Burkina Faso in ca 45 farmer’s fields with farmer’s interviews (rice variety and agricultural practices) and detailed epidemiological data for RYMV, bacterial leaf streak (BLS) and brown spot - Assays (three varieties, two agricultural practices treatments) in two sites with detailed symptom data for viral, bacterial and fungal diseases, nematodes and insects- Upgrading RYMV core collection (serotyping of 150 isolates from Bénin, Togo, Niger, Mali, Ghana and Nigeria) and sequencing of 35 isolates- Nematode survey in Vietnam, Philippine and Cambodia. A core collection and cryo-conservation of rice parasite nematodes was built. Mitochondrial genome was sequenced from these populations to assess their diversity.Publication by Ma et al. 2018. in Nematology (2018)- Field survey in Vietnam (Hai Duong) in highly nematode infected fields due to agricultural change practices: Description of the microbiome, soil and cultural practices to reveal major factors that should explain the parasitism- Building of a large collection of bacterial rice endophytes from Senegal, Burkina-Faso and Vietnam (>2000 isolates), characterized at taxonomic level (16S sequencing) and screen for in vitro plant-growth properties. - First RNAseq data of the transcriptomic response of the Rice Nipponbare (roots, leaves) to the colonization by two bacterial endophytes, has been produced and is being analyzed for publication.AfricaRice extended  -  IRD achieved

Availability of the genotypic data for the MAGIC indica population was confirmed (see details for FP4 in section 1.2).Publication of NSC promising QTls underway- SNiPlay workflows for diversity, population structure analysis and GWAS studies was achieved (http://sniplay.southgreen.fr/)-A Common Galaxy Rice instance integrating Reusable workflows for rice genomic and genetic analyses has been developed (http://galaxy.irri.org/ and http://13.250.212.83/)- An R package dedicated for rice gene functional annotation has been developed (collaboration with Dr Ho Bich Hai).

At IRRI- 422 entries screened for stagnant flooding with 10 tolerant types found. Initial GWAS accomplished. 2190 genotypes screened for seedling stage salinity with 12 tolerant genotypes identified. Reproductive stage salinity screening is on-going, 663 genotypes screened for zinc deficiency identifying 4 tolerant genotypes. 100 genotypes screened for drought, blast and blb identifying several donors per trait. 800 indica lines screened for leaf water potential, 100 selected for further evaluation. All 3K genotypes examined for mutations in EIF4G with 12 potential resistance alleles in 271 genotypes for RTSV, 90% confirmed by phenotyping. Lines possessing horizontal resistance for blast identified at IRRI, new donors for sheath blight possessing partial resistance identified at IRRI. Photosynthetic and leaf morphology measurements taken on 400 indica lines. 30 contrasting entries chosen for screen house phenotyping. zinc/Iron grain content evaluated for HDRA aus panel (250 entries), several donor lines identified and with significant GWAS peaks. Confirmatory evaluation is on-going. At JIRCAS- 12 Indonesian donors/recipient screened for tolerance to Iron toxicity.

At IRRI- 1k Amplicon panel now available as GSL service (http://gsl.irri.org/genotyping/rice-custom-amplicon-1k) and manuscript nearly completed. At CIAT-The second major version of MapDisto was released, with several new major features: (i) handling of very large genotyping datasets like the ones generated by GBS; (ii) direct importation and conversion of Variant Call Format (VCF) files; (iii) detection of linkage, i.e. construction of linkage groups in case of segregation distortion; (iv) data imputation on VCF files using a new approach, called LB-Impute. Features i to iv operate through inclusion of new At CIAT, Java modules that are used transparently by MapDisto; (v) QTL detection via a new R/to graphical interface. The version 2 beta 109 of MapDisto now provides a tool to calculate local recombination values using a sliding window and smoothing methods, and to display Marey maps. It handles recombinant inbred lines populations, and therefore handles NAM data. Download is available at http://mapdisto.free.fr. 22 NAM recombinants around one major QTL for resistance to Striga hermonthica (collaboration with Julie Scholes, University of Sheffield, UK) as well as recombinants around two new QTLs for secondary branching rate in panicles, contrasting between indica and japonica (publication in preparation) were identified.Release of MapDisto v2 (gene /QTL mapping tool) with several new major features suitable for large genotyping datasets and QTL detection in recombinant inbred lines populations and NAM populations. Download is available at http://mapdisto.free.fr.- Application for precision breeding around 2-3 candidate QTLs of interest by the identification of NAM recombinant lines.

More than 10 lines from GRiSP nominated for release by national partners. Rice varieties from FLAR germplasm released in LAC MARIEN FL (Dominican Republic) include-IDIAP FL 72-17 (Panama), ESTRELLA FL 161 (Panama), FL FEDEARROZ Orotoy (Colombia), FL FEDEARROZ Itagua (Colombia), INIAP FL Arenillas (Ecuador). At AfricaRice- 6 irrigated lowland varieties were released in Senegal including ARICA 12, AR051H (hybrid), WAS 73-B-B-231-4, IR 72593-B-3-2-3-8-2B, 08 FAN 10, WAB 2098-WAC3-1-TGR2-WAT 85, FAROX 521-288-H1. At IRRI two varieties- Musesekara, Kazogi in Burundi and NSICRc 508 in Philippines were released

New breeding lines with high yield and at least 10% reduced loss under drought, submergence, salinity developed for mega deltas. At AfricaRice- for stagnant flooding - 495 F5 lines screened and 280 lines advanced to F6; 110 F6 lines screened and 70 lines advanced to F7, for drought- 543 F4 lines screened and 185 advanced to F5; 115 F5 screened and 25 lines advanced to F6, for Iron-toxicity - 280 F6 lines screened and 170 lines advanced to F7.

Consumer and market oriented product profile developed for different breeding zones in South Asia, South East Asia and East and Southern Africa. At IRRI- product profile for 26 breeding zones for 17 countries developed, At AfricaRice- product profile for 20 countries developed-Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Cote d’lvoire, DR Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, Ghana, Kenya, Malawi, Mali, Morocco, Nigeria, Rwanda, Sudan, Uganda, Tanzania, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Madagascar, Guinea.
Development of transgenic lines with 10 genes under progress. During 2017, selection of homozygous lines with 10 genes are underway.

The CDS app can be used with any internet enabled device such as smartphone, tablet, computer or other. The CDS features enable follow-up inspections, lab confirmatory testing, and solutions to prevent and control crop pests. Current status: Technologies for conservation and sustainable use of PGRFA (new wheat collection available for characterization, routine use of markers, application of GWAS and physiological trait-based breeding) co-developed by and/or transferred to Turkish and Iranian PGRFA institutions (Turkish Seed Gene Bank, Field Crop Research Institute in Ankara, Bahri Dagdas International Agricultural Research Institute in Konya, Karaj-SPII in Iran).

The work of WLE and partners in Northern Ghana [https://drive.google.com/file/d/1SbIrk5xr9T9imtWV9GccxFbBeTjyg32T/view ; https://drive.google.com/file/d/1UPyWO0vHX2XsAe-xYBPev6u1wXAP6Taz/view] is embedded in the Savannah Accelerated Development Authority (SADA) stakeholder platform. WLE’s research and engagement with platform stakeholders covers a range of issues including bringing in women and vulnerable groups into decision making on land and water resources.   WLE continues to be present in the Upper-Tana Nairobi Water Fund [https://ciat.cgiar.org/outcome/investing-in-water-the-upper-tana-nairobi-water-fund/], which provides opportunities to support restoration pilots. To enhance efficiency and reach, WLE decided that the most appropriate entry point for policy influence in Kenya is through county governments, with work with the Makueni well underway and initial links made with Laikipia, Bungoma, Siaya and Kakamega. Also in Africa, a WLE informed stakeholder platform on land restoration generated a soil and water management action plan in Tanzania [https://ccafs.cgiar.org/news/lushoto-district-climate-change-learning-alliance-reveals-priorities-land-restoration#.WzsRkfkzaM8]; and restoration pilots were implemented in Ethiopia, with a review to be published in 2018.

WLE has started - and will continue - to engage with the private sector to build bankable land restoration investment portfolios. Examples are ASAS Dairies (Tanzania), Solidaridad, and F3Life. A key focus for 2018 is the development of a business case for land restoration of Makueni county in Kenya, to attract public-private investment

The Packard Foundation approved an investment for land restoration [https://marlo.cgiar.org/projects/WLE/deliverable.do?deliverableID=3264&edit=true&phaseID=13] piloting in Oromiya, Ethiopia. A high level US delegation visited the Jordan watershed restoration project [https://marlo.cgiar.org/projects/WLE/highlight.do?highlightID=285&projectID=562&edit=true&phaseID=13], which evaluates land restoration impacts on ecosystems services on soil and vegetation, with a view to future investment

WLE is in contact with national partners, NGO, as well as county government officials from these three counties. WLE researchers interact through 1:1 meetings, official workshops [https://marlo.cgiar.org/projects/WLE/deliverable.do?deliverableID=8130&edit=true&phaseID=13], field days, and by email. WLE has have developed an online tool [https://gis-slu.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7dedcad3f475459096f095f86fe27fd5] for assessing carbon and other soil fertility properties.This work will extend into 2018.

Assistance has been provided to Ghana and Nigeria to set up national soil information systems (GhaSIS, NiSIS) based on mid-infrared spectroscopy. Both countries have large-scale soil surveys and agronomic trials in progress to diagnose soil degradation and crop nutritional deficiencies using the new technology. WLE has also been involved in collaboration and training of Namibian UNCCD LDN scientists [https://www.isric.online/projects/developing-baselines-land-degradation-neutrality-target-setting-namibia] on digital soil mapping.

WLE/CIAT has become an official 20x20 and AFR100 [https://afr100.org/content/international-center-tropical-agriculture] technical partner, and supports Kenyan county governments in restoration planning (see outcome 1.1). Increased visibility has also been achieved via active involvement in GLF-Bonn 2017; the FAO GSP Global Symposium on Soil Organic Carbon [https://www.slideshare.net/ExternalEvents/enhancing-soc-sequestration-myth-or-reality-in-africa]; and UNCCD COP13 [http://blog.worldagroforestry.org/index.php/2017/09/17/integrated-approaches-multifunctional-landscapes-connecting-ldn-biodiversity-climate-change/]

Working papers on testing the framework with stakeholders (IUCN, Technoserve) were published (Probablistic Decision Modelling [http://www.worldagroforestry.org/downloads/Publications/PDFS/WP18008.pdf], Marsabit; DryDev’s effectiveness through Probabilistic Decision Modelling [http://www.worldagroforestry.org/downloads/Publications/PDFS/WP17107.pdf]; Valuing ecosystem services in rangelands through stochastic simulation [https://doi.org/10.1002/ldr.2590]). The main framework paper was submitted for publication and is under review.
For Tanzania, samples have taken in One Acre Fund trials and TanSIS crop surveys. Sample analysis is in progress and preliminary data sets have been generated for Kenya.

This milestone covers several stages of progress, towards which the project is on track. Three business models [http://www.iwmi.cgiar.org/About_IWMI/PDF/capability-statements/r4d-capabilities-solar-powered-irrigation.pdf] will be published in 2018: Exclosures in Ethiopia [https://cgspace.cgiar.org/handle/10568/81251], and solar pump based irrigation [http://www.iwmi.cgiar.org/2017/11/a-bright-future-for-solar-powered-irrigation/] in Ethiopia [http://www.iwmi.cgiar.org/2018/03/iwmi-research-report-172-business-model-scenarios-and-suitability-smallholder-solar-pump-based-irrigation-in-ethiopia/] and Ghana.

A number of recommendations have been incorporated into policy and development programs e.g. Tax Exemption on irrigation equipment (Ethiopia); Soil fertility maps (Ethiopia); Government of Uttar Pradesh (India) has requested WLE partners to scale up pilots on integrated agricultural water management techniques across the state .In Ghana there have been requests for further support from various stakeholders, including from the Ministry of Agriculture on conservation agriculture; from a Danish pump company considering market expansion and from iDE.

In Myanmar, LIFT [https://www.lift-fund.org/] asked WLE to research if there are business models that could make wetting front detector technology accessible. Supermarket chain Metro sought knowledge from WLE researchers as to whether farmers could supply consistently high value crops e.g. chillies, to customers in Yangon.  The Myanmar Irrigation and Water Management department has stated a wish to scale the institutional innovations that are being piloted in the Pyawt Ywar Pump Irrigation Project. In Zimbabwe, after initial delays due to government restructure, work has now started Matabeleland north and south. Planned work in Nigeria with the World Bank was cancelled.

Research and capacity development by WLE to improve water productivity using a new technology (wetting front detectors) in the 6000h irrigation scheme in Koga, Ethiopia, [https://cgspace.cgiar.org/rest/bitstreams/118552/retrieve] is ongoing.  In Egypt, extensive research has been conducted into management practices in the irrigated areas of the Nile Delta, which is being analysed and finalized for future use to support policy and practice to target improvements in agricultural water productivity and water use efficiency.

In 2017, City Region Food Systems (CRFS) assessments [http://www.ruaf.org/city-region-food-system-partner-cities] were completed in Colombo [http://www.fao.org/in-action/food-for-cities-programme/pilotcities/activitiescolombo/en/] and Quito, with further assessments under way in Nairobi, Tamale, Quagadougou [http://www.mdpi.com/2071-1050/8/12/1175/pdf], Cali, Medellin and Toronto. Assessments were based on stakeholder consultations and focused on the analysis of the whole CRFS, or a particular foodshed, urban agriculture, value chains or food security indicators based on the Milan Urban Food Policy Pact.

The 4 cities of Cali [https://twitter.com/NutricionCali/status/873518790423785472], Quito, Nairobi, and most recently, Palmira, are being assisted in their work on CRFS indicators for progress monitoring [http://www.ruaf.org/projects/developing-tools-mapping-and-assessing-sustainable-city-region-food-systems-cityfoodtools] and urban food security/safety strategies or policies. The city of Quito [https://twitter.com/NutricionCali/status/873518790423785472] is in the process of developing its own territorial food strategy. With support from RUAF/WLE, the city agreed to define key indicators for each of the pillars of the food strategy. In 2017, a very first draft of the indicator framework was formulated. Support has been provided to Nairobi to a similar level (to be reported in 2018).
Two MoU’s with the private plantation sector (Mike Flora (Pvt) Ltd. and Horana Plantations PLC) have been signed followed by the set-up of field trials for testing WLE recommendations in Sri Lanka.

The RRR business modules [https://wle.cgiar.org/business-models-fecal-sludge-management] on fecal sludge have been designed and submitted to the MOOC operating agency (SANDEC) which is working on their integration in the existing fecal sludge management MOOC. Once the WLE modules have been integrated, they should appear as part of the course, here [https://www.coursera.org/learn/faecalsludge]. WLE partner CEWAS, which specializes in start-up support, translated our latest research findings into a curriculum [https://sites.google.com/wyb.ac.lk/db3r] which will be tested in 2018.

WLE advised ADB on the construction and business models for fecal sludge management for two towns in Nepal. Based on our advice, the designs were modified and tendering was done for the construction. A Greywater guidance note was developed for World Bank staff use in India. Similar advisory activities continue in 2018. (Documents relating to Advisory Services [feasibility studies, guidance notes] are internal and therefore not in the public domain.)

A wastewater guidance note was developed for the Indian Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs in collaboration with the World Bank.  This is awaiting finalizing following structural changes in the Ministry. This activity has been supported by pilots for sanitation for low-income communities in Delhi; business models for RRR/solid waste management in Maharashtra, and training of trainers and support to state strategies on Solid, Liquid and Fecal Sludge Management in so far 9 villages of Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Jharkhand state.

This milestone has been extended as a result of a delay in making insurance payouts in Bihar. WLE produced a technical brief, "Reducing vulnerability among smallholder farmers through index-based flood insurance in India: equity matters" [https://wle.cgiar.org/reducing-vulnerability-among-smallholder-farmers-through-index-based-flood-insurance-india-equity] that made some progress towards the milestone. Furthermore, key results of the gender and equity survey from Bihar was presented along with the overall IBFI project findings at a policy dialogue workshop on flood insurance and drought management.
The preliminary framework for Southern Africa [http://www.fao.org/emergencies/regions/southern-africa/intro/en/] is complete.

Some discussions occurred with CIMMYT, custodian of the Wheat and Maize CRPs, to understand groundwater challenges underlying the production systems of the Eastern Gangetic Plains. However there was no funding available to pursue this.

This WISE-UP [http://www.waterandnature.org/initiatives/wise-climate] project, led by IUCN, increased understanding of the inter-linkages between natural and built infrastructure in two river basins (Volta and Tana), within government and also non-government organizations. This was achieved through action learning meetings which highlighted the importance of working through and understanding trade-offs in order to identify sustainable development pathways in the light of climate change.

In conjunction with UNE, WLE developed guidance on indicators for SDG 6.6.1 [http://www.iwmi.cgiar.org/Publications/wle/reports/guideline_and_indicators_for_target_6-6_of_the_sdgs-5.pdf] and a draft paper on SDG6 interlinkages [https://www.icsu.org/cms/2017/05/SDG-interactions-working-paper.pdf] with other SDG goals and targets completed using the ICSU framework that was also co-developed with WLE.
WLE made progress in terms of consolidating and extending GRIPP [https://spark.adobe.com/page/zp0S5XfNRkTCv/] through new partnerships, bringing the partner total to 29.

In Lao PDR, the first national hydro-geological map and dataset [http://www.mdpi.com/2306-5338/5/1/2] were handed over to the Groundwater Division of the Department of Water Resources, for use in national groundwater planning and management (Groundwater in Laos paper) [https://intranet.iwmi.org/hydrogeological-maps-and-data-handed-over-to-department-of-water-resources-laos.aspx]. More trials in India confirmed that additional volumes of water stored in the aquifer do bring benefits [http://utfi.iwmi.org/resources.aspx] for farming households.

The Knowledge Action Network of Future Earth issued a development strategy [http://www.futureearth.org/research-and-engagement-plan] that was informed by WLE activities.The Nile Basin Initiative invited WLE researchers to put together the first Nile Basin Economist Workshop [http://nilebasin.org/index.php/new-and-events/145-economists-forum-provides-opportunity-to-multiply-benefits-in-the-nile-basin] in May 2017, based on the economic modeling analysis of water-energy-food nexus tools. The Asian Development Bank requested guidance on how to ensure that irrigation modernization and rehabilitation projects are not only effective but are also energy-efficient.A national scale (Ethiopia) energy modelling study [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0360544218302950] was published, followed by policy and capacity building events [http://capacity.ifpri.info/2018/02/01/energy-model-options-for-policy-planning] on energy supply and demand modeling in response to requests from the Ethiopian Ministry of Water, Irrigation and Energy.
The redesigned WLE Flagship 5 [https://cgiar.sharepoint.com/:b:/s/WLE/EcK0IXWA6ctKgNMj0Ao2uhoBiN42e0_81oofDuIi-db_wQ?e=P4DrGw] was approved by the CGIAR/ ISPC in November 2017.

The redesigned WLE Flagship 5 was approved. This document and the subsequent 2018 workplan incorporated bilateral project results including building on the range of decision support and decision analysis tools; ecosystem service modeling using different approaches at scale, and synergy and trade-off analysis of management interventions. Case studies will focus on existing research, likely to focus on Uganda, Ethiopia, South East Asia.

Evidence is being generated by a series of bilaterally funded initiatives, eg on the development of methods [http://hdl.handle.net/10568/89209] that support agro-biodiversity inclusion in local and global land use management decisions.Comprehensive review undertaken of integrated landscape initiatives [http://hdl.handle.net/10568/80942] n 16 countries across Asia illustrates that institutional and stakeholder capacity is key to success.  Multiple methods for mapping small reservoirs were tested in the Volta Basin (Mapping Reservoirs [https://cgspace.cgiar.org/handle/10568/83038]; Big data and mapping small reservoirs [https://cgspace.cgiar.org/handle/10568/89845]). The developed Ecosystem Service maps can be applied to decisions on agricultural practices on landscape, watershed, and potentially global level.

An analysis of the impacts of agricultural policy [https://doi.org/10.1002/2017EF000765] on household nutrition was published. A decision analysis methods guide [http://www.worldagroforestry.org/downloads/Publications/PDFS/WP18001.pdf] was produced on agricultural policy for nutrition.The MESH-SDG tool [https://docs.google.com/document/d/15Oc-p8iw1kw40PFjfW3a1W7GSimoMbvDeRvPlczMqCQ/edit], designed to illustrate how changes in ecosystem services under alternative land use land cover conditions could impact on progress towards the SDGs was designed and tested in Honduras and Ghana.A study on heterogeneity in riverine ecosystem service perceptions: Insights for water-decision processes in transboundary rivers (IFPRI) was published, from which perceptions of ecosystems in the Indus, Mekong and Niger basins can help in understanding how decisions are taken.A spatially scalable, generalized agent-based modeling (ABM) framework [http://ebrary.ifpri.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15738coll5/id/6092] was tested in the Mekong and Niger River basins, shedding light on holistic food-water-energy-environment management policies in these two basins. The Enabling Decision-Making for Agricultural Interventions tool [https://dataverse.harvard.edu/api/access/datafile/3172758] integrates knowledge and systems thinking in making decisions for agricultural issues. This was applied to a case study in Lagdwenda, Burkina Faso and will be expanded to 3 other countries in 2018. A novel method [https://cgspace.cgiar.org/handle/10568/89845] to map reservoirs and quantify the uncertainty of Landsat derived reservoir area estimates (specifically from the Global Surface Water Monthly Water History (GSW) dataset) was tested on the Volta River Basin. This study provides guidance on the conditions with which GSW and other Landsat-based surface water maps can be used to accurately monitor reservoir resources.

outcome_sumary: The impact model as developed jointly by IFPRI and collaborating CGIAR centers was applied to beans on a country by country basis. As expected, the model predicts significant growth in bean productivity, although it underestimates realized gain in Ethiopia where government support attained the predicted gains in 10 years instead of 30 years. Unfortunately, the model does not permit experimenting with theoretical changes, for example, in annual genetic gain under different breeding innovations, or improved markets that incentivize use of inputs. Such innovations must be explored independently.A breeding population for early cooking time was developed using sources described in a recent publication with ABC breeding material. A bush breeding diversity panel was evaluated for cooking time (CKT) and well performing lines were used in the described crosses. This population is now to be sown in F3. A climbing bean panel has also been evaluated for CKT, in order to use the data in upcoming crosses. A publication on evaluations of CKT in 4 populations is being developed. ACIAR-Australia is funding a genomic selection project on cooking time.Platforms focus on product profiles that have established consumer/buyer demand. Business platforms have been established in the red mottled bean corridor in Uganda (with 2 lead firms), Tanzania, Rwanda (3 lead firms) and Burundi (1 lead firm). One platform was established in the yellow bean corridor in Tanzania in the Kagera region (1 lead firm). In Southern Tanzania, in the sugar bean corridor, another platform has been set up (1 lead firm). The Ethiopian platforms are established for the white pea bean corridor with a series of cooperatives and private sector off-takers.One of the key areas supported by ABC is scaling up value added bean products via micro and small-scale entrepreneurs in a number of countries. Producer groups have also been trained within the framework of business platforms, where some of the training areas include collective production and marketing, management of finances, quality control and gender empowerment among others. In total, 1500 entrepreneurs were trained, about 30% women.ABC supported small-scale entrepreneurs to develop six bean composite flour products in Burundi, Uganda, Rwanda, Tanzania, Kenya, Madagascar, Zambia, Malawi and Zimbabwe. The products are principally nutrient-dense porridges targeting children and women. CIAT supported studies in i) establishing willingness to consume and pay; ii) linking farmers to processors via bean platforms, iii) trainings with grain processors and bean off-takers on how to get certification from governments, iv) nutrient analysis of bean-based flours and v) supporting women entrepreneurs in value addition of bean products. These efforts will be scaled in several countries including Ghana, Cameroon, Lesotho and Eswatini.
milestone_evidence: 2019 Report to government of Canada. Delays in contracting a post doc required extension.
gender_justification: Women and men  play different but complementary  roles in bean production, distribution and consumption hubs. Beans research has mainstreamed the gender differentiation and research intervention  based on these different but complementary roles of both men and women
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Not required

other_reason: Interpreted literally, the first crosses were indeed created, but have not yet been shared with partners. This is continuous process depending on demand of complementary traits e.g. disease /drought tolerance and consumers preference.
gender_justification: Women/children play a key a role of food preparation including  looking for fuel supplies for cooking.
youth_justification: Women/children play a key a role of food preparation including  looking for fuel supplies for cooking.
capdev_justification: Capacity development  in bean research for NARS in breeding for short cooking time and later they will be information shared with  the consumers and soon to the bean retailers
climate_justification: Since the majority of consumers use biomass (fireword/crop residues) to cooking beans, this has effect on deforestation and eventually impact  climate. Therefore  short cooking time beans will reduce deforestation and contribute positively to climate change.

outcome_sumary:
Some
 123 Mesoamerican lines were developed in the drought tolerance breeding
 program with disease resistance and promising levels of iron in red, black
 and yellow grain color classes. In the Andean program 200 lines from a
 population developed for drought and BCMV resistance (p52) were evaluated in
 a drought and irrigated trial. 38 lines from a population developed for heat
 tolerance (p88) were evaluated in drought and irrigated conditions. Data
 needs to be analyzed to code new lines (~70), for multilocational
 testing.
milestone_evidence: Progress evidence: 2019 Report to government of Canada. This is an MSc student thesis who has been dedicated to the topic for a year and a half, under a Crop Diversity Trust project. Phenotyping for QTL analysis has been completed demonstrating wide variability in heat response.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Climate chanage is the main objective and is fundamental in the design and expected results in heat-tolerant breeding lines development.

milestone_evidence: Progress evidence: 2019 Report to government of Canada. Pythium resistance was evaluated in controlled screenhouse inoculations, and in a complex in the field, demonstrating correlation of results. ALS has not advanced but will need to be done in the field under inoculation with local isolates. Web blight is being evaluated in the UK.

capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Climate change is an important and deliberate objective, but not the principal reason in resistance confirmation.

other_reason: 1. Research/Science; 3. Partnership. Field phenotyping for virus resistance and for heat tolerance has been delayed, the latter by administrative steps in establishing a partnership. Crosses were made with a heat tolerants Mesoamerican line.  The breeding process was developed under moderate conditions of heat. The total of 25 advanced lines were then tested under moderately severe heat conditions and at the moment we have seven lines of Andean type that can produce seed in the caribbean coast where the nighttime temperatures exceed 22 degrees Celsius.  In a second season a subsequent group with differents comercial types (red mottled, red and pink) will be evaluated. For diseases, the Phg-2 gene for angular leaf spot resistance is being employed in the Andean gene pool.

A second tentative QTL region has been identified for a gemini virus in Colombia that is related to BGYMV. One last trial is in the field at the moment to obtain one more season of phenotypic data for the validation phase with both Mesoamerican and Andean panels.

outcome_sumary:
Some
 123 Mesoamerican lines were developed in the drought tolerance breeding
 program with disease resistance and promising levels of iron in red, black
 and yellow grain color classes. In the Andean program 200 lines from a
 population developed for drought and BCMV resistance (p52) were evaluated in

 testing.
milestone_evidence: Progress evidence: 2019 Report to government of Canada. Pod filling is a descriptive indicator of photosynthate transport to grain and was characterized in a UK funded project, BBACO. One related paper was published on leaf cooling (directly related to photoassimilates transport) in heat treated beans (Deva et al. 2020) as a heat resistance mechanism. Another paper (Suarez et al., under review) recognized 3 different groups from 70 genotypes which differ in their photosynthetic acclimation upon chronic heat. All published and ready-to publish results also contain data obtained by MultispeQ (PhotosynQ, fotosynthetic efficiency, fluorescence, leaf temperater, SPAD, etc.) which orchestrate with other phenotypic data. So far, the higher specific leaf area, higher photosynthetic efficiency (enzymatic), higher stomatal conductance and more negative leaf temperature were recognized as most important traits for phenotyping bean to heat resistance. However, the data complexity require multidimensional processing. The BBACO project will continue one more year with the ABC-CIAT physiologist in collaboration with colleagues and Reading U, Rodhamstead Inst., Manchester University and Leeds U. There are 30 000 (!) pods grown under heat ready to be analyzed. Seeds (not pollen) are the final complex product of photosynthate remobilization, the 4 different seed categories (normal, deformed, aborted seeds and aborted ovules) were selected to describe different seed filling at different seed positions. Our hypothesis is that seed position and seed categories differ between resistant and sensitive genotypes upon heat (as mainly the seed closest to apex is regularly filled). This detailled analysis is able sufficiently answer the question about the role of pod wall in photoassimilates redistribution and its effect on intra-pod abortion rates.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: The focus of the milestone is indeed climate change and the response of bean under rising temperatures associated with climate change. The Milestone could be worded as 'Researchers characterized limits on photosynthate transport to grain under heat stress induced by high temperatures of climate change.

milestone_evidence: Progress evidence: 2019 Report to government of Canada. Various climate smart and environmentally friendly pre- and post-harvest ICM practices (CA, minimum or no till, in-field water harvesting, use of root enhancing bioagents such as Trichoderma, weed management options, drying options e.g. solar bubbled driers) have been developed and recommended to partners.In Zimbabwe for example, the research teams under PABRA evaluated use of Trichoderma for reducing effects of drought on tow bean varieties (Cherry and Gloria) at two sites- Harare and Gwebi Research stations.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Climate chanage is the main objective and is fundamental in the design and expected results in developing ICM practices, and recommendation to partners.

outcome_sumary: The large seeded Mesoamerican bean lines’ drought-tolerance was tested against drought checks for two years. They also present excellent combining ability. The parentage of these lines does not reveal the source of their traits, with the exception of one parental line with superior low fertility tolerance. These lines illustrate the importance of maintaining a large number of crosses in a breeding program, to identify serendipitous combinations.Some 123 Mesoamerican lines were developed in the drought tolerance breeding program with disease resistance and promising levels of Fe in red, black and yellow grain color classes. In the Andean program, 200 lines from a population developed for drought and BCMV resistance were evaluated in a drought and irrigated trial. Thirty-eight lines from a population developed for heat tolerance were evaluated in drought and irrigated conditions. Data needs to be analyzed to code new lines (~70) for multi-location testing. Resistance to BLCrV was identified in Mesoamerican lines; so a population was developed to backcross this trait into Andean germplasm. The population was advanced under disease pressure, evaluated in two seasons, and is now entering yield trials.More than 70 families have been developed for heat tolerance. Several were evaluated under heat in the Caribia Research Station of AgroSavia, the Colombian national program. Other populations presented modest resistance to leafhoppers. Entomological studies demonstrate resistance or tolerance to leaf miners and white flies. Initial data on Fe concentration in some lines exhibit as much as 20 ppm above the baseline. These early results highlight the great value of tapping the tertiary gene pool.11,885 tons produced in 7 countries. Increased utilization of quality seed of improved varieties. Reduced time between the release and use. Increased number of seed producers engaged and increased seed business volume. Increased linkages between seed and grain production.An initial evaluation of wild P. acutifolius under a GCDT project revealed 2 accessions (G40287 and G40056) that could withstand night temperatures of 28oC and still produce seed. Families developed from these accessions were evaluated in the greenhouse under 25oC nights, with some 30 families presenting good pod formation. Further evaluation will support the search for QTL for heat tolerance. These lines complement other interspecific lines developed in previous years, of which the line SEF 16 emerged as the best in field trials on the north coast of Colombia.Greenhouse screening using breeding lines for ALS using aggressive strains identified MAB349 and MAB359 as promising resistant genotypes. Other genotypes such as NUA184, SMN184 and NXB080 showed acceptable levels of resistance.This was adopted as a PhD research topic, and thus was not pursued within the program.An R programme facilitates data processing from MSPQ tool for heat-related photosynthate transport, performing basic statistics, reflecting behavior under heat and identifying the best 10% genotypes. MPSQ seeks multidimensional evaluation of data to understand tolerance. Artificial intelligence to evaluate seed filling in scanning bleached bean pods is in final evaluation. We also verified that tolerant genotypes under heat elongate pods rapidly and consistently during pod elongation and later in seed-filling stage. An approach to evaluate abortion with and without heat shock is being developed in growth chambers.ABC research teams in Tanzania have shown that the use of micronutrients based fertilizers increase agricultural productivity by at least 25% across crops and geographies. Beyond phosphorus, research is needed on bean response to molybdenum, zinc, boron, manganese and copper.No new markers for BGMV have been tried this year. The MAGIC population needs to be evaluated for this trait in LAC, or the BASE needs to be re-evaluated in replicated trials.
milestone_evidence: SNP genotyping results from Intertek Sweden outsourcing service. Genetic markers are associated with important genes for resistance. More that 20,000 leaf samples were sent a laboratory in Sweden to detect presence of absence of 5 resistance genes.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Not required

The population was advanced under disease pressure, evaluated in two seasons, and is now entering yield trials.More than 70 families have been developed for heat tolerance. Entomological studies demonstrate resistance or tolerance to leaf miners and white flies. Initial data on Fe concentration in some lines exhibit as much as 20 ppm above the baseline. These early results highlight the great value of tapping the tertiary gene pool.11,885 tons produced in 7 countries. Increased utilization of quality seed of improved varieties. Reduced time between the release and use. Increased number of seed producers engaged and increased seed business volume. Increased linkages between seed and grain production.An initial evaluation of wild P. acutifolius under a GCDT project revealed 2 accessions (G40287 and G40056) that could withstand night temperatures of 28oC and still produce seed. Families developed from these accessions were evaluated in the greenhouse under 25oC nights, with some 30 families presenting good pod formation. Further evaluation will support the search for QTL for heat tolerance. These lines complement other interspecific lines developed in previous years, of which the line SEF 16 emerged as the best in field trials on the north coast of Colombia.Greenhouse screening using breeding lines for ALS using aggressive strains identified MAB349 and MAB359 as promising resistant genotypes. Other genotypes such as NUA184, SMN184 and NXB080 showed acceptable levels of resistance.This was adopted as a PhD research topic, and thus was not pursued within the program.An R programme facilitates data processing from MSPQ tool for heat-related photosynthate transport, performing basic statistics, reflecting behavior under heat and identifying the best 10% genotypes. MPSQ seeks multidimensional evaluation of data to understand tolerance. Artificial intelligence to evaluate seed filling in scanning bleached bean pods is in final evaluation. We also verified that tolerant genotypes under heat elongate pods rapidly and consistently during pod elongation and later in seed-filling stage. An approach to evaluate abortion with and without heat shock is being developed in growth chambers.ABC research teams in Tanzania have shown that the use of micronutrients based fertilizers increase agricultural productivity by at least 25% across crops and geographies. Beyond phosphorus, research is needed on bean response to molybdenum, zinc, boron, manganese and copper.No new markers for BGMV have been tried this year. The MAGIC population needs to be evaluated for this trait in LAC, or the BASE needs to be re-evaluated in replicated trials.
milestone_evidence: Progress evidence: 2019 Report to government of Canada. While a plan with partners was developed, multiple obstacles did not permit complete execution: civil unrest, plant quarantine issues, climate issues. The trial was lost at the site that normally supplies very reliable data. Data is yet to be compiled.
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Not required
climate_justification: Most lines had been developed for drought tolerance and thus the milestone was relevant for climate change, and drought is a primary objective for partnes who received seed. Wording was not adequate to explain the link to climate change, and should have read, 'Nurseries of 200 lines including many with  drought tolerance established with at least 5 partners...'

outcome_sumary: The large seeded Mesoamerican bean lines’ drought-tolerance was tested against drought checks for two years. They also present excellent combining ability. The parentage of these lines does not reveal the source of their traits, with the exception of one parental line with superior low fertility tolerance. These lines illustrate the importance of maintaining a large number of crosses in a breeding program, to identify serendipitous combinations.Some 123 Mesoamerican lines were developed in the drought tolerance breeding program with disease resistance and promising levels of Fe in red, black and yellow grain color classes. In the Andean program, 200 lines from a population developed for drought and BCMV resistance were evaluated in a drought and irrigated trial. Thirty-eight lines from a population developed for heat tolerance were evaluated in drought and irrigated conditions. Data needs to be analyzed to code new lines (~70) for multi-location testing. Resistance to BLCrV was identified in Mesoamerican lines; so a population was developed to backcross this trait into Andean germplasm. The population was advanced under disease pressure, evaluated in two seasons, and is now entering yield trials.More than 70 families have been developed for heat tolerance. Several were evaluated under heat in the Caribia Research Station of AgroSavia, the Colombian national program. Other populations presented modest resistance to leafhoppers. Entomological studies demonstrate resistance or tolerance to leaf miners and white flies. Initial data on Fe concentration in some lines exhibit as much as 20 ppm above the baseline. These early results highlight the great value of tapping the tertiary gene pool.11,885 tons produced in 7 countries. Increased utilization of quality seed of improved varieties. Reduced time between the release and use. Increased number of seed producers engaged and increased seed business volume. Increased linkages between seed and grain production.An initial evaluation of wild P. acutifolius under a GCDT project revealed 2 accessions (G40287 and G40056) that could withstand night temperatures of 28oC and still produce seed. Families developed from these accessions were evaluated in the greenhouse under 25oC nights, with some 30 families presenting good pod formation. Further evaluation will support the search for QTL for heat tolerance. These lines complement other interspecific lines developed in previous years, of which the line SEF 16 emerged as the best in field trials on the north coast of Colombia.Greenhouse screening using breeding lines for ALS using aggressive strains identified MAB349 and MAB359 as promising resistant genotypes. Other genotypes such as NUA184, SMN184 and NXB080 showed acceptable levels of resistance.This was adopted as a PhD research topic, and thus was not pursued within the program.An R programme facilitates data processing from MSPQ tool for heat-related photosynthate transport, performing basic statistics, reflecting behavior under heat and identifying the best 10% genotypes. MPSQ seeks multidimensional evaluation of data to understand tolerance. Artificial intelligence to evaluate seed filling in scanning bleached bean pods is in final evaluation. We also verified that tolerant genotypes under heat elongate pods rapidly and consistently during pod elongation and later in seed-filling stage. An approach to evaluate abortion with and without heat shock is being developed in growth chambers.ABC research teams in Tanzania have shown that the use of micronutrients based fertilizers increase agricultural productivity by at least 25% across crops and geographies. Beyond phosphorus, research is needed on bean response to molybdenum, zinc, boron, manganese and copper.No new markers for BGMV have been tried this year. The MAGIC population needs to be evaluated for this trait in LAC, or the BASE needs to be re-evaluated in replicated trials.

outcome_sumary:
Strong advances were made in the development of new tools for
 feed and forage prioritization (e.g. G-FEAST, SoFT and AFAWA). However,
 technical issues limited the release of the updated SoFT (Selection of
 Forages for the Tropics) tool, which was re-scheduled for 2020. (G-)FEAST (the
 Gendered Feed Assessment) tool was applied in various countries (e.g.
 Vietnam, Rwanda, Burkina Faso). New NIRS (Near Infrared Reflectance
 spectroscopy process to evaluate nutrients and characteristics of a feed or
 forage) equations were provided for barley and mobile and stationary
 facilities established in Burkina Faso and Ethiopia.
milestone_evidence:
Achievements include: application of ration balancing tool
(On-farm Feed Advisor) in India; global release of the Vegmeasure tool; training in the use of FEAST by the IFAD-funded Rwanda Dairy Development project (RDDP) in Rwanda; testing of G-FEAST with development actors in Burkina Faso; and application of G-FEAST in Vietnam.
gender_justification: G-FEAST maintains all the existing functionality of FEAST but generates extra gender-related insights into the livestock feed system. New features include graphs showing ownership of different livestock species by women and men farmers, gendered division of labour for feeding activities, gendered decision making on sales of livestock products and use of income, the main contributors to women’s income relative to overall household income, and specifications of who is most affected by certain problems.
capdev_justification: not applicable
climate_justification: not applicable

outcome_sumary: CIAT's Urochloa hybrids are being scaled on at least 100,000 additional hectares every year. The Urochloa and Megathyrsus breeding programs are advancing well and developing new hybrids for different agro-ecological conditions. The barley breeding program is making strong advances with new materials being tested and disseminated to NARS partners in Morocco and Ethiopia.
milestone_evidence: CIAT’s existing Urochloa hybrids were scaled on approximately 100,000 additional hectares in >15 countries in 2019. The total area sown with CIAT hybrids is estimated to be >1,000,000 hectares in 30 countries by 2019. This is based on private sector estimations, evidence data will be available by mid-2020.
gender_justification: not applicable
capdev_justification: not applicable
climate_justification: the improved forage hybrids being disseminated are better adapted to biotic and abiotic conditions related to a changing climate (e.g. prolongued droughts, water-logging)

outcome_sumary:
In India, two dual purpose maize hybrids bred in CIMMYT-ILRI
collaborations now occupy at least 100,000 hectares (estimated by seed
production and sales). Three new barley varieties were released (PL891 in India
and Ramtha1 and Ghweir1 in Jordan), characterized by superior grain and biomass
production and drought tolerance while further new barley genotypes were
identified with superior forage/grain/biomass production after cutting.

collaborations now occupy at least 100,000 hectares. Estimated by seed production and sales.

outcome_sumary:
We made strong progress on (a) business model development and the
provision of economic indicators for scaling sustainable feed and forage
interventions in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC), East Africa (EA), North
Africa and South Asia; (b) extension approaches (including youth and gender) in
North Africa and LAC that will support the uptake of technological innovations
developed in this flagship; and c) on policy making for sustainable
forage-based livestock production in Colombia. No changes of direction were
made.

We made strong progress on (a) business model development and the

milestone_evidence: Climate change, gender and youth (i.e. generational transfer) are key central elements in the discussions of the Colombian Roundtable for Sustainable Livestock. Sustainable livestock production is understood as increasing sustainability in relation to economic (productivity, efficiency), social (inclusion, gender, youth), and environmental (climate change, biodiversity, etc.) factors. The Colombian Roundtable is functioning on its own and technical baselines for a national level policy on sustainable bovine livestock production in Colombia have been developed. The policy is currently under review by the Ministry of Agriculture and will be published in 2020.
gender_justification: Gender is an important topic for the Colombian Roundtable and reflected in the social indicators of the technical baselines for a sustainable cattle policy
youth_justification: Youth is an important topic for the Colombian Roundtable and reflected in the social indicators of the technical baselines for a sustainable cattle policy
capdev_justification: not applicable
climate_justification: Climate change is the among the core topics of the Colombian roundtable and the upcoming policy on sustainable cattle farming

outcome_sumary:
Vietnam’s Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) mainstreamed
CCAFS inputs to several national policies and programs. The Myanmar
Climate-Smart Agricultural Strategy was developed with input from CCAFS and has
been used in the design of investment projects worth approximately USD 1
billion. CCAFS supported the Government of El-Salvador in developing an IADB
loan proposal for USD 45 million to strengthen climate change resilience in
coffee forests and implement digital climate-smart agriculture. The Secretary
of Agriculture and Livestock in Honduras issued its institutional plan for
climate change adaptation in the agri-food sector (2019–2023) with CCAFS input.
The Ministry of Agriculture of Salvador, with CCAFS support, formulated its
national agriculture policy which includes a strong climate change dimension.
CCAFS with the Genebank Platform contributed technical advice to the Convention
on Biological Diversity and made inputs to the draft Post-2020 Framework.
Inputs were made to the Department of Agriculture in the Philippines and
Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development in Vietnam to plan regional
cooperation in the seed sector.
milestone_evidence:
Several FP1 projects contributed to this milestone. There were
activities with district-level decision makers in Uganda to prioritize new
value chains to improve resilience, as well as activities with national
decision makers in Kenya and Uganda on dairy Nationally Appropriate Mitigation
Action (NAMA) proposals and tools to improve monitoring, reporting and
verification (MRV). The World Bank with CCAFS and IFPRI, published reports to
guide policymakers of Lao PDR, Cambodia, Vietnam, the Philippines and Myanmar
to better prepare for future El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events. CCAFS
continued to support Vietnam in developing its Nationally Determined
Contribution (NDC) through a low emissions development (LED) investment plan
and NDC review using the marginal cost of abatement. The capacity building
provided to science-policy dialogue platforms in Mali and Niger enabled stakeholders to connect their funding needs
to existing opportunities for new climate-smart agriculture (CSA) projects.
CGIAR has been supporting the Government of Bhutan in drafting a development
agenda for the renewable natural resources sector. CCAFS made scientific inputs
to policy documents in Honduras and El Salvador.
gender_justification: National level, not yet targeted
capdev_justification: Specific examples of capacity development tools, methodologies as well as supporting interaction with policy makers are provided in the evidence section
climate_justification: All about climate change

outcome_sumary:
Activities towards this outcome include participatory scenarios-based policy guidance work in all CCAFS target regions.
These activities have a greater emphasis on food systems and food and nutrition
security, as well as using foresight as a mechanism for inclusion of gender and
youth issues and stakeholders. Models such as IFPRI's International Model for
Policy Analysis of Agricultural Commodities and Trade (IMPACT) have an important role to play in bridging the science-policy divide and in helping to
evaluate the possible effects of different actions on different stakeholders.
milestone_evidence:
The milestone is judged to be complete, as this was an extended
milestone from 2018, and one of the 2019 milestones under this outcome
(milestone 3 below, which was completed during 2019) is very similar.
gender_justification: Gender considerations were included in the scenarios of the IFAD learning journey in Ethiopia in 2019.
capdev_justification: A significant component
climate_justification: Scenarios are for food and nutrition security under climate change

outcome_sumary:

These activities have a greater emphasis on food systems and food and nutrition
security, as well as using foresight as a mechanism for inclusion of gender and
youth issues and stakeholders. Models such as IFPRI's International Model for
Policy Analysis of Agricultural Commodities and Trade (IMPACT) have an important role to play in bridging the science-policy divide and in helping to
evaluate the possible effects of different actions on different stakeholders.
milestone_evidence:
Several outputs relate to this milestone: collaboration with A4NH on
links between climate change, nutrition and equity, work on gaming tools
development (Utrecht), a tool for "Global Foresight for Food and
Agriculture," a data viewer for IMPACT model runs, gaming around new
technologies for transformation in food systems (CSIRO, CCAFS), and a set of
scenario training videos (Utrecht).
gender_justification: Collaboration with A4NH on links between CC, nutrition and equity had a significant gender component — it was one of the equity dimensions.
youth_justification: Youth was a significant dimension of scenarios developed through the IFAD learning journey.
capdev_justification: A component of the milestone
climate_justification: Scenarios are for food and nutrition security under climate change

outcome_sumary:
Activities towards this outcome include participatory scenarios-based policy guidance work in all CCAFS target regions.
These activities have a greater emphasis on food systems and food and nutrition
security, as well as using foresight as a mechanism for inclusion of gender and
youth issues and stakeholders. Models such as IFPRI's International Model for
Policy Analysis of Agricultural Commodities and Trade (IMPACT) have an important role to play in bridging the science-policy divide and in helping to
evaluate the possible effects of different actions on different stakeholders.
milestone_evidence:
Activities contributing to this milestone in 2019 included development
and use of scenario methods that are being informed by food systems modelling,
to ensure the inclusion of gender and nutritional dimensions, in Bangladesh and
Ethiopia (Utrecht, Wageningen University [WUR], A4NH, CSIRO). New livestock
modules were utilized in novel IMPACT modelling studies. Support was provided
to the African Group of Negotiators Expert Support (AGNES) strategy meetings,
contributing knowledge on climate and food security scenarios and the gender
implications within African agriculture at a continental scale. Related to
capacity development, inputs were made to the IFAD transformation project via a "learning
journey" in Ethiopia and a project
assessment mission in Malawi during which stakeholders were guided on how to
incorporate issues of gender, youth, nutrition and climate change within their projects.
gender_justification: A significant component of the milestone
capdev_justification: All CCAFS scenarios work is at least partly (in many cases, mostly) about developing the capacity of stakeholders and workshop participants so that they can use the tools themselves for other work – several projects reported on this in 2019 in Cambodia, Bangladesh, Central America, E and W Africa (P274 and others).
climate_justification: All about climate

outcome_sumary:
Priority setting was undertaken at several levels, using models and more
qualitative frameworks, to improve food and nutrition security. This included
several sub-national and national climate-smart investment plans, investment
priorities for the Global Commission on Adaptation, and climate proofing new
World Bank investment projects worth several hundred million dollars.
milestone_evidence:
Several activities addressed this milestone, including: development of a
gender priority setting framework developed with IFAD to promote transformation
through mainstreaming of gender, youth, nutrition and climate change, informed
by situation analyses in Ghana, Ethiopia, Malawi and Uganda; new priority
setting tools based on scenario-guided policy and investment planning for food-
and nutrition-secure futures, via collaborations with IFAD, USAID, University
of Florida, Oxfam GB, and ASEAN; and contributions to an over-arching priority
setting framework with respect to the opportunities around climate-smart
breeding for future food and nutrition security (CCAFS LP1, multiple Centers
and CRPs).
gender_justification: A significant component of the milestone
youth_justification: A significant component of the milestone
capdev_justification: A significant component of the milestone
climate_justification: About climate change

outcome_sumary:
Priority setting was undertaken at several levels, using models and more
qualitative frameworks, to improve food and nutrition security. This included
several sub-national and national climate-smart investment plans, investment
priorities for the Global Commission on Adaptation, and climate proofing new
World Bank investment projects worth several hundred million dollars.
milestone_evidence:
Activities contributing to this milestone include: development of CSA profiles
and CSA Investment Plans (CSAIPs) to guide countries' investment initiatives
(six country/state profiles: Seychelles, Cape 
Verde, Guinea Bissau, and Borno, Adamawa, Yobe states of Nigeria) and
two CSAIPs (Mal, Ivory Coast), with two more
being finalized (Burkina Faso, Ghana). Future scenarios methods were used in
Honduras, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala to support prioritization of CSAIPs,
which are feeding into national policies. A CSA gender guide was developed for
informing the rural extension network in Guatemala about gender-sensitive CSA
practices.
gender_justification: A significant component of the milestone
youth_justification: A significant component of the milestone
capdev_justification: A significant component of the milestone
climate_justification: Climate change related

outcome_sumary:
Progress in 2019 toward the outcome on organizations and institutions
adapting their plans and directing investment to increase women's access to,
and control over, productive assets and resources was limited to just a few
projects. Through a visiting fellowship at IDRC, CCAFS has influenced USD 3
million in funding by the Canadian International Development Centre (IDRC) by
advising it on the gender dimensions of six climate change projects in East and
West Africa, South Asia, and Latin America. Additionally, a Transformation
Framework has been developed for IFAD on mainstreaming gender, youth, nutrition
and climate change. The milestone set for 2019 on synthesizing and comparing
the integration of gender and social inclusion considerations across the CCAFS
scenarios processes in all regions was not completed. Nevertheless, an activity
was set up in 2019 to synthesize appropriate indicators and mechanisms for tracking progress against the CCAFS gender-related policy
sub-IDOs, including in the scenario processes. Various activities were
completed in 2019 that are feeding into this synthesis. For this reason the
milestone for 2019 is judged complete. Additionally, an output comparing gender
considerations in CCAFS policy related work is planned for 2020.
milestone_evidence:
A synthesis of the integration of gender considerations in scenarios
processes across all the regions was not completed, although an activity was
set up in 2019 to synthesize appropriate indicators and mechanisms for tracking
progress against the CCAFS gender-related policy sub-IDOs, including in the
scenario processes. Various activities were completed in 2019 that are feeding
into this synthesis, and the 2020 milestone for this target addresses
investment plans that consider gender equity dimensions in several
countries/states. For this reason the milestone is judged complete.









Regarding
gender and CSA, joint work with the FP2/IDRC project resulted in development of
a step-by-step guide by Ministry of Agriculture of Guatemala with CCAFS support
which aims for supporting the implementation of the CSA Regional Strategy and
the Rural Women Agenda.
gender_justification: Gender-equitable control of assets is the main focus of the milestone and outcome
youth_justification: Youth was integrated into scenarios processes and youth participated in events.
capdev_justification: No capacity development is targeted in this milestone
climate_justification: Scenarios are for food and nutrition security under climate change

outcome_sumary:
Operational support continued to be provided to mainstream CSA in many
investment projects of the World Bank, thereby resulting in new investments
informed by CCAFS science and engagement. Also, CGIAR made inputs to a CSA
investment plan for Bangladesh prepared with the World Bank and other partners
to inform loans worth USD 500 million (CIAT, CIP, CCAFS South Asia).
milestone_evidence:
Outputs were produced on research methods for analyzing adaptation
policy needs and implementation progress in Latin America and South Asia.
Internally, a revised and expanded monitoring, evaluation and learning (MEL)
support pack was produced and launched at the 2019 MEL Community of Practice
meeting; in time this may be included as a One CGIAR product.
gender_justification: The paper from Latin America focuses on gender policies; gender is integrated into the framework
capdev_justification: The MEL support pack aims to build capacity for MEL
climate_justification: focus on adaptation and mitigation in climate-related policy

outcome_sumary:
Operational support continued to be provided to mainstream CSA in many
investment projects of the World Bank, thereby resulting in new investments
informed by CCAFS science and engagement. Also, CGIAR made inputs to a CSA
investment plan for Bangladesh prepared with the World Bank and other partners
to inform loans worth USD 500 million (CIAT, CIP, CCAFS South Asia).
milestone_evidence:
Contributions were made via the continuing operational support provided
to new investment projects of the World Bank. A new bilateral activity funded
by GIZ was designed and set up for prioritizing agricultural and natural
resource management investments in the 16 member states of the Southern African
Development Community (SADC), for implementation in 2020. CCAFS's
recommendation to mainstream climate change in SADC's new Regional Indicative
Strategic Development Plan 2020–2030 has already been adopted. CCAFS made key
inputs to the Global Commission on Adaptation report and food action track. In
an outcome study conducted, it was found that Vietnam's MARD was able to
mainstream CCAFS outputs and inputs in the national policies (e.g. Resolution
120, NDC, SBSTA) and other programs (e.g. New Rural Development Program, NAPAg,
Sustainable Agricultural Transformation, and the Rice Master Plan). For
Myanmar, the Myanmar Climate-Smart Agricultural Strategy developed by CCAFS has
been referenced in at least 19 government and NGO programs, 4 policy documents,
and 19 investment projects (worth approximately USD 1 billion). Through the
ASEAN Climate-Resilience Network, CSA is also being promoted across Southeast
Asia.
gender_justification: gender was not targeted in this milestone
youth_justification: youth were not targeted in this milestone
capdev_justification: capacity development carried out with governments on how to make use of CCAFS science
climate_justification: policies consider climate change

outcome_sumary:
The outcome target (10) has been largely exceeded in previous years
already. A total of 14 policy decisions taken were reported in 2019, of which
35% are considered Level 2 and 3. Level 3 maturity: Myanmar Climate-Smart
Agriculture Strategy developed by CCAFS and the Ministry of Agriculture,
Livestock and Irrigation (MOALI) provides the national framework for the
implementation of technical, policy, and investment initiatives to cope with
climate change in Myanmar. Level 2 maturity: co-development with the Department
of Science, Technology and Environment of Vietnam’s MARD of a study for the
implementation of Vietnam's AgINDC (agriculture Intended Nationally Determined
Contribution) component, which served as the basis of the action plan adopted
by MARD; development of the Uganda National Seed Policy 2018 to ensure
availability, accessibility and affordability of safe and high quality seeds
and the Strategy 2018/2019–2022/2023 that elaborates actions and plans to
implement the policy; gender support to AGNES with policy outcomes at global
and national levels. Level 1 maturity: two departmental climate change plans
developed in Colombia for Boyaca and Orinoquia respectively; support to Nông
Thôn Mới (NTM), a national target program under the New Rural Development in Vietnam; and the Climate Smart Agriculture Policy of El
Salvador developed
milestone_evidence:
Public
and private sector: In Ghana, CCAFS developed in collaboration with the local
cocoa License Buying Companies CSA recommendations for climate-smart cocoa,
which with the support of the World Cocoa Foundation, evolved into the Climate-Smart
Cocoa Manual and most recently into the Ghana COCOBOD Climate Smart Cocoa
Standard. Government:
In Guatemala, CCAFS in collaboration with the Ministry of Agriculture,
Livestock and Food, the Gender Network of the Central America Agricultural
Council and the Council of Ministers of Women developed an operational
step-by-step guide to mainstream gender in CSA programs and policies. The guide
fosters new actions on the ground in Guatemala and the Central American region.
 Government:
Activities facilitated by CCAFS strengthen existing partnerships and
mainstreamed scalable gender-sensitive CSA portfolios, and components of Climate-Smart
Village (CSV) approaches in key government programs and policies in the
Philippines (AMIA), Lao PDR, Vietnam (NTM), Myanmar (MOALI) and Cambodia. 









Cooperatives:
In Guatemala and Honduras, stakeholders belonging to CSVs understand and
implement the CSV approach within and beyond their communities through their
own projects. The generation of evidence has been key to trigger investments
and fund allocations from public and development agencies.
gender_justification: CAC gender mainstreaming, SEA CSV and CSA gender component, IFAD Transformation agenda
capdev_justification: Principal CapDev in CSV through development of guidelines, testing and scaling.
climate_justification: Contributions to CSA policy, programs, CSV implementation and scaling
