outcome_sumary: WLE’s decision analysis frameworks for planning and performance measurement of land restoration efforts were further developed and applied with local partners in Burkina Faso, Ethiopia (2), Kenya, and India. The Burkina Faso case evaluated alternative interventions for protecting a reservoir from siltation. The Ethiopia cases evaluated alternatives for forest landscape restoration and irrigation developments. In Kenya there was close partnership with county-level government and stakeholders to target and co-design land restoration investments. In India, an integrated framework was tested for monitoring, evaluating, and enhancing the effectiveness of initiatives designed to restore degraded land in commonly managed land.
milestone_evidence: M&E tools development continued with (1) co-design of stakeholder and cross-sectoral engagement processes in Kenya for better targeting of land restoration investments (2) co-design of an integrated framework for monitoring, evaluating, enhancing effectiveness of degraded land restoration in India; (3) exploration of mitigation benefits from expansion of trees on rangeland in Colombia and Sierra Leone (Mali replaced by other countries).

The Burkina Faso case evaluated alternative interventions for protecting a reservoir from siltation. The Ethiopia cases evaluated alternatives for forest landscape restoration and irrigation developments. In Kenya there was close partnership with county-level government and stakeholders to target and co-design land restoration investments. In India, an integrated framework was tested for monitoring, evaluating, and enhancing the effectiveness of initiatives designed to restore degraded land in commonly managed land.
milestone_evidence: Soil-plant infrared spectroscopy tool for more cost effective and efficient soil health analysis: (1) available, improved with user feedback; (2) applied in Sub-Saharan Africa; (3) design, and testing new handheld near-infrared sensor with Global Good of Intellectual Ventures and Si-Ware.
gender_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
youth_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
capdev_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Capacity Development as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Capacity Development  component aimed at national labs and related to the use of an online tool set for soil spectroscopy.
climate_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.

outcome_sumary:
Our interventions focus primarily on two human health risks - malaria
transmission in rice farming schemes and Rift Valley fever (RVF) among
livestock holders. In 2019, plans to test alternate wetting and drying (AWD)
irrigation with AfricaRice in West Africa and with IRRI in East Africa advanced.
AWD in rice farming has potential to limit malaria transmission as well as greenhouse
gas emission. In addition, studies on livestock vaccination strategies for RVF
were initiated in Kenya and Uganda. There is also ongoing work to characterize
risks related to landscape-mediated effects of agriculture on vector-borne
disease in Africa and South Asia
milestone_evidence:
ILRI researchers finalized the risk maps in 2019 and have trained some
government officers on how to use these risk maps in contingency planning. More
policy engagement is planned for 2020. At this stage, it is too early to
suggest that the maps have been adopted in government planning.
gender_justification: no evidence of gendered-risks for infection
youth_justification: no evidence of youth-risks for infection
capdev_justification: Decision makers will have better clarity on spatial distribution of RVF risk for deployment of risk-based surveillance and control measures  - https://www.ilri.org/publications/mapping-risk-rift-valley-fever-uganda
climate_justification: This disease is climate sensitive. The risk map has been produced using climate variables among other predictors. Expected changes in RVF risk in the future (2050/2070) will also be generated based on the baseline map

transmission in rice farming schemes and Rift Valley fever (RVF) among

AWD in rice farming has potential to limit malaria transmission as well as greenhouse

milestone_evidence: The synoptic review was completed and a manuscript was submitted to a peer-reviewed journal in 2019. It was rejected, so the authors are refining it to re-submit in 2020.
gender_justification: study focused on environmental and technical not social issues
youth_justification: study focused on environmental and technical not social issues
capdev_justification: broad overview study not yet with specific plans for implications for implementation
climate_justification: The review provides recommendations on irrigation practices that could be used to manage mosquito abundance while at the same time limiting GHG emissions

Our interventions focus primarily on two human health risks - malaria
transmission in rice farming schemes and Rift Valley fever (RVF) among

milestone_evidence: AfricaRice is a partner with the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) on the alternate wet and dry (AWD) irrigation in rice trials in West Africa.For CapDev - The collaboration with AfricaRice to include health-related indicators reflects a shift in institutional priorities and a recognition of the value in incorporating aspects of human health in their research. Training has taken place, and will continue, to build institutional awareness and the ability to monitor health-indicators.For Gender - Gender is part of this work because pregnant women and <5y children suffer >85% of the burden of malaria in Africa. Hence this links to the “sustainable rice-growing lifestyles” work of Kazuki Saito, our collaborator in Africa Rice.
gender_justification: Gender is part of this work because pregnant women and <5y children suffer >85% of the burden of malaria in Africa.  Hence this links to the “sustainable rice-growing lifestyles” work of Kazuki Saito, our collaborator in Africa Rice.  The indicators to be developed will include gender and equity aspects realising that rice farming practices are associated with gender .
youth_justification: youth not specifically considered but only linked to gender
capdev_justification: The collaboration with AfricaRice to include health-related indicators reflects a shift in institutional priorities and a recognition of the value in incorporating aspects of human health in their research. Training has taken place, and will continue, to build institutional awareness and the ability to monitor health-indicators.
climate_justification: A component of the study investigates how alternative irrigation practices influences GHG emissions

outcome_sumary:
The milestones for this outcome demonstrate progress in
developing, validating, and evaluating a suite of strategies to mitigate cysticercosis
in East Africa and other zoonotic threats in different contexts in Africa and
South Asia. In 2019, we established a new partnership with the University of
Munich to support the development of a diagnostic kit for cysticercosis. ILRI
is also working on national action plans for cysticercosis in Kenya and Uganda,
as well as an action plan for brucellosis in Kenya. The latter has been
submitted for approval by the government.
milestone_evidence: Earlier attempts to develop a pen-side test (a diagnostic that can provide real-time information about the health status of an animal or herd) were not successful. The partnership with University of Munich will re-start efforts to develop and validate the test. The initially designed system was based on reagents where quality control between batches was not possible. We changed supplier of reagents and have now developed this further, in collaboration with the US CDC. New tests are to be validated in 2020 (pending access to the field); a commercial sector producer is interested in taking this forward and is developing a commercial manufacture case with support from the Gates Foundation.
gender_justification: purely lab-based technical work. The technology being developed is assumed to be appropriate for men and women
youth_justification: purely lab-based technical work. Assumed to be useful for youth but not specifically designed with youth considerations.
capdev_justification: The test will improve the capacity of veterinary department to do surveillance on cysticercosis
climate_justification: Assumed test will be useful in all climate scenarios

milestone_evidence:
Technical
report has been finalized, but we are awaiting government approval before it can be disseminated. It is too early to claim that awareness has been raised as a result of this report. In Kenya, it is now a priority disease as a result of this work with a national plan to developed before 2023. In Rwanda, it is national recognized but not yet prioritized.

youth_justification: contribution to a national task force that did not consider youth

youth_justification: Youth targeted in the dissemination of information through the use of mobile phones and social media

outcome_sumary:
Partnerships for antimicrobial resistance (AMR) research and
policy interventions involving some CGIAR institutions (ILRI, IFPRI, IMWI, WorldFish),
some universities (LSHTM, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences) and a
few countries (Kenya, Uganda, Vietnam and Bangladesh) were established in 2019.
These partnerships work under the aegis of the CGIAR AMR Hub that was launched
in February 2019.
milestone_evidence: The CGIAR Antimicrobial Resistance Hub (AMR) was launched in a high-profile event at ILRI in February 2019. The Hub is led by Arshnee Moodley. The AMR Hub website was launched and contains a growing body of resources on agriculture-associated AMR.
gender_justification: establishment of platform - gender will be brought into subsequent research portfolio
youth_justification: establishment of platform - youth will be brought into subsequent research portfolio
capdev_justification: The website is a repository for materials that can be used by national and international partners for AMR research
climate_justification: establishment of platform - clmate change will be brought into subsequent research portfolio

youth_justification: youth to be included in subsequent stages

outcome_sumary:
Milestones for this outcome demonstrate how this flagship is convening
actors representing agriculture and public health to raise awareness of areas
of collaboration and eventually, design and implement joint projects. Since
2018, this flagship has convened several multisectoral meetings bringing
together agriculture and public health actors. Some have been regional in
nature while others have been international. The annual Agriculture, Nutrition,
and Health Academy (ANH Academy), which is co-led by A4NH and the London School
of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) also serves as a platform for this
flagship to facilitate these collaborations.
milestone_evidence: This is a sample of events held in 2019: (1) Agriculture Nutrition and Health Academy Week 2019 in Hyderabad; (2) London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine week; (3) workshop in Vietnam.
gender_justification: Partnership developed by LSHTM in the meetings include development of frameworks of gender and equity studies in one health. For the ANH Academy, gender was a focus issue. Three learning labs were devoted to equity and gender, and one research conferences section (  papers), as well as a keynote address (Wanjiru Kamau-Rutenberg, Director, African Women in Agricultural Research and Development) .
youth_justification: youth part of broader equity considerations
capdev_justification: Graduate fellows from various institutions trained on one health research during A4NH academy week. The ANH Academy devotes much of its effort to capacity development through learning labs, master classes and assistance to young/new researchers on preparing and presenting research papers and engaging with policy makers.
climate_justification: some considerations of climate change, but not high-priority topic

outcome_sumary:
Ex-ante/spatial assessments (incl foresight and
 targeting) assess how major drivers (like climate change, biotic stresses,
 and rural transformation) will alter MAIZE in the developing world.
 Highlights of foresight/targeting studies to inform policy:
 - Three strategic studies focused on Africa: one providing a spatial framework
 for ex-ante impact assessment of agricultural technologies (1); another assessing
 future changes and uncertainty in decision-relevant measures of East African
 climate (2) and the third assessing maize crop nutrient input requirements
 for food security (3).
 - comprehensive book reviewed the transformation of rural Africa (4) with a
 complementary paper reviewing implications for sustainable agricultural intensification
 (5).
 - Three other studies analyzed specific innovations: potential of
 site-specific extension services and high-input agriculture in Nigeria (6);
 an ex-ante assessment for scaling conservation agriculture in Zambia (7) and
 the potential of biofortified maize for child nutrition in southern Ethiopia
 (8).
 - Two papers focused on stresses: one assessing the threats of Tar Spot
 Complex disease of maize in the USA and its global consequences (9) and the
 other assessing weather shocks and spatial market efficiency in Mozambique
 (10).
 - comprehensive manual provides a guide to scaling soil and water
 conservation in the Western Highlands of Guatemala (11).
 

.

outcome_sumary:

 (4).

 Zambia (5), Malawi (6), Zimbabwe (7), Uganda (8,9)

 short-duration varieties in Nigeria (11)
 - Assessed economic impacts of maize stem borer in Pakistan (12),
 minimum tillage in Kenya (13) climate smart agriculture in Africa (14), soil Zinc on child-nutrition in Ethiopia (15).
 - Assessed impacts of services on adoption in Africa:
 credit and extension (16) and information exchange (17).Gender/social-inclusiveness:
 - Youth in Africa: Assessing heterogeneity of rural
 youth opportunities (18); access to land, migration and employment
 opportunities (19)

 Ethiopia (20), disentangling gendered information and role model
 effects in Uganda (21)
 -Two book chapters: Integrating gender into farm typologies in
 Guatemala (22); agrobiodiversity use affected by socioecologic and
 economic diversity (23) 
 - Resource material on gender in Africa’s maize seed
 systems: Women seed business (24), gender-responsive approaches
 for agro-dealers (25), breeders (26), seed companies (27) and promotion (28).

outcome_sumary:
In 2018, we reported uptake of evidence in Alive & Thrive (a multi-country
maternal and child nutrition initiative) and the World Food Program (WFP) in
Sri Lanka. In this year's milestone, we report uptake of evidence in the
Ministry of Agriculture (Bangladesh) and WFP (headquarters). IFPRI researchers are
also working with WFP-Sri Lanka to redesign their Food Assistance for Assets
Program to make it more nutrition-sensitive.​ In addition, in 2019, the
European Commission requested IFPRI’s input in a meeting to design
multi-sectoral programs to improve nutrition (bringing together rural
development, agriculture, nutrition, and health sectors).
milestone_evidence:
The Ministry of Agriculture (MoA, Bangladesh) is scaling-up a package of
agriculture, nutrition, and gender training to benefit thousands of households,
which was informed by a similar intervention co-designed and evaluated by
IFPRI. The World Food Programme (WFP) and IFPRI co-developed
nutrition-sensitive program guidance and published a paper on the development
of the guidance.
gender_justification: Government of Bangladesh has chosen to implement at scale it's integrated agriculture, nutrition, and gender intervention (ANGEL).
youth_justification: There is no specific evidence on youth from A4NH which is being used by these two organizations.
capdev_justification: Capacity Development of partnering organizations and stakeholders to design and implement nutrition-sensitive agricultural programs.
climate_justification: There is no specific evidence on climate change from A4NH which is being used by these organizations.

outcome_sumary:
The cross-flagship, IFPRI and ILRI
 evaluation (using a randomized controlled design combined with a process
 evaluation and a cost study) of the MoreMilk intervention is ongoing. In
 Burkina Faso, we are collaborating with AfricaSANTE on an integrated poultry
 value chain and nutrition intervention. The process evaluation was completed
 in 2019. The same combination of methods are being used in MoreMilk.​ With
 the World Food Program, we completed an evaluation study design; the baseline
 will start in 2020. Lastly, World Vision Ethiopia has requested our support
 to design rigorous impact evaluations of their programs, which will be further
 developed in 2020.
milestone_evidence:
In Burkina Faso, a five-year impact evaluation was designed to assess
the impact of poultry value chain interventions on women's and children's
diets, health and nutritional status. In Sri Lanka a 1-2 y impact evaluation
was developed to assess the impact of one of the World Food Program’s nutrition-sensitive
programs on men's and women's diets and other outcomes.
gender_justification: The Enhanced Homestead Food Production, A nutrition- and gender-sensitive agriculture program was evaluated in Burkina Faso
youth_justification: There is no specific evidence on youth from A4NH which is being used by these two organizations.
capdev_justification: Capacity Development is not specifically targeted in any of these programs
climate_justification: Climate change is not specifically targeted in any of these programs

outcome_sumary:
Previously, we reported on policy engagement with 10 focal countries
through the Stories of Change initiative, described further in the special
issue of Global Food Security. The focused engagement with Ethiopia in 2019 was largely
due to an A4NH researcher who is embedded in the national and supra-national
policy process. In 2019, their work brought together members from public health,
research organizations, as well as national government to review current
implementation of nutrition-sensitive policies. There are no other focal
countries in which this flagship has designated researchers in-country to work
at this level directly.
milestone_evidence:
Instead, the 2019 work focused on national leaders, rather than regional and
international organizations. Leadership courses for nutrition leadership
development training for the Ethiopian Nutrition Leaders Network were developed
and implemented to ensure quality implementation of programs.
gender_justification: Chapters on equity in nutrition in 2019 Global Nutrition Report
youth_justification: Chapters on equity in nutrition in UNICEF’s 2019 State of the World’s Children (SOWC) report
capdev_justification: Capacity development is not specifically targeted in any of these programs
climate_justification: Climate change is not specifically targeted in any of these programs

outcome_sumary:

youth_justification: Youth is not specifically targeted in any of these programs
capdev_justification: Capacity development of national and regional stakeholders and influencers is the main objective.

outcome_sumary:
We continued a systematic mapping of knowledge gaps and implementation
knowledge tools. This work should be completed in 2020. In addition, two courses
from the African Nutrition Leadership Programme were held with a focus on
strengthening the link between agriculture and nutrition. In Rwanda, we supported
training of civil society organizations (CSOs) to contextualize and use
evidence related to the Stories of Change initative. The CSOs then held district-level
dissemination workshops. Some districts used the evidence to make immediate
changes in their programming and collaboration approaches.
milestone_evidence: Two courses to strengthen leadership capacity in multi-sectoral environments: (1) in Ghana, evidence for policy and programming and (2) in Dakar, leading change in nutrition. Package of tools to enable policymakers/stakeholders in West Africa to identify gaps in their national data system to effectively track progress on nutrition and/or inform policy. A news article captured the dissemination of the results in Rwanda. The results from this process are also planned to be presented at the Micronutrient Forum in 2020.
gender_justification: Gender was not specifically targeted in the courses or tools
youth_justification: Youth was not specifically targeted in the courses or tools
capdev_justification: The courses are designed to strengthen leadership capabilities in individuals who work in multi-sectoral environments. The tools supply evidence that will support policymakers and other stakeholders in the use of nutrition data at country level in West Africa for tracking progress, setting priorities, informing policies and programs, guiding implementation, and monitoring intervention coverage for nutrition at national level.
climate_justification: Climate change was not specifically targeted in the courses or tools

outcome_sumary: CIMMYT and ICARDA shared >1000 improved spring and winter bread wheat and durum wheat candidate varieties to over 200 National partners in >60 countries through international trials and nurseries for growing during the 2019-20 crop season. Partners completed growing of wheat trials and nurseries received during 2018-19 crop season. Multi-site within country and across country data analysis identified superior yielding wheat lines with disease resistance and quality. Partners retained the selected wheat lines for further testing as required in each country for the release of variety for cultivation by farmers. Also selected wheat lines are being used by partners in their own breeding program. From previously provided wheat lines at least 50 new varieties were released by partners in key wheat growing countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America. Partners have also multiplied several tons of seed and provided to seed multiplication agencies. The Turkey-CIMMYT-ICARDA led winter wheat breeding program will close down in 2020 due to insufficient funding. This will affect the provision of new candidate varieties for East and Central Asia region.
milestone_evidence: Progress on scaling wheat technologies in Sub-Saharan Africa: TAAT-Wheat Compact; heat-tolerant varieties deployed as basic, certified and quality-declared seeds came to 30,500 MT for Sudan, 25,438 MT for Ethiopia, 7,600 MT for Nigeria, plus over 2,000 MT for 6 other countries. Farmers in Nigeria grew 500,000 hectares of wheat within the last three years. Seed production is continuous exercise and task is too large in wheat, as more than 80% seed moves from farmers to farmers.
gender_justification: Seed multiplication in Ethiopia engaged both women and men farmers through the creation of seed villages.
youth_justification: Young farmers were particularly engaged and targeted in seed production and marketing strategy.
capdev_justification: Training provided on how to multiply good quality seed.
climate_justification: N/A

Partners completed growing of wheat trials and nurseries received during 2018-19 crop season. Multi-site within country and across country data analysis identified superior yielding wheat lines with disease resistance and quality. Partners retained the selected wheat lines for further testing as required in each country for the release of variety for cultivation by farmers. Also selected wheat lines are being used by partners in their own breeding program. From previously provided wheat lines at least 50 new varieties were released by partners in key wheat growing countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America. The Turkey-CIMMYT-ICARDA led winter wheat breeding program will close down in 2020 due to insufficient funding. milestone_evidence: New disease resistant varieties are released each year by National partners. The milestone is therefore recurring each year. A total of at least 50 new varieties, directly selected from CG germplasm, released in different countries (Specifically, Ethiopia, India, Bangladesh, Kenya, Pakistan and Afghanistan).  Ethiopia since 2010: Variety development, adoption see pp.25, 28-30
gender_justification: New wheat varieties released by partners include genetic traits that are preferred by both female and male farmers, as per WHEAT funded research (GENNOVATE- see link below)
capdev_justification: National program's and CIMMYT breeding and variety release capacity continuously enhanced through the exchange of improved germplasm and data.
climate_justification: New varieties and germplasm have better built-in climate resilience in terms of drought and heat tolerance.

outcome_sumary: New functional and linked molecular markers validated and KASP markers used by breeding program. Major meta-GWAS analysis conducted and genomic regions associated with various traits identified in CIMMYT wheat breeding programs. High-throughput phenotyping being done routinely at some breeding and testing sites, however use of UAV is becoming difficult due to restrictions posed by countries.
milestone_evidence: Several journal articles published in 2019 documenting the progress. As continuous improvement and knowledge generation is required, we shall be delivering new information each year for improving breeding process.
gender_justification: Climate resilient germplasm is beneficial to all genders.
youth_justification: Farmers of all ages are benefited from climate resilient wheat germplasm.
capdev_justification: Development and use of new molecular markers and high-throughput phenotyping are done to enhance the capacity of wheat breeding programs.
climate_justification: Growing of climate resilient wheat varieties helps farmers mitigate negative effects from climate change.

outcome_sumary:
Rust epidemic in Ethiopia led to faster variety release process. Some cross-border collaboration on release/certification (ASARECA, SADC) - small (!) successes. In general, WHEAT works on this to the greatest extent possible within the 
limitations of each countries' variety release processes. WHEAT 
scientists work with national programs and government agricultural and crop representatives on an ongoing basis to
 ensure that their variety release process is agile enough to respond to
 emerging pests and diseases, in line with the improved germplasm made available 
to them by WHEAT.
milestone_evidence:
See WHEAT Annual Report section 2.2.1 on precision phenotyping platforms: Precision Wheat
Phenotyping Platforms (PWPP). WHEAT
and co-investing national partners managed 7 platforms, which China joining
during 2019. # of platforms not as high as targeted, because W1&2 co-funding limited and spreading such funds too thinly and too briefly would be counterproductive. 'Model' precision phenotyping platform is based on Obregon.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: National program and CG Center's increased capacity to conduct precision phenotyping
climate_justification: Phenotyping platforms target stress tolerance and disease resistance, which are associated with climate resilience.

outcome_sumary:
WHEAT works on this to the greatest extent possible within the 
limitations of each countries' variety release processes. WHEAT 
scientists work with national programs and government agricultural and crop representatives on an ongoing basis to
 ensure that their variety release process is agile enough to respond to
 emerging pests and diseases, in line with the improved germplasm made available 
to them by WHEAT.
milestone_evidence: CGIAR more generally and WHEAT specifically have (very) limited influence on politics of national seed business and variety release process. With regard to wheat, key challenge is not legislative or political, but how to tap into farmer-to-farmer saved seeds networks, to encourage faster replacement of obsolete varieties. In general, an ongoing process in line with seed health regulations and variety release processes within each country.
gender_justification: Milestone related to National regulations.
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary: Beyond the capacity of CRP FP3 as Seed Projects require large investment, have always been bilateral and emergency-driven (e.g. rust epidemic); also, public/private sector extension services very limited in many wheat-growing countries. In each of the target countries, seed production and commercialization being done by the public or private sectors, as soon as new varieties are released. Some cross-CRP and -FP learning generated (FP4-to-FP3) on role of agro-dealers.
milestone_evidence: Achieving this milestone fully depends on scientists collaborating across FP1, 3 and 4, as well as on bilaterally funded projects with a multi-Flagship perspective, thus significant multi-year progress in Ethiopia, South Asia (CSISA), Morocco, Turkey, but not elsewhere.
gender_justification: gender not targeted by this milestone
youth_justification: youth not targeted by this milestone
capdev_justification: significant aim of this milestone is to identify cap dev needs of NARS and identify relevant interventions at appropriate levels.
climate_justification: climate change is not targeted by this milestone

outcome_sumary: Whilst farmer organizations play an important part in raising awareness and promotion of improved varieties and improving farmer access, up to now bilateral funding (CSISA, MasAgro, AIP, etc.) has been critical for farmer organizations to expand their role.
milestone_evidence: Lack of W3 funding for the milestone and too specific, will instead be incorporated into a larger, diverse and healthy diet linked to whole grains-type milestone.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary: DNA Fingerprint based adoption studies being planned to determine adoption of new varieties.
milestone_evidence: Current evidence (since 2014) is impressionistic and ad hoc. See Bangladesh/wheat blast, Ethiopia/rusts variety release and adoption mentioned in the milestones above. Longer-term assessments make the case for greater farmer adoption under specific circumstances: See OICR Screening operations in wheat rusts have led to the release of over 100 Ug99 resistantwheat cultivars globally over the last decade.
gender_justification: Gender dis-aggregated variety adoption data, and varieties formulated based on WHEAT research on gender preferences (see GENNOVATE research below)
youth_justification: Adoption of new varieties happens by farmers of all age levels.
capdev_justification: DNA fingerprint based impact assessment capacity for routine utilization
climate_justification: Growing of new climate-resilient varieties.

outcome_sumary: DNA Fingerprint based adoption studies being planned to determine adoption of new varieties.
milestone_evidence: Lack of W3 funding for the milestone.
gender_justification: Involvement of female farmers in seed production.
youth_justification: Involvement of youth in seed production and marketing.
capdev_justification: Increased capacity of seed system.
climate_justification: Faster seed production and dissemination of climate-resilient varieties.

outcome_sumary: In 2019, a variety of iron beans (BIO-102) released in Colombia; varieties of vitamin A maize (GV6023A, GV6029A, GV6027A, GV6017A, GV6025A) released in Zambia; a variety of vitamin A maize (ZS500) released in Zimbabwe; a variety of iron pearl millet (Moti Shakti), and zinc wheat (HUW 711) released in India.
milestone_evidence:
Target was exceeded. In
2019, varieties released included:  iron beans (one) in Colombia; vitamin A maize (five) in Zambia; vitamin A maize (one) in Zimbabwe; iron pearl millet (one) and zinc wheat (two) in India.
gender_justification: Product profiles and target traits always include gender sensitive traits (ex. cooking processing, marketing).
capdev_justification: Variety development and release includes capacity building and training in biofortification breeding, provided for national partners and young scientists.
climate_justification: Traits relevant to climate change and adaptation (e.g heat and drought tolerance) has been included in metrics and tools (especially, as food system outcome, or in relation to diets).

outcome_sumary:
Budget was allocated for monitoring mainstreaming in CGIAR Centers
and national
agricultural research systems; initial contacts with selected CGIAR Centers and
Excellence in Breeding Platform were established. Meetings were planned to
develop indicators jointly. HarvestPlus defined a clear approach to enhancing
mainstreaming; we are in the process of establishing a monitoring system to
track the progress of other centers. Early generation seed production is part
of breeding contracts and harmonized with seed systems strengthening capacity
building and delivery activities/efforts. Resource mobilization for specific
crops is at various stages.

outcome_sumary:
Milestones for this outcome demonstrate that A4NH is making
 progress in increasing the availabilty of diverse nutrient-rich foods. By the
 end of 2019, and estimated 8.5 million households (corresponding to 42.4
 household members) were growing and consuming biofortified varieties of major
 staples (vitamin A cassava, maize and sweet potato; iron beans and pearl
 millet and zinc maize, rice and wheat).
milestone_evidence:
In 2019, 5 million
farming households were reached with biofortified planting material, bringing
the total number of farming households growing and consuming biofortified crops
globally to 8.5 million. The data is available in the HarvestPlus monitoring and evaluation database, the detailed explanations on reasons of the status, "changed" and the methodology is available upon request.
other_reason: Financial, Weather
gender_justification: Proportion of household members that are women of childbearing age, adolescent girls, children under 5 and disabled are estimated ex post by using national level statistics representative at rural and regional levels
youth_justification: Youth aspect - with the exception of adolescent girls - was not included in the analysis of the reported results.
capdev_justification: Partner delivery organizations were trained in M&E data collection, documentation and reporting
climate_justification: Climate change aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.

outcome_sumary:
Socioeconomic endline study (both quantitative and qualitative,
gender-sensitive components) was completed at the end of 2018, in 2019 data
were analyzed, and the preliminary results were shared with the national
partners. Nutrition endline study is in progress, and all final results will be
shared with the national partners in 2020. Qualitative gendered analyses of
delivery models were completed for Colombia, Rwanda, and Zambia. Results of the
Rwanda and Zambia analyses are included as a case study in the 2019 Annual
Trends and Outlook Report (ATOR) of the Regional Strategic Analysis and Knowledge
Support System.
milestone_evidence: Qualitative gendered analysis of delivery strategies completed for Colombia, Rwanda and Zambia. Results from Rwanda and Zambia were included as a case study “Developing Gender-Inclusive Products and Programs: The Role of Gender in Adoption and Consumption of Biofortified Crops” in the 2019 Annual Trends and Outlook Report for Africa.
gender_justification: This milestone considers gender senstive programming as well as evaluation of gendered outcomes of biofortification interventions
youth_justification: Youth aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.
capdev_justification: Capacity development aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.
climate_justification: Climate change aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.

gender_justification: This study evaluated men and women's evaluation of production and consumption characteristics of iron beans, and also the delivery intervention was targeted at both men and women in the household.
youth_justification: The target group in this study was adolescent girls and their access to iron beans and the impact of consumption of iron beans on their iron intakes and iron deficiency outcomes.
capdev_justification: Close collaboration with Guatemalan partners on iron bean development, multiplication and delivery (ICTA) and on the implementation of the nutrition training, nutrition data collection and analysis (INCAP) resulted in capacity development in biofortification research in both organizations.
climate_justification: Climate change aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.

outcome_sumary: We expect the World Health Organization (WHO) to issue a recommendation in 2020 on biofortification as a mainstream public health nutrition intervention. In addition, a draft definition was referred to the 2019 Session of the Codex Committee on Food Labelling (CCFL) to determine if it will meet their needs. The CCFL agreed current labeling texts were adequate; there was no need for a definition of biofortification in context of food labeling. HarvestPlus is no longer pursuing a standalone definition. Instead, we are working with the International Standards Organization and creating international nutrient standards for biofortified grains through a separate process.
milestone_evidence:
Efforts to have biofortification included in the Codex Alimentarius standards continued. HarvestPlus strategically decided not to pursue a standalone definition but rather have biofortification included
 under existing definitions. HarvestPlus prioritized working with the
 International Standards Organization, 
 and creating international nutrient standards for biofortified grains
 through the Publicly Available Standards process.

youth_justification: Youth aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.
capdev_justification: Capacity development aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.
climate_justification: Climate change aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.

milestone_evidence:
HarvestPlus continued communicating with the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Food and
 Agriculture Organization (FAO) on the latest evidence. A HarvestPlus-FAO biofortification brief was published. WHO plans issuing a recommendation in 2020 on biofortification as a mainstream public health nutrition intervention; guidelines expected to follow by 2021.

outcome_sumary:
Enhance adoption/impacts:
 - MAIZE Impact assessment strategy released (1) and potential implications for technological change rethought (2).- Review impact pathways for improved staple-crop
 germplasm to poverty reduction (3) and intensification through conservation agriculture
 (4).
 - Assess adoption and impacts of drought-tolerant maize in
 Zambia (5), Malawi (6), Zimbabwe (7), Uganda (8,9)
 - Revisited maize landrace use in Mexico (10), adoption of
 short-duration varieties in Nigeria (11)
 - Assessed economic impacts of maize stem borer in Pakistan (12),
 minimum tillage in Kenya (13) climate smart agriculture in Africa (14), soil Zinc on child-nutrition in Ethiopia (15).
 - Assessed impacts of services on adoption in Africa:
 credit and extension (16) and information exchange (17).Gender/social-inclusiveness:
 - Youth in Africa: Assessing heterogeneity of rural
 youth opportunities (18); access to land, migration and employment
 opportunities (19)
 - Gender differentiated adoption of improved maize in
 Ethiopia (20), disentangling gendered information and role model
 effects in Uganda (21)
 -Two book chapters: Integrating gender into farm typologies in
 Guatemala (22); agrobiodiversity use affected by socioecologic and
 economic diversity (23) 
 - Resource material on gender in Africa’s maize seed
 systems: Women seed business (24), gender-responsive approaches
 for agro-dealers (25), breeders (26), seed companies (27) and promotion (28).

outcome_sumary:
Market/value chain development refines the
 understanding of agri-food systems and develops a strategic nutritional
 agenda for CRP MAIZE to support identification of priorities and effective
 interventions. Highlights of markets/value chain studies to enhance last mile
 linkages:
 -Case studies assessed implications for designing interventions in Malawi's
 value chains for improved health and nutrition (1) and distribution systems
 for grain-protectants and hermetic grain-storage bags in Zimbabwe (2).
 -Review assessed Africa’s maize-based foods in terms of processing
 practices(3).
 -Two studies assessed maize seed systems – one reviewed relations between
 farmers’ seed demand and research methods (4) and the other provided a value
 chain analysis of maize hybrid seed by public-private sector in Bihar, India (5).
 -Two studies looked into mechanization – one provided a review
 of agricultural mechanization and its implications for reduced tillage (6)
 and the other assessed willingness to pay for scale-appropriate mechanization
 in Nepal(7)
 -Three studies looked at input supply and service
 dimensions – including irrigation and water markets in Bangladesh (8), heterogeneity in willingness to pay for fertilizer in Nepal (9) and the
 role of informal farmland rental markets for smallholders’ well-being in
 Malawi (10).
 -Ongoing review with visiting fellow assesses nutritional opportunities for
 MAIZE (in progress for 2020)

outcome_sumary:
1. A total of 562 stress tolerant and nutritious lines were shared with NARS and private seed companies
in 2019 through International Maize Improvement Consortium (IMIC) in Africa. Also,
more than 50 elite CIMMYT maize lines (parents of stress tolerant maize hybrids)
were shared with NARS and private seed companies from CIMMYT-Zimbabwe.

2. In Latin America, a total of 190 elite, stress resilient,
lowland tropical lines were shared with public and private sector partners in
Mexico and Colombia, besides 14 elite high Zinc lines with partners in
Guatemala. 3. In Asia, a total of 63 elite stress resilient
lines were shared with national partners in India, Nepal and Thailand in 2019.
In addition, 14 stress-resilient donor lines were shared with seed company partners
in India for developing joint hybrids.

seed shipment register at CIMMYT-Zimbabwe and CIMMYT-Kenya

outcome_sumary: 1. In July 2019, Oregon State University together with CIMMYT and USAID brought out a publication titled “Fall Armyworm Management for Maize Smallholders in Malawi: An Integrated Pest Management Strategic Plan”. The open-access publication has been widely disseminated .2. USAID, ICRISAT, CIMMYT, CRP MAIZE, and CRP GLDC in partnership with national and international research and development partners, including ICAR and CABI, organized the Asia Regional Fall Armyworm Management Workshop in ICRISAT, Hyderabad, India.3. FAW Preparedness and Management Workshop organized during July 29-31, 2019, in Kathmandu, Nepal.  4. A scientific 3-D animation video on FAW identification, scouting and management, jointly developed by Michigan State University, CIMMYT and USAID, has been translated extensively into different languages in both Africa and Asia in 2019. For example, in Bangladesh, the SAWBO video on FAW reached over 130,000 farmers.

gender_justification: Nutritional quality has direct impact on women and youth.
youth_justification: Nutritionally enriched maize has particular relevance for productivity of youth.

outcome_sumary: FP2 contributed to diversified enterprise opportunities by (i) generating market intelligence for gender-responsive product profiling, accelerated breeding, food choice, and women's empowerment, (ii) developing rice value chain upgrading strategies and sharing them at a regional multistakeholder workshop; (iii) developing and piloting several innovations in Asia (rice husk furnace, rice straw furnace, rice straw feed, rice straw mushroom, LCA-rice straw, rice straw pelleting, and rice straw batch biogas production); (iv) publishing several scientific articles and a Springer book on sustainable rice straw management; (v) standardizing several locally fabricated technologies (Mini-GEM system, Mini-ASI, Paddy cleaner, Rice grader and different rice husk gasifier stoves) with private sector and showcasing them at a major agricultural forum in Africa.
milestone_evidence: Articles on market intelligence for gender-responsive product profiling, food choice, and women's empowerment. Articles on value chain upgrading strategies and a special issue on food systems. Springer book on intersectoral upgrading strategies for rice straw value chains. Two press releases on FP2's partner engagements.
gender_justification: Most product and process upgrading strategies are either targeted to improve women's welfare (e.g., improved parboiling in Africa) or involve both men's and women's preferences in the product design stage (e.g., gender-responsive product profiling).
youth_justification: Most process, technology and service upgrading strategies are designed to provide alternative income opportunities to youth.
capdev_justification: All upgrading strategies are fundamentally based on capacity development of private value chain actors and NARES.
climate_justification: Most upgrading technologies are designed with the aim of increasing sustainability and, hence, indirectly mitigating climate change. Intersectoral upgrading strategies (e.g., rice straw value chain upgrading) are specifically designed with the aim of mitigating climate change.

outcome_sumary: FP2 contributed to diversified enterprise opportunities by (i) generating market intelligence for gender-responsive product profiling, accelerated breeding, food choice, and women's empowerment, (ii) developing rice value chain upgrading strategies and sharing them at a regional multistakeholder workshop; (iii) developing and piloting several innovations in Asia (rice husk furnace, rice straw furnace, rice straw feed, rice straw mushroom, LCA-rice straw, rice straw pelleting, and rice straw batch biogas production); (iv) publishing several scientific articles and a Springer book on sustainable rice straw management; (v) standardizing several locally fabricated technologies (Mini-GEM system, Mini-ASI, Paddy cleaner, Rice grader and different rice husk gasifier stoves) with private sector and showcasing them at a major agricultural forum in Africa.
milestone_evidence: Book with 11 chapters on piloting of sustainable rice straw management with partners and report on multistakeholder workshops on rice straw value chain upgrading in three countries. Press releases on scaling of rice straw management in Cambodia, multistakeholder workshop in Africa, and participation and poster at SARA 2019.
gender_justification: Improved parboiling technologies piloted in Africa specifically aim at improving women's welfare.
youth_justification: Most process, technology and service upgrading strategies are piloted with young value chain actors with the aim of providing alternative income opportunities to youth.
capdev_justification: Capacity development of private value chain actors and NARES is at the core of all upgrading strategies being piloted.
climate_justification: Most upgrading technologies address sustainability concerns and, hence, indirectly mitigate climate change. Intersectoral upgrading strategies (e.g., rice straw value chain upgrading) specifically aim at mitigating climate change.

outcome_sumary: FP2 has contributed to understanding the constraints and opportunities in value chain services and agricultural finance in Nigeria and Tanzania. It has supported three MSc students. By 2019, in Cambodia 162 students have graduated with a BSc in agricultural engineering from the Royal University of Agriculture RUA with 83 students being enrolled and 64 apprentices qualified as Agricultural machinery Mechanics from Don Bosco, Battambang, with 32 apprentices currently being enrolled. With the interventions of FP2 and related bilateral projects (e.g. BMZ rice straw and VnSAT), rice straw balers are rapidly adopted in MRD of Vietnam and Cambodia that lead to a value-adding of 5–10% to rice production. A Sustainable rice straw technology was adopted in Vietnam and Cambodia.
milestone_evidence: Participation of the Bouaké innovation platform at SARA 2019 in Cote d'Ivoire. Paper on value of improved parboiled rice in Benin and Senegal. Report and two MSc theses on rice value chain upgrading in Cote d'Ivoire.
gender_justification: Improved parboiling is specifically designed to improve women's welfare.
youth_justification: Involvement of youth is an important part of the development and piloting of improved parboiling technologies.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is at the core of the introduction of the improved parboiler.
climate_justification: Climate change is not targeted in the development and piloting of the improved parboiler.

outcome_sumary: FP2 has contributed to understanding the constraints and opportunities in value chain services and agricultural finance in Nigeria and Tanzania. It has supported three MSc students. By 2019, in Cambodia 162 students have graduated with a BSc in agricultural engineering from the Royal University of Agriculture RUA with 83 students being enrolled and 64 apprentices qualified as Agricultural machinery Mechanics from Don Bosco, Battambang, with 32 apprentices currently being enrolled. With the interventions of FP2 and related bilateral projects (e.g. BMZ rice straw and VnSAT), rice straw balers are rapidly adopted in MRD of Vietnam and Cambodia that lead to a value-adding of 5–10% to rice production. A Sustainable rice straw technology was adopted in Vietnam and Cambodia.
milestone_evidence: New business model developed for attracting youth in agribusiness. Participation of the Bouaké innovation platform at SARA 2019 enabled capturing interest of youth in improved postharvest technologies. Annual graduate and student numbers and two press releases on involvement of value chain actors in sustainable rice straw management in Cambodia.
gender_justification: In the development of agribusiness services revolving around improved parboiling in Africa, women are the principal target and providing income opportunities for both women and men is the prime objective.
youth_justification: Development of agribusiness services provision specifically aims at improving income opportunities for youth.
capdev_justification: Development of agribusiness services provision is fundamentally based on capacity development of private value chain actors and NARES.
climate_justification: Some of the agribusiness services revolve around climate change mitigation strategies such as sustainable rice straw management.

outcome_sumary: FP2 has contributed to developed, adapted and piloted post-harvest technologies in Benin, Cote d’Ivoire and Nigeria. These technologies have contributed to post-harvest loss reduction, the production of quality products, time saving, increased revenue for value chain actor and reduction in pollution. These technologies include (i) coupling optimum harvesting time with mechanized threshing reduced harvesting loss by 23%, reduces drudgery and safes time; (ii) the GEM parboiling technology, which increases the nutritional and physical quality of rice, reduces drudgery, pollution and wood consumption, increases the value rice by $0.02 per Kg compared to rudimentary parboiled rice; (iii) rice husk gasifier stoves for parboiling and household cooking, resulting in 100% saving on the cost of wood for parboiling and cooking. An added advantage is that these stoves also reduce blackening of cooking pots and adds value to rice husk, a previously wasted resource. GrainSafe Dryer verification started with national partners in Myanmar (3), Sri Lanka (1), Cambodia (1), India (1), Philippines (2), VIetnam (1), Senegal (1), Thailand (1).
milestone_evidence: Several peer-review articles and AfricaRice Annual report demonstrating each of these post-harvest technologies. Independent reports from other developmental partners in rice value chain in Africa. Activities included in CORIGAP Annual Report and several press releases.
gender_justification: Loss reduction studies focus on technology and do not have a strong gender component, unless they focus on improved parboiling in Africa.
youth_justification: Loss reduction studies focus on technology and do not have a strong focus on youth.
capdev_justification: Findings from loss reduction research are included in curricula for training of private sector value chain actors and NARES.
climate_justification: Research contributing to loss reduction indirectly contributes to climate change mitigation as it directly contributes to increased efficiency of scarce input use.

outcome_sumary: FP2 has facilitated the creation of eight functional rice multi-stakeholder platforms, composed of microfinance institutions, seed suppliers, agro-input dealers, grain producers, production advisors, millers, aggregators/marketers, parboilers, consumers, equipment fabricators and policy makers. These platforms have been established in Benin, Cote d’Ivoire, Nigeria, Niger and Togo. These platforms have as the kin-pin the GEM parboiling facilities with links to other technologies such as improved varieties, RiceAdvice/GAP, ASI-threshing, improved milling and storage. This combination of tools and technologies has resulted in (i) high volume and variety of financial flow, (ii) increased knowledge transfer, product quality and better prices, and (iii) provision of embedded services as part of a contract. Scientific evidence and practical solutions for sustainable rice straw management developed under the projects were disseminated to beneficiaries. Development of rice straw management contributed to 10–20% reduction in rice straw burning in Vietnam (2016–2019); the scalable sustainable practices in Vietnam were also transferred to Cambodia and the Philippines through the learning alliance; cross-country training workshops and study tours. The achievements such as publications, proceedings, training materials, etc., have been shared with other organizations such as GIZ, CSAM, FAO, ILRI, ACIAR, agricultural agencies and institutions in Vietnam, Cambodia, Philippines, Thailand, Myanmar, India, etc.
milestone_evidence: Videos and news reports from different countries. Solutions for rice straw: 4 innovations in MARLO; 11 book chapters; 2 scientific articles. Rice straw mushroom production was piloted, tested, and developed in Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar, and the Philippines. Technology of rice husk downdraft for paddy drying was provided to India, Myanmar, Indonesia, and the Philippines.
gender_justification: The GEM parboiling technology is specifically designed to generate income opportunities for women in Africa.
youth_justification: Development of improved parboiling technologies and novel products from rice straw aim at providing income opportunities for youth.
capdev_justification: Research on improved processing and novel products is fundamentally based on capacity development of private value chain actors and NARES.
climate_justification: The research on novel products from rice straw aims at mitigate climate change footprint.

outcome_sumary: FP2 has contributed to increase the capacity of processors, equipment fabricators and students from different countries in West Africa: (i) about 3000 rice processors (90% women parboilers) trained on the production of quality parboiled rice using the GEM parboiler fueled with improved wood or rice husk stoves; (ii) private equipment fabricators trained on the standardized production of locally fabricated equipment. FP2 and related bilateral projects such as CORIGAP, ADSP, and VnSAT substantially contributed to enhanced capacity and knowledge of NARES on sustainable postharvest management practices such as flatbed drying, in-store drying, hermetic storage, rice husk furnace, rice straw management, etc.
milestone_evidence: Several PhD and MSc dissertations. Videos and news reports from different countries. Training materials on seed processing, drying, storage developed and updated. News releases on capacity building in NARES.
gender_justification: The gender-sensitive processing technologies developed in Africa improve capacity and economic opportunities of women rice processors.
youth_justification: Capacity development focuses on PhD students and young private sector value chain and NARES actors.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is the principal target of this milestone.
climate_justification: The research and capacity development on rice straw management aims at mitigating climate change.

outcome_sumary: We expect the World Health Organization (WHO) to issue a recommendation in 2020 on biofortification as a mainstream public health nutrition intervention. In addition, a draft definition was referred to the 2019 Session of the Codex Committee on Food Labelling (CCFL) to determine if it will meet their needs. The CCFL agreed current labeling texts were adequate; there was no need for a definition of biofortification in context of food labeling. HarvestPlus is no longer pursuing a standalone definition. Instead, we are working with the International Standards Organization and creating international nutrient standards for biofortified grains through a separate process.
milestone_evidence: The Biofortification Priority Index 2.0 analysis completed, paper published online and a microsite of the tool was launched, followed by several training sessions and outreach activities for stakeholders/users.
gender_justification: Gender aspect was not focused in the analysis of the reported results.
youth_justification: Youth aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.
capdev_justification: Several training sessions and outreach activities for stakeholders/users were conducted to capacitate them on how to use this flagship tool to learn on prioritized country-crop combinations. Link to a webinar organized in 2019: https://www.harvestplus.org/knowledge-market/in-the-news/webinar-where-can-crop-biofortification-be-most-impactful.
climate_justification: Climate change aspect was not included in the analysis of the reported results.

outcome_sumary: Over 15 resources added/updated in the toolbox across a wide range of topics providing EiB stakeholders with access to data managemet systems, manuals, training resources, service providers, recommended equipment lists,
milestone_evidence: Evidence is available in the toolbox, which is an online place to find resources for breeding programs (linked below).
gender_justification: too technical to address gender
capdev_justification: the primary purpose of these best practices and tools are to build the capacity of member breeding programs of EiB and to improve their efficiency and processes
climate_justification: practices and tools don't aim to address climate change- not possible to integrate climate change

outcome_sumary: Over 15 resources added/updated in the toolbox across a wide range of topics providing EiB stakeholders with access to data managemet systems, manuals, training resources, service providers, recommended equipment lists. Resources developed by external projects such as GOBII, QAAFI, CIMMYT, KSUadded/updated in the toolbox across a wide range of topics providing EiB stakeholders with access to data management systems, costing tools, manuals and training resources.
milestone_evidence:
Forums for module specific and general queries and discussions implemented in the EiB toolbox enabling CoP communications. High priority needs have been identified and highlighted in
institutional center and crop level improvement plans. These priorities include
missing or weak features contributing to trait discovery, mobilization and
precision breeding applications. Commonalities in prioritized features have
been identified. These features encompass a broader range of interventions than
biometrics/bioinformatics approaches, though some touch on this space and
initial use cases were defined to develop stop-gap solutions and example being
the extraction of relevant data from existing breeding management systems to
support decision making at germplasm advancement meetings.
gender_justification: no specific aim to address gender
youth_justification: no specific aim to address youth
capdev_justification: significant objective of the CoP is cap dev
climate_justification: no specific aim to address climate change

outcome_sumary: Over 15 resources added/updated in the toolbox across a wide range of topics providing EiB stakeholders with access to data management systems, manuals, training resources, service providers, recommended equipment lists. Breeding program documentation is proceeding. We are completing the recruitment of two positions to accelerate the needed face to face dialogue with breeding programs to complete this activity. Work on revisons to the toolbox will begin in may 2020 and the review functions will be revisited and worked on at that time.

Existing high value training documentation and links provided directly via the toolbox as a resource to the EiB community. Strategic review of EiB engagement and prioritization conducted with a 2020 plan to initiate full implementation of LMS within the EiB structure from May 2020 and move old and new E-learning content to that system by end of 2020.
gender_justification: women not particularly targeted by material
youth_justification: youth not particularly targeted by material
capdev_justification: primary objective of milestone is training/cap dev
climate_justification: climate not particularly targeted by material

outcome_sumary: Development of a variety of decision support tools, investment options, business cases and pilots proceeded to inform and influence application of sustainable intensification, soil management and application of agrobiodiversity in land restoration in 10 countries (Kenya, Benin, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Bangladesh, Uzbekistan, Jordan, Colombia, Peru and El Salvador). There was special attention paid to how a focus on gender and equity issues can positively impact restoration and soil health interventions.
milestone_evidence: Innovative pilots established including(1) multi-stakeholder platforms in Tanzania, which identified catalysts for local land restoration;(2)new land, water management solutions for restoring Ethiopian landscapes;(3)how to establish community seed banks in Ethiopia(4)approaches for maintaining fruit crop diversity in Central Asia;(5)adoption of new durum wheat varieties for livelihoods and resilience;(6) Revegetation of the floodplain system, Jordan;(7)data that demonstrates restoration benefits from agrobiodiversity in Uzbekistan and Bolivia.
gender_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Gender as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Gender analysis of the relationship between migration and family structures (among others).
youth_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
capdev_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
climate_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Climate Change as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Climate Change component related to the multidimensional analysis of national, regional and watershed/landscape restoration options.

outcome_sumary: WLE’s decision analysis frameworks for planning and performance measurement of land restoration efforts were further developed and applied with local partners in Burkina Faso, Ethiopia (2), Kenya, and India. The Burkina Faso case evaluated alternative interventions for protecting a reservoir from siltation. The Ethiopia cases evaluated alternatives for forest landscape restoration and irrigation developments. In Kenya there was close partnership with county-level government and stakeholders to target and co-design land restoration investments. In India, an integrated framework was tested for monitoring, evaluating, and enhancing the effectiveness of initiatives designed to restore degraded land in commonly managed land.
milestone_evidence: Two papers on a decision analysis framework for development planning, performance measurement and project stochastic impact evaluation delivered.
gender_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
youth_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
capdev_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
climate_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.

outcome_sumary: To increase recognition of waste as a business opportunity, curricula and an online course were designed for universities and schools. Pilot training program and direct engagements with universities generated keen interest to adopt the curriculum into their programs or incorporate selected modules in courses.Advisory services for key sanitation/RRR investors (World Bank and BMGF) in South Asia helped strengthen business capacities.Our support of waste-based standards in Sri Lanka is helping establish an enabling environment for RRR.The need to establish standards was an important lesson for scaling up waste-based fertilizer recommendations, resulting in milestone change.
milestone_evidence: Testing waste-based fertilizer under discussion, as new standards for Municipal Solid Waste, agri-waste proposed by Sri Lanka Standard Institution. Similar discussion, in Ghana.Sri Lanka Coconut Research Institute receptive, prepared field trials proposal.Stakeholder consultative process on new standards underway, with Sri Lanka Standards Institution, Sustainable Agricultural Research and Development Centre supported by IWMI.

outcome_sumary:
The
 ongoing review of scaling approaches is generating useful lessons for
 increased technology adoption and impact through identification of successful
 approaches to technology scaling and the underlying institutional and policy
 contexts.
 The
 review of impact studies of GLDC innovations has identified major gaps in
 terms of crops, countries and types of impact and offered recommendations for
 future impact assessments of GLDC technologies to expand crop and country
 coverage; to assess environmental, nutritional or social impacts in addition
 to economic impacts; and to improve on methodological approaches.
 The
 impact evidencing strategy that has been developed is expected to facilitate
 monitoring and evaluation and impact assessment systems for greater
 accountability and enhanced adoption and impacts of GLDC innovations.

 working paper has been published on the review of impact studies of GLDC
 technologies

The
 ongoing review of scaling approaches is generating useful lessons for
 increased technology adoption and impact through identification of successful
 approaches to technology scaling and the underlying institutional and policy
 contexts.
 The
 review of impact studies of GLDC innovations has identified major gaps in
 terms of crops, countries and types of impact and offered recommendations for
 future impact assessments of GLDC technologies to expand crop and country
 coverage; to assess environmental, nutritional or social impacts in addition
 to economic impacts; and to improve on methodological approaches.
 The
 impact evidencing strategy that has been developed is expected to facilitate
 monitoring and evaluation and impact assessment systems for greater
 accountability and enhanced adoption and impacts of GLDC innovations.
milestone_evidence:
Strategy
 note
gender_justification: The assessment work will examine gender issues
youth_justification: The assessment work will examine youth inclusion issues
capdev_justification: The assessment work will examine cap dev. issues
climate_justification: The assessment work will examine climate change mainstreaming issues

outcome_sumary:
Five
 strains each of Streptomyces and Bacillus were evaluated as bio-control
 agents against Fusarium wilt and PGP agents in chickpea under both greenhouse
 and field conditions and they reduced the disease incidence. Sweet sorghum
 bagasse was found to decompose fast and its compost prepared with microbes
 successfully promoted plant growth and significantly enhanced yields. Five
 indigenous Bradyrhizobium strains were evaluated on soybean and showed
 promising results with decreasing striga population and increasing biomass
 and grain yields in Mozambique
 The
 spatial and temporal distribution of emerging diseases of chickpea and
 pigeonpea in India was assessed and risk areas mapped. In a large-scale
 application of biocontrol agents in Benin and Burkina Faso, adults of
 Therophilus javanus were recovered from parasitized Maruca vitrata
 caterpillars collected from cowpea pods 3 years after the release and the
 borer populations remains reduced by 86.3%. Plant growth promotion products
 like AMF inoculation proved to be effective on striga infection and yield of
 sole-cropped maize and maize-bean intercrops in Uganda.
milestone_evidence: N/A.Partners were not able to deliver a key piece on time
gender_justification: There is gender intergration research just starting in a bilateral project, but it might not contribute to achieving the milestone before 2021.
youth_justification: There is youth intergration research just starting in a bilateral project, but it might not contribute to achieving the milestone before 2021.
capdev_justification: Sample CapDev-related activities: graduate students, demonstration trials, biocontrol sensitization campaigns
climate_justification: Climate change is an important and deliberate objective, but not the principal reason in technology fine-tuning.

Five
 strains each of Streptomyces and Bacillus were evaluated as bio-control
 agents against Fusarium wilt and PGP agents in chickpea under both greenhouse

 successfully promoted plant growth and significantly enhanced yields. Five

 and grain yields in Mozambique
 The

other_reason: 1. Research/science - inherent risk in unknown cutting-edge research or science; 2. Financial - funding delayed and/or cut;6. External environment (political, economic, legal, market) - e.g. conflict, economic/market changes (activities under this milestone will be informed by the results previous milestone (of course with overlaps), so we expect this one to be completed by the end of 2021.)
gender_justification: Sample gender-related activities: gender-disaggregated benchmark values of some performance indicators such as the use of improved varieties, use of chemical pesticides and biopesticides, the perceived key production constraints, average cowpea yields, and gender-sensitive socio-economic values
youth_justification: Sample youth-related activities: development of effective deployment strategies for women and youth, such that they have increased access to improved strategies for safe and sustainable cowpeas pest management
capdev_justification: Sample CapDev-related activities: graduate students, demonstration trials, biocontrol sensitization campaigns
climate_justification: Climate change is an important and deliberate objective, but not the principal reason for testing technology at pilot scale.

outcome_sumary:
Comprehensive
 framework for farming systems sustainability with five domains and 115
 indicators in India. A multi-dimensional analysis was undertaken to explore
 the near-future effects of different scenarios on food security dimensions of
 SI in southern Mali. A remote sensing-based model has been calibrated for
 millet yield estimated allowing to account for parkland effects (R²=0.70) in
 Senegal.
milestone_evidence: Publications
gender_justification: At first stage we are promoting multiple livelihood assets based farm typologies to better tagert interventions, women dominated households categorised in separate farm type and need different interventions. At next step, in the whole farm systems modelled for SA and SSA, we specifically account for women participation in the farming system and how it affects the farm household's cash flows. Further in our System dynamics modelling for value chain analysis which is still under construction, we analyse impact of gender interventions on the value chain performance and accordingly identify leverage points.
capdev_justification: This miletone has strong component on capacity buildibng ofstakeholders, students and extension system on integrating systems modelling asdecisoon support in SSA and SA.
climate_justification: Not required

outcome_sumary:
The
 simultaneous improvement of both production and market traits through
 partnership with NARS under Flagship 4 resulted in commercialization of 26
 GLDC crop cultivars of chickpea (6), lentil (5), groundnut (8), pigeon pea
 (2), sorghum (1), pearl millet (3), and finger millet (1) in Africa and
 Asia.
 Rapid
 generation advancement (RGA) that enhances rate of genetic gain is used to
 develop and commercialize high oleic varieties, and protocols were
 standardized and deployed in lentil and chickpea. New genetic material of
 GLDC crops was shared with NARS partners in Africa and Asia and
 multi-location testing is established jointly with NARS to identify new
 cultivars for the target-agroecologies.
 TPE
 Characterization in Asia and WCA is completed for Groundnut, Sorghum and
 Chickpea and this activity is prioritized under CoA 4.1 and has received
 co-investment from AVISA and other bilateral projects.
 The
 first high oleic groundnut varieties that confer consumer hearth benefits are
 commercialized in India. Bio-fortified lentil and pearl millet cultivars
 commercialized are important to reduce the burden of micro-nutrient
 malnutrition.
 The
 GLDC crop product profiles have been developed and uploaded on the EiB
 platform. NARS were also trained on development of PPs at the second training
 course organized by FP4.
milestone_evidence:
High
 oliec varieties in record time of 8 years.
other_reason: Deployment of innovations including RGA requires logistic adjustment. Initial logistics plan for genetic materials deployment will be completed with all stakeholders, and optimized RGA technology just recently completed optimization for other several crops
gender_justification: Not required
capdev_justification: Optimization of the RGA protocol required training of NARS focal persons, and researchers responsible for the coordinated trials.
climate_justification: Not required

milestone_evidence:

 TPEs
other_reason: 1. Research/science - inherent risk in unknown cutting-edge research or science; The TPE analysis has been initaited under CoA 41., completed for some crops and on-going for others. For all the GLDC crops and all regions, TPEs characterization will not be completed in next two years as it needs pooling of datasets and modeling. Human resources are limiting.
gender_justification: Gender is an important and deliberate objective, but not the principal reason in stress patterns analysis. The overall objective was to add socio-economic dimension to the TPE analysis as was done Sorghum for India that can capture the gender component.
capdev_justification: Training on biophysical-related tools for climate and weather parameters
climate_justification: Climate change is the main objective and is fundamental in the design and expected results in stress patterns analysis. In particular, the TPE characterization used current weather of the regions.

 (2), sorghum (1), pearl millet (3), and finger millet (1) in Africa and
 Asia.
