outcome_sumary:
A mobile application to capture dairy cattle
performance, and provide feedback, was developed and is in use by more than 140,000 farmers in Ethiopia, Kenya and Tanzania (milestone
1.1.7). Baseline genome characterization data for sheep and goats in Ethiopia (milestone 1.1.6) was collected but analysis and writing up are ongoing, so this milestone was extended. The evidence for identification of genomic regions strongly associated with tolerance to Theileria parva infection in cattle was delayed due to issues with the patenting process, so this milestone (1.1.8) was also extended to 2021.
milestone_evidence:
The genome data will be used to investigate genetic
diversity, structure and relationships, and signatures of selection associated
with traits of economic and adaptive significance. Such information can be used
to formulate appropriate breeding and conservation strategies. In Ethiopia,
the data has been generated for sheep (analysis completed and manuscript drafted, for publication in 2021) and for goats (analysis is ongoing by a PhD
student, but was not completed due to a delay in sequencing
the samples and political conflict in Tigray where the student was
based). It is unlikely that a publication will be available for goats before the end of the CRP in December 2021. For Sudan, the data was generated but is owned by a
national partner and not available to the Flagship until it is published. For
Tanzania, sampling was not possible in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Given this, we have changed the milestone from Ethiopia, Tanzania and Sudan to Ethiopia only and extended it to 2021.
gender_justification: Upstream genomics study
capdev_justification: Involvement of a PhD student
climate_justification: Upstream genomics study

outcome_sumary:
A mobile application to capture dairy cattle
performance, and provide feedback, was developed and is in use by more than 140,000 farmers in Ethiopia, Kenya and Tanzania (milestone
1.1.7). Baseline genome characterization data for sheep and goats in Ethiopia (milestone 1.1.6) was collected but analysis and writing up are ongoing, so this milestone was extended. The evidence for identification of genomic regions strongly associated with tolerance to Theileria parva infection in cattle was delayed due to issues with the patenting process, so this milestone (1.1.8) was also extended to 2021.
milestone_evidence: Completion of a mobile application to capture dairy cattle performance and provide feedback to farmers, which is being used by 140,000 farmers across Ethiopia, Kenya and Tanzania.
gender_justification: Reaches both men and women, but not specifically desigend to benefit women
youth_justification: Reachers youth, but not specifically designed to benefit youth
capdev_justification: Increased capacity of women and men smallhold dairy cattle farmers who utilise the tool
climate_justification: No specific climate change focus

outcome_sumary:
A mobile application to capture dairy cattle
performance, and provide feedback, was developed and is in use by more than 140,000 farmers in Ethiopia, Kenya and Tanzania (milestone
1.1.7). Baseline genome characterization data for sheep and goats in Ethiopia (milestone 1.1.6) was collected but analysis and writing up are ongoing, so this milestone was extended. The evidence for identification of genomic regions strongly associated with tolerance to Theileria parva infection in cattle was delayed due to issues with the patenting process, so this milestone (1.1.8) was also extended to 2021.
milestone_evidence: The genomic regions have been identified, but the deliverables - a journal article and patent application - have been delayed due to procedural issues with the patenting process. This is expected to be resolved in the first half of 2021.
other_reason: Patent application underway delaying publication of the journal paper
gender_justification: Upstream genomics study
capdev_justification: Upstream genomics study
climate_justification: Upstream genomics study

outcome_sumary:
Updated breeding objectives and selection
indexes have been developed for the dairy cattle breeding program in East Africa, which will be
used by the breeding program moving forward (milestone 1.2.6). Successful establishment of breeding programs has been achieved for pastoral production systems (milestone 1.2.5, ongoing). The milestone of availing
a zebu x taurine admixture single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) chip for
determining the underlying breed composition of cross-bred dairy cattle is complete (milestone 1.2.4), despite not being able to find a company interested
in commercializing this tool as was originally intended (this will be revisited in
the future).
milestone_evidence:
Despite significant efforts, a genotyping company willing to 
commercialize this assay has not been found. The results of the assay 
are however published, 
and stakeholders will be able to use this information to utilize the 
assay should they wish to do so.
gender_justification: Development of a genomics assay
capdev_justification: Development of a genomics assay
climate_justification: Development of a genomics assay

outcome_sumary: Additional evidence has been generated on the importance of endemic diseases, to contribute to changing the discourse on animal health priorities. The peste des petits ruminants (PPR) assessment tool has been launched and used by a wide group of stakeholders outside the CGIAR. Other important achievements are: the mapping of sheep and dromedary ticks in Northern Africa including characterization of the dynamics and phylogeny; and identification of knowledge and information gaps about respiratory diseases of swine in Africa as well as economic impacts of the various pathogens. All these are helping policymakers to make better prioritize animal health activities.
milestone_evidence: The peste des petits ruminants (PPR) tools have been used by 70 national level researchers, papers on models accessed (check altmetrics), endemic/production diseases taken up as an important issue in the ILRI 2025 research agenda, and data generated used in the Global Burden of Animal disease project (University of Liverpool). The original milestone was overly ambitious, particularly given the disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The milestone target was therefore revised to 15 national and 8 international research partners and major donors, which has been achieved.
gender_justification: The impacts of livestock diseases affect men and women differently, given their distinct gender roles in livestock management and their exposure to risk. The disease assessment tools developed allow impact assessment of both men and women livestock value chain actors. A major focus has been developing tools and methods to assess the impacts of Peste des Ruminants (PPR), a disease of small ruminants, which are a priority livestock for women..
capdev_justification: The launch/application of the tools is a CapDev activity
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary: Additional evidence has been generated on the importance of endemic diseases, to contribute to changing the discourse on animal health priorities. The peste des petits ruminants (PPR) assessment tool has been launched and used by a wide group of stakeholders outside the CGIAR. Other important achievements are: the mapping of sheep and dromedary ticks in Northern Africa including characterization of the dynamics and phylogeny; and identification of knowledge and information gaps about respiratory diseases of swine in Africa as well as economic impacts of the various pathogens. All these are helping policymakers to make better prioritize animal health activities.
milestone_evidence: Due to COVID-19 there was limited access to the lab.
gender_justification: n/a
capdev_justification: n/a
climate_justification: n/a

Other important achievements are: the mapping of sheep and dromedary ticks in Northern Africa including characterization of the dynamics and phylogeny; and identification of knowledge and information gaps about respiratory diseases of swine in Africa as well as economic impacts of the various pathogens. All these are helping policymakers to make better prioritize animal health activities.
milestone_evidence:
Extended due to delays related to COVID-19. Data
collection had started in most sites, but was delayed by approximately 8
months.
gender_justification: The modelling is gender sensitive
capdev_justification: launching/applying the tool is a cap dev activity
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary: Additional evidence has been generated on the importance of endemic diseases, to contribute to changing the discourse on animal health priorities. The peste des petits ruminants (PPR) assessment tool has been launched and used by a wide group of stakeholders outside the CGIAR. Other important achievements are: the mapping of sheep and dromedary ticks in Northern Africa including characterization of the dynamics and phylogeny; and identification of knowledge and information gaps about respiratory diseases of swine in Africa as well as economic impacts of the various pathogens. All these are helping policymakers to make better prioritize animal health activities.
milestone_evidence: We have successfully characterized the dynamics of ticks in sheep and dromedaries, their phylogeny and also the main tick-transmitted diseases in these 2 important livestock species in drylands.
gender_justification: This is biomedical research
capdev_justification: This is biomedical research
climate_justification: The distribution of ticks is highly dependent on climate

outcome_sumary: Experiences on integrating interventions has been made in different production systems (pigs in Uganda, all species in Vietnam, small ruminants and dairy in Ethiopia). The flagship has launched a freely available guide to herd health management for dairy, pigs and small ruminants and developed a digital tool (mobile app) to monitor productivity parameters in livestock.
milestone_evidence: A herd health management framework has been developed and published by the flagship and is being rolled out in Ethiopia in dairy and small ruminants and in pigs in Uganda.
gender_justification: Gender aspects included in the analysis of the farm
capdev_justification: A practical guide was developed for veterinarians and animal health workers on herd health management (see first evidence link)
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary:
In 2020 the portfolio of
conceptual papers, including journal articles and strategic briefs, extended
and guided food systems thinking and approaches of partners and other CRPs.
Metrics and tools to carry out food systems analysis were promoted through our
newly established Food Systems Resource Center. Exchange of ideas on food
systems for healthier diets took place through dedicated blogs at the Food
System Idea Exchange. This has improved stakeholder access to excellent and
up-to-date information on food systems thinking including the metrics, methods,
and tools to do analysis, design and evaluate innovations, conduct policy
engagement, and build capacity and
awareness.
milestone_evidence: Food environment tools were used in Ethiopia by the World Food Program and Mekelle University. The city of Bahir Dar expressed interest in using the food environment tool through the European Union's Horizon 2020 project (with potentially 9 more of their "food system labs"). Johns Hopkins University and the Global Alliance for Improved Nutrition (GAIN) compared the compendium of indicators with indicators under consideration in the development of their Food Systems Dashboard. To date, at least six companies and governments and development partners in 10 countries have used the Agrobiodiversity Index. The diet quality questionnaire, currently being validated in Ethiopia and Vietnam, was used by the University of Ibadan (Nigeria), and the Hanoi Medical University in their COVID-19 study. All methods, metrics and tools were included in the Food Systems Resource Center as open access. Some were highlighted in blogs in the Food Systems Idea Exchange. A learning lab on food environment assessment methods was organized at the Agriculture, Nutrition, and Health Academy Week 2020 conference.
gender_justification: Metrics and tools will allow for gender disaggregation, and identification of gender specific leverage points
youth_justification: Although most tools and metrics do not specifically address youth, some of the tools are specifically targeted to youth such as the photovoice methods. This is highlighted in the Food systems Resource Center and Food Systems Idea Exchange
capdev_justification: This outcome is mainly focused on building capacity of others to do food system analysis.
climate_justification: Metrics and tools do incorporate those to measure for example environmental sustainability of diets.

outcome_sumary:
In 2020 the portfolio of
conceptual papers, including journal articles and strategic briefs, extended
and guided food systems thinking and approaches of partners and other CRPs.
Metrics and tools to carry out food systems analysis were promoted through our
newly established Food Systems Resource Center. Exchange of ideas on food
systems for healthier diets took place through dedicated blogs at the Food
System Idea Exchange. This has improved stakeholder access to excellent and
up-to-date information on food systems thinking including the metrics, methods,
and tools to do analysis, design and evaluate innovations, conduct policy
engagement, and build capacity and
awareness.
milestone_evidence:
In
 Nigeria, consumer work and scenarios informed the collaboration with the
 Nigerian Institute of Food Science and Technology on safer street food in
 Lagos. In Ethiopia, the identification of research gaps on (a) consumers informed
 research on food environments and (b) food-based dietary guidelines led to
 their development, an ongoing program adopted by the Government of Ethiopia. In Nigeria and Ethiopia, a fruit and vegetable voucher intervention is
 ongoing. Food systems analysis in Bangladesh informed the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO’s) Dhaka food systems program.
gender_justification: Leverage points identified specifically focused on improving access, affordability and acceptability of healthy diets to women.
youth_justification: Leverage points for youth are specifically looked at in the portfolio of leverage points identified.
capdev_justification: Local PhD students are involved in modelling activities to gain hands-on experience in this type of analysis.
climate_justification: Some of the activities to identify leverage points are connected with CCAFS activities and as such incorporate environmental sustainability and climate change considerations.

outcome_sumary:
Organizations used evidence
generated by Outcome 1.1. in making operational and investment decisions. We report
progress towards outcomes from the focus countries (in the annual milestones) and
with international partners. For example, with French institutes in the CGIAR-French
partnership, joint projects are under development. The Gates Foundation and the
Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office requested our support in
co-developing the next phase of Drivers of Food Choice with the University of
South Carolina. The International Fund for Agricultural Development invited
Wageningen University and Research (on behalf of A4NH) to assemble evidence for
the publication of their Rural Development Report 2021.
gender_justification: Project in Vietnam specifically focused on improving fruits and vegetables intake of women and addressing barriers of women to access fruits and vegetables.
youth_justification: Some projects include youth to implement food system innovations, but not all.
capdev_justification: In many of these innovations, PhD students are involved to enable them to build capacity to study food system innovations
climate_justification: The food system innovations developed do not explicitly take into account climate change, but  trade-off analysis will look at environmental sustainability trade-offs

outcome_sumary:
Building public-private
partnerships to promote the implementation of strategies for food systems for
healthier diets has been a slower process than expected because of unforeseen bottlenecks. The guidance note was
a useful starting point but needs to be expanded based on researchers’ implementation
experiences. Private-sector collaborations were established through activities
led by multi-stakeholder platforms, external partner-led initiatives to identify
game changing food system innovations in the focus countries (Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Nigeria, and Viet Nam). Internal
reflection in 2020 prompted a synthesis study on lessons learned from
A4NH’s public-private collaboration building experiences, which will be
finished before A4NH ends.
milestone_evidence: A synthesis report on working with private sector in A4NH will replace this guidance note in 2021. Through support of FP1 to Project DISRUPT: Healthy diets on a healthy planet, led by Bioversity and the Global Alliance for Improved Nutrition (GAIN), several food systems innovations were proposed and discussed with a wide range of stakeholders including the private sector. Through engagement with the Scaling up Nutrition Movement (SUN) Business Network in Bangladesh, the private sector is promoting implementation of activities that benefit food systems for healthier diets. In Viet Nam, a cooperative and two companies have been collaborating on a bilateral project on integrated vegetable seed systems development among ethnic minority communities. The FP1 focus countries include Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Nigeria, and Viet Nam.
gender_justification: Special attention is given to opportunities to strengthen womens empowerment as one the main facilitators to improve diets of themselves and their family.
youth_justification: Minimal attention is given to the youth in public-private partnership development.
capdev_justification: Capacity development happens mainly in the form of webinars where FP1 partners are together with private sector stakeholders involved in for example panel discussions.
climate_justification: Public-private partnerships are not developed specifically around climate change but  trade-off analysis will look at environmental sustainability trade-offs

milestone_evidence: The milestone should not have been included in the POWB for 2020; it was an error. It was intended for 2021 (and was in the 2021 POWB). We list it as cancelled for 2020 because it is the best option available.
other_reason: The milestone should not have been included in the POWB for 2020. It was intended for 2021.
gender_justification: The milestone should not have been included in the POWB for 2020. It was intended for 2021.
youth_justification: The milestone should not have been included in the POWB for 2020. It was intended for 2021.
capdev_justification: The milestone should not have been included in the POWB for 2020. It was intended for 2021.
climate_justification: The milestone should not have been included in the POWB for 2020. It was intended for 2021.

outcome_sumary:
Increasing the attention to
engagement and anchoring the Food Systems for Healthier Diets (FP1) thinking
and lessons learned was our plan for 2020. Unfortunately, the COVID-19 pandemic
disrupted these plans. Some activities still took place virtually; this was
much less effective. After reflection, most engagement activities, such as the
scenario workshops, have been postponed to 2021. Bangladesh, Nigeria, and Viet Nam finalized their policy baselines; delays in Ethiopia meant the four-country synthesis cannot
be completed unit 2021. Work with the multi-level stakeholder platforms progressed
in Bangladesh with the Scaling up Nutrition movement (SUN) Business Network but
has stalled in Ethiopia.
milestone_evidence:
Policy
 baselines were completed in Nigeria (2020), Bangladesh (2018) and Viet Nam (2019). Circumstances in Ethiopia have created delays, but it, along with a synthesis, will be finalized in 2021. Links to evidence to all three internal reports are available in TeamSpace.
gender_justification: System analyses incorporate a gender lense and will further inform policy discourses and identification of leverage points that will also enable women's empowerment.
youth_justification: Some analysis look at the position of youth; platforms are also assessed whether youth could be addressed better.
capdev_justification: Capacity development takes place through involvement of FP1 partners in webinars and virual meetings. Also 15 local PhD candidated are enrolled in a WUR PhD programme doing researh in FP1 projects; in addition in 3 of the 4 countries a local MSc Grant Scheme was started to engage with local knowledge institutes.
climate_justification: Although the entry point of engagement is food system transformation towward healthy diets, attention is given to not overshoot the environmental ceiling, or to harm the scial foundation in countries.

 Bangladesh, CCAFS-A4NH-WUR initiated a collaborated with Oxfam and local
 stakeholders, however follow up was
 delayed due to COVID-19 and postponed to 2021. In Nigeria, scenario engagement with federal and four state level
 ministries of agriculture and health reached inception stage, but actual
 workshops were delayed due to COVID-19 disruptions and postponed to 2021. Links to evidence for the milestone will be provided in 2021 when it is available.

milestone_evidence:
Progress
 to date has been mainly in Viet Nam and Ethiopia. In Viet Nam, the national
 office of the Zero Hunger initative, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural
 Development, and the People’s Committee in Cau Giay; Dong Anh and Moc Chau
 have all used A4NH results. In Ethiopia, the options on anchoring were included in FP1's contributions to the Seqota Declaration projects. Engagement in the other countries has been delayed due to COVID-19 and activities were postponed until 2021.
gender_justification: System analyses incorporate a gender lense and will further inform policy discourses and identification of leverage points that will also enable women's empowerment.

outcome_sumary: CCAFS scenarios guided development of sector policies based on Costa Rica's Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) in 2020, with contributions also made to NDCs of Ghana and Mali. Support continued to African Group of Negotiators Experts Support (AGNES) and the Kenya Climate-smart Agriculture Implementation Framework and the Multi-stakeholder Platform. CCAFS science was used to revise the Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan for the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and the SADC Regional Indicative Strategic Development Plan for 2022-2030. Contributions were made to the development of the National Action Plan on Gender and Climate Change for Nigeria, approved in August 2020.
milestone_evidence: The milestone were essentially completed. During 2020, there was considerable interaction with AGNES and science-policy platforms in West and East Africa. Training was conducted on CSA mapping in Vietnam, the Philippines and Cambodia, as well as on future scenarios and climate risk vulnerability assessment in the SADC region.
gender_justification: n/a
capdev_justification: All activities involved capacity development of stakeholders. In different countries, via participatory scenario processes and science-policy platforms, depending on context.
climate_justification: The nutrition security portfolios are meeting the criteria for climate finance, CSA and sustainable development.

outcome_sumary: State of the art multi-level scenarios methodology is being tested by downscaling scenarios to national/state levels and including food and nutrition security modelling outputs. Online trainings were conducted in East Africa, Southeast Asia and Central America to assist gender- and nutrition-sensitive scenario-guided policy formulation, along with training manuals and a new results dashboard, with results from Bangladesh.
milestone_evidence: New tools have been developed and tested using integrated modelling work in Bangladesh, and results made available online to policy makers in Bangladesh. Other tools and training were provided to decision makers (in the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry) in Lao PDR, while gaming prototypes were also developed.
gender_justification: gender a key component of scenarios work
youth_justification: youth a key component of futures work, including via gaming innovations
capdev_justification: on-line training materials developed and disseminated
climate_justification: These tools are used for scenario development and analysis for scientists and policy makers to better understand potential future changes in climate change, in relation to human population and demands for food and fuel and to address associated uncertainties.

outcome_sumary: State of the art multi-level scenarios methodology is being tested by downscaling scenarios to national/state levels and including food and nutrition security modelling outputs. Online trainings were conducted in East Africa, Southeast Asia and Central America to assist gender- and nutrition-sensitive scenario-guided policy formulation, along with training manuals and a new results dashboard, with results from Bangladesh.
milestone_evidence: There was some delay in implementing integrated modelling tools and linking these with food & nutrition security scenarios. Some work was completed in Bangladesh, and contributing work is underway in 2021 in Latin America,
gender_justification: gender a key component of scenarios work
capdev_justification: training a key component of the work
climate_justification: major focus

outcome_sumary:
Recommendations are feeding into several policy processes at the country-level, informing climate smart 
food and nutrition security policies. In 2020 these countries included Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, India, Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica and Colombia.
milestone_evidence: There are still considerable delays in accessing the "next generation" set of climate model outputs (CMIP6).  Some analysis work has been done with CMIP6 data, but all this has to be redone as errors have been found by suppliers of the data.  Given that robust data are expected in the third quarter of 2021, this allows little time for impact work to be undertaken. Even so, the outcome target will be achieved (although with CMIP5 and other climate data).
gender_justification: not a target
capdev_justification: training an integral part of the work
climate_justification: major focus

outcome_sumary:
Recommendations are feeding into several policy processes at the country-level, informing climate smart 
food and nutrition security policies. In 2020 these countries included Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, India, Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica and Colombia.
milestone_evidence: Milestone essentially complete. Recommendations were fed into a range of different country processes including Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, Ghana, Zambia, India, Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica and Colombia. Part of this work included information from global studies on multiple cropping systems and updated analyses of current and future climate hazards for use in prioritisation studies and initiatives such as the Global Commission on Adaptation and the Green Climate Fund Agriculture and Food Security Sectoral Guide, which are informing national investments and priorities.
gender_justification: Most of these activities included a gender component: seed systems in Uganda included analysis of women's seed management; Global Commission on Adaptation contributions included analysis of effects of climate change on women and youth; Recommendations for Kenya included analysis of gendered effects of climate change as well as key gender issues in the country.
capdev_justification: In different countries, via participatory scenario processes and science-policy platforms, depending on context.
climate_justification: major focus

outcome_sumary: A synthesis was initiated to see how gender considerations were integrated in scenarios processes across all of CCAFS focus regions, which is to be completed in 2021. Studies on gender indicators in Climate-Smart Agriculture (CSA) policy formulation, on women's empowerment and its effects on crop diversification, and the effects of COVID-19 on rural women were completed and published. A framework was developed for IFAD on programming investments that integrate climate change, gender, youth and nutrition.
milestone_evidence: The milestone contributes directly to the outcome. which should be achieved by the end of 2021, synthesised in two studies on the integration of gender considerations in scenarios processes and in policy processes more generally. Studies on gender indicators in CSA policy formulation, on women's empowerment and its effects on crop diversification, and the effects of Covid-19 on rural women, were completed and published. Guidance was developed with IDRC to the African Group of Negotiators Expert Support (AGNES) on mainstreaming gender into National Adaptation Planning and implementation in sub-Saharan Africa,
gender_justification: All of these activities included gender in the situational analysis, analysis of effects of climate and COVID-19 on women producers, and highlighted important gender issues and recommendations for policy at the national level.
youth_justification: A significant focus of the milestone
capdev_justification: Cap dev activities Via interactions and technical backstopping with AGNES (as in the text), and via science-policy platforms, depending on context.
climate_justification: All activities in this milestone focused on increasing resilience of women and youth to respond and adapt to climate change effects

outcome_sumary: The outcome target has been achieved, and a recent study found that CCAFS research and partnerships over the last 10 years in the influenced the investment decisions of a diverse range of investors globally. This has been achieved through multiple investment-oriented outcome pathways, with entry points for influencing public and private sector actors in a wide range of countries. The lessons distilled from these experiences—highlighted in the study—continue to guide future investment planning for resilient and climate-smart food systems.
milestone_evidence: Several activities contributed to this milestone in 2020. New indicator sets were developed for tracking gender in policy processes. A new online tool was developed and tested for tracking the effects / outcomes of project activities at different scales. Contributions were made to several high-level publications and research reports that sought to link nutrition- and transformation-related activities to the SDG framework, for tracking progress in the future. This included new analyses of new technology and the enablers that may be needed for uptake at scale, that can lead to food systems transformation to achieve the sustainable development goals.
gender_justification: gender-sensitive investment is a key dimension
capdev_justification: mainstreaming gender a key focus. Also, capacity development was achieved around the use of new indicator sets and a dashboard for tracking progress towards targets.
climate_justification: major focus

outcome_sumary: The outcome target has been achieved, and a recent study found that CCAFS research and partnerships over the last 10 years in the influenced the investment decisions of a diverse range of investors globally. This has been achieved through multiple investment-oriented outcome pathways, with entry points for influencing public and private sector actors in a wide range of countries. The lessons distilled from these experiences—highlighted in the study—continue to guide future investment planning for resilient and climate-smart food systems.
milestone_evidence: Through active contribution from its West Africa Program, CCAFS Science and Engagement has informed the design of World Bank funded USD480mn regional flagship program, the West Africa Food System Resilience Program (FSRP), a 10-year program to strengthen the West Africa food system resilience to shocks led by the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the Permanent Interstate Committee for Drought Control in the Sahel (CLISS), and the West and Central African Council for Agricultural Research and Development (CORAF/WECARD). CCAFS has actively contributed to the design and development of the FSRP proposal document and to the production of a blueprint document for a sound implementation planning.The work of CCAFS and partners over the last 10 years in the research and engagement arenas has influenced the investment decisions of a diverse range of investors globally. This has been achieved via multiple investment-oriented outcome pathways and entry points for influencing public and private sector actors in a wide range of countries.
gender_justification: gender-sensitive investment is a key dimension
capdev_justification: capdev in investment planning a key focus
climate_justification: Support to a 10-year program to strengthen the West Africa food system resilience to shocks led by ECOWAS, CILSS, CORAF. CCAFS actively contributed to the design and development of the FSRP proposal document and to the production of a blueprint document for a sound implementation planning.

outcome_sumary: The impacts of climate change in LAC were assessed with the Inter-American Development Bank and CCAFS, informing recommendations for adaptation. LAC was also the focus of a World Bank report which used PIM modeling results to identify 20 actions to achieve desired agriculture and food system outcomes. Estimates of the costs of adaptation options in the agricultural sector at regional and global scales were updated, informing decision making of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation as part of the Global Commission on Adaptation.
milestone_evidence: Contribution of foresight modeling to decision making for climate-smart investment planning of the World Bank and national stakeholders in Burkina Faso, Ghana, Ivory Coast and Mali.Contribution to the World Bank's strategy to unlock transformation and innovation in agrifood systems in LAC.Contribution to the Inter-American Development Bank's decision-making processes through providing estimates of the potential impact of climate change on agricultural productivity and trade of key crops in LAC.Estimation of the costs of key agricultural investment options to support climate change adaptation at regional and global scales informed decision making of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation as part of the Global Commission on Adaptation.Contribution to CGIAR Initiative on Crops to End Hunger (USAID and other donors).
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: Work to expand uptake, understanding and use of the results of foresight modeling, including through continued conversations with Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation's senior leadership and ongoing dialog with USAID, FAO and other partners. Trainings on the IMPACT model conducted for USDA and Oxford University.
climate_justification: The bulk of the work addresses questions that have climate change either as the main topic or as one of the scenarios under investigation.

outcome_sumary: Research on efficient seed systems in Uganda, with application of information and communication technologies and intensive training program for farmers on uptake of improved maize seeds.Ex ante economic assessment of TELA, a drought tolerant and insect resistant maize in Ethiopia.Expansion of Direct Seed Marketing in Ethiopia in collaboration with Ethiopia's Agricultural Transformation Agency and the Integrated Seed Sector Development Programme.Registration of farmers seed varieties in Nepal.
milestone_evidence: Adoption of Direct Seed Marketing in Ethiopia.Registration of farmers seed varieties in Nepal.Seed regulations and certification system strengthened in Afghanistan.Improved seed systems policy in Uganda.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: Training of farmers on registration of their varieties and seed business planning in Nepal, training of farmers on Quality Declared Seeds in Uganda, support to government for developing legal and technical documents for seed certification system in Afghanistan.
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary: Lao PDR, Myanmar, Papua New Guinea, The Philippines and Vietnam (among other countries) have used evidence from the Agricultural Science and Technology Indicators Initiative (ASTI) to support budgetary discussions.
milestone_evidence: As described in a 2018 independent evaluation of the outcomes of the Agricultural Science and Technology Indicators (ASTI) initiative, ASTI outputs were used in various strategic decisions of governments in Algeria, Ethiopia, Kenya, Lesotho, Mauritania, Nepal, Nigeria and Pakistan. In Myanmar, ASTI information is being used as input into the 5-year Research Master Plan Road Map of the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock to advocate for higher investment in R&D, increased focus on postgraduate training for scientists and increased scientist salaries.
gender_justification: ASTI publishes detailed R&D capacity indicators broken down by gender and degree
youth_justification: ASTI publishes detailed R&D capacity indicators broken down by age bracket and degree
capdev_justification: ASTI's work focuses on capacity building, both by informing policy and investment decisions related to agricultural research and by increasing countries' ownership of their national data.
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary: PIM research provided insights into systems to facilitate adoption of hybrid rice in India and stress-tolerant maize in Kenya, production and supply of cassava planting materials in Nigeria, regulatory frameworks to advance access to vegetatively propagated crops in Vietnam, and extension innovations to spur adoption in India, Kenya, Malawi, Peru, Tanzania and Uganda. The CGIAR Community of Excellence on Seed Systems Development was launched in 2020.
milestone_evidence: The collaboration between IFPRI and Digital Green on a video-mediated approach to extension strongly influenced the Government of Ethiopia's investment to create a digital platform for agricultural advisory services.Research from a PIM team working as part of the Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia informed the modification and improvement of India’s Soil Card Scheme.PIM research informed Malawi's National Agricultural Extension and Advisory Services Strategy and more specifically contributed to the emphasis on M&E of extension services - including indicators on technology adoption - in this document.
gender_justification: The work on Malawi's extension strategy included a focus on differentiated empowerment and technology adoption of women and men: https://ebrary.ifpri.org/digital/collection/p15738coll2/id/133688 Work on tilapia seed systems in Ghana focused on opportunities for women (https://aquaculturemag.com/2020/09/12/aquaculture-experts-train-ghanaian-small-fish-farm-operators/) Work on ways to elicit information on adaptation of women's farming practices to climate change in Uganda (https://www.rural21.com/english/scientific-world/detail/article/cellphilms-and-photovoice-how-visual-tools-can-help-understand-farmers-adaptation-to-climate-change?no_cache=1)
youth_justification: Work on tilapia seed systems in Ghana focused on opportunities for women and youth (https://aquaculturemag.com/2020/09/12/aquaculture-experts-train-ghanaian-small-fish-farm-operators/)
capdev_justification: Production of training manuals on hatchery and aquaculture management systems in Ghana (https://ebrary.ifpri.org/digital/collection/p15738coll5/id/7169; https://ebrary.ifpri.org/digital/collection/p15738coll5/id/7167; https://ebrary.ifpri.org/digital/collection/p15738coll5/id/7164) Study of the impact of different training interventions on adoption of recommended practices for coffee in Uganda (https://afca.coffee/wp-content/uploads/presentations/18AFCCE/Presentation IFPRI- Session 6 Vivian.pdf?boxtype=pdf&g=false&s=false&s2=false&r=wide) Book on agricultural extension (https://pim.cgiar.org/2020/09/02/agricultural-extension-global-status-and-performance-in-selected-countries/) Interactive practitioners' guidebook (URL: http://cd4ais.ifpri.info/)
climate_justification: Work on climate change adaptation in Kenya (https://doi.org/10.1093/ej/ueaa063) and on ways to elicit information on adaptation of women's farming practices to climate change in Uganda (https://www.rural21.com/english/scientific-world/detail/article/cellphilms-and-photovoice-how-visual-tools-can-help-understand-farmers-adaptation-to-climate-change?no_cache=1)

outcome_sumary: The year 2020 can be characterized by considerable changes in scope in the milestones in Module 5 due to the addition of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) as a Module 5 deliverable and a strengthened mandate to standardize analytics across Centers. Therefore, while in many cases we can consider milestones as complete if we only consider legacy systems as our targets, we have extended the milestones so that the progress could also be measured against EBS so as to be more relevant to the revised Module 5 outcomes for 2022.
milestone_evidence:
The individual components that will eventually enable
the generation of Genomic Estimated Breeding Values (GEBVs) were the focus of use cases. This included create experiments (trials and nurseries) and add
entries, load trait data to an experiment, extract genotyping data, track
samples. These were delivered in Breeding API (BrAPI) 2.0. In 2020 M5 assumed leadership of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) Project. We will apply the use cases in EBS feature development to support a full end to end breeding workflow in 2021.
gender_justification: agnostic technology
capdev_justification: EBS support of breeding use case will improve capacity
climate_justification: agnostic technology

outcome_sumary: The year 2020 can be characterized by considerable changes in scope in the milestones in Module 5 due to the addition of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) as a Module 5 deliverable and a strengthened mandate to standardize analytics across Centers. Therefore, while in many cases we can consider milestones as complete if we only consider legacy systems as our targets, we have extended the milestones so that the progress could also be measured against EBS so as to be more relevant to the revised Module 5 outcomes for 2022.
milestone_evidence:
Breeding API (BrAPI) 2.0 has been
published including definitions that enable trait data to be extracted and
genotyping to be extracted eg definitions of programs, Trials, Studies,
Locations, Traits, Scales, Methods, and Images, Germplasm, Germplasm
Attributes, Seed Lots, Crosses, Pedigree, and Progeny Samples, Markers, Variant
Sets, Variants, Call Sets, and Vendor Orders. Year 3-4 studies will therefore
focus on combining phenotype and genotype data in readiness for genomic
selection. BrAPI 2.0 has been adopted by breeding management system (BMS), genomics open-source breeding informatics initiative (GOBii), Breedbase, Gigwa and key
molecular breeding tools such as Flapjack. In 2020 Module 5 assumed leadership of the enterprise breeding system (EBS) Project. IN addition to these tools, we need to identify a strategy for applying BrAPI to the development of EBS. Due to technical debt in the development of EBS without reference to BrAPI, use cases must be carefully selected for value delivered within the project timeframe.
gender_justification: agnostic technology
capdev_justification: BrAPI enables interoperability between databases that adhere to it
climate_justification: agnostic technology

outcome_sumary: The year 2020 can be characterized by considerable changes in scope in the milestones in Module 5 due to the addition of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) as a Module 5 deliverable and a strengthened mandate to standardize analytics across Centers. Therefore, while in many cases we can consider milestones as complete if we only consider legacy systems as our targets, we have extended the milestones so that the progress could also be measured against EBS so as to be more relevant to the revised Module 5 outcomes for 2022.
milestone_evidence:
(i) Breeding management system (BMS) is currently maintained through a sub-grant up until August 2022 with an
increasing focus in 2021 and 2022 on functionality that can be utilized to
migrate data to enterprise breeding system (EBS) and integrate APIs with genomic open-source breeding informatics initiative (GOBii) and the Analytics pipeline. (ii) BMS has been
deployed to key new national agricultural research systems (NARS) centers (Ugandan National Agricultural Research
Organization (NARO) and Kenya Agricultural and Livestock Research Organization (KALRO) maize, wheat and rice in 2020)
and the adoption is being managed and monitored by EiB. Additional NARS centers
have been prioritized in 2021 to build on maize, wheat and rice networks. (iii)
Development time on GOBii has been reduced from 50% in 2020 to 10% in 2021 to
place GOBii-standalone in maintenance mode. In 2020 M5 assumed leadership of the EBS Project. A detailed strategy for BMS-EBS collaboration beyond 2022 is yet to be worked out. Towards the end of 2021 we will review the post 2022 strategy for BMS development, with the expectation that the system will move to maintenance mode with the BMS development team contributing more towards data migration and EBS service module (genotyping, sampling, analysis) functionality
gender_justification: agnostic technology
capdev_justification: use of data management systems enables increased capacity
climate_justification: agnostic technology

outcome_sumary: The year 2020 can be characterized by considerable changes in scope in the milestones in Module 5 due to the addition of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) as a Module 5 deliverable and a strengthened mandate to standardize analytics across Centers. Therefore, while in many cases we can consider milestones as complete if we only consider legacy systems as our targets, we have extended the milestones so that the progress could also be measured against EBS so as to be more relevant to the revised Module 5 outcomes for 2022.
milestone_evidence:
Breeding management system (BMS) and
Breedbase functionalities and gaps were reviewed through CGIAR module 5
assessments and gaps prioritized for BMS and Breedbase development. Several key
priorities; Integrated mixed-model and genomic selection pipelines,
heritability tool and near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) tool in Breedbase and seed inventory management in
BMS have since been delivered. Breeding for results (B4R) gaps were evaluated, prioritized for
development and were delivered in v2.0 (ii) To deliver genomic selection case
studies, BrAPI calls were prioritized and these will be tested in 2021 with
BMS/EBS and genomic open-source breeding informatics initiative (GOBii) integrations (iii) no new databases and tools have been acquired
for production use – existing open-source tools will be used where possible,
although tools such as Spotfire and Tableau are being evaluated for decision
support. In 2020 module 5 assumed leadership of the enterprise breeding system (EBS) Project. Functionalities from the gap analysis are implemented in EBS V3 and V4.
gender_justification: agnostic technology
capdev_justification: Use of software and databases increase capacity
climate_justification: agnostic technology

outcome_sumary: The year 2020 can be characterized by considerable changes in scope in the milestones in Module 5 due to the addition of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) as a Module 5 deliverable and a strengthened mandate to standardize analytics across Centers. milestone_evidence:
Advancement
tools have been developed in Flapjack that enable batch analysis and threshold
settings to make selections for a series of traits at a time. This will be
incorporated into the enterprise breeding system (EBS) decision support pipeline in combination with other
selection criteria. Breeding teams have been trained in use of the decision
support tools in Flapjack. In 2020 Module 5 assumed leadership of the EBS Project. The development of a more generalized advancement decision support tool has been
delayed due to delayed deliverables in general for EBS, and is currently expected to be available in 2022.
gender_justification: agnostic technology
capdev_justification: Decision support tools increase capacity
climate_justification: agnostic technology

milestone_evidence:
(i) Meta-data standards will follow crop ontology guidelines wherever
possible. Breeding management system (BMS) has standardized all crops to crop-ontology standards and these will
be maintained in enterprise breeding system (EBS). (ii) This work is being led by Big Data Platform. We are aligned with their efforts.

milestone_evidence:
(i) All standard operating procedures (SOPs) have been updated to the Toolbox. (ii) and (v) The communities of practice (CoPs) have been disbanded
and re-formed as the Breeding
Informatics Network in 2021 to meet new mandate to coordinate and standardize analytics across Centers. (iv) Breeding API (BrAPI) updates are being made continuously – focus is on
authentication, haplotype identification, use case development. (iii) and (vi) and (viii) In 2020 M5 assumed leadership of the enterprise breeding system (EBS) Project. Software related goals moved to EBS Analytics Framework development. (vii) Training workshops not conducted due to Covid.

outcome_sumary: The Platform awarded 7 start-up grants under its digital innovation process, the Inspire Challenge, growing the total portfolio to 21 active projects linked to enhancing agricultural livelihoods, understanding nutrition trends and food system flows, pest and disease surveillance and response, improving natural resource management, localized advisory services, and digital financial services.  The Platform also awarded three “rapid response grants” to previous awardees seeking to leverage their on-the-ground projects for COVID-19 response, recovery, and resilience.
milestone_evidence: Projects from the 2019 award cycle, and scale-up awards from the 2018 cycle, were implemented in 2020. Some of these experienced implementation delays as a result of reduced access to the field during COVID-19 related quarantine, and request no-cost extensions into 2021. Public reporting for all Inspire Challenge projects continues to grow as these projects evolve.
gender_justification: The Inspire Challenge process requires gender representation in teams and a clear theory of change for how interventions will affect social inclusion and empowerment.
youth_justification: Youth inclusion and empowerment was not specifically targeted, though the user base of digital innovations has tended to skew young.
capdev_justification: Inspire Challenge projects are intended to increase CGIAR and partners' capacity to leverage big data tools in support of their work.
climate_justification: A significant number of awarded projects include a climate or weather analysis element in their proposed solutions.

outcome_sumary: The Platform awarded 7 start-up grants under its digital innovation process, the Inspire Challenge, growing the total portfolio to 21 active projects linked to enhancing agricultural livelihoods, understanding nutrition trends and food system flows, pest and disease surveillance and response, improving natural resource management, localized advisory services, and digital financial services.  The Platform also awarded three “rapid response grants” to previous awardees seeking to leverage their on-the-ground projects for COVID-19 response, recovery, and resilience.
milestone_evidence: The review of 2019 Inspire Challenge data and lessons learned was rolled into a cumulative evaluation product in 2020, under milestone 3.1.10. 2020.
gender_justification: The process collected data on how a gender dimension was included (or not) in the projects, specific theories of change were only required in a later cycle, and evaluation of these will only be possible at a later date.
youth_justification: Youth inclusion was not specifically targeted through this milestone.
capdev_justification: Inspire partnerships build organizational capacity on partnering and scaling digital innovation. This particular milestone feeds back into guidance for managing digital innovation.
climate_justification: Climate change was not specifically targeted in this synthesis product.

outcome_sumary: The Platform awarded 7 start-up grants under its digital innovation process, the Inspire Challenge, growing the total portfolio to 21 active projects linked to enhancing agricultural livelihoods, understanding nutrition trends and food system flows, pest and disease surveillance and response, improving natural resource management, localized advisory services, and digital financial services.  The Platform also awarded three “rapid response grants” to previous awardees seeking to leverage their on-the-ground projects for COVID-19 response, recovery, and resilience.

youth_justification: The user base reported by several of the projects (particular food system and farm-facing services) skew young.
capdev_justification: The Inspire Challenge is designed to help build CGIAR and partners' capacity to leverage big data tools to solve agricultural problems.
climate_justification: Several of the projects include a weather or climate analysis dimension.

milestone_evidence: 7 new startup projects were awarded in 2020, leveraging a combination of W1/W2 and new bilateral funding.
gender_justification: Applicants were required to have gender representation on their teams and to make their theories of change explicit regarding how their intervention would affect gender inclusion and empowerment.
youth_justification: Applicants were required to make their theories of change explicit about how their digital innovation would affect social inclusion and empowerment.

climate_justification: Climate change and related challenges are integral to challenge areas through various lenses, sustainable practice, pest and disease, financial services for navigating weather shocks.

outcome_sumary: The Platform awarded 7 start-up grants under its digital innovation process, the Inspire Challenge, growing the total portfolio to 21 active projects linked to enhancing agricultural livelihoods, understanding nutrition trends and food system flows, pest and disease surveillance and response, improving natural resource management, localized advisory services, and digital financial services.  The Platform also awarded three “rapid response grants” to previous awardees seeking to leverage their on-the-ground projects for COVID-19 response, recovery, and resilience.
milestone_evidence: An external evaluation looking at the entire history of the Inspire Challenge was completed, specifically looking at how successful the Challenge was in advancing digital innovation in agriculture, fostering use of CGIAR and other data, development and evaluation of emergent research methods (e.g. Machine Learning) and digital pathways to impact, and in serving as a partnership mechanism that can build the overall innovation ecosystem for digital agriculture.
gender_justification: The process collected data on how a gender dimension was included (or not) in the projects, specific theories of change were only required in a later cycle, and evaluation of these will only be possible at a later date.

outcome_sumary: Big Data held its annual Convention entirely online, attracting 8,000 registrants and generating massive digital media reach.   Communities of Practice (CoPs) grew to over 5,000 public, private, and non-profit members. 72 external partnerships helped drive digital innovation in research; unlock data sharing across research organizations and public, private, and non-profit partners; and deliver new impact pathways for CGIAR. Partnerships where 30% private sector, 26% universities; national and international research organizations, 14%; and a combination of government, non-profits, development banks, and other international organizations. A majority of CGIAR Centers participated in one or more of these alliances.
milestone_evidence: The CoPs continued to grow and produce rich technical engagement in each of their thematic areas.    The CoPs were also a key source of technical depth for the annual Big Data in Agriculture convention.
gender_justification: The CoPs focus on individual and institutional capacities and research innovations.  Inclusion and ethics regarding human subjects and human-centered design are part of the efforts of all CoPs.
youth_justification: The CoPs focus on individual and institutional capacities and research innovations.  Inclusion and ethics regarding human subjects and human-centered design are part of the efforts of all CoPs.
capdev_justification: The CoPs focus on individual and institutional capacities and research innovations.
climate_justification: The CoPs focus on individual and institutional capacities and research innovations cutting across all research areas including climate.

outcome_sumary: Big Data held its annual Convention entirely online, attracting 8,000 registrants and generating massive digital media reach.   Communities of Practice (CoPs) grew to over 5,000 public, private, and non-profit members. 72 external partnerships helped drive digital innovation in research; unlock data sharing across research organizations and public, private, and non-profit partners; and deliver new impact pathways for CGIAR. Partnerships where 30% private sector, 26% universities; national and international research organizations, 14%; and a combination of government, non-profits, development banks, and other international organizations. A majority of CGIAR Centers participated in one or more of these alliances.
milestone_evidence: The CGIAR Convention on Big Data in Agriculture was produced entirely virtually in October 2020.
gender_justification: The Convention serves as a mechanism to identify, validate, and/or disseminate big data research methods to enhance research into women's economic and social empowerment.
youth_justification: The Convention serves as a mechanism to support young agripreneurs to promote their businesses and connect with each other and potential partners, especially through its 'Youth in Data Connect' track.
capdev_justification: The Convention features workshops curated and delivered by the Platform Communities of Practice, specifically on establishing and promoting best practices at the intersection of big data and agriculture.
climate_justification: Big data enabled tools, practices, and analytic pipelines are an explicit focus of the Convention, aiding discovery and promotion of best practices.

outcome_sumary: Big Data held its annual Convention entirely online, attracting 8,000 registrants and generating massive digital media reach.   Communities of Practice (CoPs) grew to over 5,000 public, private, and non-profit members. 72 external partnerships helped drive digital innovation in research; unlock data sharing across research organizations and public, private, and non-profit partners; and deliver new impact pathways for CGIAR. Partnerships where 30% private sector, 26% universities; national and international research organizations, 14%; and a combination of government, non-profits, development banks, and other international organizations. A majority of CGIAR Centers participated in one or more of these alliances.
milestone_evidence: A partnerships and IP lawyer advised the Platform on how to structure such an alliance and to develop the formal agreements to constitute it, but this was not yet formalized at the end of 2020. Multi-party alliances require significant negotiation and alignment of public, private, and non-profit interests.    The Alliance is expected to launch in 2021.
gender_justification: The  alliance would include significant commitment to social inclusion when it is operational.
youth_justification: The  alliance would include significant commitment to social inclusion when it is operational.
capdev_justification: The alliance would help partners accelerate their own capacity development when it is established.
climate_justification: The partners' ability to generate and leverage agroclimatic analytics would be enhanced when the alliance is launched.

outcome_sumary: Communities of Practice(CoPs) grew to over 5,000 public, private, and non-profit members, and became an important mechanism for CGIAR to remain abreast of digital innovations in their technical research domains.    The Platform piloted a "Data Science Academy" with the online learning platform Coursera for a cohort of 20 CGIAR scientists who studied emergent analytic methods (e.g. machine learning) and common software tools for conducting them (R and Python).
milestone_evidence: The communities of practice produced serveral data products that advance digital innovation in agricultural research for development.
gender_justification: The Communities of Practice and M1 focused on data standards for CGIAR research data, to ensure gender disaggregation that will unlock more gender research.
youth_justification: No youth products were developed in 2020
capdev_justification: New methods for collecting and organization socioeconomic data, planning for scale, and conducting geospatial analysis, and implementing interoperable data were the focus of active virtual seminars.
climate_justification: The Spatial Production Allocation Model is a key dataset enabling climate adaptation research.

outcome_sumary: Communities of Practice(CoPs) grew to over 5,000 public, private, and non-profit members, and became an important mechanism for CGIAR to remain abreast of digital innovations in their technical research domains. The Platform piloted a "Data Science Academy" with the online learning platform Coursera for a cohort of 20 CGIAR scientists who studied emergent analytic methods (e.g. machine learning) and common software tools for conducting them (R and Python).
milestone_evidence: This effort builds on the digital strategy research conducted by the Platform as well as overall architecture design work. The Design Working Group for Digital Services has requested that the Platform lead a task team on research infrastructure design that will draw from this work and inform and validate a way forward for OneCGIAR.
gender_justification: Computing and storage infrastructure cuts across all CGIAR research areas.
youth_justification: Computing and storage infrastructure cuts across all CGIAR research areas.
capdev_justification: Understanding best practices implementing them in scientific computing is central to this activity.
climate_justification: Computing and storage infrastructure cuts across all CGIAR research areas.
