The Platform piloted a "Data Science Academy" with the online learning platform Coursera for a cohort of 20 CGIAR scientists who studied emergent analytic methods (e.g. machine learning) and common software tools for conducting them (R and Python).
milestone_evidence: This effort builds on the digital strategy research conducted by the Platform as well as overall architecture design work. The Design Working Group for Digital Services has requested that the Platform lead a task team on research infrastructure design that will draw from this work and inform and validate a way forward for OneCGIAR.
gender_justification: This efforts cuts across all CGIAR research areas.
youth_justification: This efforts cuts across all CGIAR research areas.
capdev_justification: Implementing best practices in information architecture is central to this activity.
climate_justification: This efforts cuts across all CGIAR research areas.

outcome_sumary: Communities of Practice(CoPs) grew to over 5,000 public, private, and non-profit members, and became an important mechanism for CGIAR to remain abreast of digital innovations in their technical research domains. The Platform piloted a "Data Science Academy" with the online learning platform Coursera for a cohort of 20 CGIAR scientists who studied emergent analytic methods (e.g. machine learning) and common software tools for conducting them (R and Python).
milestone_evidence: In 2020 the Platform evaluated an array of shared data services it had on offer for geospatial data, weather data, population weather data and more, and the team decided that the running costs and value of these external services did not generally justify the subscription costs.  As a result, the Platform centralized its shared services offerings into CGLabs, an analytic environment in which anyone with a CGIAR.ORG or IRRI.ORG email address can create an account and assemble data from GARDIAN or other sources, run commonly used analytic software, and share scripts.  CGLabs is powered by Globus, a software service enabling data permissions and transfer of very large datasets that is used actively by the scientific computing community.
gender_justification: This milestone focused on building analytic capacity across all domains.
youth_justification: This milestone focused on building analytic capacity across all domains.
capdev_justification: The shared analytic environment CGSpace gives researchers access to data discovery tools and an analytic workbench.
climate_justification: This milestone focused on building analytic capacity across all domains.

outcome_sumary: Communities of Practice(CoPs) grew to over 5,000 public, private, and non-profit members, and became an important mechanism for CGIAR to remain abreast of digital innovations in their technical research domains. The Platform piloted a "Data Science Academy" with the online learning platform Coursera for a cohort of 20 CGIAR scientists who studied emergent analytic methods (e.g. machine learning) and common software tools for conducting them (R and Python).
milestone_evidence: 43 Convention sessions and webinars from CoPs, a data science bootcamp for CGIAR scientists, and an online course on FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) data is still available. Geospatial CoP led a pilot of a 'Data Science Bootcamp" on the online learning platform Coursera. The most popular courses from the 25 participants are from the curated Data Science topics, like “Deep Learning with TensorFlow,” “AI in Production,” and “Statistics for Machine Learning.”
gender_justification: Data science skills cut across all research domains.
youth_justification: Data science skills cut across all research domains.
capdev_justification: Next generation analytic skills development is the focus of this activity.
climate_justification: Data science skills cut across all research domains.

outcome_sumary: Communities of Practice(CoPs) grew to over 5,000 public, private, and non-profit members, and became an important mechanism for CGIAR to remain abreast of digital innovations in their technical research domains. The Platform piloted a "Data Science Academy" with the online learning platform Coursera for a cohort of 20 CGIAR scientists who studied emergent analytic methods (e.g. machine learning) and common software tools for conducting them (R and Python).
milestone_evidence: Big Data conducted wide-ranging consultations and internal assessments. Specifically, in collaboration with Accenture Development Partnerships, conducted over 160 surveys, 80 semi-structured interviews, 10 internal workshops on digital trends and capabilities, and an extensive literature review.The 160 surveys, conducted over the second half of 2020, included a wide range of people across CGIAR and the wider agricultural research for development ecosystem. Specifically, over 60 CGIAR researchers and otherwise, from the 15 Centers across the globe were included. The rest of the survey sample included external stakeholders in the sectors of non-CGIAR research, development funding and finance, private sector (not-consulting), private sector (consulting), and small-scale and start-up organizations in the AgriTech industry.This research was guided by three overarching questions:What digital trends will transform agriculture in the next 10 years?What should an organization be able to do to navigate these trends?What roles should public interest actors like play in the digital agriculture sector?
gender_justification: Social inclusion cuts through most of the strategic research and recommendations.
youth_justification: Social inclusion cuts through most of the strategic research and recommendations.
capdev_justification: Assessing and building digital capabilities is a primary focus of the strategic research.
climate_justification: Climate change cuts through most of the strategic research and recommendations.

outcome_sumary: 1) validation of aus donors for grain Zn content using biparental populations and mainstreaming of these to the breeding program; 2) identification of donors, Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) peaks and Quantitative Trait Loci (QTLS) for stagnant flooding and anaerobic germination from diverse aus germplasm, and publication of results from related work; 3) identification of lines for direct seeding breeding programs using best-of-the-best studies where diverse germplasm was chosen based on prior characterization for drought, and identification of GWAS peaks for drought recovery at seedling stage where underlying candidate genes show similarity to ones reported for drought recovery in maize.
milestone_evidence: Pandemic lockdown resulted in the loss of dry season trials that will be done during 2021. Publications on grain zinc studies form GWAS on diverse aus rice populations and validation in biparental publications are nearing completion and will be submitted in 2021. A number of papers on drought and anaerobic germination were published in 2020. Analyses and manuscripts on drought and root related studies are nearing completion, and new donors for direct seeding have been identified.
gender_justification: While CoA 5.1 does not specifically involve gender research, a woman scientist leads the studies on drought.
youth_justification: Research impacting youth is not targeted.
capdev_justification: There are no capacity development activities in the CoA.
climate_justification: Research and outputs from these activities have downstream implications for breeding for climate change relevant traits.

outcome_sumary: Seventeen new genes for major diseases and pests in the IRRI 154 background were released and made available to the breeders. These have never been available in elite backgrounds before, and marks a step-change in breeding for these traits. Over 200 trait markers implemented on the RiCA v4 panel at Agriplex. These are now being rolled out to other service providers. Setbacks: loss of materials during the covid-19 lockdown has severely impacted ongoing deployment efforts.
milestone_evidence: Summaries of deployed genes are available online. The trait markers on the RiCA v4 panel are still being analyzed for performance but will be made available on IRRIs genotyping service laboratory (GSL) website.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary: Several varieties have been nominated for adaptive trials in the Philippines. Two varieties have been released in favorable lowlands in Bangladesh and three varieties have been released in Mozambique with significant yield advantage over checks. The varietal development process has been accelerated by adoption of OneRice breeding strategy of IRRI involving population improvement using elite lines, hence the nominated/released varieties are expected to perform better year-on-year.
milestone_evidence: Two lines are released in Bangladesh, three in Mozambique, and 12 promising irrigated lowland lines nominated to multi-location adaptive trials/national trials in the Philippines. In India, 34 advanced lines and 49 donors were used as one of the parental lines in national breeding programs for the favorable ecologies. The milestone is extended to allow more time for testing and release by national systems of the nominated lines.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: Trials are conducted with NARES partners in Asia and Africa.
climate_justification: Varietal development process is accelerated to match varieital adoption to climate.

outcome_sumary: Six varieties were released in the rainfed ecosystems in the Philippines. Similarly, two more varieties have been nominated in Nepal for flood prone ecosystems in Nepal. Other countries such as India, Bangladesh, Tanzania, Mozambique, etc. currently engage in screening breeding lines shared from IRRI headquarters and will advance them into the release pipelines this year. More lines are being tested in the network in 2021 to catch up with the time lost in 2020. The Direct Seeded Rice (DSR) breeding network is a particular addition to the effort.
milestone_evidence: There has been a delay in some activities due to termination of trials at headquarters at IRRI  and in the regions because of the covid-19 lockdown in 2020. All possible efforts are being made to catch up to the lost time in the current dry season and in the upcoming wet-season.
gender_justification: Direct-seeded rice is targeted towards reducing drudgery in rice production.
youth_justification: Direct-seeded rice  and climate responsive varieties reduce risk and improve income which may help in attracting youth to rice farming.
capdev_justification: The Direct-seeded rice  and rainfed programs are engagedin significant capacity building activities through various trainings and National Agricultural Research and Extension Systems (NARES) partners network.
climate_justification: The developed varieties are especially resilient to stresses induced or exacerbated by climate change, such as the heat, cold, drought, salinity

outcome_sumary: We have conducted a genome-wide association study using a combined population panel of indica and japonica rice varieties, and identified the underlying genetic networks that reduce (Progastricsin) PGC to 2 %. Several breeding lines possessing low chalk genetic regions (0-5%) were identified to support future breeding programs to improve the grain quality of elite genetic material with high yielding potentials. Three lines to possess head rice yield of 55 % were identified, while many of the lines shown to possess median of head rice yield 45 %.
milestone_evidence: Several breeding lines possessing low chalk genetic regions (0-5%) identified. After thorough screening of breeding material, 3 lines were that possess head rice yield of 55 % were identified, while many of the lines were shown to possess median of head rice yield 45 %.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: NA
climate_justification: The developed varieties are especially resilient to stresses induced or exacerbated by climate change, such as the effect of heat on chalkiness)

outcome_sumary: IRRI’s global market segmentation work is completed. The breeding programs are currently being aligned to the markets segments which will work with the selected NARES partners in respective market segments based on maturity and other considerations. OneRice breeding strategy and framework has been completed and launched at IRRI in early 2020. This standard framework provides the breeding programs an end to end and a rapid varietal developments and dissemination, based on proven best practices in breeding. Irrigated core panel has been established and rainfed and Direct Seeded Rice (DSR) core panels are also in advance stages of development.
milestone_evidence: This milestone has been updated during the 2019 FP5 meeting as follows: "Develop market segment; establish maturity groups (identify standard checks for different environments); develop product profiles; breeding pipelines defined and characterized; separation of pre-breeding from core breeding operations; improve rate of genetic gain through optimization of one component of the breeders' equation; data management; breeders' reference panel established".
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: OneRice breeding strategy will be jointly implemented by IRRI-NARES partners.
climate_justification: Market segmentation and varietal development will effectively address immediate and future climate needs.

outcome_sumary: This outcome relies on projects on managing African rice intensification to minimize malaria and climate change impacts and animal disease interventions in Uganda. The rice work is halfway through a 2-year program of field research. We have estimated the (impressively large) numbers of mosquitoes produced in a rice-growing season by a hectare of rice. We have demonstrated the feasibility of using modified alternate wet-dry (AWD) methods to suppress production of both methane and mosquitoes. Doing this in practice in other settings will require detailed study and locally-adapted methods. In the next stage fieldwork will be extended to East Africa.
milestone_evidence: The Rift Valley fever (RVF) risk maps were presented to stakeholders in an online stakeholder workshop held in October. How they will be used can yet be determined, so we report this milestone as changed (or completed, but not exactly as expected).
gender_justification: There is no evidence of gendered risks for infection.
youth_justification: There is no evidence of age-related risks for infection.
capdev_justification: Building awareness of the evidence and capacity to use them in planning and response has been a central focus of this flagship and has a significant role in the achievement of this milestone.
climate_justification: Climate change is one of the drivers of Rift Valley fever.

outcome_sumary: This outcome relies on projects on managing African rice intensification to minimize malaria and climate change impacts and animal disease interventions in Uganda. The rice work is halfway through a 2-year program of field research. We have estimated the (impressively large) numbers of mosquitoes produced in a rice-growing season by a hectare of rice. We have demonstrated the feasibility of using modified alternate wet-dry (AWD) methods to suppress production of both methane and mosquitoes. Doing this in practice in other settings will require detailed study and locally-adapted methods. In the next stage fieldwork will be extended to East Africa.
milestone_evidence: One review for urban Vietnam was published online last year (link provided). A paper on the rural context is in progress. This was originally a series of case studies (already completed), but its scope has been expanded to include some key lessons learned about (a) the biological mechanisms by which vectors are affected by agricultural activities, (b) how the agricultural activity can be modified to minimise the attendant risk, and (c) why we should not think of such problems as an exercise is balancing risks with benefits.
gender_justification: The research has been  focused on environmental and technical not social issues.
youth_justification: The research has been  focused on environmental and technical not social issues.
capdev_justification: Building awareness of monitoring change in vector indicators alongside design and testing of agricultural innovations has been a central focus of this flagship and has a significant role in the achievement of this milestone.
climate_justification: The review is expected to identify climate change as one of the main drivers of vector-borne disease transmission

outcome_sumary: This outcome relies on projects on managing African rice intensification to minimize malaria and climate change impacts and animal disease interventions in Uganda. The rice work is halfway through a 2-year program of field research. We have estimated the (impressively large) numbers of mosquitoes produced in a rice-growing season by a hectare of rice. We have demonstrated the feasibility of using modified alternate wet-dry (AWD) methods to suppress production of both methane and mosquitoes. Doing this in practice in other settings will require detailed study and locally-adapted methods. In the next stage fieldwork will be extended to East Africa.
milestone_evidence: One constraint to scaling-up the trials has been the unmet need for easier methods for vector indicators. This milestone is unlikely to be completed as planned, so we're cancelling it. There are no relevant links to evidence that we can provide.
gender_justification: The information gathered takes into account human behavior and risks. This work has reached a stopping point so it's not clear how the innovations would have been designed to be gender-sensitive.
youth_justification: The information gathered will affect population based on age. This work has reached a stopping point so it's not clear how the innovations would have been designed to reach different age groups.
capdev_justification: Building awareness of monitoring change in vector indicators alongside design and testing of agricultural innovations (and capacity to do so) has been a central focus of this flagship and has a significant role in the achievement of this milestone.
climate_justification: The distribution of arthropod vectors in influenced by climate change

outcome_sumary: This outcome relies on projects on managing African rice intensification to minimize malaria and climate change impacts and animal disease interventions in Uganda. The rice work is halfway through a 2-year program of field research. We have estimated the (impressively large) numbers of mosquitoes produced in a rice-growing season by a hectare of rice. We have demonstrated the feasibility of using modified alternate wet-dry (AWD) methods to suppress production of both methane and mosquitoes. Doing this in practice in other settings will require detailed study and locally-adapted methods. In the next stage fieldwork will be extended to East Africa.
milestone_evidence: A final version of the model was developed and will be described in a forthcoming special series in Frontiers in Veterinary Science. It is still too early to say how the model will be used by the Ministry of Agriculture, so we report this milestone as changed (or completed, but not exactly as expected). There are no relevant links to evidence that we can provide.
gender_justification: There is no evidence on gendered risks for infection.
youth_justification: There is no evidence of age-related risks for infection.
capdev_justification: Building awareness of the model and capacity to use it in intervention design and evaluation has been a central focus of this flagship and has a significant role in the achievement of this milestone.
climate_justification: Climate change is one of the drivers of Rift Valley fever.

outcome_sumary: This outcome relies on projects on managing African rice intensification to minimize malaria and climate change impacts and animal disease interventions in Uganda. The rice work is halfway through a 2-year program of field research. We have estimated the (impressively large) numbers of mosquitoes produced in a rice-growing season by a hectare of rice. We have demonstrated the feasibility of using modified alternate wet-dry (AWD) methods to suppress production of both methane and mosquitoes. Doing this in practice in other settings will require detailed study and locally-adapted methods. In the next stage fieldwork will be extended to East Africa.
milestone_evidence: IRRI joined Africa Rice in the Wellcome Trust-funded collaboration with the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) as part of A4NH. The collaboration is testing how a modification of alternate wetting and drying (AWD) can reduce the production of mosquitoes and greenhouse gas emissions. Relatedly, one of A4NH’s key research questions asks if an overall decrease in malaria, and more equitable access to interventions since the 1990s, might have changed the relationship between rice and malaria. Recently completed analysis confirms that additional malaria mosquitoes coming from the rice do cause an increase in the intensity of malaria transmission in irrigated rice communities. One funder was keen to understand this trend. They convened two groups of experts - agronomists with expertise in growing rice in Africa and entomologists with expertise in the ecology of mosquitoes in African rice fields – and gave A4NH researchers an opportunity to inform the direction of a major development investment strategy to mitigate any unintended negative consequences on human health. Results suggest that nowadays, villages with rice do tend to have more malaria. The discussion focused on how this could shape the funder's plans to support a major expansion of irrigated rice in Africa.
gender_justification: The work is motivated based on data indicating that pregnant women (and children <5yo) suffer >85% of the burden of malaria in Africa. The research has been  focused on environmental and technical not social issues.
youth_justification: The work is motivated based on data indicating that pregnant women (and children <5yo) suffer >85% of the burden of malaria in Africa. The research has been  focused on environmental and technical not social issues.
capdev_justification: Building awareness of monitoring change in vector indicators alongside design and testing of agricultural innovations has been a central focus of this flagship and has a significant role in the achievement of this milestone.
climate_justification: One of objectives of the work is to identify practices that reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in rice farming. GHG emission drive climate change

outcome_sumary: Good progress has been made in incorporating cysticercosis into Kenya's national One Health strategy. The country, with support from FAO and other partners, is also pushing for the implementation of the brucellosis strategy that was adopted earlier. FP5 scientists continue to support the generation of evidence, specifically risk maps and magnitude of burden.
milestone_evidence: Progress in developing this diagnostic test is ongoing. In 2020, legal agreements were signed with partners for test validation and the reagents were put in place at ILRI. However, no farmer interaction was possible in 2020 due to the pandemic, so work will resume in 2021.
gender_justification: Lab-based technical work. The technology being developed is assumed to be appropriate for men and women.
youth_justification: Lab-based technical work. Assumed to be useful for youth, but not specifically designed with those considerations.
capdev_justification: Stakeholder training and sensitization will precede the distribution and use of the cysticercosis test when it is ready.
climate_justification: This disease is not climate sensitive.

outcome_sumary: Good progress has been made in incorporating cysticercosis into Kenya's national One Health strategy. The country, with support from FAO and other partners, is also pushing for the implementation of the brucellosis strategy that was adopted earlier. FP5 scientists continue to support the generation of evidence, specifically risk maps and magnitude of burden.
milestone_evidence: Convening of the national Neglected Tropical Disease (NTD) task forces (which includes ILRI researchers from A4NH) completed in Rwanda and a technical report was shared with Government. Peer reviewed papers summarizing the evidence for scientific audiences are in progress. In Kenya, a presentation was made to the National NTD Conference.
gender_justification: Results identify risk factors related to gender, age, occupation and so forth. Gender and age are gaps that are likely to be built in later.
youth_justification: Results identify risk factors related to gender, age, occupation and so forth. Gender and age are gaps that are likely to be built in later.
capdev_justification: One Health stakeholders will be sensitized on cysticercosis occurrence patterns and will be able to access the data generated for other potential needs
climate_justification: This disease is not climate sensitive.

outcome_sumary: Good progress has been made in incorporating cysticercosis into Kenya's national One Health strategy. The country, with support from FAO and other partners, is also pushing for the implementation of the brucellosis strategy that was adopted earlier. FP5 scientists continue to support the generation of evidence, specifically risk maps and magnitude of burden.
milestone_evidence: To date, the serum bank is more than 75% complete with material from Kenya and Rwanda. Although incomplete, it is now open access. Some additional positive control sera from Kenya will be required. Part of the delay was because fieldwork was paused during the pandemic.
gender_justification: Lab-based technical work. Results from testing in humans, complemented by fieldwork, will look at factors that increase risk (gender, age, occupation, and so on).
youth_justification: Lab-based technical work. Results from testing in humans, complemented by fieldwork, will look at factors that increase risk (gender, age, occupation, and so on).
capdev_justification: There won't be any capacity development efforts linked to the serum bank.
climate_justification: This disease is not climate sensitive.

outcome_sumary: Good progress has been made in incorporating cysticercosis into Kenya's national One Health strategy. The country, with support from FAO and other partners, is also pushing for the implementation of the brucellosis strategy that was adopted earlier. FP5 scientists continue to support the generation of evidence, specifically risk maps and magnitude of burden.
milestone_evidence: In 2020, Kenya finalized its One Health Strategic Plan to guide one health prioritization in the country. Cysticercosis is now part of this due to evidence generated by A4NH researchers. The One Health Strategic Plan lists the priority diseases for surveillance by the National Zoonotic Disease Unit, and lists a clear set of steps to build a national evidence base for the impact of a pathogen in both the health and livestock sectors. Cysticercosis was not previously part of the priority list, but it is now (p.31 as part of the Strategic Framework). Evidence generated by A4NH researchers from the International Livestock Research Institute were presented to the strategic planning group and resulted in the disease being on the list and having a set of evidence-based surveillance and control steps associated with it. A4NH researchers from ILRI are cited as contributors (p. 39-40), included in the stakeholder analysis, and A4NH evidence (from Phase I) is cited. Progress has been slower in Rwanda, which is why we are reporting this as changed (completed, but not exactly as expected).
gender_justification: At this stage,  it is not yet clear how the action plan will address risk factors related to equity, including gender or age.
youth_justification: At this stage,  it is not yet clear how the action plan will address risk factors related to equity, including gender or age.
capdev_justification: Kenya and Rwanda's capacity to manage cysticercosis will be improved through the implementation of the action plan.
climate_justification: This disease is not climate sensitive.

outcome_sumary: Good progress has been made in incorporating cysticercosis into Kenya's national One Health strategy. The country, with support from FAO and other partners, is also pushing for the implementation of the brucellosis strategy that was adopted earlier. FP5 scientists continue to support the generation of evidence, specifically risk maps and magnitude of burden.
milestone_evidence: The Government of Kenya adopted a control strategy for brucellosis. The document describes Kenya’s strategic plan for the prevention and control of human and animal brucellosis. It reiterates brucellosis as among the top five priority zoonotic diseases in Kenya and the lack of accurate information on its geographical distribution, economic impact, burden estimates and costs of intervention. ILRI is acknowledged for participating in the development and validation of the strategy.
gender_justification: At this stage,  it is not yet clear how the surveillance will address risk factors related to equity, including gender or age.
youth_justification: At this stage,  it is not yet clear how the action plan will address risk factors related to equity, including gender or age.
capdev_justification: Brucellosis strategy is part of recommendations on how to improve countries' capacity to manage brucellosis.
climate_justification: This disease is not climate sensitive.

outcome_sumary: The pandemic disrupted several activities in 2020 that were expected to contribute to this outcome. The CGIAR Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) Hub was closed temporarily; all training activities were stalled. In Kenya, the Fleming Fund Agriculture Sector Surveillance protocol has yet to be adopted and implemented due to delays brought about by the pandemic. Progress is expected in 2021. Surveillance of AMR bacteria in poultry will cover healthcare settings and community and livestock farms to generate a more comprehensive understanding of AMR and inform policy and practice. Researchers were able to write-up results from initial work on insecticide resistance.
milestone_evidence: Draft of the risk map work was finalized and is now in the publication pipeline. There are no relevant links to evidence that we can provide at this time.
gender_justification: This is early-stage technical risk analysis without any social dimension, like gender.
youth_justification: This is early-stage technical risk analysis without any social dimension, like age.
capdev_justification: This is early-stage technical risk analysis that is yet to be completed. When complete, there are likely to be activities around building awareness among stakeholders on how the maps can be used in decisionmaking.
climate_justification: Climatic factors influence development and distribution of insecticide resistant mosquitoes

outcome_sumary: The pandemic disrupted several activities in 2020 that were expected to contribute to this outcome. The CGIAR Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) Hub was closed temporarily; all training activities were stalled. In Kenya, the Fleming Fund Agriculture Sector Surveillance protocol has yet to be adopted and implemented due to delays brought about by the pandemic. Progress is expected in 2021. Surveillance of AMR bacteria in poultry will cover healthcare settings and community and livestock farms to generate a more comprehensive understanding of AMR and inform policy and practice. Researchers were able to write-up results from initial work on insecticide resistance.
milestone_evidence: Fleming Fund Agriculture Sector Surveillance protocol is yet to be adopted and implemented due to delays brought about by the pandemic. Progress is expected in 2021. The surveillance of AMR bacteria in poultry will cover healthcare settings and community and livestock farms in order to generate a more comprehensive understanding of AMR to inform policy and practice at national and international levels. There are no relevant links to evidence that we can provide at this time.
gender_justification: At this stage,  it is not yet clear how the surveillance plan will monitor risk factors related to equity, including gender or age.
youth_justification: At this stage,  it is not yet clear how the surveillance plan will monitor risk factors related to equity, including gender or age.
capdev_justification: Decisionmakers in Kenya will get  accurate data on AMR  in areas covered by the project
climate_justification: This issue is not climate sensitive.

outcome_sumary: The pandemic disrupted several activities in 2020 that were expected to contribute to this outcome. The CGIAR Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) Hub was closed temporarily; all training activities were stalled. In Kenya, the Fleming Fund Agriculture Sector Surveillance protocol has yet to be adopted and implemented due to delays brought about by the pandemic. Progress is expected in 2021. Surveillance of AMR bacteria in poultry will cover healthcare settings and community and livestock farms to generate a more comprehensive understanding of AMR and inform policy and practice. Researchers were able to write-up results from initial work on insecticide resistance.
milestone_evidence: Due to COVID-19, the CGIAR AMR Hub lab was shut down and training activities cancelled. We had intended to have lab based workshops on bacterial isolation, identification and antimicrobial susceptibility testing. In 2020, we focused on establishing the lab (equipping it), securing the memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with partners. Lab activities re-started in October 2020, and training workshops for partners are expected to resume in 2021.
gender_justification: Lab-based technical work. Results from testing in humans, complemented by fieldwork, will look at factors that increase risk (gender, age, occupation, and so on).
youth_justification: Lab-based technical work. Results from testing in humans, complemented by fieldwork, will look at factors that increase risk (gender, age, occupation, and so on).
capdev_justification: The Hub lab meets a regionally identified capacity need for good facilities for AMR research.
climate_justification: This issue is not climate sensitive.

outcome_sumary: Progress was made in the establishment of One Health collaborations for COVID-19 impacts assessments (by IFPRI and the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine (LSHTM)). ILRI also entered into partnership with the Ministry of Health in Kenya to facilitate diagnosis of COVID-19 in humans. This collaboration is being extended to include genomic surveillance capitalizing on the sequencing platform that ILRI has developed. The collaboration between A4NH and LSHTM around the Agriculture, Nutrition, and Health (ANH Academy) week conference continues to gain strength and provide a valuable platform for linking the public health community to CGIAR.
milestone_evidence: The 2020 ANH Academy Week was held in virtual mode over six days, attracting 914 online participants different research sectors and disciplines from 72 countries, and including 63 participants from CGIAR centers. Gender and equality, was a strong theme, and a keynote on inequality, nutrition and health was given by Angus Deaton. Most sessions focused on food systems and nutrition, and intersectoral conference and training sessions of specific relevance to FP5 were held on animal source foods, food safety, animal welfare and COVID-19. Beyond the Academy, FP5 organized an intersectoral conferences on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in Southeast Asia (October 2019) and One Health session during the Bonn Digital Global Landscape Forum (June 2020). ILRI convened a One Health session with the United Nations Environment Programme during the Bonn Digital Global Landscapes Forum in June.
gender_justification: Several sessions in the research conference and Learning Labs had a particular focus on gender research results and/or building capacity to use tools and methods that measure empowerment.
youth_justification: Youth was not a special topic in the research conference or Learning Labs.
capdev_justification: The intent of the ANH Academy is to foster knowledge exchange, innovation and learning around interdisciplinary ANH research. A4NH researchers led several of the Learning Labs that were offered.
climate_justification: Several sessions in the research conference and Learning Labs had a particular focus on climate change research and/or building capacity to use tools and methods related to climate change.

outcome_sumary: Worldwide field trials were completed for Antenna (AP) and Reference (RP) panels. We received 55 AP datasets (25 locations), 21 RP datasets (11 locations), and location soil/climate data from the global network. Data has been curated; R-scripts shared with partners. Preliminary GWAS was completed, identifying consistent genomic regions for agronomic traits. These results allow understanding GxE, identifying stable germplasm, finding QTLs/genes for rice breeding. 28 AP and 7 RP entries were selected and are now in breeding pipelines of CGIAR centers and NARES partners in India, Vietnam, Burundi, Bangladesh, Senegal, Cote d'Ivoire, Colombia, Uruguay.
milestone_evidence: The FP4 CoA 1 outcome above to define GxE factors was not achievable in 2020. We hired a post-doctoral fellow at Cirad who is working on climate, soil and AP data to accomplish this during 2021. This information will be shared with the collaborators the Agricultural Model Inter-comparison Project (AgMIP) from Japan  for modeling scenarios. Some trials could not be completed in 2020 and are being done in 2021. All agronomic and yield data collected from the trials has been uploaded in the following website and folders. Field photos of some of the experiments conducted have also been uploaded. Preliminary results have been presented as a poster during the online 25th Federation of Crop Science Society of the Philippines Scientific Conference.
other_reason: Covid-19 pandemic
gender_justification: There are no gender specific activities, but several women are involved in leading NARES GRA activities.
youth_justification: No youth specific activities, but one PhD scholar is working on analyses. Resource and pandemic constraints have limited youth involvement.
capdev_justification: The pandemic has hampered this.
climate_justification: Results from the analysis of GRA panels has huge potential to address climate change issues by developing climate smart rice varieties.

outcome_sumary: 2019 high-throughput (HTP) data from IRRI and India was processed and compiled. 2020 HTP data at IRRI was limited to the antenna panel for the wet season due to the pandemic, while data was successfully acquired for both the antenna and the reference panels in India. We currently have three RICE partners and one NARES partner from India using unmanned aerial vehicles for HTP. Two NARES from India dropped their involvement on loss of personnel. An image analysis method to determine biomass and leaf nitrogen content was developed at CIAT. Meteorology and imaging stations were established at AfricaRice sites.
milestone_evidence: High-throughput (HTP) datasets from IRRI and India for 2018-2020 are stored locally at IRRI. It was not possible to collect HTP data for the reference panel (RP) at IRRI in 2020 due to the pandemic. Data is available for the wet seasons of 2018 and 2019 and for the dry season of 2019; an additional trial will be conducted in the dry season of 2021 in order to have four seasons of data from IRRI. Unmanned aerial vehicles were obtained by AfricaRice in 2020, trials are underway at Senegal and Cote d'Ivoire sites. During 2020, two image-analysis trials for HTP on the RP were conducted at CIAT. An IRRI instance of BreedBase (a BrAPI compliment database) accommodating HTP (image) data is now being implemented and will be extended at IRRI in collaboration with Lukas Mueller (Cornell). The API to our BreedBase will include additional analyses tools for machine learning and downstream analyses, e.g. for GWAS and genomic selection/prediction. The web API and database will be hosted at the Philippines Dept. of Science and Technology super-computing facility via an ongoing collaboration.
other_reason: Pandemic
gender_justification: This activity is gender neutral.
capdev_justification: CapDev (in person workshops) could not occur in 2020 due to the pandemic.
climate_justification: CoA 4.2 spillover to climate change with CoA 4.1.

outcome_sumary: We characterized several pathogen populations, identified effective resistance genes for South Asia, Southeast Asia, and Africa for the diseases Bacterial Leaf Blight (BLB), Blast, Rice Yellow Mottle Virus, and for Brown Spot in West Africa. In addition, we have developed molecular markers to monitor and track BLB, Blast, and Brown Spot populations in the field, allowing across countries. All information is updated in the PathoTracer tool. Further, the root microbiome of modern varieties was characterized in China. Collections are done by partner institutions; most setbacks stemmed from the pandemic. This has resulted in collection of fewer samples.
milestone_evidence: Based on 450 Xanthomonas oryzae genomes collected in Asia, we have developed 40 SNP markers to track Bacterial Leaf Blight populations. Based on 180 Magnaporthe oryzae genomes collected worldwide, we have developed 30 SNP markers to track leaf blast disease. A collection of around 50 Rice Yellow Mottle Virus samples from East Africa are stored at the IRRI hub in Nairobi. Most information is currently integrated into the PathoTracer platform.
gender_justification: CoA 4.3 is gender neutral.
capdev_justification: CoA 4.3 did not have CapDev activities in 2020.
climate_justification: This CoA has spillover to climate change by monitoring more frequent pest occurrences resulting from climate change.

outcome_sumary: In Preliminary analyses of the antenna and reference panels were accomplished for phenotypic data available in 2019. Both within and across site AMMI analyses for GxE were performed showing site groupings of traits. Since more complete panel data is now available, we will analyze these datasets. Also, delivery of major QTLs/genes is closely linked to FP5, CoA 1 on the use of genetic diversity. Four varieties in the Antenna Panel now have high quality genome builds, allowing extension of the antenna panel Single Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP) set for analyses of its phenotypic data.
milestone_evidence: Single Nucleotide Polymorphism and phenotypic data from the antenna (AP) and reference panels (RP) are available from our project shared site, and AMMI analyses on AP data have been loaded in a shared gdrive folder (link below). A publication on new reference genomes that includes AP varieties is available from Scientific Data. Personnel limitations meant slower than expected progress. With completed phenotyping of the AP and RP and cross-cluster teamwork with input from a consultant, data analyses will be completed this year.
gender_justification: This CoA is gender neutral.
capdev_justification: Two training courses on GWAS held during 2020.
climate_justification: This CoA has spillover to climate change through analysis of results from CoA 4.1 and 4.2.

outcome_sumary: We implemented analysis software for crop genomics in Galaxy via a CropGalaxy server available worldwide. This merged and built on two previous efforts serving slightly different communities, RiceGalaxy and EiB-Galaxy. New tools were added for Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) and post-GWAS. A training workshop on CropGalaxy was held during the Bioinformatics Community Conference 2020 (BCC2020), an Open Bioinformatics Foundation virtual conference. We plan to continue adding new tools to CropGalaxy and hold annual training workshops. While phenotype data is available through the FP4 website, it is not yet in Galaxy. Progress was hampered due to personnel constraints.
milestone_evidence: Crop Galaxy can be accessed globally by the public via http://cropgalaxy.excellenceinbreeding.org . Tools implemented in CropGalaxy can be browsed using the left navigation bar. For example, one of the GWAS tools can be seen here: http://cropgalaxy.excellenceinbreeding.org/?tool_id=gemma-assoc-lmm&version=v.01&__identifer=psrm4m957g. Datasets can be browsed in the Shared Data -> Data Libraries section: http://cropgalaxy.excellenceinbreeding.org/library/list. Two training courses were held during 2020. The Crop Galaxy workshop at BCC2020 had 25 participants representing while an IRRI Education online course "SNPs to GWAS" had 43 participants from Bangladesh, China, Indonesia, India, Philippines, Thailand and Tunisia. Currently, we have begun implementing an instance of BreedBase at IRRI to host manual and HTP data on the AP and RP (BreedBase is an open source platform developed by the Mueller group at Cornell). We will extend this to include additional tools for machine learning, GWAS and genomic selection/prediction. This system will supplant flat file data storage and the tools and data libraries provided by CropGalaxy. We envision this will become the CRP Rice Data Hub, hosted by the Department of Science and Technology (DOST-ASTI) in the Philippines.
gender_justification: Gender neutral. However, women scientists participate in training courses.
youth_justification: Youth neutral. However, your scientists/students participate in training events.
capdev_justification: Two training courses were held in 2020 (June and December).
climate_justification: Climate Change neutral.

outcome_sumary: Program implementers such as World Food Programme, Alive & Thrive, government ministries (Ministry of Agriculture in Bangladesh) and the European Commission have used A4NH evidence in their funding, design, and/or programming of nutrition- and gender-sensitive agriculture programs. In 2020, two more implementing organizations requested IFPRI researcher expert advice on the design of nutrition-sensitive and -specific programs, specifically how to interpret and use stunting in ways that are meaningful and to identify indicators that may more meaningfully capture the full range of benefits of nutrition interventions.
milestone_evidence:
An IFPRI researcher gave an expert consultation to USAID on the use of stunting and other indicators for their Advancing Nutrition programs. Alive & Thrive is using the review by Ruel et al on nutrition-sensitive agriculture (based on A4NH Phase I evidence) to inform their nutrition-sensitive
agriculture work in Generation 2 of their program. The World Food Programme (WFP), through a partnership with IFPRI researchers, has developed nutrition-sensitive program guidance and plans for improving program effectiveness and contributing to the evidence base through rigorous evaluations. In 2020, IFPRI was invited to assess the impact of Phase II of WFP's Food Assistance for Assets (FFA) program in Sri Lanka (a type of social protection program) coupled with a behavior change communication intervention on agriculture, nutrition and well-being outcomes.
gender_justification: Alive & Thrive is using evidence on Nutrition Sensitive Agriculture (based on Phase 1 evidence) to inform their nutrition sensitive agriculture work in Generation 2 of their program.
youth_justification: Based on partnerships on Phase I projects and evidence generated from these projects, HKI sought collaboration with NSAP researchers on the Suaahara II program to design a school-based adolescent strategy to improve health and nutrition outcomes and associated evaluation plan.
capdev_justification: Interactions between A4NH researchers and national governments build the capacity of these governments. WFP and USAID have requested consultations from IFPRI researchers to increase their awareness on nutrition outcomes.
climate_justification: Climate change is not a specific target of these social protection programs.

outcome_sumary: Significant outreach and capacity development around the Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index (WEAI) and other tools to measure empowerment have led to increased interest and use. A complementary stream of work to improve the comparability and use of economic evaluation findings across different multisectoral nutrition interventions through a standardized method, set of tools, and analysis is making progress. Lastly, IFPRI researchers alongside the World Food Programme will be part of a new UNICEF-led project in four West African countries (Mali, Chad, Mauritania, and Niger) to assess operational feasibility, impact, and cost-effectiveness of community based integrated interventions to reduce wasting.
milestone_evidence: Piloting of the project-level Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index (pro-WEAI) in 11 agricultural development projects wrapped up in 2020. To promote uptake and use, the team launched the pro-WEAI Foundations Module, the first in the pro-WEAI Distance Learning Course, in January 2020. Although the final version won't be available until 2021, the WEAI team has tracked widespread use of the current version in research and evaluation. As part of IFPRI's participation in the Strengthening Economic Evaluation for Multisectoral Strategies for Nutrition (SEEMS) initiative, they are developing a comprehensive set of data collection tools for estimating financial and economic costs of nutrition-sensitive interventions delivered through multisectoral projects, designed so that they can be used alongside planned or ongoing process or impact evaluations. The methodology was applied in an economic evaluation of an early child development scheme in Malawi with preliminary results finding its estimated benefits outweighed the intervention costs. Lastly, an A4NH strategic brief framed how agriculture programs can be designed and evaluated to reduce forms of malnutrition and outlined key components of successful implementation and measurement of impacts of such programs. Less than a year after publication, it is in the top 25% of all research outputs scored by Altmetric.
gender_justification: The pro-WEAI is designed to measure women's empowerment in agriculture projects.
youth_justification: Tools and methods frequently consider the unique needs of adolescents. For example, researchers are aware of the evidence gaps of daily nutrient intake in adolescents and have validated a tool to estimate daily nutrient intake; research teams have developed a new mobile based app to improve adolescent nutrition in two urban locations.
capdev_justification: The WEAI Resource Center, new Distance Learning Course, and the growing community around these tools are designed to build capacity for use. Building capacity for the tools to measure economic costs is part of the overall workplan.
climate_justification: Climate change is not a specific target of these tools or methods.

outcome_sumary: A4NH researchers from IFPRI continued to engage with the Scaling Up Nutrition (SUN) Movement and the African Union's Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Programme (CAADP). In 2019, researchers led an initative to identify opportunities for mainstreaming gender equality into a CAADP workshop. Researchers supporting the Partnerships and Opportunities to Strengthen and Harmonize Actions for Nutrition in India co-led a virtual event with Nutrition International to convene stakeholders on the development of a survey toolkit to assure quality nutrition data with appropriate gender indicators. This enagagement with international and regional organizations will continue into 2021.
milestone_evidence: During 2020, attention and priority was given to responding to policy research needs on health and socio-economic shocks of the COVID-19 pandemic, so many outreach and engagement activities were postponed. Regardless, progress was made in elevating the discourse of new approaches to climate change, gender relations, and equity in relation to nutrition sensitive programming and policy. Results from the joint collaboration between CCAFS and A4NH were published online in Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Climate Change. The systematic literature review identified connections, trends and pathways between climate change, inequity and nutrition outcomes. It also highlighted the value of looking at those most affected by climate change by moving beyond traditional, empirical climate change research. Researchers contributed a chapter on equity in nutrition to the 2020 Global Nutrition Report and organized a session on the Stories of Change research at the Micronutrient Forum, an international conference organized to bring together cross-sectoral actors interested in reducing malnutrition.
gender_justification: The Global Nutrition Report Chapter focuses on issues of equity, including gender equity.
youth_justification: Youth/adolescents are indicated as important target group for addressing social determinants of nutrition.
capdev_justification: The Scaling up Nutrition and CAADP engagement activities include capacity development of partners and researchers.
climate_justification: Climate change is not specifically targeted in any of these programs

milestone_evidence: Continued engagement with Nigerian counterparts and stakeholders have raised awareness on investing in accelerating the reduction of malnutrition through a collaborative effort. This builds on past work, including an evidence note that outlined opportunities to strengthen research initiatives and fill knowledge gaps on how to reduce malnutrition in Nigeria (through Stories of Change) and an IFPRI-led Transform Nutrition West Africa session at the Nutrition Society of Nigeria Annual Conference to review and reflect on the evidence note, where commitment was made to enhance research capacity of Nigerian nutrition researchers. In Rwanda, results (again from Stories of Change) resulted in a convincing advocacy case for systemic change and for an inclusive, multi-stakeholder national strategy to reduce malnutrition. A framework of cooperation between civil society organizations and the provincial administration was generated to help address some of the identified gaps, as revealed by Stories of Change. Lastly, in Bangladesh, the Ministry of Agriculture, continues its commitment to scale-up a package of agriculture, nutrition, and gender training to benefit thousands of households, which was informed by a similar intervention co-designed and evaluated by IFPRI.
gender_justification: The new program in Bangladesh is scaling up a package of gender training.
youth_justification: Youth are not specifically targeted in any of these programs
capdev_justification: Interactions (including short courses, dialogues, and validation events through the Stories of Change studies) between A4NH researchers and national governments build the capacity of these governments.
climate_justification: Climate change is not specifically targeted in any of these programs

outcome_sumary: A4NH researchers have worked to build evidence into functional capacity training, targeting programs that implement agriculture and nutrition interventions and related multi-sectoral coordination to strengthen nutrition action for African and Asian Countries. Ongoing engagement with regional and country level partners in Africa, through the IFPRI-led Transform Nutrition West Africa and Stories of Change initiative, have resulted in building capacity for enabling evidenced based programming and policy for nutrition. This engagement addresses capacity needs with tools and methods to meet the goal of providing opportunities to use the evidence among stakeholders of the implementing communities for the needed actions in countries.
milestone_evidence: In June 2020, the African Academy of Sciences (AAS) convened a consultative roundtable on food security and nutrition with a diverse group of experts. An IFPRI researcher was involved in prioritizing the research on multiple burdens of malnutrition and how African health systems could be strengthened to reduce malnutrition in all its forms. The prioritization of research for the AAS will be used to develop an evidence synthesis that will inform policies and programs on future food security and nutrition in Africa. Through the IFPRI-led Transform Nutrition West Africa platform, a two-day conference on data for nutrition led to a Call To Action to invest in a data value chain for nutrition in West Africa, supported by the West African Health Organization. In Nigeria, in 2019 two organized sessions at the Nutrition Society of Nigeria Annual Conference led to the launch a new project to enhance research capacity of Nigerian nutrition researchers at the conference. In 2020, the Stories of Change study continued to engage with partners and stakeholders online: 25 participants from federal and state level identified key policy barriers to reducing malnutrition and created a policy recommendations to share with Ministers and Commissioners of different sectors.
gender_justification: A4NH researchers continue to advocate for integrating gender-sensitive programs and policies.
youth_justification: Youth is not specifically targeted in any of these programs
capdev_justification: Interactions (including short courses, dialogues, and validation events through the Stories of Change studies) between A4NH researchers and national governments build the capacity of these governments.
climate_justification: Climate change is not specifically targeted in any of these programs

outcome_sumary:
Updated breeding objectives and selection
indexes have been developed for the dairy cattle breeding program in East Africa, which will be
used by the breeding program moving forward (milestone 1.2.6). Successful establishment of breeding programs has been achieved for pastoral production systems (milestone 1.2.5, ongoing). The milestone of availing
a zebu x taurine admixture single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) chip for
determining the underlying breed composition of cross-bred dairy cattle is complete (milestone 1.2.4), despite not being able to find a company interested
in commercializing this tool as was originally intended (this will be revisited in
the future).
milestone_evidence: The paper on framework for community-based breeding programs in pastoral regions has been submitted and is being reviewed.  We expect this to be published in 2021.
gender_justification: Women reached but not specifically benefiting
youth_justification: Youth reached but not specifically benefiting
capdev_justification: Involvement of national partners in implementation of the breeding program
climate_justification: Only though increased livestock productivity resulting in reduced GHG emission intensity
