milestone_evidence:
Extended due to inability to obtain stakeholder
 input in 2020 resulting from Covid-19 related issues, including travel
 restrictions. The ministry has requested ILRI to convene a joint stakeholder workshop
 in 2021 where this can be addressed.
gender_justification: This milestone considers the needs and preferences of both women and men smallholder pig keepers in relation to pig keeping objectives, and breed and trait preferences, as input into the development of the national genetic improvement strategy.  This was based on data obtained from both quantitative surveys implemented separately to adult male and females within households, and qualitative survey with separate focus group discussions for women and men.
youth_justification: Youth reached but not specifically targeted
capdev_justification: Not specifically targeted
climate_justification: Not specifically targeted at this stage

outcome_sumary: Experiences on integrating interventions has been made in different production systems (pigs in Uganda, all species in Vietnam, small ruminants and dairy in Ethiopia). The flagship has launched a freely available guide to herd health management for dairy, pigs and small ruminants and developed a digital tool (mobile app) to monitor productivity parameters in livestock.
milestone_evidence: The primary shortcomings identified are: reproductive management, parasite control and feed quality as presented in this thesis.
gender_justification: n/a
capdev_justification: n/a
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary: Experiences on integrating interventions has been made in different production systems (pigs in Uganda, all species in Vietnam, small ruminants and dairy in Ethiopia). The flagship has launched a freely available guide to herd health management for dairy, pigs and small ruminants and developed a digital tool (mobile app) to monitor productivity parameters in livestock.
milestone_evidence: Travel to Uganda was not possible due to COVID-19, resulting in delays.
gender_justification: The study has not yet been completed, but it is being stratified by gender.
capdev_justification: n/a
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary: Experiences on integrating interventions has been made in different production systems (pigs in Uganda, all species in Vietnam, small ruminants and dairy in Ethiopia). The flagship has launched a freely available guide to herd health management for dairy, pigs and small ruminants and developed a digital tool (mobile app) to monitor productivity parameters in livestock.
milestone_evidence:
Vaccination and deworming at community level,
combined with capacity development through community conversations, is being
implemented. (Monitoring is ongoing, some evidence has been published in early
community conversation modules).
gender_justification: Engaged community members and local partners in dialogues and joint actions on gender in livestock development. The community conversations addressed various topics such as gender and zoonosis, animal welfare, and antimicrobial resistance: https://livestock.cgiar.org/news/community-conversations-contribute-transform-gender-relations-rural-ethiopia
youth_justification: the community conversations also targets youth specifically
capdev_justification: this is very much a cap dev activity
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary: In 2020, the following first wave of varieties were released: zinc rice varieties in Colombia and Nicaragua and zinc wheat varieties in Nepal. Several 2nd wave varieties were released, including: zinc wheat in Pakistan, vitamin A cassava in Ghana, vitamin A maize in Nigeria, iron beans in Tanzania; and zinc maize varieties in Colombia, El Salvador, Guatemala.
milestone_evidence: Even though delays occurred due to COVID-19, there were 23 new varieties released in 2020 (23 innovations). An updated crops released map showing the new varieties from 2020 is not yet publicly available, but a link to the latest one has been provided.
gender_justification: Product profiles and target traits always include  which include  gender relevant  traits (ex. cooking processing, marketing)
capdev_justification: Variety development and release includes capacity building and training in biofortification breeding for national partners and young scientists
climate_justification: Traits relevant for climate change and adaptation (e.g. heat and drought tolerance) has been included in metrics and tools (esp. as food system outcome, or related to diets)

outcome_sumary: Budget was allocated for monitoring mainstreaming in CGIAR Centers and NARS. Initial contacts with selected CGIAR Centers and the Excellence in Breeding Platform were established. A set of indicators were developed to assess and monitor mainstreaming, and some context-specific programs are in the advanced stage for implementation.
milestone_evidence: Set of indicators were developed to assess and monitor mainstreaming, and some context-specific programs are in advance stage for implementation, so that is why we report this 2020 milestone as changed. We are in the process of finalizing indicators across crops. Crops are at different stages in that process. For example, wheat and pearl millet are advanced and everything needed can be measured. For other programs, HarvestPlus is continuing to assess whether they are mainstreaming in the crop season. Following the development of indicators, the next step will be to i) assess programs using indicators (inventory/state-of-art), and ii) develop mainstreaming roadmaps (assuring integration in Excellence in Breeding platform (EIB) profiles. For example, at ICRISAT, in 2020, more than 90% of pearl millet involves one iron parent and crop-country prioritization provided to the EIB accordingly), and optimization of methodologies with context-specific definition of targets). The last step will be implementation.
gender_justification: Product profiles and target traits take into consideration gender issues (ex. cooking processing, marketing)
capdev_justification: Variety development and release includes capacity building and training in biofortification breeding for national partners and young scientists.
climate_justification: We intentional test and release climate-resilient varieties, whenever possible.Traits relevant for climate change and adaptation (e.g. heat and drought tolerance) were included in metrics and tools (esp. as food system outcome, or related to diets)

outcome_sumary: The Global Households Reached Projection Model will be revised in 2021, including a new calibration of the model based on new data. Over the past two years, the effects of COVID-19, drought, etc., have been significant. HarvestPlus continues to find innovative ways to continue the delivery. Under HarvestPlus leadership, in 2020, an estimated 9.7 million households were growing and consuming biofortified crops, which translates to an estimated 48.5 million people benefiting from biofortified crops.
milestone_evidence: An estimated 9.7 million households were growing biofortified crops in 2020, which translates to an estimated 48.5 million people, at the farm household level, benefiting from biofortified crops. The 2020 target was intended to be 10 million households (adjusted after the submission of POWB2020), so the adjusted target was nearly reached but not quite, which is why we are reporting this as changed. The target for the 2021 milestone is 12 million households. The Global Households Reached Projection Model is currently being revised (new calibration of the model, based on new data). The effects of COVID-19, drought, etc. are taken into consideration. HarvestPlus continues to find innovative ways to continue the delivery. For example, in Nigeria during the early months of the pandemic, the country team negotiated a 10 percent price discount with seed companies in six states for vitamin A maize (VAM) seed and 20 percent for vitamin A cassava (VAC) stems. The farmers were offered the VAM seed and Aflasafe (another CGIAR/A4NHinnovation) as a package to reduce aflatoxin contamination under a partnership with HarvestField, a Nigerian agro and healthcare company that is licensed to manufacture Aflasafe.
gender_justification: Varieties are developed incorporating women's micronutrient needs and preferences and co-developed men and women farmers. Gender-sensitive delivery models have been developed, implemented, and evaluated.
youth_justification: We have delivery models, especially those along the value chain, targeting the training of youth and youth engagement, especially for youth and women-owned SMEs.
capdev_justification: HarvestPlus provides capacity strengthening at the NARS level and the community level.
climate_justification: We intentionally release  climate-resilient varieties, whenever possible. Traits relevant for climate change and adaptation (e.g., heat and drought tolerance) have been included in metrics and tools (esp. as food system outcome or related to diets). Biofortified varieties are developed to offset the negative impact of CO2 emissions on crops' nutrient content.

outcome_sumary: HarvestPlus methodology for ex-ante impact and cost-effectiveness analyses was revised. HarvestPlus researchers provided technical support to CGIAR colleagues to conduct cost-effectiveness analyses for orange sweet potato. Other studies and lessons learned that were completed in 2020 include: gender-sensitive iron beans effectiveness study in Guatemala; lessons learned from partnerships with AgResults and World Vision International; and key innovations and program achievements for Uganda. Additions to the evidence base on zinc included: a book summarizing consultation outputs, learnings, and evidence; role of zinc in the prevention of non-communicable diseases; and results from a zinc efficacy study in Bangladesh (submitted for publication).
milestone_evidence:
The study in Guatemala is nearly complete. In 2020, the analysis
 was completed and results were presented at the Micronutrient Forum. A
 journal article is in progress. No decisionmaking tools were developed and
 there are no plans to develop those, although support to local partners to
 advocate for (based on the evidence) and to develop and implement national
 biofortification programs will continue.
gender_justification: This is a gender-sensitive study that focuses on adolescent girls. Also, investigated women farmers' evaluation of iron bean varieties.
youth_justification: The target population is adolescent girls.
capdev_justification: Worked very closely with local institutions on breeding, multiplication, and delivery.
climate_justification: Climate change was not a focus of the research

outcome_sumary: HarvestPlus methodology for ex-ante impact and cost-effectiveness analyses was revised. HarvestPlus researchers provided technical support to CGIAR colleagues to conduct cost-effectiveness analyses for orange sweet potato. Other studies and lessons learned that were completed in 2020 include: gender-sensitive iron beans effectiveness study in Guatemala; lessons learned from partnerships with AgResults and World Vision International; and key innovations and program achievements for Uganda. Additions to the evidence base on zinc included: a book summarizing consultation outputs, learnings, and evidence; role of zinc in the prevention of non-communicable diseases; and results from a zinc efficacy study in Bangladesh (submitted for publication).
milestone_evidence: The two major decisionmaking tools from 2020 included a summary of outcomes and outputs from a major zinc consultation organized by HarvestPlus, which is expected to catalyze future efficacy studies on zinc biofortified crops and a book by Howarth Bouis on biofortification evidence and learning. In addition, a zinc wheat brochure, summarizing the research to date was widely disseminated (available upon request). In addition, a 2020 study serves as a key resource on the potential of biofortification to address non-communicable diseases (NCDs) and a basis for deeper research. Filling evidence gaps on zinc for biofortification has been one of the major goals of HarvestPlus in Phase II of A4NH. A zinc efficacy study in Bangladesh has been delayed due to COVID-19, but is expected to be completed and published in 2021. Other studies - on effects of zinc-biofortified wheat intake on zinc status biomarkers in men, supplemental zinc, and fatty acid endpoints from a zinc-fortified rice trial - are all in the publication pipeline.
gender_justification: Research underlying the tools takes into consideration the differential needs of men and women across the lifecycle.
youth_justification: Research underlying the tools supports that zinc is vital for survival, meaning a deficiency has serious consequences for health, particularly during childhood when zinc requirements are increased.
capdev_justification: The intent of the tools is to increase capacity of decisionmakers to make evidence-based decisions around biofortification.
climate_justification: Climate change was not a focus of the research  underlying the tools.

outcome_sumary: HarvestPlus methodology for ex-ante impact and cost-effectiveness analyses was revised. HarvestPlus researchers provided technical support to CGIAR colleagues to conduct cost-effectiveness analyses for orange sweet potato. Other studies and lessons learned that were completed in 2020 include: gender-sensitive iron beans effectiveness study in Guatemala; lessons learned from partnerships with AgResults and World Vision International; and key innovations and program achievements for Uganda. Additions to the evidence base on zinc included: a book summarizing consultation outputs, learnings, and evidence; role of zinc in the prevention of non-communicable diseases; and results from a zinc efficacy study in Bangladesh (submitted for publication).
milestone_evidence: Due to limited internal resources and capacity, this large piece of work has been delayed. Analyses are expected to be finalized in 2021 for publication in 2022. In the meantime, the methodology has been updated for zinc and analyses are ongoing for other crops. HarvestPlus researchers have provided support to CGIAR colleagues from CIP and the CRP on Roots, Tubers, and Bananas (RTB) to conduct analyses for orange sweet potato (OSP). Preliminary results and progress to date were shared in scientific conferences in 2020.
gender_justification: Gender was not a focus of the analysis of the reported results.
youth_justification: Youth was not a focus of the analysis of the reported results.
capdev_justification: Capacity development was not a focus of the analysis of the reported results.
climate_justification: Climate change was not a focus of the analysis of the reported results.

outcome_sumary: HarvestPlus methodology for ex-ante impact and cost-effectiveness analyses was revised. HarvestPlus researchers provided technical support to CGIAR colleagues to conduct cost-effectiveness analyses for orange sweet potato. Other studies and lessons learned that were completed in 2020 include: gender-sensitive iron beans effectiveness study in Guatemala; lessons learned from partnerships with AgResults and World Vision International; and key innovations and program achievements for Uganda. Additions to the evidence base on zinc included: a book summarizing consultation outputs, learnings, and evidence; role of zinc in the prevention of non-communicable diseases; and results from a zinc efficacy study in Bangladesh (submitted for publication).
milestone_evidence: In the 2020POWB, we expected to report on lessons learned from Rwanda, Nigeria, and Bangladesh. The countries selected depend on partnerships, demands, and progress in the countries. Instead what could be reported on in 2020 occurred in Uganda and Rwanda. For example, success in reaching so many Ugandans has hinged on continuous innovation, made possible under two projects funded by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID). In these projects HarvestPlus promoted several novel approaches to scaling up the reach and impact of biofortified crops in Uganda, and many of these innovations have been duplicated in other countries. In Rwanda, a video released in 2020 on YouTube tells the "nutrition success story" of iron beans. COVID-19 impacted fieldwork (interviews/focus group discussions), so the work in Nigeria, Bangladesh and India has been delayed and is expected to be completed in 2021.
gender_justification: The lessons learned are incomplete, so it's too early to say how gender issues were a factor.
youth_justification: The lessons learned are incomplete, so it's too early to say how youth was a factor.
capdev_justification: Capturing the lessons learned from projects aim to strengthen internal and external capacity, mainly on delivery.
climate_justification: The lessons learned are incomplete, so it's too early to say how youth was a factor.

outcome_sumary: HarvestPlus is enabling a conducive policy environment at national, regional, global levels by leveraging the evidence and tools developed under HarvestPlus leadership. As a result of the World Health Organization and Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (WHO/FAO)-led biofortification consultation (2016) and the ongoing Cochrane review of available evidence (to be released by mid-2021), we expect the WHO Nutrition Guidance Expert Advisory Group to issue a recommendation– and most likely guidelines – on biofortification as a mainstream intervention for improving nutrition, in 2022. There was also progress with the African Union, and in Malawi Nigeria, Tanzania, and more.
milestone_evidence:
In 2020, HarvestPlus continued communicating
with the World Health Organization (WHO) on the review of evidence as part of
the process of issuing joint WHO-FAO guidance to governments. (The link
provided shows an example of the joint effort.) The WHO plans to complete the
evidence review by mid-2021, convene the Nutrition Guideline Advisory Group,
and issue a recommendation on biofortification as a mainstream nutrition
intervention to prevent micronutrient deficiency. The corresponding guideline
is expected to follow in 2022. In response to a request by the WHO nutrition
and food safety department, and in an effort to elevate the priority given to
biofortification by the Nutrition Guidance Expert Advisory Group and accelerate
the process, HarvestPlus country managers are asking their health ministries to
officially request guidance on biofortification from the respective national
WHO office.
gender_justification: The guidelines have not yet been finalized, so it is not clear yet how gender will be included.
youth_justification: The guidelines have not yet been finalized, so it is not clear yet how youth will be included.
capdev_justification: The guidelines have not yet been finalized, so it is not clear yet how capacity development will be included.
climate_justification: The guidelines have not yet been finalized, so it is not clear yet how climate change will be included.

outcome_sumary: HarvestPlus is enabling a conducive policy environment at national, regional, global levels by leveraging the evidence and tools developed under HarvestPlus leadership. As a result of the World Health Organization and Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (WHO/FAO)-led biofortification consultation (2016) and the ongoing Cochrane review of available evidence (to be released by mid-2021), we expect the WHO Nutrition Guidance Expert Advisory Group to issue a recommendation– and most likely guidelines – on biofortification as a mainstream intervention for improving nutrition, in 2022. There was also progress with the African Union, and in Malawi Nigeria, Tanzania, and more.
milestone_evidence: In 2020, biofortification was cited as a strategy to tackle micronutrient malnutrition in policies and official statements from (1) Tanzania, (2) India, (3) USA (concerning overseas development), (4) Nigeria, and (5) Uganda. The target for three international financial institutions (IFI) loans was achieved. IFI loans related to biofortification that were approved included (1) an investment from the World Bank to Malawi (approximately $258k). By the end of 2020, negotiations were nearly complete with The World Bank on (2) an agricultural development loan to the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC); by mid-year 2021, the loan was approved. HarvestPlus has been working closely with the DRC Government. Two additional loans from the World Bank that will include biofortification were developed, though not yet approved in 2020: (3) one in Nigeria and (4) one in DRC. HarvestPlus is advising both the World Bank task force as well as the national teams on integration of biofortification. The African Development Bank's second phase of Technologies for African Agricultural Transformation (TAATII) was paused in 2020, so we may have more to report on this in 2021.
gender_justification: Gender is not targeted in any of the policies or loans
youth_justification: Youth is not targeted in any of the policies or loans
capdev_justification: HarvestPlus outreach, engagement, and technical support has been a key part of the attention to and inclusion of biofortification.
climate_justification: Climate Change is not targeted in any of the policies or loans

outcome_sumary: HarvestPlus is enabling a conducive policy environment at national, regional, global levels by leveraging the evidence and tools developed under HarvestPlus leadership. As a result of the World Health Organization and Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (WHO/FAO)-led biofortification consultation (2016) and the ongoing Cochrane review of available evidence (to be released by mid-2021), we expect the WHO Nutrition Guidance Expert Advisory Group to issue a recommendation– and most likely guidelines – on biofortification as a mainstream intervention for improving nutrition, in 2022. There was also progress with the African Union, and in Malawi Nigeria, Tanzania, and more.
milestone_evidence: in 2020, HarvestPlus researchers worked to upgrade and expand the BPI to include: (1) more biofortified crops: iron lentil, cowpea, and Irish potato; vitamin A banana/plantain; and zinc sorghum. They add to the previously available iron bean and pearl millet; vitamin A cassava, maize, and orange sweet potato; and zinc maize, rice, and wheat; (2) new releases of biofortified crop varieties available for scaling in the 128 countries; (3) new evidence on the nutrition impact of biofortified crops; and (4) more functions, including downloadable maps and data. Its official launch and updated website happened in April 2021.
gender_justification: Gender was not part of the the analysis
youth_justification: Age (youth) was not part of the analysis
capdev_justification: There were not any capacity development efforts surrounding the use of BPI, although maybe there will be in the future.
climate_justification: Climate change was not part of the analysis

outcome_sumary: Through a public-private initiative, business models for fixed-time (synchronized) artificial insemination for enhanced delivery of improved dairy cattle genetics to farmers in emerging dairy regions of Kenya and Tanzania were developed and implemented (milestone 1.3.4). A network of reproductive technology labs, run by National Agricultural Research Organizations (linked to small ruminant (SR) community-based breeding programs run by co-operatives), were established to improve delivery of improved SR genetics to SR keepers in Ethiopia and Tanzania (milestone 1.3.3). Due to ongoing technical difficulties, ILRI has not been successful in producing a transgenic trypanoresistant calf and the related milestone (1.3.6) has been cancelled.
milestone_evidence:
7 reproductive platforms have been established in
 Ethiopia and 2 in Tanzania (as previously reported). Additional reproductive
 platforms were planned in Ethiopia in 2020, but this was delayed due to the
 Covid-19 pandemic and it is unclear whether this will be possible in 2021. We
 thus propose to change the milestone to "A network of reproductive
 technology labs to improve fertility and the delivery of improved genetics
 established for sheep in Ethiopia (7 laboratories) and goat in Tanzania (2
 laboratories)". This milestone is
 thus changed and complete.
gender_justification: Women reached but not specifically benefiting
youth_justification: Youth reached but not specifically benefiting
capdev_justification: Training was provided to the partner team in the 9 labs in Ethiopia and the 2 labs in Tanzania. For sustainability of our capacity development investment, a core group of these partners received an advanced, expert training in various reproductive technologies and they are today our training ambassadors. On-the-job coaching was also provided on a routine basis every time one of the labs was involved in implementing artificial insemination or pregnancy diagnosis at large scale.
climate_justification: Only via increased livestock productivity reducing GHG emission intensity

outcome_sumary: Through a public-private initiative, business models for fixed-time (synchronized) artificial insemination for enhanced delivery of improved dairy cattle genetics to farmers in emerging dairy regions of Kenya and Tanzania were developed and implemented (milestone 1.3.4). A network of reproductive technology labs, run by National Agricultural Research Organizations (linked to small ruminant (SR) community-based breeding programs run by co-operatives), were established to improve delivery of improved SR genetics to SR keepers in Ethiopia and Tanzania (milestone 1.3.3). Due to ongoing technical difficulties, ILRI has not been successful in producing a transgenic trypanoresistant calf and the related milestone (1.3.6) has been cancelled.
milestone_evidence: The models for fixed-time and conventional artificial insemination technologies have been designed and successfully piloted in Kenya.
gender_justification: Women reached but not specifically benefiting
youth_justification: Youth reached but not specifically benefiting
capdev_justification: This result will underpin later capacity development efforts
climate_justification: Not relevant to climate change, though eventual improved livestock productivity can result in lower GHG emission intensity

outcome_sumary: Through a public-private initiative, business models for fixed-time (synchronized) artificial insemination for enhanced delivery of improved dairy cattle genetics to farmers in emerging dairy regions of Kenya and Tanzania were developed and implemented (milestone 1.3.4). A network of reproductive technology labs, run by National Agricultural Research Organizations (linked to small ruminant (SR) community-based breeding programs run by co-operatives), were established to improve delivery of improved SR genetics to SR keepers in Ethiopia and Tanzania (milestone 1.3.3). Due to ongoing technical difficulties, ILRI has not been successful in producing a transgenic trypanoresistant calf and the related milestone (1.3.6) has been cancelled.
milestone_evidence:
The project activities were delayed due to the
unreliability of external egg suppliers, enhanced by COVID-19 restrictions. To
overcome this, the project established its own chicken flock, which extended
the delay. The deliverable is now expected to be produced in 2021.
gender_justification: Proof of concept of a laboratory methodology
youth_justification: Proof of concept of a laboratory methodology
capdev_justification: Proof of concept of a laboratory methodology
climate_justification: Proof of concept of a laboratory methodology

This deliverable has encountered unexpected technical difficulties 
compounded by the departure of the lead scientist. Work on this is

youth_justification: Upstream science around developing a protcol for creating transgenic animals

outcome_sumary: Scaling of the Community-based breeding program in Ethiopia was initiated and will continue in 2021 (milestone 1.4.2, ongoing). This is a follow up of the piloting that has been completed, with the focus being dissemination of improved (for both productive and adaptive attributes) sires from established CBBPs through both natural mating and artificial insemination to the base population.
milestone_evidence:
This upscaling was initiated in 2020 but progressed
 slower than expected due to the COVID-19 pandemic restricting access to the
 field, and conflict in the Tigray region. Due to this delay and uncertainties
 around whether this can be achieved in 2021, we propose to change this
 milestone to "Community-based breeding program upscaled in three regions
 of Ethiopia (Amhara, Oromia, and
 South) with more than 3,000 households participating". This milestone is
 thus changed and extended.
gender_justification: Women reached but not specifically benefiting
youth_justification: Youth reached but not specifically benefiting
capdev_justification: Of national partnes involved in implementing the breeding program, and who will continue to implement when the Flagship withdraws
climate_justification: Only via increased livestock productivity resulting in reduced GHG emission intensity

outcome_sumary: In 2020 MAIZE publicly released the first bridging germplasm in the form of CMGRLs (CIMMYT Maize Genetic Resource Lines)  the releases targeting the broadening the diversity of breeding germplasm specifically for drought resistance and tar spot disease complex tolerance. The adoption and deployment of new tools and resources to enhance maize breeding has continued despite challenges of COVID-19 and resourcing. Some reprioritization of interventions has occurred to focus on those with greater potential to enhance, in the longer-term, the effective and comprehensive implementation of new breeding tools, methods and approaches to improve delivery of genetic gain.
milestone_evidence: The strategies for implementation of validated breeder-ready markers/haplotypes for at least 4 priority traits is well advanced, with validated production markers and genotyping available through a high throughput service provider. Together with the Excellence in Breeding Platform clear steps to modify breeding program structure to facilitate routine implementation have been conducted with more outlined. Seed chipping requires access to proprietary technology in order to effectively leverage the value of application. We have discussed opportunities for access with IP holders. To effectively deploy the technology requires further breeding program operational restructuring. To date we have focused on higher priority and higher return interventions and changes. Application of seed chipping is still a potential in the future but is not currently a high priority.
other_reason: Assessment of requirements for effective implementation of a technology indicated we are not yet ready to deploy the technology optimally, work was instead refocused on more tangible and higher priority interventions such as breeding Quality Control (QC) using low-plex markers.
gender_justification: Trait priorities are defined from client-oriented demands, these may include gender relevant traits, however the strategy for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver
youth_justification: Trait priorities are defined from client-oriented demands, these may include youth relevant traits, however the strategy for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver
capdev_justification: Capacity development will be a focus of strategy implementation but is not targeted for strategy development
climate_justification: Trait priorities are defined from client-oriented demands, these may include climate change relevant traits, however the strategy for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver

The adoption and deployment of new tools and resources to enhance maize breeding has continued despite challenges of COVID-19 and resourcing. Some reprioritization of interventions has occurred to focus on those with greater potential to enhance, in the longer-term, the effective and comprehensive implementation of new breeding tools, methods and approaches to improve delivery of genetic gain.
milestone_evidence: Broad recommendations for genomic prediction in pre-breeding have been made exploring the breeding strategy and targeting of exotic allelic variation. Validation experiments in three traits are ongoing; drought, salinity tolerance and maize lethal necrosis (MLN) tolerance. These efforts have been impacted by COVID-19 and work to complete validation has been extended to provide the needed evidence to further inform the recommendations
gender_justification: Traits targeted by GS may include gender relevant traits, however the recommendations for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver
youth_justification: Traits targeted by GS may include youth relevant traits, however the recommendations for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver
capdev_justification: Capacity development will be a focus of recommendation implementation but is not targeted for recommendation development
climate_justification: Traits targeted by GS may include climate change relevant traits, however the recommendations for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver

outcome_sumary: In 2020 MAIZE publicly released the first bridging germplasm in the form of CMGRLs (CIMMYT Maize Genetic Resource Lines)  the releases targeting the broadening the diversity of breeding germplasm specifically for drought resistance and tar spot disease complex tolerance. The adoption and deployment of new tools and resources to enhance maize breeding has continued despite challenges of COVID-19 and resourcing. Some reprioritization of interventions has occurred to focus on those with greater potential to enhance, in the longer-term, the effective and comprehensive implementation of new breeding tools, methods and approaches to improve delivery of genetic gain.
milestone_evidence: The use of genomic estimations of breeding value in selection is implemented in three breeding programs with further roll out planned. The availability of affordable, fast and effective mid/high-density genotyping services and pipelined analysis and interpretation has impacted further roll out as current implementation involves a lot of manual processing. These bottlenecks are being addressed through engagement with Excellence in Breeding and broader roll out will be conducted as soon as effective solutions are availible to breeders
gender_justification: Traits targeted by GS may include gender relevant traits, however the implementation is agnostic of the trait selection driver
youth_justification: Traits targeted by GS may include youth relevant traits, however the implementation is agnostic of the trait selection driver
capdev_justification: Capacity to implement GS is required but is a feature of other milestones focused specifically on elements of adoption enabling.
climate_justification: Traits targeted by GS may include climate change relevant traits, however the implementation is agnostic of the trait selection driver

outcome_sumary: In 2020 MAIZE publicly released the first bridging germplasm in the form of CMGRLs (CIMMYT Maize Genetic Resource Lines)  the releases targeting the broadening the diversity of breeding germplasm specifically for drought resistance and tar spot disease complex tolerance. The adoption and deployment of new tools and resources to enhance maize breeding has continued despite challenges of COVID-19 and resourcing. Some reprioritization of interventions has occurred to focus on those with greater potential to enhance, in the longer-term, the effective and comprehensive implementation of new breeding tools, methods and approaches to improve delivery of genetic gain.
milestone_evidence: Bridging germplasm carrying favorable variation for TSC and drought tolerance has been released as newly defined pre-breeding lines called CIMMYT Maize Genetic Resource Lines (CMGRL). Work has advanced on the development of bridging germplasm for MLN tolerance however COVID-19 related challenges have delayed the development and release processes in this area.

youth_justification: The development of the specific germplasm focused on defined traits. youth was not specifically targeted in this 'upstream' activity
capdev_justification: The development of the specific germplasm focused on defined traits. CapDev was not specifically targeted in this 'upstream' activity
climate_justification: The development of the specific germplasm focused on defined traits. climate change was not specifically targeted in this 'upstream' activity though links with drought tolerance are prevalent

The adoption and deployment of new tools and resources to enhance maize breeding has continued despite challenges of COVID-19 and resourcing. Some reprioritization of interventions has occurred to focus on those with greater potential to enhance, in the longer-term, the effective and comprehensive implementation of new breeding tools, methods and approaches to improve delivery of genetic gain.
milestone_evidence: Breeders are adopting molecular characterization more routinely to assess the genomic composition and potential complementarity of germplasm introduced into their programs in addition to assessing for unifromity and homozygosity in the case of line introductions

The adoption and deployment of new tools and resources to enhance maize breeding has continued despite challenges of COVID-19 and resourcing. milestone_evidence: Nine pre-breeding lines, have been released as CIMMYT Maize Genetic Resource Lines (CMGRL). Additionally, resourcing limitations from bi-lateral projects resulted in a scale back of activities impacting the needed testing for release.

outcome_sumary: The refinement of a framework and development of resources to enable more efficient and effective storage and use of data for the purpose of varietal development has advanced comprehensively in 2020. This inspite of a number of challenges related not only to the COVID-19 pandemic but also to a change in the structure and oversight of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) development. The work delivered moves MAIZE closer to comprehensive, efficient and effective breeding data management.
milestone_evidence: Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) v1.0 and v2.1 have been deployed to specific breeding team members at CIMMYT for the purpose of testing and training. Based on their specific feedback development sprints have been formulated and have and will be conducted to develop the next version for broader release to the MAIZE breeding community.
other_reason: Re-formulation of EBS development and COVID-19 pandemic
gender_justification: The data management systems enable the capture and management of gender-related traits though this functionality is not targeted
youth_justification: The data management systems enable the capture and management of youth-related traits though this functionality is not targeted
capdev_justification: The deployment requires significant capacity development activities to facilitate adoption of the system
climate_justification: The data management systems enable the capture and management of climate change-related traits though this functionality is not targeted

outcome_sumary: The refinement of a framework and development of resources to enable more efficient and effective storage and use of data for the purpose of varietal development has advanced comprehensively in 2020. This inspite of a number of challenges related not only to the COVID-19 pandemic but also to a change in the structure and oversight of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) development. The work delivered moves MAIZE closer to comprehensive, efficient and effective breeding data management.
milestone_evidence: The GOBii -Genomic Open-source Breeding informatics initiative- project developed a centralized database for genotypic data. Breeding team members can access it though functionality is limited for direct breeding application. Breeders need to be able to select both genotypic data and phenotypic data for relevant germplasm entities (seed lots) to conduct needed analyses and select and advance germplasm. To facilitate this in a more integrated manner the genotypic data management system is being incorporated into the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS). While GOBii delivered a system the uplift into EBS is needed to enable broad use of data by breeding teams.
gender_justification: The development of a data management system enables application in gender-targeted breeding but is not developed with that specific purpose.
youth_justification: The development of a data management system enables application in youth-targeted breeding but is not developed with that specific purpose.
capdev_justification: GOBii has conducted some training on use of the data systems developed but this was not a core activity of the work conducted nor was it rolled out to broader breeding team members outside genomics application specialists
climate_justification: The development of a data management system enables application in climate change-targeted breeding but is not developed with that specific purpose.

outcome_sumary: The refinement of a framework and development of resources to enable more efficient and effective storage and use of data for the purpose of varietal development has advanced comprehensively in 2020. This inspite of a number of challenges related not only to the COVID-19 pandemic but also to a change in the structure and oversight of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) development. The work delivered moves MAIZE closer to comprehensive, efficient and effective breeding data management.
milestone_evidence: The responsibility for product profile definition and formulation of metrics defining performance needs of germplasm under development is the responsibility of individual breeding teams (comprising market specialists, gender and youth specialists, breeders, trait specialists etc.). The Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) is designed to handle any kind of trait that can be measured, and include defined thresholds for traits in particular pipelines. In the future, trait metrics of germplasm within a particular product profile, including those relevant for gender, youth, and market-based preferences, will be summarized and viewed using business intelligence tools through a dashboard. Through the ability to handle a diverse portfolio of traits Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) accomplishes the desired goal without requiring a separate and tailored data model.
other_reason: The desired outcome can be achieved through a more efficient route
gender_justification: The system developed enables capture of gender-related traits however this was not a targeted feature
youth_justification: The system developed enables capture of youth-related traits however this was not a targeted feature
capdev_justification: The system developed work did not require specific capacity development activities
climate_justification: The system developed enables capture of climate change-related traits however this was not a targeted feature

outcome_sumary: The refinement of a framework and development of resources to enable more efficient and effective storage and use of data for the purpose of varietal development has advanced comprehensively in 2020. This inspite of a number of challenges related not only to the COVID-19 pandemic but also to a change in the structure and oversight of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) development. The work delivered moves MAIZE closer to comprehensive, efficient and effective breeding data management.
milestone_evidence: Work has been started to enable transfer of data between Maize Fieldbook and Kansas State University (KSU) Field Book as a stepping stone for using Kansas State University (KSU) Field Book across CGIAR maize breeding (the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) chosen data capture application). Additionally work has been ongoing to ensure all traits required for data capture are included in Enterprise Breeding System (EBS). . R scripts and protocols for checking and curating genotypic data for upload to standalone GOBii -Genomic Open-source Breeding informatics initiative- have been enhanced. These base scripts can be repurposed into pre-loading validation processes in the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS). Efforts have ensued to update pedigree curation processes to incorporate new nomenclature rules, e.g. new backcross nomenclature and to enhance the efficiency of the curation process to help load more current and historic germplasm faster in preparation for Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) rollout.
other_reason: Need to align and integrate activities with EBS development
gender_justification: The resources developed enable capture, curation and analysis of gender-related traits however this was not a targeted feature in development
youth_justification: The resources developed enable capture, curation and analysis of youth-related traits however this was not a targeted feature in development
capdev_justification: The guidelines developed can be used in capacity development activities during deployment but this was not a targeted feature
climate_justification: The resources developed enable capture, curation and analysis of climate change-related traits however this was not a targeted feature in development

outcome_sumary: Three different kinds of trainings on using antimicrobials in a responsible and prudent way have now been successfully established and rolled out in priority countries. The emphasis now is on making this Capacity Development material available to a larger audience.The AMUSE tool to assess antimicrobial use was used in Uganda, Vietnam, Ethiopia, Burkina Faso, Benin, and Kenya, with more stakeholders expressing interest. The long-term impact of trainings in Ethiopia on prudent use of antimicrobials will be assessed in 2021.
milestone_evidence: This milestone was cancelled, since during the course of the CRP it has become evident that we do not have a comparative advantage in this area.
gender_justification: n/a
capdev_justification: n/a
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary: Three different kinds of trainings on using antimicrobials in a responsible and prudent way have now been successfully established and rolled out in priority countries. The emphasis now is on making this Capacity Development material available to a larger audience.The AMUSE tool to assess antimicrobial use was used in Uganda, Vietnam, Ethiopia, Burkina Faso, Benin, and Kenya, with more stakeholders expressing interest. The long-term impact of trainings in Ethiopia on prudent use of antimicrobials will be assessed in 2021.
milestone_evidence:
In
Uganda a first round of trainings (hybrid virtual and on-site) was completed, with
two more scheduled in 2021. Training material has been made available online. In
Vietnam one round of training with 20 vets and 110 farmers on antibiotic use
took place.



In
Ethiopia trainings were provide though community conversations, which will
continue in other CRP sites in 2021 through the priority country program. This
will enable us to monitor changes in attitudes and practices.
gender_justification: We have put gender awereness into the training and made sure that both men and women participate
capdev_justification: This is a training activity
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary:
There has been considerable progress in the laboratories
 regarding development of vaccines for African swine fever (ASF) as well as
 East Coast fever (ECF). However, the planned validation and further testing
 of this progress by partners or in the field was halted due to COVID-19
 pandemic restrictions.
milestone_evidence: Work with partners was put on hold due to COVID-19, but a presentation on literature review of rapid nucleic acid based diagnostic technologies was produced.
gender_justification: biomedical research
capdev_justification: biomedical research
climate_justification: biomedical research

outcome_sumary:
There has been considerable progress in the laboratories
 regarding development of vaccines for African swine fever (ASF) as well as
 East Coast fever (ECF). However, the planned validation and further testing
 of this progress by partners or in the field was halted due to COVID-19
 pandemic restrictions.
milestone_evidence:
The commercial company IDvet has taken up the contagious
 bovine pleuropneumonia (CBPP) elisa diagnostic developed by ILRI and
 partners. A prototype kit has been developed by IDvet but have yet to decide
 on commercialization of this test. A market-needs analysis for the lateral
 flow CBPP test is ongoing under the bilateral Transformation of Animal Health
 Services and Solution in Low to Middle Income Countries (TAHSSL) project, for
 which data has been generated but not yet fully analyzed.
gender_justification: biomedical research
capdev_justification: biomedical research
climate_justification: biomedical research

outcome_sumary:
There has been considerable progress in the laboratories
 regarding development of vaccines for African swine fever (ASF) as well as
 East Coast fever (ECF). However, the planned validation and further testing
 of this progress by partners or in the field was halted due to COVID-19
 pandemic restrictions.
milestone_evidence: Eleven viral genes have been prioritized for testing as subunit vaccines using AdHu5 and MVA as vaccination vehicles. Five AdHu5 constructs have been made. This is an outsourced activity to the Jenner Institute and has been delayed because of COVID-19.
gender_justification: biomedical research
capdev_justification: biomedical research
climate_justification: biomedical research

outcome_sumary:
There has been considerable progress in the laboratories
 regarding development of vaccines for African swine fever (ASF) as well as
 East Coast fever (ECF). However, the planned validation and further testing
 of this progress by partners or in the field was halted due to COVID-19
 pandemic restrictions.
milestone_evidence: Ten modified candidate attenuated viruses were constructed using CRISPR/cas9 technology. This is a gene editing technology by which genes can be deleted to obtain attenuation. An attenuated vaccine consists of live, whole bacterial cells or viral particles which have been treated to reduced their virulence so they can be used safely to provoke an immune response. Testing of these vaccine candidates in pigs was delayed in 2020 because of COVID-19.
gender_justification: biomedical research
capdev_justification: biomedical research
climate_justification: biomedical research

There has been considerable progress in the laboratories
 regarding development of vaccines for African swine fever (ASF) as well as
 East Coast fever (ECF). However, the planned validation and further testing
 of this progress by partners or in the field was halted due to COVID-19
 pandemic restrictions.
milestone_evidence: A qPCR test using the Theileria parva p104 gene has been validated. Sporozoites and host cells for infections have been stockpiled and antibodies to test in the neutralization assay have been purified. Validation of this test was delayed because of COVID-19.
gender_justification: Biomedical research
capdev_justification: biomedical research
climate_justification: biomedical research

outcome_sumary: Market analyses and analyses of the role of the private sector in delivery of animal health services in general, and vaccines in particular, has provided crucial information to policy makers in some priority countries. In other countries, these analyses have been delayed due to COVID-19 but are ongoing.
milestone_evidence: Evaluation of developed models delayed because of COVID-19. An article was published on the role of gender in adoption of the infection and treatment method in the control of East Coast fever in Kenya and a gender context analysis conducted for the One Health for Humans, Environment, Animals and Livelihoods (HEAL) project.
gender_justification: the delivery models are gender sensitive
youth_justification: the delivery models are partly directed to youth
capdev_justification: launching/applying the models is a a cap dev activity
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary: Market analyses and analyses of the role of the private sector in delivery of animal health services in general, and vaccines in particular, has provided crucial information to policy makers in some priority countries. In other countries, these analyses have been delayed due to COVID-19 but are ongoing.
milestone_evidence: An analysis of the role of the private sector for delivering vaccines in Kenya has been concluded as has a study of willingness to vaccinate and pay in Mali. In other countries, these analyses have been delayed due to COVID-19.
gender_justification: Most analyses are gender stratified
capdev_justification: n/a
climate_justification: n/a

outcome_sumary: CLEANED-X (Comprehensive Livestock Environmental Assessment for Improved Nutrition, a Secured Environment, and Sustainable Development along Livestock and Fish Value Chains) version 3 was released, which will allow more users to have access to the application. The tool has been disseminated in five countries (Uganda, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Vietnam and Tunisia).
milestone_evidence: The CLEANED-X version 2 has been downloaded 184 times. The CLEANED-X version 3 tool has been disseminated in five countries (Uganda, Ethiopia, Tanzania, Vietnam and Tunisia) and its use by national partners documented.
gender_justification: Gender not relevant for environmental priority setting.
youth_justification: As for gender, did not target youth.
capdev_justification: CLEANED is a tool designed to help national stakeholders.
climate_justification: The tool is designed to help stakeholders understand the impacts of climate change.

outcome_sumary: Several reports were produced on heat stress impacts in East and West Africa. The Rural Household Multi-Indicator Survey (RHoMIS) database was used in two different analyses that looked at pathways to sustainable intensification and trade-offs.
milestone_evidence: RHoMIS and the bilateral funded Livestock Yield Gaps: Increasing household nutrition security and incomes (LiveGAPS) project analyses have contributed to the completion of the milestone this year. The link on the right is to an article on Rwanda. Work in other countries is reported under milestone 4.1.4.
gender_justification: The RHoMIS analyses allow for gender disaggregation.
youth_justification: We don't have data on youth.
capdev_justification: RHoMIS is intended to be used with a range of stakeholders.
climate_justification: Climate change is a key environmental impact.

outcome_sumary: Several reports were produced on heat stress impacts in East and West Africa. The Rural Household Multi-Indicator Survey (RHoMIS) database was used in two different analyses that looked at pathways to sustainable intensification and trade-offs.
milestone_evidence:
Analyses conducted of heat stress impacts in East and West
 Africa, but so far there is only evidence of uptake of research results in
 one country (Uganda). Work in other countries was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
gender_justification: We disaggregate impacts by gender.
capdev_justification: The heat stress tools are used with stakeholders.
climate_justification: Heat stress is a major climate change impact.

outcome_sumary: Rangeland management interventions continue to be disseminated through the Sustainable Rangeland Management Toolbox.
milestone_evidence:
The flagship has been developing a toolbox for sustainable
 rehabilitation and management of rangelands in arid environments based on an
 integrated and multidisciplinary approach. Additional sustainable rangeland
 management (SRM) practices were completed in partnership with IUCN including
 grazing management and direct seeding. More SRM practices will be added in
 2021, when the toolbox is expected to be completed. In Tunisia, science-based
 rangeland monitoring and evaluation became the standard since national
 partners (development agencies) sensed the urgent need to improve their
 methodology and requested technical backstopping from ICARDA, provided in the
 form of on-the-job training. This behaviour change is directly linked to
 their conviction of the need to rely on scientific data (4 criteria)
 developed earlier under this CRP, which are now being taken up by government
 agencies in Tunisia for sustainable management of the restored rangeland
 sites. Furthermore, 2 ISI papers were published in 2020 related to rangeland
 revegetation and governance.
gender_justification: we have not yet targeted gender
youth_justification: we have not yet targeted youth
capdev_justification: training partners e.g. in SRM is a significant part of the process.
climate_justification: SRM is a tool to build adaptive capacity to climate change

outcome_sumary: We continued to promote the rangelands agenda in the Global Landscapes Forum.  We promote Participatory Rangeland Management (PRM) through the Rangelands Initiative
milestone_evidence: We published a paper on policy engagement about rangeland management in Tunisia, a blog about Participatory Rangeland Management, a briefing paper that summarizes CGIAR contributions to rangeland governance, and guidelines on PRM. We also made a film documenting land use planning for rangelands in Tanzania.
gender_justification: We have developed a toolkit on gender and pastoralism.
capdev_justification: we do a lot of trainings on rangeland management, land use planning.
climate_justification: Climate change is not the focus.

outcome_sumary: An event was organized on rangelands advocacy and a study was completed on the feasibility of Index Based Livestock Insurance (IBLI).
milestone_evidence: A study was published on expanding IBLI in Ethiopia. Feasibility study reports for Senegal, Niger, Mali and Burkina Faso are being finalized with the World Bank and the feasibility assessment process is underway in Sudan. Delays were caused both by the COVID-19 pandemic and issues with remittance of donor funding.
gender_justification: Not relevant
capdev_justification: We train stakeholders on the feasibility of IBLI.
climate_justification: IBLI is a climate risk management tool.

outcome_sumary: An event was organized on rangelands advocacy and a study was completed on the feasibility of Index Based Livestock Insurance (IBLI).
milestone_evidence: We published a paper on achieving greenhouse gas emission reduction targets in the livestock sector of Latin America.
gender_justification: not relevant
capdev_justification: not relevant
climate_justification: All about GHG emissoins.

outcome_sumary:
Outcome 5.1 on
analyses to guide livestock related priority setting, investment and policy
development – two Livestock Master Plans (LMPs) were started (Odisha and The Gambia) and the Kenya LMP was
initiated. ILRI engagement in the United Nations Food Systems Summit (UNFSS) started early to ensure that the
contribution of livestock in sustainable food systems is well recognized.
milestone_evidence:
Two Livestock Master Plans (LMPs) were started in 2020,
in The Gambia and Odisha (India), while training was conducted to facilitate
development of a LMP in Kenya (to start in 2021). Partners in the LMP work included CIRAD and FAO, plus national ministries in the countries of implementation.

outcome_sumary:
Outcome 5.5 on nutrition sensitive livestock
interventions- The Rwanda National
Early Childhood Development Program revised its national Maternal Infant and Young Child Nutrition (MIYCN) counselling
cards and adopted one of the Feed the Future Innovation Lab for Livestock Systems (LSIL) nutrition project intervention cards for
their own use. A follow up project “Engaging men in supporting maternal and
child consumption of milk and other animal source foods in Rwanda’ was approved
by the LSIL as a follow up of the Rwanda Reach nutrition project.
milestone_evidence: For the past four years, in partnership with government departments in health, education and agriculture, the Accelerated Value Chain Development (AVCD) project has been supporting agri-nutrition training by community health volunteers (CHVs) in communities in Garissa, Isiolo, Marsabit, Turkana and Wajir counties of Kenya. The CHVs have passed on messages to mothers and caregivers about the value of consuming nutritious food and promoting dietary diversity to reach households with children below 2 years of age. These efforts have created public awareness on the nutrition value of diverse, safe and nutritious foods that include leafy green vegetables, fruits, tubers, nuts, grains and animal products, enabling community members to make informed choices on their food consumption to cover their nutritional needs. Through this work, community ownership and sustainability of agri-nutritional interventions has increased.
gender_justification: Training specifically targets women as children's care givers.
capdev_justification: This intervention is a nutrition education intervention targeting women, thus capacity building is at the core of the work.
climate_justification: none

comprehensive review on maize lethal necrosis (MLN) management was published in the journal Virus

outcome_sumary:
a) 
 A total of 48 improved MAIZE
 varieties with farmer-preferred traits have been released by public/private
 sector partners in sub-Saharan Africa (28), Asia (10) and Latin America (10).
 
 b) 
 Three FAW-tolerant improved maize
 hybrids developed by CIMMYT have been announced to the partners in Dec 2020.
 c) 
 Certified seed production and

 5.5 million ha, and benefiting about 9.4 million households (64.8 million
 people).
 

Increased deployment both in SSA (STMA- and FAW-driven) and S Asia (HTMA-driven).

Tegbaru A et al. (2020). Addressing
gendered varietal and trait preferences in West African maize. World
Development Perspectives 20, 100268.

b) 
Teklewold et al. (2020) What
explains the gender differences in the adoption of multiple maize varieties?
Empirical evidence from Uganda and Tanzania. World Development Perspectives,
2020, 18, 100206.
gender_justification: gendered impact pathways to improved technology combinations; gender-preferred traits as part of new variety
capdev_justification: gender research mainstreaming among CGIAR scientists

outcome_sumary: As of 2020, 108 organizations in 56 countries use Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index-derived products. In Uganda, researchers developed videos for extension campaigns to increase women’s empowerment in agriculture. In Southeast Asia, a guidance note was developed on gender inclusive agro-advisory services. Guidelines on collecting gender-sensitive measures of freedom of movement in agricultural value chains were piloted in Benin and Malawi. Researchers published findings from using mobile phone data and phone surveys to predict women's economic empowerment in Uganda. A brief on methods for measuring women’s empowerment was disseminated. Eight blog posts were published on the PIM EnGendering Data blog.
milestone_evidence: As of 2020, 108 organizations in 56 countries are using Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index-derived products. In Uganda, researchers developed videos for extension campaigns to increase women’s empowerment in agriculture. In Southeast Asia, a guidance note was developed on gender inclusive agro-advisory services. Guidelines on collecting gender-sensitive measures of freedom of movement in agricultural value chains were piloted in Benin and Malawi. Researchers published findings from using mobile phone data and phone surveys to train machine learning models to predict women's economic empowerment in Uganda. A brief on methods for measuring women’s empowerment was disseminated. A researcher from Central Asia came to IFPRI to collaborate on gender research. Eight blog posts were published on the PIM EnGendering Data blog. A chapter on concepts, frameworks and tools on gender dynamics in agricultural value chains was published in the Routledge Handbook of Gender and Agriculture, which targets young professionals.
gender_justification: Milestone focused on gender research.
capdev_justification: Milestone focused on capacity building.
climate_justification: N/A

contributed to the development of the policy’s components on training of
agricultural officers to address gender issues in agriculture; mainstreaming
attention to gender in agricultural extension and climate change adaptation and
mitigation efforts; empowering women through building skills of women’s groups
on financial management, and monitoring and evaluating implementation of the
policy and assessing the differential impacts of projects and interventions on
women and men.
gender_justification: Milestone focused on gender research.
capdev_justification: The dissemination of policy lessons from gender research builds the capacity of policy makers.
climate_justification: N/A
