outcome_sumary:
Researchers from Flagship 3 generated new evidence that helped to significantly change the donor landscape and key food safety actors have changed their
priorities. In 2020, researchers produced key reports for the African Union,
Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa and the United Nations Environment Programme, and other agencies in
response to growing demand for food safety evidence. The 2020 milestones describe in more detail how key food safety evidence users are becoming aware of and using A4NH evidence related to food safety in informal markets (e.g., USAID, Ministry of Health of Kenya) and Aflasafe (10 countries in Africa).
milestone_evidence: A mix of governmental and intergovernmental agencies that adapted and/or used A4NH evidence in 2020 include (1) the United Nations Environment Programme; (2) the Ministry of Health of Kenya, which co-designed an aflatoxin surveillance plan that includes informally milled maize with researchers from IFPRI (relevant links to evidence will not be available until 2021); (3) the African Union's Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Programme (CAADP), which is using the Africa Food Safety Index as part of their biennial review and ILRI's research on AFSI validation; and (4) the Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA), which included practical recommendations for decisionmakers on how they can better provide support to improve food safety in their 2020 Status Report, which included evidence-based advice from ILRI research on food safety and public health implications of growing urban food markets (Chapter 5).
gender_justification: Female traders were targeted, but gender was not an explicit part of the evidence or advice.
youth_justification: Youth were not targeted specifically as part of the evidence or advice.
capdev_justification: Building capacity of food safety actors to use evidence and advice was a significant aspect of this milestone.
climate_justification: Climate change was not the main focus of the evidence or advice.

outcome_sumary:
Researchers from Flagship 3 generated new evidence that helped to significantly change the donor landscape and key food safety actors have changed their
priorities. In 2020, researchers produced key reports for the African Union,
Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa and the United Nations Environment Programme, and other agencies in
response to growing demand for food safety evidence. The 2020 milestones describe in more detail how key food safety evidence users are becoming aware of and using A4NH evidence related to food safety in informal markets (e.g., USAID, Ministry of Health of Kenya) and Aflasafe (10 countries in Africa).
milestone_evidence: To date, ten African countries - Burkina Faso, The Gambia, Ghana, Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Nigeria, Senegal, Tanzania, and Zambia - have Aflasafe products registered for use in maize; nine countries for use in groundnut; and in Ghana, for use in sorghum. In 2020, two more Aflasafe products were registered, for use in Malawi.
gender_justification: Production registration information was limited to technical efficacy and changes in fungus populations in short term
youth_justification: Production registration information was limited to technical efficacy and changes in fungus populations in short term
capdev_justification: IITA conducts field efficacy trials of Aflasafe alongside national partners, building research capacity. The trials are an important part of the process to prepare Aflasafe products for registration.
climate_justification: Production registration information was limited to technical efficacy and changes in fungus populations in short term

outcome_sumary:
Researchers from Flagship 3 generated new evidence that helped to significantly change the donor landscape and key food safety actors have changed their
priorities. In 2020, researchers produced key reports for the African Union,
Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa and the United Nations Environment Programme, and other agencies in
response to growing demand for food safety evidence. The 2020 milestones describe in more detail how key food safety evidence users are becoming aware of and using A4NH evidence related to food safety in informal markets (e.g., USAID, Ministry of Health of Kenya) and Aflasafe (10 countries in Africa).
milestone_evidence: Funded by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), the Feed the Future Innovation Lab for Food Safety (Food Safety Innovation Lab) is jointly managed by Purdue and Cornell Universities. The Lab leverages extensive experience in international food safety research, education, and extension to develop and manage a portfolio of food safety and capacity development projects to meet four objectives: (1) Increasing awareness of food safety; (2) Enhancing capacity to conduct food safety research; (3) Developing policies that enable conditions for food safety research, translation, and practice (4) Accelerating translational research technologies and practices for households, communities, and the food industry. As has been reported before to CGIAR, a white paper authored by a CGIAR researcher was catalytic in the motivation and design for the Innovation Lab. CGIAR researchers from ILRI are leading several projects funded through the Innovation Lab alongside local partners. For example, ILRI is leading a situational analysis and review of investments in food safety in five East Africa Community (EAC) member countries. This analysis documents existing policy and regulatory frameworks, available data on major foodborne diseases associated with livestock, fruits, and vegetables, and current stakeholder awareness of food safety in these food industry sectors.
gender_justification: Empowering women, youth, and other marginalized groups is one of the global themes of the Innovation Lab, in particular, to Increasing women’s ability to influence food safety, nutrition, and hygiene decision-making in households, communities, and societies.
youth_justification: Empowering women, youth, and other marginalized groups is one of the global themes of the Innovation Lab, in particular, Engaging youth in food safety awareness and outreach programs
capdev_justification: Developing human and institutional capacity is one of the global themes of the Innovation Lab
climate_justification: Addressing risks related to climate change is not a particular focus of the Food Safety Innovation Lab.

outcome_sumary: In 2020, A4NH researchers continued testing and scaling food safety interventions in six countries, which included engaging stakeholders applying the ‘three-legged stool’ approach: (1) training and technologies, which include training, awareness raising and simple technologies; (2) the enabling environment, meaning that regulatory authorities have to be on board with the intervention and there has to be some mechanism for institutionalization and a means of quality assurance; and (3) motivation and incentives, which are essential but very context specific. The approach has potential to improve food safety at scale, which to date, is most advanced in Vietnam, Cambodia and India.
milestone_evidence: The two new value chains are in Nigeria and in Mali. In Nigeria, ILRI is a partner in EatSafe: Evidence & Action Towards Safe Food, a five-year project of Feed the Future, which is implementing and testing interventions to substantially improve food safety, working with vendors and creating consumer demand for safe nutritious foods. The interventions are gender-sensitive and developed based on existing evidence and the generation of new knowledge on what influences food safety in informal markets. In Mali, ILRI will work in 20 selected villages of the Ségou region to pilot an innovative water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) model that builds upon a community-led total sanitation approach through the addition of animal waste management strategies. The aim is to is to improve the health status of community members in rural, underserved areas.
gender_justification: The pilots were not yet fully designed in 2020, but the one in Nigeria will be gender-sensitive.
youth_justification: The pilots were not yet fully designed in 2020. Youth is not expected to be a central focus.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is not the main focus of this stage of the research, but there may be some components later on.
climate_justification: Climate change is not specifically targeted in either of these pilots

outcome_sumary: In 2020, A4NH researchers continued testing and scaling food safety interventions in six countries, which included engaging stakeholders applying the ‘three-legged stool’ approach: (1) training and technologies, which include training, awareness raising and simple technologies; (2) the enabling environment, meaning that regulatory authorities have to be on board with the intervention and there has to be some mechanism for institutionalization and a means of quality assurance; and (3) motivation and incentives, which are essential but very context specific. The approach has potential to improve food safety at scale, which to date, is most advanced in Vietnam, Cambodia and India.
milestone_evidence: Milestone was achieved in two value chains (dairy and pork) but in only one country (India), not in four. The World Bank and the Government of Assam in India are scaling a food safety intervention designed and tested by ILRI in informal dairy value chains in 16 districts and in informal pork value chains in 13 districts, expected to benefit millions of consumers. The OICR provides more detail. In 2020, pilots with pork slaughterhouses (Vietnam) and pork sellers in traditional markets (Cambodia) were completed, but it is still too early to say how policymakers/regulators are using the evidence. Evidence generation through pilots of different versions of the "three-legged stool" approach in six value chains in four countries in Africa are ongoing so recommendations are not yet available nor are they expected to be before A4NH ends. An assessment on how policy innovations linked to ILRI's "three-legged stool approach" that has been trialed in dairy value chains in three countries worked, and why they struggled to continue beyond a pilot phase in some countries has not been completed. The first step, a literature review, was completed. The full report is expected in 2021 with the synthesis completed after A4NH ends.
gender_justification: The project in Assam intends to address equity, by increasing participation of women and reducing geographical barriers. Prior research and experience showed that women can spare only about 3 hours on each day during 11.00 am-2.00 pm after sending their children to school and before they return from school. Also, they can spare that time without affecting other daily household works. Therefore, training programs have been designed to not exceed 3 hours during mid-day. To increase access to training, all training will be delivered at the village at a preferred venue selected by the trainees.
youth_justification: Youth is not an explicit part of any of the food safety recommendations.
capdev_justification: Training dairy and pork value chain actors, in particular, is a central part of the intervention package that the Government of Assam is implementing.
climate_justification: There was no systematic inclusion of climate issues in the recommendations.

outcome_sumary:
The global pandemic prevented the full achievement of 2020 targets for Aflasafe coverage, which is described in more detail under the relevant milestone. However, targets for the other milestones were exceeded. Now Aflasafe is available at 92 distribution points across nine countries (in 2019, it was 30 distribution points across seven countries). In addition, IITA shared lessons learned from its 5-phased approach and prepared four guides on implementing the business development
strategy. A willingness-to-pay study on Aflasafe KE01 concluded that increased education efforts through extension services to farmers about aflatoxins is necessary to support adoption.
milestone_evidence: Approximately 380,000 hectares were covered with Aflasafe; target not exceeded due to COVID-19 related challenges. However, more than 250,000 farmers used Aflasafe and more than 600,000 tons of aflatoxin-safe maize and groundnut were produced in 2020, exceeding both of those 2020 targets. These are cumulative values until 2020.
gender_justification: Aflasafe products are developed and promoted for use by all farmers regardless of age, sex, religion, or any other characteristic
youth_justification: Aflasafe products are developed and promoted for use by all farmers regardless of age, sex, religion, or any other characteristic
capdev_justification: Building capacity is a central part of the IITA strategy and this includes enabling the capacity of manufacturers to produce Aflasafe. Trainings are designed to increase capacity of farmers and aggregators on how to use Aflasafe, how and when  to harvest the crops, and how to process them prior to storage.
climate_justification: Aflasafe products are developed using atoxigenic fungi native and adapted to major cropping areas across a country. This results in greater chaces of the technology being effective in a wide range of conditions, including those resulting from climate change.

outcome_sumary:
The global pandemic prevented the full achievement of 2020 targets for Aflasafe coverage, which is described in more detail under the relevant milestone. However, targets for the other milestones were exceeded. Now Aflasafe is available at 92 distribution points across nine countries (in 2019, it was 30 distribution points across seven countries). In addition, IITA shared lessons learned from its 5-phased approach and prepared four guides on implementing the business development
strategy. A willingness-to-pay study on Aflasafe KE01 concluded that increased education efforts through extension services to farmers about aflatoxins is necessary to support adoption.
milestone_evidence: Targets outlined in this milestone were exceeded. To date, three companies have been licensed to manufacture and distribute Aflasafe products in four countries – BAMTAARE Services (Senegal and The Gambia), HarvestField Industries (Nigeria), and A to Z Textile Mills Ltd. (Tanzania). In Kenya, the Kenyan Agricultural and Livestock Research Organization manufactures and distributes Aflasafe KE01. IITA also produces country-specific Aflasafe products at its Ibadan production facility for Nigeria and other countries. Now that production units are being established, distribution networks are following. In 2020, Koppert Biological Systems was licensed to distribute Aflasafe KE01 in Kenya and a private sector consortium was appointed as the local distribution and marketing agent. Now Aflasafe is available at 92 distribution points across nine countries whereas in 2019, it was 30 distribution points across seven countries.
gender_justification: Business plan/commercialization strategies did not include gender analysis
youth_justification: Business plan/commercialization strategies did not include youth analysis or targeting
capdev_justification: Capacity development of manufacturers and distributors is key to design, implement, learn and adapt the manufacturing,  commercialization, and distribution processes and strategies designed by IITA. For example, IITA’s support includes training the technical and sales staff on the integrity of the technology to increase their confidence during commercial deployment of this new-to-market product; providing technical assistance for structured awareness-raising and demonstration of the economic and social value of the product to different market segments using business cases; and support in setting up of their factory, quality control and the associated specialized staff training.
climate_justification: Business plan/commercialization strategies did not include explicit consideration of climate change

outcome_sumary: CIRAD, AfricaRice and IRRI assessed the state of rice value chain upgrading in 15 West African countries, which can assist the Coalition for African Rice Development (CARD), value chain actors and policymakers in refining upgrading strategies and policies. AfricaRice initiated rice value chain upgrading studies in Nigeria and Benin, generating opportunities for value chain actors, such as increased efficiency and access to new markets and industry knowledge. IRRI published a book on sustainable rice straw management covering several countries, which can guide policy makers in South and Southeast Asia in their strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution.
milestone_evidence: The state of rice value chain upgrading together with a follow-up paper on COVID-19 policy options was published in Global Food Security. A market study on NERICA rice varieties in Uganda was published in Outlook on Agriculture and a consumer study on rice fragrance in 37 cities across seven countries (Bangladesh, India, Cambodia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam) in British Food Journal. Progress with rice value chain upgrading in Nigeria and Benin was captured in annual and technical reports: AfricaRice, 2020. Upgrading the rice value chain in Nigeria for competitive markets. In: Africa Rice Center (AfricaRice) Annual Report 2019: Toward rice-based food systems transformation in Africa. Abidjan, Côte d’Ivoire: Africa Rice Center, page 12; 2020 Annual Report on the Project "Applying Innovation System Approach in Rice Value Chain Analysis and Development for Competitive Markets in Nigeria"; Fiamohe R., Dedehouanou S. F.A., 2021. Improving local rice market performance and consumers’ welfare through the usage of branded and labelled packaging in Benin. Technical report, January 16, 2021. University of Abomey Calavi (UAC), Benin; IRRI's book on rice straw management was published by Springer and features 11 studies, covering various aspects of the use of rice straw to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
gender_justification: The market intelligence that is collected to inform the upgrading strategies is always sex-disaggregated, which helps making upgrading strategies more gender responsive.
youth_justification: Most process, technology and service upgrading strategies are designed to provide alternative income opportunities to youth.
capdev_justification: All upgrading strategies are fundamentally based on capacity development of private value chain actors and NARES.
climate_justification: Most upgrading technologies are designed with the aim of increasing sustainability and, hence, indirectly mitigating climate change. Intersectoral upgrading strategies (e.g., rice straw value chain upgrading) are specifically designed with the aim of mitigating climate change.

outcome_sumary: Due to donor priorities, activities in Africa shifted to other countries than initially planned. Significant progress was made, thanks to innovation platforms centered around technology upgrading: 1. Innovation platforms in Nigeria successfully connected rice value chain stakeholders to microfinance institutions, generating substantial income increases; 2. The Glazoue Rice Innovation Platform in Benin set up around the GEM parboiling facility in 2015 was able to access substantial financial credit; 3. CEMAs (Mechanized Service Centers) provide mechanized and digital services to producers have attracted sizeable funding and generated substantial income increases of rural youth in Mali and Senegal.
milestone_evidence: Since its establishment, the Goronyo innovation platform has generated US$ 3,800 revenue and US$584 profit in Nigeria. The Bukan-Sidi-Lafia Rice Innovation Platform set up around the GEM parboiling facility in 2016 generated over US$ 181,800 and raised US$ 13,130 among its membership. Within a month, the platform generated over US$ 53,968 through service provision and sale of quality domestic parboiled rice from the new rice mill, with 16 women and 7 men employees. The Promoting Youth Entrepreneurship and Job Creation in West Africa’s Rice Value Chain project PEJERIZ enabled a 23.7% increase in the annual income of rural youth involved in innovative rice development models along the rice value chain in Mali and Senegal. The CEMAs (Mechanized Service Centers), which provide mechanized and digital services to producers, have seen their funding multiplied by 3.5 for Senegal (from EUR 125,770 to EUR 435,187). The CEMAs of Mali received for the first time substantial financing for EUR 126,228. In Benin, the Glazoue Rice Innovation Platform attracted a total credit of US$ 380,164 between 2017 and 2020.
gender_justification: Improved parboiling is specifically designed to improve women's welfare.
youth_justification: Involvement of youth is an important part of the development and piloting of improved parboiling technologies.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is at the core of the introduction of the improved parboiler.
climate_justification: Improved parboiling technologies use rice husk instead of wood, which contributes to climate change mitigation.

outcome_sumary: IRRI conducted research on post-harvest losses and carbon footprint in intensive lowland rice production in Myanmar. Despite using additional energy for machine manufacturing and fuel consumption, the mechanized practices significantly reduced postharvest losses. AfricaRice established a processing facility for the Goronyo Rice Innovation Platform, including ASI thresher-cleaner, Satake SB10 mill, destoner, rice grader, GEM (Grain quality enhancer, Energy-efficient and durable Material) and mini-GEM parboiling equipment, drying and storage space. The Glazoue Rice Innovation Platform set up around the GEM parboiling facility in 2015 in Benin has made significant progress in upgrading along the value chain trajectory.
milestone_evidence: IRRI published research findings in Scientific Reports on post-harvest losses and carbon footprint in Myanmar. The article demonstrates that mechanized practices increased net income by 30-50% compared with traditional practices. Despite using additional energy for machine manufacturing and fuel consumption, the mechanized practices significantly reduced postharvest losses and did not increase the total life-cycle energy and greenhouse gas emissions. Reducing rice postharvest losses is one of the major achievements of the Vietnam Sustainable Agriculture Transformation Project (VnSAT), 2017-2020. IRRI’s contribution over the past 4 years has helped increase the productivity and profitability of Vietnam’s farmer associations” said MARD Deputy Minister Dr. Le Quoc Doanh in 15 Dec 2020. The information is featured in a news article. Since its establishment, the Goronyo Rice Innovation Platform has processed around 23 tons of paddy each month, generating US$ 3,800 revenue and US$ 584 profit. A complete switch from wood to rice husk as fuel has saved an estimated $30–40 per ton of rice that would otherwise be spent on wood. In Benin, the Glazoue Rice Innovation Platform set up around the GEM parboiling facility has made significant upgrading along the value chain trajectory. The progress is captured in annual reports and a video.
gender_justification: Improved parboiling is specifically designed to improve women's welfare.
youth_justification: Involvement of youth is an important part of the development and piloting of improved parboiling technologies.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is at the core of the Goronyo Rice Innovation Platform.
climate_justification: Research contributing to loss reduction indirectly contributes to climate change mitigation as it directly contributes to increased efficiency of scarce input use.

outcome_sumary: IRRI published a book on rice by-product development in several countries and a database capturing the diversity of food choice in India, which can help value chain actors introduce novel products in Indian diets. AfricaRice demonstrated the methodology for the production of fortified and non-fortified rice-based products, which can be a reliable vehicle for delivering micronutrients to vulnerable populations. JIRCAS (Japan International Research Center for Agricultural Sciences)' plan to visit AfricaRice to check pilot-scale pop-rice equipment was cancelled due to covid-19 travel bans. JIRCAS concentrated only physicochemical analysis of pop-rice starch and their Thai partners conducted product development for pop-rice.
milestone_evidence: Although good progress was made by IRRI and AfricaRice, JIRCAS had to move some deliverables to 2021 due to covid-19 related restrictions. IRRI's book on rice straw management features several reports on successful rice by-product development in multiple countries in Asia. A database of Indian diets, which can be used for product development and value addition to products by value chain actors was published in the International Journal of Gastronomy and Food Science and Data in Brief. AfricaRice's study on fortified and non-fortified rice-based products was published in Food Science and Nutrition.
gender_justification: The research on food choice has a strong gender component. Sex-disaggregated data is collected and women's empowerment is measures as an important driver of healthy diets.
youth_justification: This line of research does not particularly target youth.
capdev_justification: Not particularly addressed in this milestone in 2020, though capacity development is an essential objective of our food choice research and the development of novel rice products.
climate_justification: Contribution to climate mitigation is part of planetary health diets, which is captured in our food choice research.

outcome_sumary: A USD 1.2bn investment by the Philippines in climate-smart rice production targeted 1.89 million rice farmers in 57 provinces. Vietnam used Climate-Smart Maps and Adaptation Plans (CS-MAP) to manage salinity intrusion in more than 800,000ha and 500,000ha respectively in the last two years. Honduras, Guatemala and Consejo Agropecuario Centroamericano (CAC) co-develop with CCAFS an implementation roadmap of a CSA regional strategy, specifically its gender component. CCAFS informed the National Climate Change Plan for Agriculture in Colombia and a GCF proposal in Tanzania. Two local and three county-level adaptation plans were developed in Guatemala and Kenya respectively.
milestone_evidence: Technical assistance provided to the Philippines Department of Agriculture developed manuals and platforms for the extension service to push for climate-resilient rice production; Memorandum on the Implementation of a Unified School-on-the-Air (SOA) Program on Smart-Rice Agriculture in the Philippines.Honduras and Guatemala's Ministries of Agriculture and the Central America Agricultural Council supported by CCAFS, co-develop a road map to implement the CSA regional strategy and specifically its gender component.In Colombia, CCAFS informed the National Climate Change Plan for Agriculture.In Vietnam CCAFS synthesized CSA lessons for mainstreaming CSA within the National Target Program on New Rural Development2021-2030 Strategy, establishing multi-level coordination mechanism for its implementation.Two local adaptation plans - including CSA - developed in Guatemala(Santa Cruz and Isidro).In Kenya data and analyses from the Evidence for Resilient Agriculture (ERA) meta-dataset supported government design of 3 county-level adaptation plans and informed the design of a Green Climate Fund (GCF) project led by IUCN and the Tanzanian Government.The Vietnamese Department of Crop Production of the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development scaled the implementation of the Climate-Smart Mapping and Adaptation Planning (CS-MAP) to major rice-producing provinces of South Central Coast and Red River Delta and Northern Midlands.
gender_justification: The roadmap developed in Central America specifically supports the implementation of the gender dimension of the CSA strategy for the SICA region.
capdev_justification: The development of the road map in central america as well as the scaling of the Climate-Smart Mapping and Adaptation Planning for ice in Vietnam were based on strong capacity buildign activities with the users and key implementing institutions; the development of subnational adaptation plans in Kenya involved trainings and capacity building also related to NDC implementation
climate_justification: All the national/sub-national plans and interventions developped with the support of CAFS sceince target increasing climate resilience

outcome_sumary: WFP is using the CCAFS Transformation Imitative to guide food systems thinking and programming. African Improved Foods uses CCAFS science to invest $130M-205M in climate-smart and nutrition-sensitive value chains Ethiopia and Kenya. CCAFS wrote the Agriculture and Food Security Sector Guidance Document of the GCF investment strategy. Ethiopia starts constructing a drinking water dam to benefit 100,000 people based on CCAFS water harvesting insights. In Ghana the private sector and CCAFS examine challenges faced by women, men and youth in the context of climate smart cocoa adoption, its remedies and clear pathways for companies to incorporate the Gender Transformative Approach (GTA).
milestone_evidence: Subnational:* In India an impact assessment study was carried out across three states focused on CSV/CSA scaling activities (USAID project) using a phone-based end-line survey. The survey was conducted with 195 project farmers capturing experiences across all categories (CSA portfolio). Convergence and the intended spillover effects were also highlighted and the likelihood of the program outcomes to persist in the near future.Private sector :* In Ghana: Climate-smart cocoa adoptionstudy carried out across two climatic impact zones (Cope and Adjust) to i) examine the key challenges faced by women, men and youth in the context of CSC adoption, ii) propose and give clear feasible remedies for the challenges identified by the various social groups with a special focus on women and youth and iii) develop clear pathways on how companies can incorporate the Gender Transformative Approach (GTA) in their programs. Results showed interesting insights on adoption rates amongst men and women. (IITA and Rainforest Alliance).* The World Business Council for Sustainable Development develops new metrics for climate-smart agriculture to guide global corporate productivity, resilience and mitigation commitments for 2030.
gender_justification: *Impacts assessment study in India adopted a gender inclusive approach that included promotion of women friendly CSA technologies and practices, training and capacity building exercises, and promotion of entrepreneurial activities. A key outcome of these efforts has been improved agency, and community participation for these women farmers.  In Ghana, the Cliamte-Smart cocoa adoption study had also a specific focus on gender and led to recommendations for Gender TRansformative Approaches for companies
youth_justification: In Ghana, the Cliamte-Smart cocoa adoption study had also a specific focus on gender and intergenerational aspects
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: The core work focuses on the alignment of climate-smart practices and portfolios to increase farmers adaptive capacity and decrease their vulnerabilities to climate risks.

outcome_sumary: WFP is using the CCAFS Transformation Imitative to guide food systems thinking and programming. African Improved Foods uses CCAFS science to invest $130M-205M in climate-smart and nutrition-sensitive value chains Ethiopia and Kenya. CCAFS wrote the Agriculture and Food Security Sector Guidance Document of the GCF investment strategy. Ethiopia starts constructing a drinking water dam to benefit 100,000 people based on CCAFS water harvesting insights. In Ghana the private sector and CCAFS examine challenges faced by women, men and youth in the context of climate smart cocoa adoption, its remedies and clear pathways for companies to incorporate the Gender Transformative Approach (GTA).
milestone_evidence: Policy document and outreach materials detailing the use of the stepwise investment approach for climate-smart cocoa adoption shared with private companies. Report on Gender Transformative Approaches highlighting the challenges and remedies to address emboldened the vulnerable group to adopt CSC.CCAFS-NWO outputs about technical-financial packages enable women farmers and women-led SMEs to invest in CSA.Capacity building training capacity building on needs with respect to implementing NDCs in the agriculture sector across Africa; Specific module delivered on Private sector engagement for NDC implementationTrainer' guide "Eight guide steps for setting up a Climate-Smart Village"Philippine compendium of climate-resilient technologies and approaches launched by the Southeast Asian Regional Center for Graduate Study and Research in Agriculture and CCAFS; Official manual of operationsfor the national schools-on-the-air on smart-rice agriculture developed by the Philippine Department of Agriculture and the Philippine Federation of Rural Broadcasters, with support from CCAFS.GSI provided technical advice on climate-resilient approaches to gender equality, transformation and increased adaptive capacity to IDRC'scohort of gender and climate change projects; Contributions to strengthened language on gender and social inclusion in the Theory of Change of the IDRC-FCDO Climate and Resilience Framework Programme (CLARE), approximately $150 million.
gender_justification: Policy guidance to cocoa companies in ghana with strong Gender focus; CCAFS outputs on financial packages for CSA scaling target women and women led SMEs; Gender focused programatic support to IDRC portfolio of projects
youth_justification: Incorporated into Policy guidance for cocoa companies; target users of CCAFS capacity buildign/outreach products
capdev_justification: Main focus of CCAFS outputs that support guidance for the public and private sector
climate_justification: At the core of the CSA adoption/investment targets supported by the CCAFS products

outcome_sumary: The Latin American Fund for Irrigated Rice (FLAR) and CGIAR research program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) developed the Rice Observatory for Latin America (LAM) to inform digital climate-smart agriculture (CSA) decisions across >2.000.000 hectares. Improved rice varieties adopted by 40% of Colombian rice farmers (of which 57% used agro-climatic forecasts) combined with technical assistance increased yield to 0.6 tons/ha. The climate-smart village (CSV) approach is being scaled with public and private investments in India (42m USD) and Nepal (5.5m USD). World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD) launched new metrics for climate CSA, providing guidance to corporate value chains on how to reduce greenhouse by 50%, while making 50% more nutritious food available to reach goals for 2030.
milestone_evidence: * In Ghana total of 40 Farmer Field School (FFS) supported by companies (Cargill, PBC) and NGOs ( Agro Eco) used to support training of cocoa farmers in Climate-smart cocoa and generating high-quality CBA data to support the development of business models and novel financial packages* In Kenya CCAFS is working with partners to integrate climate resilienceinto the FFS methodology, to promote climate-resilient agricultural practices in selected value chains and agribusinesses; climate-resilient FFS Guidebook and associated crop-specific curricula published. This is linked to a five-year Climate Resilient Agribusiness for Tomorrow (CRAFT) project funded by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the Netherlands, and implemented by the Netherlands Development Organization (SNV) in partnership with CCAFS, WUR, Agriterra and Rabo Partnerships.*The new modelimplemented by CARE in Iringa, Tanzania, and tested by the CSASuPER project bundles villages savings and loan associations (VSLAs), which provide agricultural finance with farmer field business schools (FFBSs), which deliver agricultural knowledge to groups of small-scale women farmers. VSLAs are being supported with climate risk profiling and CBA analyses through the associated farmer Field Schools.
gender_justification: Villages savings and loan associations (VSLAs) deliver agricultural knowledge to groups of small-scale women farmers. The model also follows sustainable, productive, profitable, equitable and resilient, so-called SuPER, farming principles. These principles guarantee that women are not excluded and receive equal opportunities to adopt those practices. FFS in Ghana involve women's and youth groups.
youth_justification: FFS in Ghana involve women's and youth groups.
capdev_justification: The key aim of the Farmers sield scholls is to share CSA knowledge and increase agronomic and agribusiness related skills
climate_justification: CSA and increasing cliamte adaptive capacitya nd resilience is at the core of the FFS

outcome_sumary: The Latin American Fund for Irrigated Rice (FLAR) and CGIAR research program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) developed the Rice Observatory for Latin America (LAM) to inform digital climate-smart agriculture (CSA) decisions across >2.000.000 hectares. Improved rice varieties adopted by 40% of Colombian rice farmers (of which 57% used agro-climatic forecasts) combined with technical assistance increased yield to 0.6 tons/ha. The climate-smart village (CSV) approach is being scaled with public and private investments in India (42m USD) and Nepal (5.5m USD). World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD) launched new metrics for climate CSA, providing guidance to corporate value chains on how to reduce greenhouse by 50%, while making 50% more nutritious food available to reach goals for 2030.
milestone_evidence: This stream of work evolved towards a focus on scaling sustainable finance. One of the 11 priority actions for transforming food systems outlined in the initiative's flagship report, launched in June 2020. Online session “Unlocking billions in sustainable finance"(https://ccafs.cgiar.org/es/node/85553) part of the “ A New Era for Food and Climate” virtual event on 25 June.* Strategic partnership established:- with responsAbility Investments AG (rA)to support the design of Climate-Smart Food Systems Funds;- with Tiserin Capital to help set up a USD50Mio impact investment fund focused on climate adaptation for SMES in East Africa.* Scoping studies for DSM: Climate-Smart and Nutrition-Sensitive Investment Opportunities in Ethiopia and Kenya* Support provided by CCAFS to:- the Asian Development Bankto design an innovative blueprint investment model that could help mobilize private sector investment in sustainable rangeland management in Mongolia.- USAID in the design of a “Sustainable Land Use Finance” project in Ghana (USD1.5Mio). Specifically, the sustainable finance component will develop a blueprint investment model to avoid deforestation in supply chains.* Participation in a global E&S consultation led by UNEP to help private investors better understand how to integrate social and environmental issues into their investment strategies/impact frameworks.
gender_justification: Gender-focused financial mechanisms identified as an essencial component of the climate finance agenda
capdev_justification: Delivery of a training program (modules on climate finance and private sector engagement) for two different German Corporation for International Corporation (GIZ) programs (CAADP-Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Programme and SV NAREN) to support African Group of Negotiators expert support system (AGNES) and The African Union Development Agency-NEPAD to implement National Determined Contributions (NDCs) in Africa.
climate_justification: At the core of the sustainable finance work

outcome_sumary: The Latin American Fund for Irrigated Rice (FLAR) and CGIAR research program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) developed the Rice Observatory for Latin America (LAM) to inform digital climate-smart agriculture (CSA) decisions across >2.000.000 hectares. Improved rice varieties adopted by 40% of Colombian rice farmers (of which 57% used agro-climatic forecasts) combined with technical assistance increased yield to 0.6 tons/ha. The climate-smart village (CSV) approach is being scaled with public and private investments in India (42m USD) and Nepal (5.5m USD). World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD) launched new metrics for climate CSA, providing guidance to corporate value chains on how to reduce greenhouse by 50%, while making 50% more nutritious food available to reach goals for 2030.
milestone_evidence: * Business model testingand advisory with Root Capital and Sustainable Food Lab to apply the Terra-i tool to their coffee portfolio, both in Honduras and more broadly. Root Capital seek a tool that will allow them (over time) to conduct a global scan of coffee-driven deforestation risk and identify “hotspots” within their portfolio requiring deeper diligence.Key research outputs:* A framework for establishing the business casefor specific farm-level agricultural technologies developed based onexisting data from Evidence for Resilient Agriculture (ERA). It focuses on the costs, benefits, and risks of adoption of CSA by smallholder farmers; Two case studies in Kenya and Malawi to highlight opportunities, challenges, and lessons learned from building business cases for CSA. These give potential investors the tools to screen and select appropriate technologies and help de-risk investmentswhere data are few and far between.* Inclusive and adaptive business models for climate-smart value creation: Paper seeking to operationalise and to assess the inclusiveness of a business model partnerships in terms of its organisational structures. This empirical paper draws from Vuna-supported business models involving women and youth smallholder farmers.
gender_justification: Inclusive Business models for climate-smart value creation
youth_justification: Empirical paper on inclusiveness of business models  (involving women and youth smallholder farmers.)
capdev_justification: outputs aiming to support/increse capacities on CSA business cases development
climate_justification: main aim of the climates-smart business models

outcome_sumary: 75 CSA practices and technologies where implemented across 8 Climate Smart Villages (CSVs) in LAM, EA, WA and SEA, 46 with mitigation potential and 13 were evaluated for their effects on the three CSA pillars and on gender related dimensions (participation in decision making; participation in CSA implementation; access/control over resources; labor).CSA monitoring Framework was implemented in 4 CSV (Honduras, Guatemala, Senegal and Ethiopia). The top practices most implemented were: Improved Cookstoves (7700 HH); Improved Seeds (2385 HH) andFarmer Managed Natural Regeneration (1448 HH). Results are published online and data is archived in DATAVERSE.
milestone_evidence: * 2019- 2020 Inventories of the CSA practices implemented across the CSVs* Mapping of the CSV where CSA practice testing is linked to climate services delivery.* Documentation of CSA options evaluated across CSVs (2017-2020).* CSV-specific online pages developed displaying the monitoring results in 10 countries, including adoption trends and (gender-disaggregated) perceived effects on households, livelihoods, food security and reduced vulnerability to climate shocks.* Analyses published (Senegal and Ethiopia)* Synthesis of temporal and spatial trends over a 2-years implementation in Central America.* Databases/files published in DataVerse.* The Gender Empowerment Index for CSVs developed to measure gender impacts of CSA approaches. Development of gender indicators for monitoring and evaluation of CSA based on experience in MAP-Norway.* MBs thesis evaluated the productive performance and contribution to households' incomes of improved small ruminants in Kenya's CSV.* In Bangladesh, India and Nepal: season-wise crop management, soil and environmental data collected and analyzed.* In Colombia and Peru: assessment of environmental footprint for maize and rice (905.15 and 2080 tons CO2 equivalent/hectare, respectively). Suitable and resource-efficient nutrient management practices identified in Colombia for an optimized application (can reduce by 15% GHG emissions, without affecting crop-yields).
gender_justification: Gender dimensions assessed through the CSA monitoring framework; The framework indicators can be used as a tool to understand the entry points to achieve gender equality as an important aspect in the adoption of climate-smart agriculture practices (CSAPs).
capdev_justification: CSA monitoring; Identification of promisong options for key value chains incorporate a strong capacity building compoenent
climate_justification: main scope

outcome_sumary: 75 CSA practices and technologies where implemented across 8 Climate Smart Villages (CSVs) in LAM, EA, WA and SEA, 46 with mitigation potential and 13 were evaluated for their effects on the three CSA pillars and on gender related dimensions (participation in decision making; participation in CSA implementation; access/control over resources; labor).CSA monitoring Framework was implemented in 4 CSV (Honduras, Guatemala, Senegal and Ethiopia). The top practices most implemented were: Improved Cookstoves (7700 HH); Improved Seeds (2385 HH) andFarmer Managed Natural Regeneration (1448 HH). Results are published online and data is archived in DATAVERSE.
milestone_evidence: *Info note on lessons learned from a local 17-year initiative on cassava-based soil conservation measure on sloping land as a CSA practice in Van Yen District and Yen Bai Province, Vietnam. The recommendations push for institutional level strategies on how this can be replicated in areas with similar biophysical and socio-economic conditions.*Synthesis and key insights from the implementation of the gender sensitive Climate-Smart Agriculture monitoring framework in the Olopa (Guatemala) and Santa Rita (Honduras) climate-smart villages: temporal and spatial dynamics* COVID-19 delayed data collection; new outputs expected in 2021 (CCAFS-EU-IFAD project in EA and WA) focusing on the changes observed accross time in smallholder farmers adaptive capactities accross the WA CSVs (compartison between CCAFS baseline and the CSA monitoring and Midline surveys).
gender_justification: Gender disaggregated analyses undertaken on the perceived effects of CSA and assessment of impact on gender dimensions.
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: core

outcome_sumary: Approximately 4 million farmers and rural households in India and Nepal benefitted from scaling CSA practices and technologies in 2020. Additionally, 4,000 smallholder farmers in Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania have improved livelihoods and strengthened capacity to adapt to climate change. CCAFS and SNV worked with the "Climate Resilient Agribusiness for Tomorrow (CRAFT) to catalyze EUR 34mn in 36 climate-informed business cases, targeting 237,250 smallholder farmers in Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda. CCAFS informed a USD1.2bn investment by the Philippine government in climate-smart rice production, targeting 1.89mn rice farmers in 57 provinces of the country.
milestone_evidence: · Evidence for Resilient Agriculture (ERA) informs more than USD 1 billion in investment plans in Mali, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Burkina Faso and guides evidence-based policy, programming and capacity building in Africa (OICR). Also informed the adaptation portfolio of the Gates Foundation, the design three county adaptation plans in Kenya, the design of a Green Climate Fund (GCF) projects and Government of Tanzania and built capacity for NDC implementation across Africa.* In SA: CCAFS with IWMI and NARS partners developed a web-based tool for technology characterization and suitability mapping for CSA; District-level adaptation plan for resilient farming in the Adilabad district of Telangana, India.* Designing profitable, resource use efficient and environmentally sound cereal based systems for the Western Indo-Gangetic plains* Integrated ecological niche-water balance modeling approach developed and applied in Burkina Faso to evaluate the potential for rice expansion under alternate wetting and drying.* High level Iraqi stakeholders trianed on the assessment of climate vulnerability and identification of optimal adaptation strategies in agriculture and water resources sectors to prepare the BUR to be submitted to UNFCC. * The Gender Empowerment Index for CSVs developed to measure gender impacts of CSA approaches in terms of women and men's empowerment
gender_justification: Gender Empowerment Index
capdev_justification: Training/workshops: * In Kenya, In Burkina Faso (to raise awareness and train the staff of NARS, government officers, national and regional development agencies about the benefits of the technologies).
climate_justification: Core

outcome_sumary: Approximately 4 million farmers and rural households in India and Nepal benefitted from scaling CSA practices and technologies in 2020. Additionally, 4,000 smallholder farmers in Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania have improved livelihoods and strengthened capacity to adapt to climate change. CCAFS and SNV worked with the "Climate Resilient Agribusiness for Tomorrow (CRAFT) to catalyze EUR 34mn in 36 climate-informed business cases, targeting 237,250 smallholder farmers in Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda. CCAFS informed a USD1.2bn investment by the Philippine government in climate-smart rice production, targeting 1.89mn rice farmers in 57 provinces of the country.
milestone_evidence: * In Niger, CSV models adapted from a village-level to a commune-level with the development of local CSA plansin 6 communes. Application of the CSA prioritization tool/scenario process in Mali, Niger, Burkina Faso. Gender profile of CSA in Ghana* In the Philippines, the national school-on-the-air (SOA) protocol developed under the extension service component of RCEF to provide a learning program in rice producing provinces, initially serving 300,000 rice farmer-enrollees within two years.* Support to Agricultural Ministries and national level institutions from Guatemala and Honduras for the implementation of the regional CSA strategy (specifically its gender strategic line)* Capacity building activities and materials shared with main actors of rural development (incl. NARS, technical services, universities, development projects, private sector -bank and insurance, farmers organization, NGOs, collectivities and individual farmers) on climate risk profiling and CSA (in WA), on climate-smart rice cultivation (SEA) on digital CSA (SA and LAM) and on CSA and gender (LAM). In Vietnam assessment study on the use and impact of the training materials on climate-smart rice cultivation (over 12,000 trainings for 17,000 extension staff and 75,800 farmers in 2020).* In Kenya: Training to support development of county level adaptation plans
gender_justification: CSA-gender specific recommendations provided in central america
capdev_justification: Technical assistance provided to the Philippines Department of Agriculture developed manuals and platforms for the extension service to push for climate-resilient rice production,Capacity building activities and materials shared with main actors of rural development (incl. NARS, technical services, universities, development projects, private sector -bank and insurance, farmers organization, NGOs, collectivities and individual farmers) on climate risk profiling and CSA (in WA), on climate-smart rice cultivation (SEA) on digital CSA (SA and LAM) and on CSA and gender (LAM). In Vietnam assessment study on the use and impact of the training materials on climate-smart rice cultivation (over 12,000 trainings for 17,000 extension staff and 75,800 farmers in 2020).   * In Kenya: Training to support development of county level adaptation plans
climate_justification: Main target

outcome_sumary: Two high-value data products were created using GARDIAN's data and CG Labs analytics environment: (1) Climate risk profiles for 16 countries using pre-loaded data, tools, and models in CG Labs; (2) Analysis of fertilizer profitability in Africa using over 200 GARDIAN datasets. Machine learning was employed to create crop yield curves based on fertilizer inputs, and input/output price data used to determine where fertilizer use was profitable. All R scripts developed to clean, process, and standardize datasets are available through GitHub and can be called from CG Labs for reuse or modification by any user.
milestone_evidence: Climate risk profiles for 16 countries were developed by a CCAFS team of researchers using CG Labs for their high-compute needs and analysis. The results are available via a Google Drive, while the team finalizes reports and publications. The assessment of fertilizer profitability for Africa is complete and in review for publication in early 2021. The R scrips used to clean and process the over 200 datasets used in this study are available, and will be available in association with individual datasets in GARDIAN in 2021.
gender_justification: Gender was not an explicit determinant in the questions that generated the data products.
youth_justification: Youth was not an explicit determinant in the questions that generated the data products.
capdev_justification: There was a significant learning component to this work, involving data cleeaning, processing etc. - for the authors and wider community.
climate_justification: The data products focused on climate effects and system intensification.

outcome_sumary: Two high-value data products were created using GARDIAN's data and CG Labs analytics environment: (1) Climate risk profiles for 16 countries using pre-loaded data, tools, and models in CG Labs; (2) Analysis of fertilizer profitability in Africa using over 200 GARDIAN datasets. Machine learning was employed to create crop yield curves based on fertilizer inputs, and input/output price data used to determine where fertilizer use was profitable. All R scripts developed to clean, process, and standardize datasets are available through GitHub and can be called from CG Labs for reuse or modification by any user.
milestone_evidence: The Machine Learning (ML) approaches used in developing climate risk profiles for 16 countries is in the process of being published, as is the assessment of fertilizer profitability for Africa - which is currently in review and should be available as a Nature Food publication in early 2021.
gender_justification: Gender was not an explicit determinant in the questions that required the development of ML approaches.
youth_justification: Youth was not an explicit determinant in the questions that required the development of ML approaches.
capdev_justification: There was a significant learning component to this work for the authors and wider community.
climate_justification: The ML efforts focused on answering questions related to climate effects and system intensification.

outcome_sumary: Two high-value data products were created using GARDIAN's data and CG Labs analytics environment: (1) Climate risk profiles for 16 countries using pre-loaded data, tools, and models in CG Labs; (2) Analysis of fertilizer profitability in Africa using over 200 GARDIAN datasets. Machine learning was employed to create crop yield curves based on fertilizer inputs, and input/output price data used to determine where fertilizer use was profitable. All R scripts developed to clean, process, and standardize datasets are available through GitHub and can be called from CG Labs for reuse or modification by any user.
milestone_evidence: About 200 relevant GARDIAN datasets were cleaned, processed, and standardized, before a machine learning model could be used to generate insight on crop yield response to fertilizer application for different countries. A unique R script was developed to clean, process, and standardize each dataset, with a "mother" script to run them all. All the scripts are available via GitHub and can be called from CG Labs for reuse or modification by any user. Pipelines to three mechanistic crop simulation models have also been made available via CG Labs for easier leveraging: these include R implementations  WOFOST, EcoCrop, and DSSAT.
gender_justification: Gender was not an explicit determinant in this milestone.
youth_justification: Youth was not an explicit determinant in this milestone.
capdev_justification: The data cleaning and processing scripts developed and shared are expected to enhance capacity across stakeholders to manipulate data effectively.
climate_justification: These efforts focused on answering questions related to climate effects and system intensification.

outcome_sumary: GARDIAN (Global Agricultural Research Data Innovation and Acceleration Network) was launched in 2018 to promote discoverability of CGIAR data and publications with tools for data visualization and back-end services to accommodate data privacy, ethics, and clarity on licensing. GARDIAN enhancements for 2020 include: “Collaborative GARDIAN Labs” (CG Labs) offering pre-loaded data and toolsets for analytical, visualization and data insight; a data query and aggregator pilot; secure transfer and sharing of data; and the inclusion of a data management toolkit, including a FAIR data and publications upload workflows. GARDIAN also indexed data from new data sources.
milestone_evidence: GARDIAN's data discovery portal was expanded in 2020 to include data and publications from the World Bank's Living Standards Measurement Survey catalog, and data from the ISRIC Soil Grids database, offering geographic administrative boundary and user-based global visual mapping and download of several soil parameters. Data from the 2017 Spatial Production Allocation Model (SPAM) for crops grown in Africa was also indexed and made similarly visualizable. Lastly, IRRI's Farm Household Survey Database (FHSD) with about 150 datasets was also rendered discoverable via GARDIAN.
gender_justification: Several data assets made discoverable have a gender dimension, and enrich gender research capabilities.
youth_justification: Several data assets made discoverable have a youth dimension, and enrich research capabilities in this area.
capdev_justification: All of the resources included in GARDIAN enhance the ability of CGIAR and other researchers to build their capacity and that of their teams.
climate_justification: Several data assets made discoverable have a climate change focus, and enrich research capabilities in this area.

outcome_sumary: GARDIAN (Global Agricultural Research Data Innovation and Acceleration Network) was launched in 2018 to promote discoverability of CGIAR data and publications with tools for data visualization and back-end services to accommodate data privacy, ethics, and clarity on licensing. GARDIAN enhancements for 2020 include: “Collaborative GARDIAN Labs” (CG Labs) offering pre-loaded data and toolsets for analytical, visualization and data insight; a data query and aggregator pilot; secure transfer and sharing of data; and the inclusion of a data management toolkit, including a FAIR data and publications upload workflows. GARDIAN also indexed data from new data sources.
milestone_evidence: Collaborative GARDIAN Labs (CG Labs) was tested, refined, and made available in the GARDIAN data ecosystem. Users can set up an individual or team work space on CG Labs to collaborate on data processing and analytics, working together on data that is found through GARDIAN or elsewhere, that can be securely exchanged and saved for collaborative processing and analysis via the CG Labs R and Python analytical environment. Tooling includes a workflow to add CG Core metadata, choose licenses, and add ontology terms to describe data, allowing easy data FAIRification. A PII-checker is an automated part of this workflow.
gender_justification: 2020 tooling enhancements enable safer leveraging of sensitive data (including gender data), and enrich gender research capabilities.
youth_justification: 2020 tooling enhancements enable safer leveraging of sensitive data (including about youth in agriculture), and enrich research capabilities in this area.
capdev_justification: CG Labs offers pre-loaded data and tools that enhance the ability of CGIAR and other researchers to build their capacity and that of their teams.
climate_justification: Use cases on 2020 CG Labs enhancements have focused on data science approaches to climate-smart agriculture, and enrich research capabilities in this area.

outcome_sumary: Several webinars and training sessions on the CG Core Metadata Schema v.2.0 were organized and consultations with Gender Platform representatives and CGIAR Metadata Working Group members held to ensure that gender-disaggregated and other data assets were as FAIR as possible. Two new data collection apps were added to the AgroFIMS repertoire in addition to KDSmart: Open Data Kit (ODK) and Field Book, both of them Android-based.
milestone_evidence: Webinars and training sessions on the CG Core Metadata Schema v.2.0 were organized and consultations with Gender Platform representatives and CGIAR Metadata Working Group members held to ensure that gender-disaggregated and other data assets were as FAIR as possible. A session entitled "Gender data: knowledge gaps, research protocols, and improving data systems" was held during the Big Data Platform's 2020 Annual Convention, and highlighted the importance of uisng metadata standards and rich annotation to make data more FAIR.
gender_justification: Consistent use of the CG Core Metadata Schema enables data assets on gender to be more FAIR.
youth_justification: Consistent use of the CG Core Metadata Schema enables data assets on youth in agriculture to be more FAIR.
capdev_justification: Work on the CG Core Metadata Schema focused on ways to improve annotation to enable FAIRer gender data.
climate_justification: Consistent use of the CG Core Metadata Schema enables data assets on climate impacts on agriculture to be more FAIR.

outcome_sumary: Several webinars and training sessions on the CG Core Metadata Schema v.2.0 were organized and consultations with Gender Platform representatives and CGIAR Metadata Working Group members held to ensure that gender-disaggregated and other data assets were as FAIR as possible. Two new data collection apps were added to the AgroFIMS repertoire in addition to KDSmart: Open Data Kit (ODK) and Field Book, both of them Android-based.
milestone_evidence: Two new data collection apps were added to the AgroFIMS repertoire in addition to KDSmart: Open Data Kit (ODK) and Field Book, both of them Android-based. Progress was made in developing AgroFIMS to enable collection of data from agronomic survey-type trials through design and mockups; however, this work will not be moved to development until users from the Excellence in Agronomy Initiative can specify requirements and co-create the tool in 2021 for maximizing success.
gender_justification: The gender dimension is not applicable to development of AgroFIMS.
youth_justification: The youth dimension is not applicable to development of AgroFIMS.
capdev_justification: AgroFIMS helps develop capacity related to the collection of agronomic data that is born FAIR.
climate_justification: The climate change dimension is not applicable to development of AgroFIMS.

outcome_sumary: In 2020 Module 1 continued to develop training materials and guides on achieving and managing FAIR data assets, including licensing, privacy/ethics, and best practices in data management. Center data sprints were encouraged to promote the uploading of well-annotated datasets to repositories. Module 1 also supported several workshops and/or trainings on ways to improve the FAIRness of CGIAR data assets, and continued to work with Centers and stakeholders like the World Bank to incentivize this.
milestone_evidence: Data assets that are interpretable and interoperable for humans and machines are critical to enhance the impact of research in the agricultural domain and to catalyze innovation and transform agricultural research for development. A course entitled "Best Practices for Open, FAIR, and Ethical Data" was made available via the TechChange platform in 2020 with the goal of strengthening capacity in the CGIAR System and beyond to create, manage and share research and development data assets that are not only open (i.e., discoverable and downloadable), but also easily interpretable, interoperable, and reusable. Several webinars were also offered on data management-related topics under the auspices of the Information and Data Management CoP of the Module, other CoPs, and the Platform webinar series.
gender_justification: Capacity development materials addressed making gender data assets more discoverable and actionable, and also ensuring that sensitive information in these assets is appropriately handled and protected.
youth_justification: Capacity development materials addressed making data assets related to youth in agriculture more discoverable and actionable, and also ensuring that sensitive information in these assets is appropriately handled and protected.
capdev_justification: This milestone is specifically focused on enhancing capacity around data management in a variety of ways, for varied stakeholders.
climate_justification: Capacity development materials addressed making agricultural data assets relating to climate change more discoverable and actionable.

milestone_evidence: Two user trainings were held on the FAIRification workflow, involving data managers and information specialists across CGIAR and the World Bank. A training on CG Labs was organized for members of the Community for Spatial Information, consisting of researchers at CGIAR and beyond. A demo and hands-on workshop was organized for data managers and biometricians at ICRISAT on the use of AgroFIMS to collect data that is born-FAIR. Several other AgroFIMS discussions were also organized with project teams at CIMMYT and IITA, and documentation and a video developed to help train users on using AgroFIMS.

climate_justification: Capacity development workshops and trainings addressed making agricultural data assets relating to climate change more discoverable and actionable.

outcome_sumary: CCAFS research and partnerships supported improved nationally determined contributions in at least four countries (Colombia, Ethiopia, Kenya and Vietnam). This included technical advisory capacity, sustainable investment criteria and strategies, and a certification scheme for the scaling of significant mitigation. IRRI research expanded low-emission practices in paddy rice in Vietnam, via extension programs for 929,067 farmers, almost doubling the adoption area of low-emission practices to 163,418 ha and reducing emissions by 1.5 MtCO2-eq, compared to 2019. A paper on the feasibility of large-scale mitigation concluded that more realistic targets are needed that recognize what is feasible, based on current incentives.
milestone_evidence: 1. A working paper on cost of transition to low-emissions dairy: mitigation options and finance in Kenya includes NAMA and LED implementation and finance in Kenya and brief analysis of gender. See https://cgspace.cgiar.org/handle/10568/1105682. CGIAR centers in Vietnam, with CCAFS as the main focal point, helped to translate the country's Nationally Determined Contribution goals into full-pledged LED projects for paddy rice and agroforestry.3. Ambition Meets Reality: Achieving GHG Emission Reduction Targets in the Livestock Sector of Latin America.4. Challenges to implementing Vietnam's NDC
gender_justification: 50% of women were targeted for training in Vietnam's extension training for AWD.
capdev_justification: Technical guidance provided to investment and certification groups on criteria for mitigation
climate_justification: Low emissions development is our focus.

outcome_sumary: CCAFS research and partnerships supported improved nationally determined contributions in at least four countries (Colombia, Ethiopia, Kenya and Vietnam). This included technical advisory capacity, sustainable investment criteria and strategies, and a certification scheme for the scaling of significant mitigation. IRRI research expanded low-emission practices in paddy rice in Vietnam, via extension programs for 929,067 farmers, almost doubling the adoption area of low-emission practices to 163,418 ha and reducing emissions by 1.5 MtCO2-eq, compared to 2019. A paper on the feasibility of large-scale mitigation concluded that more realistic targets are needed that recognize what is feasible, based on current incentives.
milestone_evidence: (1) China's Ministry of Ecology and Environment partnered with CCAFS to develop provincial guidance for Tier 2 MRV of livestock. The guidelines were shared in seven training events with 1300 participants to build capacity at the provincial level. The Tier 2 guidelines include mitigation actions such as low protein feed, biogas utilization, and manure management.(2) IRRI built an MRV Toolbox and guidelines for GHG emissions calculation along the rice value chain, including IRRI's GHG calculator and AWD suitability mapping tools, a cost-benefit analysis tool (co-developed with UNIQUE-https://www.unique-landuse.de/), and a new reporting tool (currently piloted in the Mekong River Delta), which contribute to planning and MRV of GHG mitigation projects and plans.(3) Kenya's State Department of Livestock used Tier 2 emissions factors developed by ILRI in their most recent GHG inventory of the livestock sector.(4) CIMMYT produced a framework for rapid national analysis of mitigation priorities in the land sector, applied to Mexico and analysis of optimal nitrogen fertilizer applications for minimizing emissions.(5) WUR further developed their emissions calculator for food loss in the supply chain and worked with Olam and Bayer to identify emissions hotspots.(6) ILRI provided training in GHG emissions measurement in East Africa
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: In each country, capacity was strengthened for improved MRV
climate_justification: Low emissions development is the focus of the program

outcome_sumary: In collaboration with the CCAFS Sustainable Finance Team, this work was planned in 2020 but is being initiated in 2021 with Sagana, Catalyst at Large and Chi Impact. The main product will be a roadmap for practical implementation for relevant stakeholders. The roadmap gives investors and other stakeholders clear guidance on how to incorporate a gender-smart investment approach into decision making process that advance climate mitigation objectives, and will be focused in priority geographies.
milestone_evidence:
In collaboration with the CCAFS
Sustainable Finance Team, this work started in early 2021 with Sagana,
Catalyst at Large and Chi Impact. Recruiting the right
constellation of partners and developing the terms of reference with them took
more time than expected. The Sustainable Finance Team has taken the lead on
this work. The focus has shifted to gender in private sector investment for mitigation
rather than NAMAs due to the high interest from the impact investment community
in gender and climate investments.
gender_justification: Focus in on women-owned businesses, women-dominated supply chains, and products and services that benefit women.
capdev_justification: The study will build the capacity of investors for gender-smart investment
climate_justification: Low emissions development  is the focus of the program

outcome_sumary:
Colombia, Kenya, Ethiopia, and Vietnam used mitigation research outputs in
their updated inventories and NDCs. The Minister of Agriculture in Vietnam also
recognized the scope of the AWD suitability mapping methodology for
low-emission rice production and that AWD can bring practical benefits to
Vietnam's agriculture sector. CCAFS
research and partnerships also supported use of food loss and waste calculator
by private companies (Olam and Bayer) and integration of agricultural criteria
for finance assessment by the Climate Bond Initiative (CBI), EU Taxonomy for
Sustainable Finance, and Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs).
milestone_evidence: (1) CCAFS, together with other CGIAR programs in Vietnam, supported the updating of Vietnam's Nationally Determined Contribution for agriculture sector byhelping to shortlist 15 adaptation and 10 mitigation options. Vietnam's Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development included AWD suitability mapping developed by IRRI-CCAFS in a ministerial-level initiative. Policy makers were trained to use digital tools for planning and evaluating mitigation options. The National Agricultural Extension Center's training programme increased the capacity of 17,000 extension staff in sustainable rice production. IRRIhelped update Vietnam's national GHG inventory by estimating region-specific methane emission(2) Six research outputs scaled up to facilitate the implementation of low emissions development (LED) strategies in agriculture in Colombia, Kenya, and Vietnam. The key achievements include the use of activity data for a national GHG inventory in Colombia, agriculture sector inputs to Colombia’s nationally determined contribution (NDC), dairy sector inputs to the Subsidiary Body of Scientific and Technological Advice (SBSTA), and Vietnam’s NDC, and recognition of climate-smart agriculture county plans by Kenya’s updated NDC. The use of research outputs offers a large GHG mitigation co-benefits in the crop, livestock, and agroforestry systems in the countries.
gender_justification: NA
capdev_justification: Capacity development on evaluation of impact pathway and scaling the use of research outputs
climate_justification: Low emissions development is the focus of the program

outcome_sumary:
CCAFS science on precision nutrient
management practices and tools has informed the International Fertilizer
Association and Yara's strategies towards sustainable crop nutrient
management in Sub-Saharan Africa. CCAFS and Wageningen University and Research
partnership has further developed the emissions calculator for food loss in the
supply chain and worked with Olam and Bayer to identify food loss and emissions
hotspots. CCAFS-CIMMYT conducted several on-farm research on precision
nutrient management (PNM) in collaboration with state departments of
agriculture and agriculture universities in India. Some state governments such
as Punjab, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh, and Bihar integrated PNM in their regular
state agricultural programs.
milestone_evidence: (1) Barriers to adoption of mitigation technologies were examined for women, men and youth in three provinces in Vietnam.(2) For livestock in Latin America: Strategies and bottlenecks for the implementation of technologies in LAC to achieve the NDCs while reducing enteric methane emissions were identified in seven countries alongside with partners from a variety of institutions.The main hotspots of negative environmental impacts of dual-purpose cattle farms in Colombia and proposed possible mitigation options and their cost-effectiveness. we identified options to reduce the carbon footprint for meat and milk production by adopting improved pastures and better agricultural management practices.(3) A working paper on cost of transition to low-emissions dairy: mitigation options and finance in Kenya LED implementation and finance in Kenya and brief analysis of gender was produced.Food loss and waste incentive analysis will not be conducted, due to an increased emphasis on working directly with companies to deliver impacts.
gender_justification: Adoption factors were examined for women, men and youth in Vietnam study
youth_justification: Adoption factors were examined for women, men and youth in Vietnam study
capdev_justification: Not a focus
climate_justification: Low emissions development is the focus of the program

outcome_sumary:
CCAFS science on precision nutrient
management practices and tools has informed the International Fertilizer
Association and Yara's strategies towards sustainable crop nutrient
management in Sub-Saharan Africa. CCAFS and Wageningen University and Research
partnership has further developed the emissions calculator for food loss in the
supply chain and worked with Olam and Bayer to identify food loss and emissions
hotspots. CCAFS-CIMMYT conducted several on-farm research on precision
nutrient management (PNM) in collaboration with state departments of
agriculture and agriculture universities in India. Some state governments such
as Punjab, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh, and Bihar integrated PNM in their regular
state agricultural programs.
milestone_evidence: (1) CCAFS continued to provide technical and policy guidance on efficient management options. We did meta-analyses to identify profitable, resource-use efficient and environmentally sound systems. In North-Western India, technical guidance was provided on residue management, direct-seeded rice and other CSA technologies.(2) Two agricultural development initiatives used CCAFS-WUR science to increase input efficiency: 1) piloting of the Maize Nutrient Manager (MNM) mobile phone app and 2) a large demonstration experiment in Iringa, Tanzania, which is part of Ilula Orphan Program. The experiment demonstrates how yield gap closure and low emissions can be combined.(3) WUR also further developed their emissions calculator for food loss in the supply chain and worked with Olam and Bayer to identify food loss and emissions hotspots.(4) In Indonesia, WUR supported practice guidelines about improved feed and manure practices in collaboration with the local, West Java and umbrella dairy cooperative and other partners, including Friesland Campina. A national seminar was held on improved feed and manure practices. In China, a policy guidance webinar was held for the Ministry of Agriculture, regional authorities and dairy processing companies.
gender_justification: Outreach has been inclusive of women farmers and decision makers
youth_justification: It has been too early to target youth, as we are still consolidating general guidance
capdev_justification: All of this work focuses on building capacity of implementers and trainers
climate_justification: Low emissions development  is the focus of program
