outcome_sumary: The continued development and distribution of pre-breeding germplasm to colleagues within the CGIAR and to NARES partners was a highlight of a challenging year. The synthesis of work on sparse testing provided clear guidelines on effective implementation of sparse testing highlighting the opportunities and potential pitfalls of the approach. Challenges in transformation of wheat resulted in a slowing of progress in gene editing, newly sourced resources offer potential to address this challenge in 2021. Finally COVID-19 heavily impacted the initiation of doctoral training under HeDWIC, this important endeavor will extend into 2021.
milestone_evidence:
Transformation of elite wheat lines has proven
to be challenging, thus has presented a bottleneck in editing genes. Although
we have generated more than two dozen transgenic plants with the editing
machinery for the Lr67 gene in Reedling, none carried an edited copy of the
gene. We have recently acquired new vectors from UC Davis that have been shown
to improve both transformation and gene editing efficiencies. These vectors
containing guide RNA molecules for Lr67 and MLO genes have just been
transformed into Reedling. We expect to see results in 5-6 months and hope to
identify edited copies for both the genes.
gender_justification: Gene editing for these traits does not specifically target gender
youth_justification: Gene editing for these traits does not specifically target youth
capdev_justification: In-house capacity is being developed to conduct the gene editing in wheat though it is not a main focus of the work
climate_justification: Gene editing for these traits does not specifically target climate change

outcome_sumary: The continued development and distribution of pre-breeding germplasm to colleagues within the CGIAR and to NARES partners was a highlight of a challenging year. The synthesis of work on sparse testing provided clear guidelines on effective implementation of sparse testing highlighting the opportunities and potential pitfalls of the approach. Challenges in transformation of wheat resulted in a slowing of progress in gene editing, newly sourced resources offer potential to address this challenge in 2021. Finally COVID-19 heavily impacted the initiation of doctoral training under HeDWIC, this important endeavor will extend into 2021.
milestone_evidence: Sparse testing implies modifying the original multi-environment breeding trials system (where all breeding germplasms are evaluated in all the testing environments) into a system where not all the breeding lines are sown in all environments. How best to establish a multi-environmental trial system that will be economically feasible, save land and water resources, without highly affecting the precision by which breeding lines or varieties’ performance are assessed, predicted and selected? Sparse testing was applied to maize and wheat breeding of CIMMYT in order to study the genomic-enabled prediction accuracy of different field sparse testing systems. We studied three sparse testing allocation designs: (1) no-overlapping lines in environments, (2) complete overlapping (0 non-overlapping) lines tested in all of the environments and (3) combinations of the two previous cases where certain number of non-overlapping/overlapping lines were distributed in the environments. The study used three extensive wheat data sets and two large maize data sets. Results for sparse testing on wheat and maize data sets indicated that substantial save on testing resources can be achieved by allocation designs and genome-based models. Reducing the size of the calibration sets always reduced the genomic-enabled prediction accuracy. The study manuscrip is currently under peer review.
gender_justification: Traits targeted by prediction may include gender relevant traits, however the recommendations for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver
youth_justification: Traits targeted by prediction may include youth relevant traits, however the recommendations for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver
capdev_justification: Capacity development will be a focus of sparse testing implementation but it is not a focus of demonstration
climate_justification: Traits targeted by prediction may include climate change relevant traits, however the recommendations for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver

Challenges in transformation of wheat resulted in a slowing of progress in gene editing, newly sourced resources offer potential to address this challenge in 2021. milestone_evidence: More than 100 datasets of detailing ranges of phenotypic, genotypic, and genealogical data were released publicly in 2020 following data management polocies and procedures
gender_justification: Data include gender relevant features, however dissemination is agnostic of gender
youth_justification: Data include youth relevant features, however dissemination is agnostic of youth
capdev_justification: Data release does not directly target capacity development
climate_justification: Data include climate change relevant features, however dissemination is agnostic of climate change

milestone_evidence: Materials derived from pre-breeding activities have been developed and distributed to CG and NARS partners. Examples include derivative lines from octaploid synthetic wheat lines (AABBDDDD and AABBDDAA), CIRNO derivatives developed for quality and leaf rust resistance and a suite of lines and trials from Seeds of Discovery incorporating novel diversity for drought, heat and disease tolerance.
gender_justification: Pre-breeding does not specifically address gender though the traits under selection may reflect gender responsive variety breeding
youth_justification: Pre-breeding does not specifically address youth though the traits under selection may reflect youth responsive variety breeding
capdev_justification: Pre-breeding does not specifically target capacity development
climate_justification: Pre-breeding does not specifically address climate change though the traits under selection may reflect climate change responsive variety breeding, especially for drought and heat tolerance

milestone_evidence: The doctoral program was established with two enrolled PhD students in 2020. The global initiatives were developed in partnership with the Wheat Initiative. For the development of global initiatives HeDWIC and the Julius Kuehn Institute's TERTIUS project joined forces with AHEAD (an organization under the wheat initiative) to expand representation of wheat researchers working in heat and drought and to broaden the scope and scale of conceived initiatives.
gender_justification: In many countries where food is already prioritized to male family members, climate-resilient crops will help avoid further disparity
youth_justification: Climate resilient staple crops will help ensure adequate diets for younger family members whose development can be permanently impaired by malnutrition
capdev_justification: Recruiting young scientist from LDCs to pursue tertiary education will reinforce national crop research, breeding and extension capacity
climate_justification: Deploying climate resilience crop technologies will buffer crops against climate change

milestone_evidence:
Improving parent selection in
pre-breeding. The use of genome selection methods for pre-breeding will
facilitate and improve the selection based on breeder knowledge, phenotypic
data and genomic data. Differentiate the contribution of exotic and elite
materials is of paramount importance to identify new sources of allele. Genome
selection predictive models have been shown to be effective to do genome
selection in exotic and pre-breeding materials. New genome selection predictive
models contribute to have a better precision and facilitate the selection of
crosses between exotic and elite materials
gender_justification: Pre-breeding may include gender targeted traits but methodology development does not target gender
youth_justification: Pre-breeding may include youth targeted traits but methodology development does not target youth
capdev_justification: A graduate student is working on this topic for their thesis but their training is not the reason for the study
climate_justification: Pre-breeding may include climate change targeted traits but methodology development does not target climate change

outcome_sumary: The refinement of a framework and development of resources to enable more efficient and effective storage and use of data for the purpose of varietal development has advanced comprehensively in 2020. This inspite of a number of challenges related not only to the COVID-19 pandemic but also to a change in the structure and oversight of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) development. The work delivered moves WHEAT closer to comprehensive, efficient and effective breeding data management.
milestone_evidence: Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) v1.0 and v2.1 have been deployed to specific breeding team members at CIMMYT for the purpose of testing and training. Based on their specific feedback development sprints have been formulated and have and will be conducted to develop the next version for broader release to the MAIZE breeding community.
other_reason: Re-formulation of Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) development and COVID-19 pandemic
gender_justification: The data management systems enable the capture and management of gender-related traits though this functionality is not targeted
youth_justification: The data management systems enable the capture and management of youth-related traits though this functionality is not targeted
capdev_justification: The deployment requires significant capacity development activities to facilitate adoption of the system
climate_justification: The data management systems enable the capture and management of climate change-related traits though this functionality is not targeted

outcome_sumary: The refinement of a framework and development of resources to enable more efficient and effective storage and use of data for the purpose of varietal development has advanced comprehensively in 2020. This inspite of a number of challenges related not only to the COVID-19 pandemic but also to a change in the structure and oversight of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) development. The work delivered moves WHEAT closer to comprehensive, efficient and effective breeding data management.
milestone_evidence: The Genomic Open-Source Breeding informatics initiative (GOBii) project developed a centralized database for genotypic data. Breeding team members can access it though functionality is limited for direct breeding application. Breeders need to be able to select both genotypic data and phenotypic data for relevant germplasm entities (seed lots) to conduct needed analyses and select and advance germplasm. To facilitate this in a more integrated manner the genotypic data management system is being incorporated into the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS). While GOBii delivered a system the uplift into EBS is needed to enable broad use of data by breeding teams.
gender_justification: The development of a data management system enables application in gender-targeted breeding but is not developed with that specific purpose.
youth_justification: The development of a data management system enables application in youth-targeted breeding but is not developed with that specific purpose.
capdev_justification: GOBii has conducted some training on use of the data systems developed but this was not a core activity of the work conducted nor was it rolled out to broader breeding team members outside genomics application specialists
climate_justification: The development of a data management system enables application in climate change-targeted breeding but is not developed with that specific purpose.

outcome_sumary: The refinement of a framework and development of resources to enable more efficient and effective storage and use of data for the purpose of varietal development has advanced comprehensively in 2020. This inspite of a number of challenges related not only to the COVID-19 pandemic but also to a change in the structure and oversight of the Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) development. The work delivered moves WHEAT closer to comprehensive, efficient and effective breeding data management.
milestone_evidence: Improving parent selection for recycling of lines. The use of genome selection methods for parent selection will facilitate and improve the selection of parents based on breeder knowledge, phenotypic data and genomic data. The use of genome selection allows also a rapid recycling since phenotypic evaluation at early stages is more difficult. We contribute developing analytical methods for breeders and scientists in order to incorporate genomic data in parent selection. New genome selection predictive models contribute to have a better precision and facilitate the selection within population. The new methods have shown a good performance however more studies are necessary to incorporate more efficiently environmental information, to define the training population, and to do the predictions in particular cases.
other_reason: Complete analysis is only possible post 2022 due to biological limitations

capdev_justification: An undergraduate student is exploring this as part of their thesis, however capacity development was not a target of this study
climate_justification: Traits targeted by mendelian sampling may include climate change relevant traits, however the recommendations for integration of traits is agnostic of the trait selection driver

outcome_sumary: CCAFS increased access to weather index insurance and associated capital, promoting tools and public private partnerships that facilitate the scaling of insurance and finance services. Building on successful implementation of a flood insurance program that previously reached 11,000 households in India and Bangladesh, CCAFS developed new partnerships with Weather Risk Management Ltd and Green Delta Insurance Company to provide flood related insurance to more than 125,000 farmers in both countries. Picture based insurance tools, previously advanced by CCAFS, have now been adopted by six major institutions, creating opportunities to strengthen crop insurance, financing and agro-advisory services to millions of farmers.
milestone_evidence: In the South Asia flood insurance project (P1607), new partnerships with private companies has expanded flood related insurance to farmers in India and Bangladesh. The project is also building recommendations on how to reach women. The picture-based insurance tool previously advanced under FP4 (P1609) has now been adopted by six major institutions, creating opportunities to strengthen crop insurance, financing and agro-advisories for millions of farmers.
gender_justification: P1607 is developing recommendations on how to reach women farmers with insurance. https://cgspace.cgiar.org/handle/10568/109893
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Insurance is supporting resilience to climate change and variability.

outcome_sumary: CCAFS increased access to weather index insurance and associated capital, promoting tools and public private partnerships that facilitate the scaling of insurance and finance services. Building on successful implementation of a flood insurance program that previously reached 11,000 households in India and Bangladesh, CCAFS developed new partnerships with Weather Risk Management Ltd and Green Delta Insurance Company to provide flood related insurance to more than 125,000 farmers in both countries. Picture based insurance tools, previously advanced by CCAFS, have now been adopted by six major institutions, creating opportunities to strengthen crop insurance, financing and agro-advisory services to millions of farmers.
milestone_evidence: While there has been significant progress on adoption of insurance programs in Ethiopia, India, and Bangladesh, none have been mainstreamed into a national strategy yet. In Ethiopia and Bangladesh, index insurance is part of the national strategies being discussed, but they have not been adopted yet. Instead of having a strategy to start with the entire country, the strategy being used currently to scale projects up to the national level, year by year. In India, the national crop insurance scheme (PMFBY) is testing some technologies for yield estimation, but they must be carefully vetted before implementation. Hence this milestone has been extended until next year.
gender_justification: P1607 is developing recommendations on how to reach women farmers with insurance. https://cgspace.cgiar.org/handle/10568/109893. Joint work with R4 in Ethiopia also
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Insurance is supporting resilience to climate change and variability.

outcome_sumary: Technical advisory committees have been scaled up to 41 across ten LAM countries, incorporating around 350 institutions working with tailored agro-climatic products. R4 Ethiopia incorporated IFPRI's picture-based crop monitoring approach for index insurance into operations, using a participatory design to scale up the insurance scheme to 230 villages. Key evaluation studies based on climate services projects previously advanced in Senegal and Rwanda have revealed significant increases in production and income associated with the use of these services. In Ethiopia, through a partnership with the FANA Broadcasting Corporate, the CCAFS-supported EDACaP agro-advisory services platform was disseminated to 13-15 million smallholder farmers.
milestone_evidence: Technical advisory committees introduced in LAM have been scaled up to 41 in ten countries, encompassing 350+ institutions, R4 Ethiopia incorporated IFPRI's picture-based crop monitoring approach for index insurance into their operations, key evaluation studies in Senegal and in Rwanda. In Ethiopia, agro-advisory services of the (CCAFS supported) EDACaP platform were successfully disseminated to 13-15 million smallholder farmers. In Vietnam, scale up of climate information services has continued with provincial and district partners, and DeRISK more generally has engaged directly with national and sub-national actors in Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia.
gender_justification: Evaluation studies in Rwanda and Senegal had a gender component,  Latin America project also targeted women and produced multiple guides for reaching women.
youth_justification: Latin America project also targeted youth and produced some guides regarding this.
capdev_justification: Training provided to farmers and others on use of climate services.
climate_justification: Climate services support resilience of farmers to climate change and variability

outcome_sumary: DeRISK launched a project to scale the CCAFS supported CS-MAP tool to address irrigation water shortage and better manage reservoirs in Vietnam. In West Africa, CCAFS supported the agCelerant business development platform, as part of the implementation of a USD 18.4mn Islamic Development Bank Rural Rice Value Chain Program in Niger. It also supported a USD 5.7mn USARO program to assist decisionmakers in assessing and managing climate security risks. With CCAFS engagement and support, the Global Center on Adaptation advanced the process of developing a Blueprint for Digital Agricultural Advisory Services, targeting USD 7bn in new investments globally.
milestone_evidence: In West Africa, CCAFS supported the agCelerant business development platform, which was adopted in the implementation of the USD 18.4mn Islamic Development Bank Rural Rice Value Chain Program in Niger, and a USD 5.7mn USARO program to assist decision makers to assess and manage climate security risks. Uptake of evidence from Rwanda evaluation has been delayed due to delays in holding final events around project because of COVID.
gender_justification: The Investment Blueprint for DCAS advocates for a gender dimension to new investments in advisory services. https://marlo.cgiar.org/projects/CCAFS/studySummary.do?studyID=3903&cycle=Reporting&year=2020
youth_justification: Cascaid project also targets young entrepreneurs.
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Climate services support resilience of farmers to climate change and variability

outcome_sumary: CCAFS increased awareness and adoption of gender-inclusive implementation, and advancing gender-specific project performance metrics. Specifically, work in LAM achieved high engagement with women in the co-production and dissemination of agro-climatic information in Guatemala, and PICSA interventions in Honduras. Work on climate services continued in Mexico. Work in SEA similarly engaged the development of gender-sensitive services, and gender-specific guidance materials incorporated into three bilateral programs (SIPA-HaTinh, Infoact, DeRISK) that were implemented in Vietnam. The Investment Blueprint for DCAS calls for a gender dimension to new investments in advisory services, and so is expected to influence several hundred million dollars of investments.
milestone_evidence: LAM achieved high engagement of women in the co-production and dissemination of agroclimatic information in Guatemala, and PICSA interventions in Honduras.Although first introduced in 2019, activities in Chiapas, Mexico continued, marking the adoption of climate servicses work in North America (one additional region).Work in SEA similarly has targeted women engagement, the development of gender-sensitive services, and gender-specific guidance materials, incorporated in 3 bilateral programs in Vietnam.The Investment Blueprint for DCAS advocates for a gender dimension to new investments in advisory services, expected to influence perhaps several hundred million dollars in investments.

climate_justification: Climate services support resilience of farmers to climate change and variability

outcome_sumary: Vietnam's Department of Crop Production adopted CCAFS Climate-Smart Maps and Adaptation Plans (CS-MAP) to establish national policy on rice production in the Mekong River Delta. Over the past year, cropping adjustments were applied over more than 1.3mn ha to address drought, salinity intrusion and irrigation management. The World Bank announced a $60M investment with CCAFS under the Accelerating the Impact of CGIAR Climate Research for Africa initiative. This investment was responsive to the Agriculture Action Track of the Global Commission on Adaptation, supported by CCAFS.
milestone_evidence: 1) Vietnam's Department of Crop Production has adopted the CCAFS Climate-Smart Maps and Adaptation Plans (CS-MAP) tool for establishing national policy regarding rice production in Mekong River Delta.2) The World Bank announced a $60M investment with CCAFS under the Accelerating the Impact of CGIAR Climate Research for Africa initiative.3) Guatemala and Honduras have been advancing the National Framework for Climate Services (NFCS) formulation that aims to coordinate, facilitate and strengthen collaboration between institutions to advance climate services in the country.
gender_justification: N/A
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: Climate services support resilience of farmers to climate change and variability

outcome_sumary:
At least 57
varieties were released in 12 countries in 2020, among them 6
new wheat varieties for multiplication and distribution to nearly 1 million wheat farmers
/ 28 million wheat consumers in Nepal. In Pakistan, long-term WPEP project
(USDA) support resulted
in the release of more than 40 high yielding, disease resistant varieties since
2010. See the Annual Technical Report, p.9.
milestone_evidence:
International germplasm exchange for research maintained during COVID-19
 times. CIMMYT and ICARDA invest $700,000+ annually (mainly WHEAT 
W1&2) to distribute more than 350,000 packages of experimental seed 
(trials and nurseries) to over 220 IWIN collaborators worldwide. A 
majority of partners returned data
 voluntarily. Their key interest, according to a 2020 survey (87 
respondents), was to obtain genetic diversity or parental germplasm 
(86.2%), or candidate varietal material (46%); most valuable to them was
 IWIN data on grain yield (76%) and diseases (75%). In addition, CIMMYT 
and ICARDA wheat genebanks fulfill seed requests from scientists 
globally on the basis of Standard Material Transfer Agreements (SMTA); 
this activity is funded by the Genebanks Platform.– See Table 4.

milestone_evidence:
This study estimated
the genetic gains of the High Rainfall Trials (2006-2017) grown by NARS partners worldwide. The results indicate genetic
gain ranging from 0.5-1%, per annum, which on average represents 46.6
kg/ha/year. The above described genetic gains impact ca. 61 million hectares on
which farmers grow CGIAR-derived varieties, of 215 million global wheat area.

outcome_sumary: A Bioenergy strategy was supported for Kenya and awaiting roll out. Three regions in The Gambia (Central River Region, Lower River Region and Upper River Region) have already began implementing the Tree growing paradigm including around schools whereby we managed to establish close to 400 ha of agroforestry and tree growing around 40 schools. In Kenya, Elegyo Marakwet County (one of the 47 counties of Kenya) using our tree growing narrative has developed a Sustainable Forest management Tree growing policy that has been approved and is already being implemented.

outcome_sumary:
Prior to the COVID19 pandemic, CSISA organized a national level consultation workshop on integrated weed
management on 10 October 2020 in Dhaka, Bangladesh. National agricultural research and
extension systems (NARES) partners, NGOs, herbicide companies, input dealers and private
entrepreneurs participated in the workshop, which focused on presenting CSISA’s research results
and coordinating participants to identify and build business models that can assist in expanded use
of appropriate weed control predicts. CSISA also launched first-of-a-kind research trials with the
Bangladesh Rice Research Institute (BRRI) on weed competitive rice cultivars in Bangladesh. All
activities related to integrated weed management, exempting field trials located on research
stations.During the reporting period, and despite challenges caused
by the COVID-19 Pandemic, CSISA assisted 185 farmers of the Susheli Dairy Cooperative Ltd. to
develop business models for expansion of their dairy sales business.
milestone_evidence:
Noticeable
achievements are documented in Farm Mechanization and conservation argriculture for sustainable ntensification (FACASI), Taking Maize  Agronomy to Scale in Africa (TAMASA) final reports and on progress
reports of Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia (CSISA Nepal, CSISA MEA, CSISA-BD),  MAsAgro.
other_reason: COVID-19
gender_justification: supports women farmers by improving their access and exposure to modern and improved technological innovations,
youth_justification: -supports youth  farmers by improving their access and exposure to modern and improved technological innovations, knowledge and entrepreneurial skills;
capdev_justification: -collaborates with numerous strategic public, civil society and private-sector partners, aligning them in synergy with regional and national efforts
climate_justification: --increase the adoption of resource-conserving and climate-resilient agricultural technologies

outcome_sumary:
By using innovative approaches to transform agronomy.Working with service providers (i.e. input suppliers, government and private research and extension services, agro-dealers, and others) to identify and co-develop systems and applications that transform this data and information to useable products that support their businesses or programs to reach clients more effectively; andBuilding capacity in national programs to support and sustain these approaches.Nutrient
expert benefits assessed for South Asia, Nutrient decision support tools at
different levels (field, farms, regions) assessed in Taking Maize Agronomy to Scale in Africa (TAMASA). Global study on
contribution of better nitrogen management published. Water management project
funded by USAID Nepal.Water useefficiency (WUE)  research through subsurface drip irrigation.

outcome_sumary: 2020 - Smart mechanization lessons learned routinely applied in other FP4 projects.2020 – (1) Increase resource-use efficiencies (irrigation water, N, P) while maintaining high, stable yields. (2) Extension of crop mgmt practices that arrest soil degradation. (3) Reduce labor burden and shortages.2020 - Continuous scaling up and out through W3 projects
milestone_evidence: Farmers have been exposed to and experiment with improved SI and climate-smart practices. The trials and demonstrations carried out have shown that targeted and smart soil nutrient use can substantially improve the nutrient quality and content of crops, with potential enhancement to human nutrition.

outcome_sumary: On public and private commitments to zero deforestation significant progress was made at several pilot sites, including in South Sumatra on green development and zeroing deforestation; in the Amazon on launching the TerrAmaz project with five pilot territories in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru, on the fight against deforestation and the transition to sustainable development pathways.On plantations and tree crop commodities progress on governance of natural rubber sustainability by advancing Capacity Building, Strategy and Objectives, and Climate Change in the Rubber Industry. On mixed timber plantations, a study identified their potential role in forest restoration. Effectiveness of approaches to sustainable supply Shea were evaluated and presented to the Global Shea Alliance with a focus on empowering women shea producers in Burkina Faso.
milestone_evidence: Contributions and outputs in working groups on Capacity Building, Strategy and Objectives, and Climate Change in the Rubber Industry. The mixed timber plantation study identified important role in forest restoration. Evaluated effectiveness of approaches to sustainable supply Shea.

outcome_sumary: On public and private commitments to zero deforestation significant progress was made at several pilot sites, including in South Sumatra on green development and zeroing deforestation; in the Amazon on launching the TerrAmaz project with five pilot territories in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru, on the fight against deforestation and the transition to sustainable development pathways.On plantations and tree crop commodities progress on governance of natural rubber sustainability by advancing Capacity Building, Strategy and Objectives, and Climate Change in the Rubber Industry. On mixed timber plantations, a study identified their potential role in forest restoration. Effectiveness of approaches to sustainable supply Shea were evaluated and presented to the Global Shea Alliance with a focus on empowering women shea producers in Burkina Faso.
milestone_evidence: Tools and guidelines available in two jurisdiction of two countries, Colombia and Guaviare (1).ToR for a study were developed to assess the vulnerabilities of rural women producers in the shea value chain as well as opportunities available to them. Such vulnerabilities may encompass diverse factors such as new regulatory requirements to meet global market demand for Cocoa Butter Equivalents, new legal requirements for the recognition of women shea producers and their associations and/or federated structures, growing insecurity in the country, reduced densities of shea trees in the agroforestry parklands, and constraints associated with the collection, processing and marketing of shea nuts and/or shea butter. One key element of the research will be to focus on the recent impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on shea producers and the shea value chain.
gender_justification: Focus on women Shea producers in Burkina Faso
capdev_justification: Identified training needs for women  Shea producers
climate_justification: not specifically targeted

outcome_sumary: Reconceptualized inclusive business models with implications for sustainable development policy. Assessed the sustainability impacts of 12 contract farming businesses using econometric estimation strategies to address heterogeneous impacts of contract farming in perennial agriculture. Three welfare-enhancing accumulation pathways were identified. Assessed COVID-19 recovery and transforming food systems through inclusive agribusiness scaling, and critically reviewed policies and strategies. The research offers practically relevant solutions for the convergence of the climate, COVID-19 and food crises. Developed a conceptual framework for understanding how smallholders derive value from agrifood chains, and applied this to the case studies developed earlier in Mozambique and Tanzania.
milestone_evidence: George C. Schoneveld 2020. Review. Sustainable business models for inclusive growth: Towards aconceptual foundation of inclusive business. Journal of Cleaner Production. Volume 277, 20 December 2020, 124062Reconceptualizing inclusive business and inclusive business models. Journal of Cleaner Production:
gender_justification: Included women in business model analysis
capdev_justification: Not targeted
climate_justification: Commodities of focus are associated with deforestation and GHG emissions

outcome_sumary: Finalized a working paper on innovative finance, which helped to connect to private sector actors in the field of finance (Impact investment Exchange and Financial Access), starting a longer term collaboration. Further work was done on the Landscape Analysis of Financial Flows tool and a preliminary report on lessons learned was prepared. A strategy for enhancing financial literacy was published together with Financial Access and the draft framework to assess smallholder farmer risks and their influence on investments served as basis for four case studies, which address barriers to innovative finance and will help improve the enabling environment.
milestone_evidence:
FTA Working Paper on Innovative finance for
sustainable landscapes

capdev_justification: Not directly addressed
climate_justification: Not directly addressed

outcome_sumary: In Egypt, research on the Takaful and Karama national cash transfer program led to improved targeting of transfers and awareness raising for the program; the Ministry of Social Solidarity approached PIM researchers for another impact evaluation of the program as well as an evaluation of the new FORSA graduation program; finally, the country's food subsidies program was modified based on PIM research. In other countries where researchers have longstanding relationships with government and implementing agencies, many of the resources and efforts were diverted into COVID-19 responses.
milestone_evidence: In Egypt, research on the Takaful and Karama national cash transfer program led to improved targeting of transfers and awareness raising for the program; the Ministry of Social Solidarity approached PIM researchers for another impact evaluation of the program as well as an evaluation of the new FORSA graduation program; finally, the targeting of the country's food subsidies program was modified based on PIM research (the number of beneficiaries was reduced and the amount per beneficiary was increased).An impact assessment of the Vulnerable Group Development program in Bangladesh identified ways of making the program more effective; four of the five changes recommended were implemented.Preventive nutrition packets in randomly-assigned villages were added to Mali's Jigisémèjiri national cash transfer program based on recommendations from PIM research.
gender_justification: Egypt: the Takaful and Karama program's impact evaluation is focused on women's empowerment (https://ebrary.ifpri.org/digital/collection/p15738coll2/id/133538); the requested evaluation of the new FORSA program includes gender-specific indicators.
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary: Egypt's food subsidies program was modified based on PIM research. In a collaborative effort with PIM and A4NH, the World Food Programme and the government of Sri Lanka improved their Food for Assets programming to be more nutrition-sensitive. In response to COVID-19, many governments and implementing agencies diverted resources to respond to the socio-economic shocks created by the lockdown and PIM research also pivoted to help inform these responses.
milestone_evidence: In Bangladesh, World Vision International incorporated a nutrition behavior change communication component into the Nobo Jatra project based on a PIM evaluation of another project. Based on an ongoing evaluation of a Food for Assets program in Sri Lanka, jointly with the World Food Programme, nutrition-sensitive behavior change communication was integrated into the program. In Egypt, research on food subsidies played a role in the change of the organizational mechanism implemented by the government (from a ration card to a smart card system with access to a more diverse set of foods); this research was conducted in collaboration with the Central Agency of Public Mobilization and Statistics and the Ministry of Planning, Monitoring and Administrative Reform. In Mali, a national social protection program adopted cash transfers and nutrition behavior change communication as an integrated approach to reduce child stunting.
gender_justification: In Sri Lanka, the evaluation of the program will measure how male and female diets vary in rural, drought prone regions (https://docs.wfp.org/api/documents/WFP-0000113814/download/ (page 13))
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary: The impact of social protection programming to improve agricultural and nutrition outcomes was assessed in Mali and Yemen. Research in Burkina Faso is carried out to understand the intensity of conflict and the potential for an integrated nutrition-agricultural intervention to enhance diets and resilience. A study to inform the transition from emergency to livelihood programs in Somalia started in 2020.
milestone_evidence: IFPRI partnered with Yemen's Social Fund for Development to provide cash transfers and nutrition education to women in rural Yemen. When the civil war broke out, the Social Fund for Development managed to continue and even expand the program. Results from the evaluation of the program showed that cash transfers combined with nutrition education improved maternal and child dietary diversity, child weight-for-height and child height-for-age and that nutrition-sensitive programming was still successful in war-torn areas.
gender_justification: The nutrition counseling programming in Yemen was targeted to women and mothers.
capdev_justification: N/A
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary: virtual consultations relating to 2 Degrees Initiative and DryArc concept development and partner/stakeholder consultations, as well as virtual workshops about specific CASI technologies.
milestone_evidence: INRA-Morocco funded wheat research continues, 2 proposal developments for PRIMA done, others ongoing. Consultations occurred at various stages throughout 2020, resulting in 2 proposals for PRIMA being submitted, with others continuing to be developed into 2021.
gender_justification: The proposals submitted included gender components.
capdev_justification: Consultations occurred at various stages throughout 2020, resulting in 2 proposals for PRIMA being submitted, with others continuing to be developed into 2021.
climate_justification: The proposals submitted included climate change components.

outcome_sumary: virtual consultations relating to 2 Degrees Initiative and DryArc concept development and partner/stakeholder consultations, as well as virtual workshops about specific CASI technologies.
milestone_evidence:
Across Indo-Gangetic
Plains of India, NutrientExpert-based fertilizer management lowered global warming potential by 12-20%in wheat, in addition to
increased crop yield and incomes. Extension approaches included focus on youth empowerment (mechanization service providers that reach many farmers), partnership with India's Regional Institutions on Training and Extension (KVK) and applied research on extension (see publications New Frontiers in Agricultural Extension) - see 2020 Technical Annual Report, SLO 3.1, Table 1.MasAgro
Productor partners continued
to manage 38 innovation platforms in 32 Mexican states (see pp. 6-7 in hyperlinked report), in
which 17,000 farmers engaged, adapting 36 agronomic practices. By 2020, the
449th extension agent graduated from the training program set up in 2009 - see MELIA Table, S3069 & S3997.  Early sowing of wheat supports climate change adaptation. Using modern extension methods to engage farmers, the package of new seed, machines and agronomy
led to October sown wheat in >1 million hectares with about 0.8 t/ha extra
yield and savings on irrigation. About ~0.3 million farmers benefitted with
additional income (~US$ 200/ha) and reduced environmental footprints - see SLO1.1, Table 1
gender_justification: gender equality and equity; technologies adaptation and access
capdev_justification: NARS private and public sector partners, development partners. Trainings were conducted in mulltiple locations and on many topics over the course of 2020.
climate_justification: adaptation benefits relevant for all intervention regions

outcome_sumary: progress on integration with regard to climate-smart practices in South Asia; mainstreaming targeted at FP4 scientists. Extension to 2021 required due to COVID-19 impacts
milestone_evidence:
Researchers reported that when given
similar access to production resources, women have a higher probability of adopting
mini-tillers in Nepal. Other research highlighted that climate-smart agricultural technologies have the potential to reduce women’s drudgery along with
improvement in productivity and farm income.

WHEAT
researchers proposed policy options to promote
climate-smart technologies in India that have the potential to mitigate GHG
emissions and reduce women’s labor drudgery, with caveats about potential
negative implications to some specific vulnerable populations.

A Guidance Note was designed for researchers working in
smallholder farming systems. It is useful to interventions planning community
and household level action research with women and men farmers.
gender_justification: benefits of climate-smart technologies, focus of the first study listed in evidence was women's access to resources
youth_justification: social inclusion; service provider business models
capdev_justification: training and know-how exchange among NARS partners
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary: progress on integration with regard to climate-smart practices in South Asia; mainstreaming targeted at FP4 scientists. Extension to 2021 required due to COVID-19 impacts
milestone_evidence:
Some progress, but not as much as planned due to COVID-19Pilot analysis of robust
nitrogen cycles in mid-hills and lowland (Terai) of Nepal . Nitrogen (N) is often the most limiting
nutrient to productivity in smallholder mixed crop-livestock systems.Farm
Power – Mechanization. Research has revealed much higher demand for mechanization in Eastern
and Southern Africa, with African farming households being more dependent on
labor markets than commonly assumed; and thus far more inclined to hire
mechanization services.Research on
 gender
norms and poverty dynamics from 32 villages in South Asia concluded that villagers associate movements out of poverty mainly
with the actions and capacities of men, despite evidence revealing examples of
women who exercise major roles in agriculture and actively work to improve the
well-being of their families. Such evidenced experiences rarely alter normative
beliefs and practices that entitle men to control women and family resources.

WHEAT
researchers proposed
policy options to promote
climate-smart technologies in India that have the potential to mitigate GHG
emissions and reduce women’s labor drudgery, with caveats about potential
negative implications to some specific vulnerable populations.
gender_justification: adoption dynamics; norms and agency. 4th evidence link provided is specific to gender
youth_justification: intra-household and at community-level, youth considered alongside gender
capdev_justification: training on methodologies; data collection and analysis. Also farmer field days.
climate_justification: NA

outcome_sumary: Significant progress in SSA and South Asia, also Central America (more maize-systems focused), also in terms of making the case ex ante.
milestone_evidence:
A key factor responsible for low wheat productivity in the eastern
Indo-Ganges Plain is delayed planting. Science-based evidence,
enhanced capacity and an enabling environment for adopting innovations, using
systems optimization tools like Zero-tillage and adapted varieties led to advancing wheat seeding on> 500,000 ha, benefiting (>US$200/ha) over 800,000 smallholder farmers in eastern Indo-Gangetic
Plains. Despite the increasing climatic risks, during 2018-19 the average grain
yields in Bihar and eastern Uttar Pradesh have increased by 1.0 tons/ha,
compared to base year (2009-10), with current yields of 3.0 and 3.7 tons/ha
(Bihar/Eastern Uttar Pradesh). This translates to annual wheat production gains
of ~0.5 million tons worth US$ 145 million per year. prevailing Zero-Till (ZT) practices in Bihar, India(ca. 77% of population
engaged in agriculture), led to significant yield gains in 3 out of 4 years,
notably in the less favorable seasons (unique panel dataset, 961 farm
households in 87 villages). Estimated yield increase was 660 kg/ha. ZT led to
significant farmer cost savings in all four seasons, equal to a 5% increase in
average total household income.
gender_justification: only indirectly
capdev_justification: NARS capacity-building, knowledge sharing
climate_justification: adaptation and to some extent mitigation benefits

outcome_sumary: Significant progress in SSA and South Asia, also Central America (more maize-systems focused), also in terms of making the case ex ante.
milestone_evidence: NA
gender_justification: adoption dynamics
youth_justification: service provider business moels linked to mechanization
capdev_justification: train-the-trainer models; extension partner capacity building
climate_justification: not the focus, though linked to adaptation benefits of zero-till

outcome_sumary: Significant progress under CSISA/mechanization and MasAgro/responsible sourcing
milestone_evidence:
Ex post, CCAFS/WHEAT: Assessment offactors affecting the adoption of Laser Land Leveling (LLL)

and its impact on crop
yields and net returns, based on HH survey data (621 randomly selected farmers,
Haryana, India) and models. Adoption of LLL has significant positive impacts on
yields (rice +549 kg/ha; wheat +471 kg/ha) and net returns (an aggregate
increase of US$230/ha) in the rice‐wheat production system, raising farmers'
income substantially.
gender_justification: not in scope for all bilateral projects
youth_justification: service provider business models which have a clear benefit to youth
capdev_justification: train-the-trainer approach to enable extension partners to increase number of LLL service providers
climate_justification: not the focus

outcome_sumary: significant progress documented in OICR4042
milestone_evidence:
Lessons learned from Mechanization have been applied in various projects under FP4 as follows: Research has revealed much higher demand
for mechanization in Eastern and Southern Africa, with African farming
households being more dependent on labor markets than commonly assumed; and
thus far more inclined to hire mechanization services. WHEAT and partner scientists compared case studies across 3 continents, reviewed Nepalese policy with a focus on
appropriate-scale mechanization and investigated best-bet climate smart
technologies, identifying the positive impact of appropriate mechanization on
income and livelihoods; such as the Happy Seeder, which would offerfarmers significant savings in production costs, amounting to 136
USD ha–1, on top saving water and making timely wheat sowing easier.
Approximately 1 1, 000 Happy Seeders are in use innorth-west India; over 80% in Punjab. 18 manufacturers currently produce the Happy
Seeder - see OICRs Table.
gender_justification: gender based adoption dynamics/bottlenecks were considered in studies listed
youth_justification: service provider business models & scaling which benefit youth were outcomes under this milestone
capdev_justification: concerning to-be scaled technologies & scaling as such
climate_justification: not the focus

outcome_sumary: significant progress documented in OICR4042
milestone_evidence: Significant scaling efforts occurred through the scaling to researchers of the findings from the GENOVATE project. While the wheat seed scaling project in Ethiopia that concluded in 2019 was shown to benefit 131,000 rural households.
gender_justification: The GENOVATE project which is gender focused was a key scaling effort
youth_justification: Scaling efforts and W3 funded projects considered youth as part of data collection and project implementation
capdev_justification: CapDev was conducted in projects with scaling components on an ad-hoc basis
climate_justification: Scaling out of projects that had an important climate change impact, such as the Ethiopia seed scaling project.

outcome_sumary: significant progress documented in OICR4042
milestone_evidence:
Pilot analysis of robust nitrogen cycles in mid-hills and lowland (Terai) of Nepal . Nitrogen (N) is often the most limiting
nutrient to productivity in smallholder mixed crop-livestock systems. The
Terrai farm N networks were organized (high productivity), but inflexible
(poorly resilient). Consequently not sufficiently robust scenarios of
improved management (improved seed, intercropping, fertilizer use, better
timing of activities) resulted in improved crop production.Farmer
impacts and uptake of conservation agriculture.WHEAT, CCAFS and
NARS partners verified farmer benefits of adopting laser land levelling (LLL): on yields (rice
+549 kg ha−1; wheat +471 kg ha−1) and net returns (increase of US$230/ha)
in the rice‐wheat production system of Haryana, India. Science-based evidence,
enhanced capacity and systems optimization such as zero-tillage and adapted
varieties led to advancing wheat seeding on more than 500,000ha, benefiting over 800,000 smallholder farmers in the eastern Indo-Gangetic Plains.

In the
Indo-Gangetic Plains of India, 0.87 million ha, e.g. 2.8% of total cultivated
land, is under zero-tillage, with multiple economic and environmental
benefits. ZT led to significant
farmer cost savings, equal to a 5% increase in average total household incomes. Nutrient Expert-based fertilizer management lowered global
warming potential by 12-20% in wheat, compared to conventional fertilization increasing incomes.
gender_justification: gender-friendly technologies and adoption approaches
capdev_justification: train-the-trainer approach
climate_justification: The nutrient expert based fertilizer management efforts had an impact on global warming

outcome_sumary: Achievements targeting this outcome were threat assessments of Brazil nut, Sandalwood, Dipterocarps, medicinal and aromatic plants in Nepal; safeguarding of threatened Rosewood species in SE Asia implemented; vulnerability assessment of tree species from tropical dry forest in Peru and Ecuador; Boswellia papyrifera in Ethiopia; baseline analyses of genetic resource collections of cocoa in Central America and of coffee and cocoa in El Salvador and Peru; Bamboo seed sourcing in Ethiopia undertaken; and growth potential of Rattan in Cameroon mapped. Thematic studies linking up to different aspects of the work on biodiversity by FP1, were published.
milestone_evidence:
Threat assessment of Brazil nut (habitat degradation and genetic diversity) (1), Sandalwood (2), Dipterocarps (3), medicinal and aromatic plants in Nepal (4); safeguarding of threatened Rosewood (5) species in SE Asia implemented; vulnerability assessment of tree species from tropical dry forest (6) in Peru and Ecuador; Boswellia papyrifera (7) in Ethiopia; baseline analyses of genetic resource collections of cocoa in Central America and of coffee and cocoa (8) in El Salvador and Peru; Bamboo (9) seed sourcing in Ethiopia undertaken; and growth potential of Rattan (10) in Cameroon mapped. Most assessments have included significant local
trainings. Studies of school gardens to conserve agrobiodiversity (11) and promote healthy diets were published, as was work on the impact of agrobiodiversity on women and children’s diet (12); two thematic studies on FAO State of the Worlds Forest Genetic Resources published, one on indicators of genetic diversity (13) of trees (state, pressure, benefit and response), and one on trees, tree genetic resources and the livelihoods of rural communities (14).
gender_justification: Gender senstive prioritisation of species
capdev_justification: Capacity development and training performed. Most vulnerability assessment of tree species have included significant local trainings.
climate_justification: Climate suitability of species assessed

outcome_sumary: Deliverables from collaborations between the African Orphan Crops Consortium (AOCC), the Gene Bank Platform and the Nutrition and Orphan crops priorities of FTA have contributed to knowledge that supports diversification of food systems through integrating nutrient rich orphan crops into current food systems with a range of outputs. Domestication studies were carried out in over 20 species in more than 10 countries with a diversity of partners and high level publications were published in Nature Genetics and Global Food Security.
milestone_evidence: Characterisation of genotypes and phenotypes, and cultivar development of trees and crops, including African Orphan Crops with enhancement using genomics and business model development focusing on food trees but also including other functional uses. Domestication studies of > 20 species in > 10 countries with a diversity of partners (links), including Castor bean (1), Shea (2), Trichoscypha acuminata (3), Giant milkweed (4), Boswellia papyrifera (5), Teak (6), Allanblackia floribunda (7), Baobab (8), Bos frontalis (9), Manglietia conifera (10), Guava (11), Eucalyptus camaldulensis (11), Rubber (12), Ganoderma spp (13), Allanblackia stuhlmannii (14), trees in Wag-Lasta (Ethiopia) (15), Cocoa, medicinal plants in Cameroon (16), coffee (17), A. senegal woodland (18), Jernang (19), Canarium schweinfurthii (20), Bitter Kola (21), Water Yam (22), Moringa oleifera (23), Artocarpus spp (24), Parkia biglobosa (in Burkina Faso (25) and a systematic review (26)). High level publications in Nature Genetics (27) and Global Food Security (28) covered enhancing African orphan crops with genomics (29), mainstreaming nutritious orphan crops into African food systems and the contribution of forests, trees and agroforestry to sustainable food security and nutrition in a time of crisis (30).
gender_justification: Gender sensitive prioritisation of species
capdev_justification: Capacity development and training performed (including African Plant Breeding Academy)
climate_justification: Climate suitability of species assessed

outcome_sumary: Various outputs have been produced within the frame of the FTA priorities on Restoration and Tree Seed Delivery. A study on priorities and challenges of tree seed supply was published in Unasylva and a contribution was made to germplasm acquisition and distribution by CGIAR in Plants. Contributions were made to the Global Landscape Forum Conference ‘Can Tree Planting Save the Planet’, with associated blogs and a Tree Planting Outcome Statement. An integrated tree seed programme in Ethiopia is well established and similar programmes are being prepared for Rwanda, Burkina Faso, Tanzania and Central Asia.
milestone_evidence: A study on priorities and challenges of tree seed supply was published in Unasylva (1) and a contribution was made to germplasm acquisition and distribution by CGIAR in Plants. Contributions were made to the GLF Conference ‘Can Tree Planting Save the Planet’ (3), with associated Tree Planting Outcome Statement (4). An integrated tree seed program in Ethiopia is well established (PATSPO) including more than 30 seed and multiplication production areas of 18 species established 2018-2020, with documentation of the mass breeding approaches applied on its way.  Work on habitat and suitability modelling for 153 African tree species continued, including the preparation of new programming software for Community Ecology and Suitability Analysis (5). Base-line climate analyses for Tanzania, Kenya and Mauritania in support of applying climate appropriate portfolios of tree diversity for restoration were also prepared in connection with preparation of proposals for the Green Climate Fund. New and updated support tools for the work have been provided for the WorldFlora (6) (with R Commander Plug-in (7), Standardize Plant Names - module (8), and User Guide (9)), for biodiversity analyses (8 new tools in 2020 (10)), and the Seed-IT app (11).
gender_justification: Gender senstive prioritisation of species
capdev_justification: Capacity needs assessment and development and traing performed
climate_justification: Climate suitability of species assessed, recommendations provided and resources built

outcome_sumary:
In 2020,
 CIMMYT licensed a total of 37 improved maize hybrids (19 in Africa, 16 in
 Asia, and 2 in Latin America) to 27 public/private sector partners (12 in
 Africa, 13 in Asia, and 2 in Latin America) for varietal release and
 commercialization in 15 countries (10 in Africa, 3 in Asia and 2 in Latin
 America) after stage-gate advancement and product announcement in the last
 quarter of 2019.
milestone_evidence:
Licensing
of new MAIZE hybrids from different maize breeding hubs to a wide array of
public and private sector partners in Africa, Asia and Latin America for
varietal release and commercialization.
gender_justification: only indirectly in terms of breeding profiles and gender-preferred traits
capdev_justification: focus on seed companies adaptive breeding program capacity
climate_justification: drought and heat traits

outcome_sumary:
See annual reporting under SLO Table 1, innovations, FP2 and FP3
 
 
 a) 
 In 2020,9 NARS partners in Africa
 utilized doubled haploidy  line development service offered by
 CIMMYT-Kenya. Over 100 maize populations were submitted for DH development at
 CIMMYT-Kenya DH facility by NARS breeders in Africa  from which over 15,00 DH
 lines were produced and delivered back to the breeders.
 b) 
 Digitization equipment  distributed to maize
 programs in KALRO, NARO and CSIR-Ghana. This enabled NARS to collect data
 digitally, print plot tags, and save time in seed counting. 
 c) 
 QA/QC using molecular markers  adopted by four seed company partners in ESA.
milestone_evidence: Accelerating Genetic Gains in Maize and Wheat (AGG) Annual Report for 2020. :https://cgiar-my.sharepoint.com/:w:/g/personal/l_train_cgiar_org/EQPD8_PEa6RAg5EV-WNtX1UBWL4T_5pgxivKKkjZStZvzA?e=9DMCVG
gender_justification: only indirectly, in terms of gender-inclusive breeding profiles
youth_justification: seed sector business models, By facilitating young people’s participation in agriculture. see: https://stma.cimmyt.org/street-theater-amplifies-need-for-stress-tolerant-maize-varieties/
capdev_justification: NARS incl seed companies capacity-building
climate_justification: heat and drought traits, water and nitrogen use efficiency

outcome_sumary:
a) 
 A total of 48 improved MAIZE
 varieties with farmer-preferred traits have been released by public/private
 sector partners in sub-Saharan Africa (28), Asia (10) and Latin America (10).
 
 b) 
 Three FAW-tolerant improved maize
 hybrids developed by CIMMYT have been announced to the partners in Dec 2020.
 c) 
 Certified seed production and
 commercialization of recently released MAIZE varieties in 13 countries across
 sub-Saharan Africa reached 134,260 metric tons (MT), covering an estimated
 5.5 million ha, and benefiting about 9.4 million households (64.8 million
 people).
 

Increased deployment both in SSA (STMA- and FAW-driven) and S Asia (HTMA-driven).
milestone_evidence:
a) 
MAIZE Varietal Release Map for 2020,
presented in the Annual Report.b) 
Announcement on the CIMMYT website of fall armyeorm (FAW)-tolerant maize hybrids;



c) Accelerating Genetic Gains in Maize and Wheat (AGG), Annual Report for 2020.
gender_justification: women-owned seed businesses; gender-preferred traits as part of new variety
capdev_justification: Capacity of targeted African NARS and SME seed companies in maize breeding and seed systems strengthened through collaborative networks and training opportunities. Trainings and online courses with a total of 85 participants were also imparted'
climate_justification: heat and drought traits; water and nitrogen use efficiency

outcome_sumary:
In
2020, five nutritionally enriched improved maize varieties, developed by the
MAIZE team, have been released by partners; these include 1 provitamin
A-enriched maize variety in Nigeria, one QPM variety released in Colombia, and
three QPM + High Zinc varieties released in Latin America (one in El Salvador
and two in Guatemala).
milestone_evidence: see annual reporting: CGIAR-derived variety releases
gender_justification: The gender analysis of sex-disaggregated data captures the top ranked traits preferred by men and women farmers. Such analyses would guide monitoring and evaluation of project objectives as well as assess whether adjustments made in maize breeding pipelines have achieved both availability and equitable dissemination of maize varieties with gender-relevant traits.

outcome_sumary: Crop by region priorities have received analytical and simulation support to implement changes to their breeding scheme per year. The impact of COVID resulted in the team having to delay or cancel planned trainings with stakeholders given inability to travel and hold face to face meetings. As a result a review of digital needs was conducted and plans for portal IT development were reprioritized. The shifts incurred represent a change in scheduling of activities within the project timeframe, therefore in the overall frameowrk of planned deliverables we are still on track.
milestone_evidence: In 2020 32 new resources were added to the toolbox spanning breeding scheme optimization, phenotyping, genotyping and the continuous improvement methodology, this was just under to a 50% increase in tools and best practices. The EIB toolbox had 942 registered users at the end of 2020, an increase in 55 % from the end of 2019. Members are accessing directly and linking out to resources as part of communities of practice activities, training and during implementation of activities. The number of page views for the toolbox are among the highest in the EIB portal with significant time being spent on the pages of the most recently uploaded resources such as the breeding scheme optimization manuals. Specific user-group resources are being added as pioritized, e.g. Banana specific information on mid-density genotyping has been added in resonse to community direction, these resource addition efforts contunie to be added as prioritized by module defined needs and use cases.
gender_justification: Resources developed and added to the toolbox may address gender but this is not a key target of the milestone
youth_justification: Resources developed and added to the toolbox may address youth but this is not a key target of the milestone
capdev_justification: The tools and resources made available through the toolbox are key resources for use in learning and capacity development activities

outcome_sumary: Budget was allocated for monitoring mainstreaming in CGIAR Centers and NARS. Initial contacts with selected CGIAR Centers and the Excellence in Breeding Platform were established. A set of indicators were developed to assess and monitor mainstreaming, and some context-specific programs are in the advanced stage for implementation.
milestone_evidence: There were no major disruptions for the commercialization of biofortified crops, however, COVID-19 disrupted capacity strengthening activities (travel/meeting restrictions). When possible, this was done via webinars, etc.
gender_justification: Product profiles and target traits take into consideration gender issues (ex. cooking processing, marketing), which informs delivery and commercialization efforts.
capdev_justification: HarvestPlus provides capacity strengthening to CGIAR Breeding Centers, NARS, and to other actors along the biofortified crop value chain
climate_justification: We intentional test and release climate-resilient varieties, whenever possible.

outcome_sumary:
The global pandemic prevented the full achievement of 2020 targets for Aflasafe coverage, which is described in more detail under the relevant milestone. However, targets for the other milestones were exceeded. Now Aflasafe is available at 92 distribution points across nine countries (in 2019, it was 30 distribution points across seven countries). In addition, IITA shared lessons learned from its 5-phased approach and prepared four guides on implementing the business development
strategy. A willingness-to-pay study on Aflasafe KE01 concluded that increased education efforts through extension services to farmers about aflatoxins is necessary to support adoption.
milestone_evidence: To date, three private companies have been licensed to manufacture and distribute Aflasafe products in four countries – BAMTAARE Services (Senegal and The Gambia), HarvestField Industries (Nigeria), and A to Z Textile Mills Ltd. (Tanzania). By the end of 2020, all the manufacturing plants were fully operational with the plant in Nigeria expected to start commercial production from its plant during the 2021 agricultural season. Private sector-led demonstrations have shown 98% effectiveness of Aflasafe in farmers’ fields in Nigeria. Companies are bringing Aflasafe closer to users.
gender_justification: Business plan/commercialization strategies for the private firms do not include explicit consideration of gender
youth_justification: Business plan/commercialization strategies for the private firms do not include explicit consideration of youth
capdev_justification: Capacity development of the private firms that manufacturer and distribute aflasafe is key to design, implement, learn and adapt the manufacturing,  commercialization, and distribution processes and strategies designed by IITA. For example, IITA’s support includes training the technical and sales staff on the integrity of the technology to increase their confidence during commercial deployment of this new-to-market product; providing technical assistance for structured awareness-raising and demonstration of the economic and social value of the product to different market segments using business cases; and support in setting up of their factory, quality control and the associated specialized staff training.
climate_justification: Business plan/commercialization strategies for the private firms do not include explicit consideration of climate change

outcome_sumary: Crop by region priorities have received analytical and simulation support to implement changes to their breeding scheme per year. The impact of COVID resulted in the team having to delay or cancel planned trainings with stakeholders given inability to travel and hold face to face meetings. As a result a review of digital needs was conducted and plans for portal IT development were reprioritized. The shifts incurred represent a change in scheduling of activities within the project timeframe, therefore in the overall frameowrk of planned deliverables we are still on track.
milestone_evidence:
Part i is now a formal component of module 5 associated with 
















Enterprise Breeding System (EBS) development. Under this effort attention is being paid to those features which are critical to the enhancement of breeding efficiency and effectiveness (e.g. trial design and analysis) and those features required to assess breeding program health and performance (e.g. genetic gains assessment). Part ii is an integral component of all modules with each module leader collecting and responding to feedback. Part iii was completed with a number of videos being created and loaded to the toolbox reviewing the use and application of specific resources contained therein. Finally it was not possible to conduct face to face training in 2020 due to COVID-19. Nonetheless training was provided in methodologies such as continuous improvement training, the content being delivered by virtual means.
gender_justification: The work looked at technical requirements and capacity, there was no inclusion of any targeting of gender
youth_justification: The work looked at technical requirements and capacity, there was no inclusion of any targeting of youth
capdev_justification: Capacity development us a principal focus of the training work conducted and resources developed
climate_justification: The work looked at technical requirements and capacity, there was no inclusion of any targeting of climate change

milestone_evidence: Best practices identified and resources implemented in the re-developed learning management system (LMS). Lists of potential resources of targeted online learning in plant breeding developed, work extended into 2021 to contact these resource owners and establish potential to link to/reuse content for EiB clientele.By end 2020, planned to have i)developed/documented best practice: document to re-purpose and repackage materials from regional workshops for digital learning content, ii)collated full online courses lists for plant breeding, iii)reviewed materials and reach out to content owners to request high-value materials use by EiB stakeholders. COVID impact resulted in the team delaying/canceling planned training with stakeholders given the inability to travel/hold face-to-face meetings. Consequentially, content was not developed/refined. Additionally, given the inability to conduct workshops, reprioritisation of activities was conducted and acceleration of development and testing on learning management system was instead implemented. Activities described in the milestone were extended to enable focus to be placed on the LMS development-a a critical need given the ongoing pandemic related challenges. The shifts incurred represent a change in the scheduling of activities within the project timeframe, not a cancellation of activities, therefore in the overall framework of planned deliverables, we are still on track.

milestone_evidence: Due to COVID-19 related engagement challenges, this activity has been deferred to 2021.By the end of 2020, we planned to have met and worked with members of trait pipelines to document the scope and scale of activities. Meetings to facilitate the intensive discussion and interaction were not possible (travel restrictions/other COVID-related contraction of bandwidth) within respective trait teams to conduct this intensive exercise. To appropriately document a trait pipeline clear understanding of terms/stages definition from trait discovery to trait deployment are needed. Given the inability to meet meaningfully with trait pipeline actors within the various programs we worked to provide a framework and lexicon to use to describe pipeline activities enabling clearer and more rapid documentation in 2021. This resource facilitates easier and more direct documentation of pipeline work. Additionally, now that core pipelines have been defined we are better able to directly link activities and show the flow of information and resources along with entire breeding programs.

outcome_sumary: The EiB low-density SNP genotyping (LDSG) and mid-density SNP genotyping (MDSG) platforms are now fully self-sustaining in providing low cost and highly scalable genotyping solutions to various CGIAR, national agriculture research (NARs) and private users. These platforms enable rapid dissemination of genomic products to a larger audience along with a high degree of production standardization ensuring reliable data to support rapid breeding decisions. Due to OneCGIAR transition, many breeding programs are currently undergoing improvement plan reviews. Some of the milestones under M3 were affected/ changed to ensure alignment. M3 has also contributed significant staff time in supporting various programs in development of improvement plans to address Crops to End Hunger (CtEH) funders' requests.
milestone_evidence:
Despite
the COVID challenges, usage and adoption of low-density marker platform
remained on track with a reported business volume of over $1M USD (25% increase
from previous year). In addition, module 3 launched the mid density service in July of 2020 and to date, a total of 6 crops (maize, rice, wheat, bean, cowpea and potato) had successfully developed mid density SNP panels on the shared platform.
gender_justification: Technical output
capdev_justification: Effective use of genotyping tools by partner programs
climate_justification: Out of scope

outcome_sumary: The EiB low-density SNP genotyping (LDSG) and mid-density SNP genotyping (MDSG) platforms are now fully self-sustaining in providing low cost and highly scalable genotyping solutions to various CGIAR, national agriculture research (NARs) and private users. These platforms enable rapid dissemination of genomic products to a larger audience along with a high degree of production standardization ensuring reliable data to support rapid breeding decisions. Due to OneCGIAR transition, many breeding programs are currently undergoing improvement plan reviews. Some of the milestones under M3 were affected/ changed to ensure alignment. M3 has also contributed significant staff time in supporting various programs in development of improvement plans to address Crops to End Hunger (CtEH) funders' requests.
milestone_evidence: As mentioned in 2019 milestones, cost benefit analysis is no longer a stand alone activity. For breeding programs to effectively deploy molecular tools, a holistic approach is needed to redesign the entire breeding pipeline. This work is on going and it is done in collaboration with various breeding leads and EiB members. Instead of focusing on deployment of genomic tools per se, under the OneCGIAR and Donor supported Crops to End Hunger initiative, modernization should focus on the 6 funders' request aimed at generating greater rate of genetic gain and stronger CGIAR and national agriculture research (NARs) breeding network.
other_reason: A holistic approach is needed to redesign the entire breeding pipeline. This work is on going and it is done in collaboration with various breeding leads and EiB members.
gender_justification: Technical output
capdev_justification: Effective use of genotyping tools by partner programs
climate_justification: Out of scope

These platforms enable rapid dissemination of genomic products to a larger audience along with a high degree of production standardization ensuring reliable data to support rapid breeding decisions. Due to OneCGIAR transition, many breeding programs are currently undergoing improvement plan reviews. Some of the milestones under M3 were affected/ changed to ensure alignment. milestone_evidence:
EiB low-density SNP genotyping (LDSG) service had been successfully renegotiated. The base price per sample for 10 
















single nucleotide
polymorphism (SNP) marker remained at $2.00 per sample whereas for higher number of SNPs, there's a reduction of cost between 25% to 40% depending on the job size. This reduction in pricing on higher SNP per sample is especially important for smaller users and many NARs partners which are starting to use the EiB LDSG service for their quantitative trait loci (QTL) fingerprinting effort. For mid-density SNP genotyping (MDSG) service, the service was launch in July of 2020, so it is too early for pricing renegotiation. To date, 6 crops (maize, rice, wheat, bean, cowpea and potato) have successfully developed mid-density panels for genomic selection and genome profile use in 2021.
other_reason: due to One CGIAR and Crops to End Hunger prioritization.
gender_justification: Out of scope

milestone_evidence: Despite COVID lockdowns which significantly affected many breeding operations globally, low-density SNP genotyping (LDSG) business volume remained at over $1M USD in 2020. Mid-density SNP genotyping (MDSG) service for genome profiling started in July of 2020. However, with the OneCGIAR transition, many breeding programs are at the final year of CRP and bilateral project funding. The funding gap has prevented many programs to initiated large scale genomic selection and profiling work until new funding arrives in 2021.
other_reason: due to One CGIAR and Crops to End Hunger prioritization.
