Roadmap for capacity-building program developed
with African Women in Agricultural Research and Development (AWARD). The
program will support gender researchers in enhancing their capacities and
influence to place gender research and equality and inclusion at the heart of
the CGIAR agenda.A preliminary needs
assessment was conducted among CGIAR gender scientists. A follow-up CGIAR-wide
capacities and needs assessment will be completed in 2021.
gender_justification: Gender is the entire focus of the Platform
youth_justification: Youth is not a key focus of the strategy which targets target mid-career scientists
capdev_justification: This is a capacity strengthening and professional development programme for gender scientists
climate_justification: The programme does not focus on thematic content per se, but rather on developing the 'soft skills' of gender scientists

outcome_sumary:
Together, the Module milestones contribute to
strengthening the capacities of scientists within CGIAR and national
agricultural research and extension systems to practice quality gender-focused
and gender-integrated research and to place gender equality at the heart of the
One CGIAR agenda. The milestone on generating an enabling institutional (One
CGIAR) environment for gender research is mutually reinforcing efforts to
strengthen individual and collective capacities for gender research. Given this
critical juncture in the One CGIAR process, institutional culture change
efforts have focused on influencing the agenda and mechanisms of One CGIAR.
milestone_evidence:
A preliminary needs
assessment was conducted among CGIAR gender scientists. A follow-up CGIAR-wide
capacities and needs assessment will be completed in 2021.
gender_justification: Gender is the entire focus of the Platform
youth_justification: Youth is not a focus of the capacity development activities, although early career scientists are part of the target group
capdev_justification: This is a capacity strengthening programme aiming to strengthen the capacities of social and biophysical scientists in gender-responsive crop improvement
climate_justification: Part of the programme will focus on establishing links between gender, crop improvement, and climate resilience

outcome_sumary:
Together, the Module milestones contribute to
strengthening the capacities of scientists within CGIAR and national
agricultural research and extension systems to practice quality gender-focused
and gender-integrated research and to place gender equality at the heart of the
One CGIAR agenda. The milestone on generating an enabling institutional (One
CGIAR) environment for gender research is mutually reinforcing efforts to
strengthen individual and collective capacities for gender research. Given this
critical juncture in the One CGIAR process, institutional culture change
efforts have focused on influencing the agenda and mechanisms of One CGIAR.
milestone_evidence:
An institutional
culture change initiative was developed to generate an enabling environment for
gender research in CGIAR; and an advisory committee for the initiative has been
established.
gender_justification: Gender is the entire focus of the Platform
youth_justification: Youth is not a focus area of the initiative
capdev_justification: This initiative aims to create an enabling environment for gender research within CGIAR, partly by strengthening scientists' capacities to understand how gender norms influence their research
climate_justification: Climate Change is not a focus area of the initiative

outcome_sumary: It has become evident as the programme matures that co-learning, beyond developing locally appropriate options, acclerates scaling through spontaneous spread of options being trialled in communities of practice. In Vietnam farmer co-operatives neighboring exemplar landscapes have sought and replicated succeses, in Kenya farmers not directly involved in projects have started using innovations such as planting basins because of the interest generated by groups of farmers adapting basin designs to their local circumstances. We are now directing effort to document spontaneous spread and understand what enables or constrains it.
milestone_evidence: Impact of adopting a co-learning approach on regreening outcomes across seven countries in Africa showed increased integration of trees on farmland resulting in improved soil health, productivity and income. Co-learning in Vietnam led to development of multistrata options preferred by farmers that provide greater and more reliable returns while co-learning led to viable oil plam diversification straties in Brazil.
gender_justification: African and Latin American research disaggregated by gender and produced gender differentiated results
capdev_justification: not directly addressed
climate_justification: All three analyses related to increasing tree cover or crop diversity with climate change mitigation and adaptation outcom

outcome_sumary: The quantification of benefits far exceeding 25% increased income from market based agroforestry options in Vietnam coupled with farmer preferences for more diverse and hence resilient options and the critical need for strategies to cover the time lag between investment and return; have shifted our emphasis from comparative evaluation of different options to holistic assessment of what combinations of options ( technology, market and policy) lead to rapid uptake and impact.
milestone_evidence: Livelihood and environmental benefits from community forestry were analysed across 643 cases in 51 countries and augmented by detailed analysis of impacts on farm income for different agroforestry options quantified across three provinces in Vietnam.
gender_justification: Gender was an explicit factor in the community forestry study
youth_justification: Agroforestry options increasing income are a key means to retain young people in rural areas in Vietnam
capdev_justification: Not targeted
climate_justification: Agroforestry options in Vietnam are an adaptation to climate change through diversification and erosion control in the face of higher and more intensive rainfall

outcome_sumary: Combining local knowledge of tree attributes with scientific advances has allowed development of practically useful tools for selecting companion trees for both cocoa and coffee production systems that are now freely available and being taken up and enhanced by growing community of users who access tree selection tools online. Farmers rarely select companion trees for the sole purpose of improving soil fertility, and so embedding impacts on soil fertility within the overall basket of goods and services provided by different tree species in varying contexts matches advice about impacts of trees on soil fertility to farmer needs.
milestone_evidence: Understanding of effects of trees and other management factors on soil fertility and tools for selecting companion tree species to sustain soil fertility (amongst other utilities) developed for both cocoa and coffee.
gender_justification: Not directly addressed
capdev_justification: Shade tree advice tool develops capacity by providing extension staff and farmers with information on tree attributes that affect suitability of trees for integration with cocoa and coffee including potential to improve soil fertility
climate_justification: Companion trees can ameliorate climate change effects through buffering temperatures allowing coffee and cocoa to continue to be grown in areas that would otherwise become unsuitable for the crops.

outcome_sumary: Understanding how trees influence soil micro and macro fauna is critical for both productivity and product quality, recent breakthroughs in metagenomics facilitate making faster progress in understanding what practices can influence microbial diversity and abundance as well as understanding their implications for yield and product quality.
milestone_evidence: Duong B, Marraccini P, Maeght J-L,Vaast P, Lebrun M and Duponnois R(2020) Coffee Microbiota and Its Potential Use in Sustainable Crop Management. A Review.Front. Sustain. Food Syst. 4:607935.
gender_justification: Not targeted
capdev_justification: Not targeted
climate_justification: Coffee is a major tree-crop commodity for which the suitable cultivated area is predicted to decrease and shift to higher elevations - microbiota can be instrumental in adapting to climate change, notably in conferring pest and disease resistance.

outcome_sumary: The program has taken a key step forward in quantifying effects of heat stress on productivity of dairy cattle in China and identifying where, given climate change predictions, interventions are most needed to protect animals from heat stress. The emphasis of research has now shifted to comparative analysis of different options of reducing heat stress, and particularly the difference between living shade from trees in fields (that may also provide a seasonal fodder) and options that involve housing animals in buildings or other providing shade from other artificial structures.
milestone_evidence: Effects of heat stress on dairy cattle and their productivity were quantified in China identifying areas where climate change is predicted to exacerbate this and management interventions to reduce heat stress, including tree shade, are therefore important.
gender_justification: not targeted
capdev_justification: not targeted
climate_justification: Explicit analysis of predicited effects of climate change on heat stress in diary cattle was quantified

outcome_sumary: Aspirations and urban food environments were extensively evaluated as demand and decision trade-offs related aspects to make value chains more inclusive. Broader audiences have been reached with conversations and articles. Collaborative work with crosscutting theme MPAB has produced a paper on further intensifying emphasis on an agri-food system framing, including a special Issue around aspirations with GLDC contributions.
milestone_evidence: Great progress was made in reaching broader audiences with conversations and articles while advancing the activities on aspirations as well as urban food environments. The collaboration with Markets and Partnerships in Agri-Business has been intensified to further emphasize the value chain aspects of the cluster and the implications of an agri-food system framing (Global Food Security paper). The special Issue around aspirations is on track and GLDC contributions have been submitted.
gender_justification: Within the aspirations work gender dynamics have been the focus of one paper that has been accepted. The urban food work had laid a focus on gender based on the notion that women are critical change agents in food choices.
youth_justification: Parts of the outputs are specifically analyzing youth aspects
capdev_justification: 1 MSc students' work has been published within the aspiration special issue; several students and interns are involved in the urban food work and conference participations and media publications have ensured wider awareness and appreciation of the topics. Case stidy material developed in collaboration with MPAB has been used in GLDC e-learning course on Managing for Impact.

outcome_sumary: The GLDC scaling framework which integrates nine components required for successful scaling of its innovations was tested using case studies of four large scaling projects. Beyond GLDC, the framework offered a systematic way to review the design of the projects and their scaling initiatives, but was less useful for evaluating project performance. Among components of marketability, policies and institutions, and upstream research, the framework defines policies and institutions as “an enabling environment with supporting institutions and appropriate incentives/absence of bottlenecks.
milestone_evidence:
This was completed as a working paper in 2019. The framework identifies several possible gaps in the design of the four scaling projects. In some cases, components in the scaling framework are missing. Three examples of missing components are marketability, policies and institutions, and upstream research. The
framework defines marketability as “ready access to markets with profitable and predictable returns”. This component is fundamental for scaling new technology designed for commercial markets. Yet it was deliberately omitted from the TL III project on the grounds that “research on markets, policy and seed regulation … are being adequately covered by other initiatives or that sufficient information is now available”. Similarly, the framework defines policies and institutions as “an enabling environment with supporting institutions and appropriate incentives/absence of bottlenecks.”

outcome_sumary: The GLDC scaling framework which integrates nine components required for successful scaling of its innovations was tested using case studies of four large scaling projects. Beyond GLDC, the framework offered a systematic way to review the design of the projects and their scaling initiatives, but was less useful for evaluating project performance. Among components of marketability, policies and institutions, and upstream research, the framework defines policies and institutions as “an enabling environment with supporting institutions and appropriate incentives/absence of bottlenecks.
milestone_evidence: Instead this milestone, the impact estimation strategy was prioritized.
other_reason: Instead of this milestone, the impact estimation strategy was prioritized.

outcome_sumary: Adoption of the performance assessment tools is enabling partners to widen the coverage of performance assessment research. Progress was made in the production of improved strains of silver carp in Bangladesh and in the production of genomic data for resilience traits for tilapia.Improved strains were produced for carps (rohu generation 3) and tilapia (genetically improved farmed tilapia - GIFT - generation 17) utilising genomic information.Phenotyping methods for disease resistance, feed efficiency and oxygen resilience were designed and tested.
milestone_evidence: Genomic information was used to correct pedigrees and breed rohu generation 3 so enhancing accuracy of selection.  Molecular data to confirm identity to create genetically improved farmed tilapia (GIFT) generation 17 from a back up stock. The genetic tools (single nucleotide polymorphism  - SNP - markers and SNP chip) used to achieve this milestone were published.

outcome_sumary: Adoption of the performance assessment tools is enabling partners to widen the coverage of performance assessment research. Progress was made in the production of improved strains of silver carp in Bangladesh and in the production of genomic data for resilience traits for tilapia.Improved strains were produced for carps (rohu generation 3) and tilapia (genetically improved farmed tilapia - GIFT - generation 17) utilising genomic information.Phenotyping methods for disease resistance, feed efficiency and oxygen resilience were designed and tested.
milestone_evidence: Phenotyping methods for disease resistance, feed efficiency and oxygen resilience were designed and those for feed efficiency and oxygen resilience tested.

outcome_sumary: Public and private sector adopting improved health and feed management practices within their programs contributes to scaling of the innovations emerging from FISH research. Progress was made in Bangladesh, Egypt, Myanmar and Zambia in 2020
milestone_evidence: FISH researchers collaborated with public and private sector in Bangladesh, Egypt, Myanmar and Zambia to co-develop and disseminate improved practices related to biosecurity, health, feed management to support aquaculture development. WorldFish collaborated with government and a private company to establish the first-ever aquatic animal disease diagnostic laboratory in Bangladesh.
gender_justification: A gender-sensitive approach is recommended in applying the management practices developed
youth_justification: The management practices and recommendation developed are youth-responsive
capdev_justification: The scope of the better management practices is to support capacity development to enhance sustainability of aquaculture. In addition all management practices include capacity development activities to support adoption

outcome_sumary: Evaluations of co-management application in coastal fisheries progressed and are being used to inform improvements in policies and practice for co-management, and livelihood diversification at national, regional and global levels.Data collection and analysis was progressed through the global, collaborative Illuminating Hidden Harvests (IHH) research.Trade research was completed through an evaluation in Africa, with research positioned to influence policy in Malawi and Zambia. Global research progressed through a set of “Blue Food Assessment” papers being prepared for the UN Food Systems Summit in 2021.Progress was made in enabling adoption of improvements in fisheries co-management policies and practice, in the Pacific, Bangladesh and Myanmar. Adoption is taking place through direct engagement with policy makers and communities in FISH focal countries.Progress was made in enhancing visibility of small-scale fisheries in various policy initiatives, seeking to avoid marginalising small-holders and the food and nutrition security benefits they provide.Development of tools and approaches to “nutrition sensitive fisheries” made progress, but was extended to incorporate further work on nutrient values of inland fisheries and work on integration of nutrition into the FishBase.
milestone_evidence:
In Solomon Islands are integrated into new and adapted arrangement management plans in 40 coastal communities across Solomon Islands, Vanuatu and Kiribati.  These fisheries management arrangements address the weakness of many community-based, co-management, that is gender equity.
  
Scaling strategies for gender-inclusive methodologies and approaches of co-management developed with Pacific regional partner The Pacific Community (SPC).
Further adoption by national governments, larger investment programs and NGOs will be evaluated in 2021.

Hilsa fisheries co-management in Bangladesh has been strengthened with additional management measures and alternative livelihoods measures: including size of fish and resilience enhancing measures for fisher households. A revised national management plan (2021-2030) was prepared.
gender_justification: FISH research works on co-management models that are gender sensitive
youth_justification: FISH research works on co-management models that offers alternative livelihoods opportunities to youth
capdev_justification: Adoption process for co-management models incudes an important component of capacity development that sees participation of local communities.
climate_justification: Fish research includes aspects related to climate change into the co-management models recommended for adoption.

outcome_sumary: Evaluations of co-management application in coastal fisheries progressed and are being used to inform improvements in policies and practice for co-management, and livelihood diversification at national, regional and global levels.Data collection and analysis was progressed through the global, collaborative Illuminating Hidden Harvests (IHH) research.Trade research was completed through an evaluation in Africa, with research positioned to influence policy in Malawi and Zambia. Global research progressed through a set of “Blue Food Assessment” papers being prepared for the UN Food Systems Summit in 2021.Progress was made in enabling adoption of improvements in fisheries co-management policies and practice, in the Pacific, Bangladesh and Myanmar. Adoption is taking place through direct engagement with policy makers and communities in FISH focal countries.Progress was made in enhancing visibility of small-scale fisheries in various policy initiatives, seeking to avoid marginalising small-holders and the food and nutrition security benefits they provide.Development of tools and approaches to “nutrition sensitive fisheries” made progress, but was extended to incorporate further work on nutrient values of inland fisheries and work on integration of nutrition into the FishBase.
gender_justification: Gender is explicitly included into the small-scale fisheries actions developed
climate_justification: Climate Change is  included  and explicit into the messages to raise visibility of small-scale fisheries

outcome_sumary: Evaluations of co-management application in coastal fisheries progressed and are being used to inform improvements in policies and practice for co-management, and livelihood diversification at national, regional and global levels.Data collection and analysis was progressed through the global, collaborative Illuminating Hidden Harvests (IHH) research.Trade research was completed through an evaluation in Africa, with research positioned to influence policy in Malawi and Zambia. Global research progressed through a set of “Blue Food Assessment” papers being prepared for the UN Food Systems Summit in 2021.Progress was made in enabling adoption of improvements in fisheries co-management policies and practice, in the Pacific, Bangladesh and Myanmar. Adoption is taking place through direct engagement with policy makers and communities in FISH focal countries.Progress was made in enhancing visibility of small-scale fisheries in various policy initiatives, seeking to avoid marginalising small-holders and the food and nutrition security benefits they provide.Development of tools and approaches to “nutrition sensitive fisheries” made progress, but was extended to incorporate further work on nutrient values of inland fisheries and work on integration of nutrition into the FishBase.
milestone_evidence: Some foundation publications and presentations were completed in 2020, but the range of system- specific nutrition sensitive innovations are still under development for release in 2021. The delay is due to the need to include some additional findings on the nutritional values of inland fisheries and the work on integrating nutrition into the FishBase (https://www.fishbase.us).

outcome_sumary: Adoption of the performance assessment tools is enabling partners to widen the coverage of performance assessment research. Progress was made in the production of improved strains of silver carp in Bangladesh and in the production of genomic data for resilience traits for tilapia.Improved strains were produced for carps (rohu generation 3) and tilapia (genetically improved farmed tilapia - GIFT - generation 17) utilising genomic information.Phenotyping methods for disease resistance, feed efficiency and oxygen resilience were designed and tested.
milestone_evidence: National partners are using performance assessment methods and tools in Bangladesh, Egypt and Myanmar. This expanded to farmers and partners in Nigeria and Sierra Leone too.
gender_justification: The proposed methods and tools support the collection of sex-disaggregated data and have been developed to support in-depth analysis, including gender.
youth_justification: The proposed methods and tools support the collection of age-disaggregated data and have been developed to support in-depth analysis, including on youth.
capdev_justification: National partners receive training to learn using the methods and tools. A guide is also available online to explain step-by-step how to use the tools.

outcome_sumary: Environmental analysis of aquaculture improvements associated with FISH research and innovation is partially completed and in some cases published, with translation into better management practices (BMPs) and policy guidance now scheduled for 2021.Partnerships with public and private sector through formal and informal platforms, working groups and other mechanisms is considered an important mechanism for influencing policy, capacity development and investment in putting FISH research into use, including environmental performance and management of major technologies as part of a sustainable development of aquaculture in partner countries.
milestone_evidence:
The focus on “environmental performance” has been extended to cover other dimensions necessary to accelerate sustainable aquaculture practice and policy in cooperation with public and private sector.
 
Zambia: joint work with public and private sector to partner on integrating FISH research into vocational education. 
 
India: Odisha State and Indian Joint working group with the Ministry of Fisheries, Animal  
Husbandry and Dairying 

Cambodia: Participation in the aquaculture working group for aquaculture development
 
In Africa, participation in a Country Engagement Coordination (CEC) mechanism in Tanzania, Malawi, Nigeria and Benin under the African Development Bank TAAT investment. 

Contributions were made to the development of global criteria for investment into aquaculture and fisheries through “Climate Bonds”.
gender_justification: Through the construction of public and private partnership, FISH worked to meet needs of rural smallholder and commercial fish farmers, including women and youth.
youth_justification: Through the construction of public and private partnership, FISH worked to meet needs of rural smallholder and commercial fish farmers, including women and youth.
capdev_justification: Through the construction of public and private partnership, FISH worked to enhance the technical education, vocational and entrepreneurship skills of rural women, men and youth smallholder commercial fish farmers and increasing their linkages to input/output markets and entrepreneurship opportunities via private sector extension support and services delivery. This has happened particularly in Africa.
climate_justification: Working groups and platforms discussed climate-smart and climate-resilient solution for aquaculture development.

outcome_sumary: Important progress was made through the maturing of innovations, and their wider adoption in four major areas:(1) BigData & ICT tools;(2) rice-fish systems;(3) livelihood intervention diagnosis; and(4) gender-inclusive innovations.
milestone_evidence:
PeskAAS: A near-real-time, open-source monitoring and analytics system (BigData award winner) adopted by government as Timor Leste fisheries monitoring system, with early scaling (Malaysia and Kenya). 

ICT applications in small-scale fisheries evaluated and a handbook developed with FAO to enable wider application. 

Rice-fish systems Guide (2019) being applied for scaling in Cambodia by government and WorldFish scientists and further development of a Novel rice-fish typology (drawing on agroecological  principles) completed and published.
  
Livelihood diagnosis guide being applied with partners in the Pacific (SPC/EU/ACIAR).
 
FISH guidance for gender inclusion integrated into various monitoring and evaluation (M&E) guides and policy and practice guidelines
gender_justification: Sex disaggregated data collection and methodologies prepared. Gender bias in different methods made explicit.
capdev_justification: Capacity Development is a key element for the wider adoption of the different methodologies and tools prepared
climate_justification: Agroecological principles included in the design of climate change-resilient systems promoted through co-management. Technologies and models promoted include climate data and modeling.

outcome_sumary: Three evaluations for hilsa fisheries indicating co-management and livelihood investments have positive returns for productivity and resilience. Evaluations guided revision to Bangladesh Hilsa fishery national management plan (2020-2030) that is now under government consideration.Knowledge on trade-offs was progressed through evaluations of marine fisheries and conservation; on fish in multi-functional landscapes; and on the African Great Lakes region. This helps policies and practices development for managing trade-offs and enhancing food, nutrition and livelihood outcomes.FISH successfully partnered with a number of global, regional and national institutions to enable wider application of governance and production models for improving freshwater fisheries management.
milestone_evidence:
Evaluations of Hilsa fishery stock, management, livelihood interventions were completed in Myanmar and Bangladesh (3 evaluations).

Novel indicators showing previously overlooked benefits of co-management on ecosystem productivity developed and tested in community-based co-management in Solomon Islands, and two other Pacific countries.

Cambodia rice-fish systems innovations and ecosystem productivity and resilience paper published.

outcome_sumary: Three evaluations for hilsa fisheries indicating co-management and livelihood investments have positive returns for productivity and resilience. Evaluations guided revision to Bangladesh Hilsa fishery national management plan (2020-2030) that is now under government consideration.Knowledge on trade-offs was progressed through evaluations of marine fisheries and conservation; on fish in multi-functional landscapes; and on the African Great Lakes region. This helps policies and practices development for managing trade-offs and enhancing food, nutrition and livelihood outcomes.FISH successfully partnered with a number of global, regional and national institutions to enable wider application of governance and production models for improving freshwater fisheries management.
milestone_evidence:
The joint launch with FAO and IWMI of the guidelines “Increasing the benefits and sustainability of irrigation through integration of fisheries: A guide for water planners, managers and engineers” provided a globally influential policy guideline for further widescale application of governance and production models.  
 
In addition, joining a coalition of partners in the newly founded Inland Fisheries Alliance is a further pathway towards enabling wider application of governance and production models for freshwater systems.

Mini-symposium convened for Cambodia and the Mekong region to publicize and support scaling of rice-fish innovations with partners IRRI, IWMI, Cambodia FiA, ACIAR, Australian Universities.

outcome_sumary: Three evaluations for hilsa fisheries indicating co-management and livelihood investments have positive returns for productivity and resilience. Evaluations guided revision to Bangladesh Hilsa fishery national management plan (2020-2030) that is now under government consideration.Knowledge on trade-offs was progressed through evaluations of marine fisheries and conservation; on fish in multi-functional landscapes; and on the African Great Lakes region. This helps policies and practices development for managing trade-offs and enhancing food, nutrition and livelihood outcomes.FISH successfully partnered with a number of global, regional and national institutions to enable wider application of governance and production models for improving freshwater fisheries management.
milestone_evidence: Developed framework for scaling social principles and dynamic/flexible practices published, but further work needed to apply framework to evaluate scaling strategies.

outcome_sumary: Data management platforms were developed for all RTB crops and ontologies have been developed for end user relevant traits. This allows to screen populations for desired traits and digitize the information. In potato, progress made on late blight and bacterial wilt resistance traits in elite varieties.Genomic mapping is allowing the mapping of genes for important traits and providing tools for selecting within populations. Progress in editing will allow desirable traits to be added to popular varieties.
milestone_evidence: Data management platforms developed: CassavaBase, YamBase, MusaBase, SweetpotatoBase, BreeDBase.
gender_justification: End-user preferences being incorporated into databases have related gender-differentiated data.
capdev_justification: There was extensive training of breeding program staff in the use of the databases, also of national program partners.

outcome_sumary: Data management platforms were developed for all RTB crops and ontologies have been developed for end user relevant traits. This allows to screen populations for desired traits and digitize the information. In potato, progress made on late blight and bacterial wilt resistance traits in elite varieties.Genomic mapping is allowing the mapping of genes for important traits and providing tools for selecting within populations. Progress in editing will allow desirable traits to be added to popular varieties.
milestone_evidence: For potato, we demonstrated that direct transfer of 3 resistance genes provided complete resistance to late blight disease. Maximized gains described in study cases for key traits in cassava, yam, and sweet potato.

outcome_sumary: Genomic approaches implemented to find molecular markers for traits in potato, banana, yam, cassava and sweetpotato, in order to accelerate breeding programas and trait discovery. These include Genome Wide Association Studies and Genomic Selection.
milestone_evidence: A genome-wide association study of water yam for dry matter content and oxidative browning was published.  In cassava, a catalog of more than 40 genomic regions associated with 14 traits including pest and disease resistance; root quality; and several agro morphological traits were identified from a large GWAS study. From this, the top SNPs from the major gene loci have been converted to allele-specific SNP assays for technical and biological validation and deployment in breeding programs. In addition, uni-plex SNP markers linked to increased provitamin A content and resistance to cassava mosaic disease were converted and validated in independent breeding populations. In sweetpotato, quantitative trait loci and differential gene expression analyses were carried out to understand the genetic basis for negatively associated β-carotene and starch content. Deep RNA-seq analysis reveals key responding aspects of wild banana relative resistance to Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense tropical r

outcome_sumary: Genomic approaches implemented to find molecular markers for traits in potato, banana, yam, cassava and sweetpotato, in order to accelerate breeding programas and trait discovery. These include Genome Wide Association Studies and Genomic Selection.
milestone_evidence: High-throughput transpiration phenotyping of wild banana diversity for growth potential and water deficit sensitivity completed. Drought tolerance was tested in 59 sweetpotato crop wild relative accessions using potential short-term memory induction, and certain accessions were shown to have the potential to improve sweetpotato resilience in dry environments and can be included in breeding programs. The reason of extension due to not reach high throughput phenotyping for traits unrelated to climate resilience and the evidence presented is for 3 crops only: banana, plantain, and sweetpotato.
climate_justification: Advanced screening platform for drought tolerant banana varieties

outcome_sumary: The application of nine Payments for Agrobiodiversity Conservation (PACS) schemes that have been applied to date in four Latin American countries over the period 2010-2018 was reviewed. These covered 130 threatened varieties across a number of major food crops, and involved over 100 farming communities and 1,100 farmers (45% of which were women). Progress was made to document the diversity of RTB crops in hotspot areas: banana in Samoa, Cook islands, Papua New Guinea (PNG,) and yam in PNG and Benin. In addition, there was extensive genotyping of the collected samples.
milestone_evidence: These involved collaborations with NARS and Universities for identifying and characterizing hotspots, understanding the evolutionary context and indigenous knowledge, sampling strategies, and DNA-based diversity studies.  To be able to implement the activities in PNG, the decision was taken in July, once it came obvious that no travels will be allowed for the Alliance and CIRAD researchers before 2021, to ask NARI, the national partner, to conduct the surveys. To prepare the mission, researchers from the Alliance and CIRAD organized WhatsApp calls and sent documentation, guidelines for documentation, and protocols for leaf sampling by emails.
capdev_justification: Due to Covid, banana collections were carried out mainly by partners. Trainings on setting up and monitoring triple s for governmental personnel were carried out.

outcome_sumary: The application of nine Payments for Agrobiodiversity Conservation (PACS) schemes that have been applied to date in four Latin American countries over the period 2010-2018 was reviewed. These covered 130 threatened varieties across a number of major food crops, and involved over 100 farming communities and 1,100 farmers (45% of which were women). Progress was made to document the diversity of RTB crops in hotspot areas: banana in Samoa, Cook islands, Papua New Guinea (PNG,) and yam in PNG and Benin. In addition, there was extensive genotyping of the collected samples.
milestone_evidence: The application of nine Payments for Agrobiodiversity Conservation (PACS) schemes that have been applied to date in four Latin American countries (Bolivia, Ecuador, Colombia, Peru) over the period 2010-2018 was reviewed. These covered 130 threatened varieties across a number of major food crops and involved over 100 farming communities and 1,100 farmers (45% of which were women).
capdev_justification: Due to Covid, banana collections were carried out mainly by partners. Trainings on agrobiodiversity using bioinformatics for advanced research and academic institutions were carried out.

outcome_sumary: Capacity building in advanced biotechnology techniques for RTB crop improvement has been developed for genome editing through courses and individual training. In addition, application and development of genomic assisted cassava breeding established and operationalised in 5 countries.
milestone_evidence: The training was conducted for data management in SweetpotatoBase, which is one of the Breedbases designed for RTB crops. Application and development of genomic assisted cassava breeding established and operationalized in 5 countries.
gender_justification: Training also targetted women scientists
youth_justification: Training of young breeders and scientists
capdev_justification: Training in advanced statistics to apply mixed models in data analysis.  Training in the application of genomic selection

outcome_sumary: Breeding programs are engaging with the NARS partners in each country where they operate. Collaboration among center and partner breeding programs led to the implementation of product profiles to define breeding targets across the programs. Collaboration with the Breeding Application Programming Interface (BrAPI) community is facilitating interoperability among breeding applications.
milestone_evidence: Product profile and market segment Hackathon convened. Additional activities in 6 countries (Nigeria, Uganda, Ghana, Benin, Vietnam, Cambodia) will be completed in 2021. Also, Breeding Community of Practice activities is an ongoing activity; moreover, with the RTB hackathon, there were over 40 participants from over 10 countries (Nigeria, Togo, Ghana, Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam, Thailand, India, and Myanmar).
other_reason: Breeding Community of Practice activities are ongoing activities.
gender_justification: Hackathon included discussions of integrating gender and breeding tools into product profiles
capdev_justification: Hackathon had a strong CapDev component, as participants shared experiences and provided feedback to breeding programs
climate_justification: Climate-resilient traits part of product profiles and some agro-ecological zones are arider

outcome_sumary: Breeding programs are engaging with the NARS partners in each country where they operate. Collaboration among center and partner breeding programs led to the implementation of product profiles to define breeding targets across the programs. Collaboration with the Breeding Application Programming Interface (BrAPI) community is facilitating interoperability among breeding applications.
milestone_evidence: Application and development of genomic assisted cassava breeding established and operationalized in 5 countries (Zambia, Rwanda, Kenya, Mozambique, Nigeria) and in-process of implementation in other 5 countries (Ghana, Sierra Leone, DR Congo, Cote D'Ivoire, Benin).
gender_justification: New breeding techniques contributed to addressing gender-differentiated trait preferences and nutrition.
youth_justification: Training of young breeders and scientists
capdev_justification: Deliverable is about training sessions for national partners from several countries

outcome_sumary: Adoption of the performance assessment tools is enabling partners to widen the coverage of performance assessment research. Progress was made in the production of improved strains of silver carp in Bangladesh and in the production of genomic data for resilience traits for tilapia.Improved strains were produced for carps (rohu generation 3) and tilapia (genetically improved farmed tilapia - GIFT - generation 17) utilising genomic information.Phenotyping methods for disease resistance, feed efficiency and oxygen resilience were designed and tested.
milestone_evidence:
Silver carp completed in 2020.

outcome_sumary: The Flagship on Land and Water Solutions (LWS) for Sustainable Intensification has revitalized irrigation schemes through supporting irrigation asset management and facilitating learning and innovation platforms (via online events). A Special Issue of International Journal of Water Resources Development was published. Management of irrigation schemes has improved through development and use of tools (e.g. SAMS4i, in-situ measurements), utilization of novel data sources (e.g. Earth Observation inWaPOR project, ground-truthing data) and the development of IT applications for a range of users. Water governance has been supported through water users’ associations and outreach activities for Africa, Asia, and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region.
milestone_evidence: The Special Issue of theInternational Journal of Water Resources Development is now used to support dialogues with donors and policymakers in several countries. (1–3) In Zimbabwe, these published results led to other projects and NGOs using the tools and approaches. The original donor ACIAR funded a further scoping study to evaluate the potential for further work on the integration of irrigation, dryland farming and livestock to develop local food systems based on circular economy principles. ICRISAT used the special issue to introduce the project approach and impact to the coordinator of the large IFAD-funded Participatory Small-scale Irrigation Development Project (PASIDP) in Ethiopia. At their request, we introduced the concept to the IFAD representative in Ethiopia, Mawira Chitima. The aim is for ICRISAT to support the existing PASIDP and contribute to this program’s next development phase.
gender_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Gender as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Gender analysis of the relationship between water user schemes and household dynamics.
youth_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Youth as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Youth analysis related to profitable farming schemes.
capdev_justification: The set of activities covered in the milestone are principally aimed at advancing CapDev.
climate_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Climate Change as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Climate Change component related to the establishment of sustainable projects based on circular economy principles.

outcome_sumary: PIM research informed land-related (forest, rangelands...) policy reforms through work on multistakeholder platforms, land tenure policies, payments for ecosystem services, and inclusion of women, indigenous peoples and minorities in a dozen of countries in Africa, LAC and Asia.
milestone_evidence: The Monitoring and Evaluation of Land in Africa (MELA) project planning workshop was held on October 29, 2020 in collaboration with the African Land Policy Centre and the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), with participation of the Directors/Ministers of Land from the seven IGAD countries. The extension of the milestone is due to delays in the signature of the contract for the MELA project.
gender_justification: The M&E system and manuals have gender dimensions (https://www.dropbox.com/s/filw6s4jozhstly/MELA%20toolkit?dl=0)
youth_justification: The M&E system and manuals have youth dimensions (https://www.dropbox.com/s/filw6s4jozhstly/MELA%20toolkit?dl=0)
capdev_justification: Contribution to strengthening the capacity of national partners
climate_justification: N/A

outcome_sumary: We have continued the implementation of innovative approaches for mitigating climate-related shocks in Asia and Africa. This includes: i) scaling up of index-based flood insurance as one component of bundled measures in India and Bangladesh; ii) development of guidance on equity issues and uptake of weather insurance by marginalized women and men; and iii) extension of drought monitoring and planning to additional countries in Asia (Nepal, Afghanistan) and Africa (commenced roll-out to 16 Southern African countries).
milestone_evidence: During a review of WLE's results framework, this work was integrated into the 2019 milestone (now complete) on 'WLE diagnostic and planning tools (particularly software) developed for flood and drought mitigation across Asia (Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Vietnam, India) are used and supported by national/state governments and UN-SPIDER' and the broader 2020 milestone (now complete) on "Tested WLE solutions for mitigation of, and adaption to, flood and drought risks (including nature based solutions, insurance, pre-event forecasting and post-event monitoring), where possible bundled with complementary solutions from other CRPs (e.g. fisheries and seed options) to enhance adaptive capacity and build resilience to multiple climate risks, further along the pathway to scaling in at least 5 countries (India, Myanmar, Nepal, Vietnam, Sri Lanka)". Refer to the evidence listed under these two milestones for details.
other_reason: The work has been completed under other milestones, as part of a restructure of WLE's results framework
gender_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
youth_justification: The milestone does not target for that objective.
capdev_justification: CapDev is a significant factor in the activities, outputs and analysis for this milestone; however, it is not the main reason for the work. The score is based on the preponderance of Capacity Development as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a significant Capacity Development resulting from the development of training materials for United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs.
climate_justification: The score is based on the preponderance of Climate Change as a cross-cutting dimension identified by projects mapped to the milestone.  Here, deliverables included a Climate Change component related to technical innovation of the South Asia Drought Monitoring System.

outcome_sumary: We have continued the implementation of innovative approaches for mitigating climate-related shocks in Asia and Africa. This includes: i) scaling up of index-based flood insurance as one component of bundled measures in India and Bangladesh; ii) development of guidance on equity issues and uptake of weather insurance by marginalized women and men; and iii) extension of drought monitoring and planning to additional countries in Asia (Nepal, Afghanistan) and Africa (commenced roll-out to 16 Southern African countries).
milestone_evidence: Collaborating with CCAFS, government partners and insurance companies, the continued roll-out of index-based flood insurance in both India and Bangladesh has resulted in increasing numbers of beneficiaries, (1, 2) including casual laborers. (3)We continue to enhance the technical foundation underpinning the South Asia Drought Monitoring System (SADMS), (4–7) the utility of which was extended to Afghanistan and Southern Africa in 2020.We continue to work with the United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UN-SPIDER), including through development of training materials (8) and modification of existing tools to assist with new hazards (e.g. locust swarms). (9)

While this is laudable, the related changes in methodologies put the teams back to the starting line, resulting in significant delays in parallel with those affecting fieldwork during the pandemic.

outcome_sumary: Use of WLE tools in Ethiopia, Uganda, India and Zambia helped identify synergies and tradeoffs in agricultural and natural resource management programs. There is an increased interest in and use of WLE tools by private sector partners and in collaboration with A4NH to leverage synergies and minimize tradeoffs between food and nutrition, livelihoods and environmental sustainability. Insights from a survey among decision makers and researchers identified ways to bridge science and decision making. WLE with Wageningen University contributed to training of researchers and decision makers from some 10 institutions and 10 countries on systems approaches and using WLE tools.
milestone_evidence: FP5 identified ways to better bridge decision making with evidence use through a large survey among decision makers and researchers. (1)The survey was widely distributed via email and online networks (e.g. Ag2Nut community, WBCSD newsletter, Bridge Network, Integrated Landscape Initiative Network). Key insights include: bridging science with policy is facilitated particularly through expert engagement in decision making, consolidating materials to avoid fragmentation of the evidence, and easily accessible online materials; the nature of the institution (public, private, non-profit, research) determines the way evidence is used for decision making more than if the individual is male or female. (1)A reflection piece was also developed on use of evidence under the pandemic. (2)

outcome_sumary: Gender (including age groups) component was well integrated into breeding objectives which informed the understanding of end users’ trait preferences to meet the needs/demands of the target population and accelerate the adoption and impacts of GLDC technologies thereby, effectively and efficiently helping reduce hunger and poverty.
milestone_evidence: Great progress was made towards achieving the FP outcome for 2020. In order to effectively and efficiently reduce hunger and poverty, meet the needs/demands of the target population, accelerate the adoption and impacts of GLDC technologies, the gender component was integrated into breeding objectives which informed the understanding of end users’ trait preferences, assessed through a number value chains, and sex and age disaggregated studies to achieve an inclusive and equitable innovation design and dissemination.
gender_justification: The research design and objective was focused on gender and youth inclusive approaches
youth_justification: Both research and intervention were youth focused in order to target and reach out to youth as key stakeholders and beneficiaries of the dryland agriculture
capdev_justification: Capacity building activities like training was designed and conducted based on the research findings as an intervention to provide the opportunity structure that incentivize and engender youth's involvement in specific value chain nodes.

outcome_sumary: The GLDC scaling framework which integrates nine components required for successful scaling of its innovations was tested using case studies of four large scaling projects. Beyond GLDC, the framework offered a systematic way to review the design of the projects and their scaling initiatives, but was less useful for evaluating project performance. Among components of marketability, policies and institutions, and upstream research, the framework defines policies and institutions as “an enabling environment with supporting institutions and appropriate incentives/absence of bottlenecks.
milestone_evidence: This was completed as a working paper in 2019. GLDC has developed a scaling framework that integrates nine components required for successful scaling of its innovations. We tested the utility of this framework using case studies of four large scaling projects. The framework was useful because it provided a systematic way to review the design of the projects and their scaling methods. This highlighted potential design flaws as well as opportunities for testing alternative scaling methods. The framework was less useful for evaluating project performance.

outcome_sumary: Evaluations of co-management application in coastal fisheries progressed and are being used to inform improvements in policies and practice for co-management, and livelihood diversification at national, regional and global levels.Data collection and analysis was progressed through the global, collaborative Illuminating Hidden Harvests (IHH) research.Trade research was completed through an evaluation in Africa, with research positioned to influence policy in Malawi and Zambia. Global research progressed through a set of “Blue Food Assessment” papers being prepared for the UN Food Systems Summit in 2021.Progress was made in enabling adoption of improvements in fisheries co-management policies and practice, in the Pacific, Bangladesh and Myanmar. Adoption is taking place through direct engagement with policy makers and communities in FISH focal countries.Progress was made in enhancing visibility of small-scale fisheries in various policy initiatives, seeking to avoid marginalising small-holders and the food and nutrition security benefits they provide.Development of tools and approaches to “nutrition sensitive fisheries” made progress, but was extended to incorporate further work on nutrient values of inland fisheries and work on integration of nutrition into the FishBase.
milestone_evidence:
Data collection complete for IHH –four case studies, and nutrition and gender chapters completed by FISH scientists for integration into a 2021 global.
 
Zambia national synthesis & policy consultation completed.  
 
IHH analysis reveal 20% of children in Zambia and Malawi  reliant on fish as only animal source food, locate geographic and social nexus where fish needed most to address micronutrient deficiencies. 
 
Intra-regional trade research illuminated substantially greater volumes of fish and employment (particularly of women) associated with cross-border trade, exposed policy “myths” about the perceived (low) value of the sector and its importance to national and regional economies.  
 
Global analyses complete for trade, climate and justice implications on nutrition potential of capture fisheries. The findings are in press as policy recommendations from the “Blue Food Assessments” to the Scientific Group of the UN Food System Summit 2021.
gender_justification: Sex-disaggregated data collected and analyzed, gender focused analysis (where data existed) produced.
capdev_justification: Data collection processes and analysis were developed and implemented through a collaborative process aiming to build capacities of partner organizations and stakeholders.

outcome_sumary: Three evaluations for hilsa fisheries indicating co-management and livelihood investments have positive returns for productivity and resilience. Evaluations guided revision to Bangladesh Hilsa fishery national management plan (2020-2030) that is now under government consideration.Knowledge on trade-offs was progressed through evaluations of marine fisheries and conservation; on fish in multi-functional landscapes; and on the African Great Lakes region. This helps policies and practices development for managing trade-offs and enhancing food, nutrition and livelihood outcomes.FISH successfully partnered with a number of global, regional and national institutions to enable wider application of governance and production models for improving freshwater fisheries management.
milestone_evidence:
Trade-offs evaluated in 3 systems: 

(1) For marine systems trade-offs between conservation of biodiversity goals and fisheries goals evaluated, as well as social justice goals as changes are navigated in coastal systems.

(2) For multi-functional landscapes trade-offs and opportunities of agricultural development were evaluated – with this and previous evaluations between developed into a guide for water managers – launched with FAO and IWMI in 2020. 

(3) In Africa’s Great Lakes region research protocols were designed, ethics approved and were collected to evaluate the trade-offs and opportunities in the fish oil and fish meal industries – where livelihood and nutrition trade-offs were explicitly examined.  Novel Delphi stakeholder analysis was used to identify policy pathways (in prep).
climate_justification: Climate impacts on justice and distribution of benefits made explicit in the research.

outcome_sumary: Data management platforms were developed for all RTB crops and ontologies have been developed for end user relevant traits. This allows to screen populations for desired traits and digitize the information. In potato, progress made on late blight and bacterial wilt resistance traits in elite varieties.Genomic mapping is allowing the mapping of genes for important traits and providing tools for selecting within populations. Progress in editing will allow desirable traits to be added to popular varieties.
milestone_evidence: Genomic mapping and editing tools applied to RTB Crops: Yam, Cassava, and Banana. Genome editing protocol developed for yam.  CRISPR/Cas9 based editing in banana and plantain were shown to be precise, providing a methodological framework for single or multiple knockouts in banana and plantain. Metabolite database published for root, tuber, and banana crops to facilitate modern breeding

outcome_sumary: Evaluations of co-management application in coastal fisheries progressed and are being used to inform improvements in policies and practice for co-management, and livelihood diversification at national, regional and global levels.Data collection and analysis was progressed through the global, collaborative Illuminating Hidden Harvests research. Trade research was completed through an evaluation in Africa, with research positioned to influence policy in Malawi and Zambia.Progress was made in enabling adoption of improvements in fisheries co-management policies and practice, in the Pacific, Bangladesh and Myanmar. Adoption is taking place through direct engagement with policy makers and communities in FISH focal countries.

Three evaluations for hilsa fisheries indicating co-management and livelihood investments have positive returns for productivity and resilience. Evaluations guided revision to Bangladesh Hilsa fishery national management plan (2020-2030) that is now under government consideration.Knowledge on trade-offs was progressed through evaluations of marine fisheries and conservation; on fish in multi-functional landscapes; and on the African Great Lakes region. This helps policies and practices development for managing trade-offs and enhancing food, nutrition and livelihood outcomes.FISH successfully partnered with a number of global, regional and national institutions to enable wider application of governance and production models for improving freshwater fisheries management.

Target population environments (TPE) analysis was completed for groundnut in India and in progress for pearl millet in India. TPE background information is being gathered for pearl millet in WCA. The GLDC crop cultivars released in 2020 included (1) early-maturing and drought tolerant combined pearl millet and groundnut with resistance to biotic stresses like fusarium wilt in chickpea, downy mildew, androsette disease (2) high oil groundnut variety, (3) forage cultivars of sorghum and millet with high digestibility, (4) blast-resistant finger millet, and fusarium wilt-resistant chickpea. Early-maturing chickpea and soybean cultivars, drought-tolerant groundnut and chickpea cultivars were commercialized in Malawi and India
milestone_evidence: Progress was made towards TPE analysis: completed for groundnut in India and in progress for pearl millet in India and background information being gathered for pearl millet in WCA.
capdev_justification: CapDev component is training of researchers in study locations on the protocols to harmonize the application of the data gathering and data analysis.
climate_justification: TPE analysis will result in better targeting and deployment of varieties especially ones with climate-related values based on observed climatic patterns as component of TPE analysis.

outcome_sumary: Target population environments (TPE) analysis was completed for groundnut in India and in progress for pearl millet in India. TPE background information is being gathered for pearl millet in WCA. The GLDC crop cultivars released in 2020 included (1) early-maturing and drought tolerant combined pearl millet and groundnut with resistance to biotic stresses like fusarium wilt in chickpea, downy mildew, androsette disease (2) high oil groundnut variety, (3) forage cultivars of sorghum and millet with high digestibility, (4) blast-resistant finger millet, and fusarium wilt-resistant chickpea. Early-maturing chickpea and soybean cultivars, drought-tolerant groundnut and chickpea cultivars were commercialized in Malawi and India
milestone_evidence: The GLDC crop cultivars released are early maturing and drought tolerant combined with resistance to biotic stresses like fusarium wilt in chickpea, downy mildew in pearl millet and groundnut rosette disease in groundnut.
capdev_justification: CapDev component of breeding for drought tolerance involved attendance of breeders in conferences to orient on the state of the art, train partners e.g. on screening techniques.

outcome_sumary: Target population environments (TPE) analysis was completed for groundnut in India and in progress for pearl millet in India. TPE background information is being gathered for pearl millet in WCA. The GLDC crop cultivars released in 2020 included (1) early-maturing and drought tolerant combined pearl millet and groundnut with resistance to biotic stresses like fusarium wilt in chickpea, downy mildew, androsette disease (2) high oil groundnut variety, (3) forage cultivars of sorghum and millet with high digestibility, (4) blast-resistant finger millet, and fusarium wilt-resistant chickpea. Early-maturing chickpea and soybean cultivars, drought-tolerant groundnut and chickpea cultivars were commercialized in Malawi and India
milestone_evidence: The GLDC cultivars released for cultivation in 2020 include disease-resistant downy mildew in pearl millet, blast in finger millet, fusarium wilt in chickpea and groundnut rosette disease.
capdev_justification: The breeding pipeline of these varieties were contributed by partners, young scientists, field workers where orientation and training was done to implement the genotype screening and breeding protocols.

outcome_sumary: The process innovations developed and/or deployed include speed breeding, multi-environment testing (MET), product profile design through multi-stakeholder engagement and optimizing the breeding schema of GLDC crop commodities.
milestone_evidence: The process innovations developed and/or deployed include speed breeding, multi-environment testing (MET), product profile design through multi-stakeholder engagement and optimizing the breeding schema of GLDC crop commodities.
capdev_justification: Capacity development included training of students and interns contributing to the GLDC breeding initiatives with partners, capacity building of NARS partners, and integrating crosscutting focals e.g. to make breeding more inclusive.

outcome_sumary: Training and support of smallholder seed multipliers in RTB crops is ongoing in more than 20 countries, of which a large proportion are women. Moreover, RTB seed value chains are contributing to improved yields from access to improved varieties with clean planting material and allowing the growth of product value chains. Socio-economical needs in Uganda and Tanzania better understood. RTB Gender-responsive seed system approaches are accepted by national and local partners. Various studies completed on gendered end-user preferences for processed products of RTB crops, providing insights of critical quality traits to be considered in breeding programs.
milestone_evidence: The Accelerated Value Chain Development (AVCD) project in Kenya improves the productivity of potato farming systems for 20,500 farmers.  Up to 50,000 Bangladeshi women and their households adopted better child feeding practices, and other health measures while growing and eating orange-fleshed sweetpotato (OFSP).  Potato Stakeholder Platforms set up in Malawi, Cameroon, and Uganda. The assembly of the Toolbox for Working with Roots, Tubers, and Banana Seed Systems was completed. This is helping researchers, policymakers, and practitioners use the tools to improve seed systems, which will help foster adoption of improved varieties. The tools were used to evaluate gender impacts in seed systems affected by the banana bunchy top disease in Cameroon, assess banana seed sources and various traits in Uganda, as well as the impacts of gender in accessing banana tissue culture-derived planting material;  create scenarios to manage seed degeneration at different climatic conditions, and to docu
gender_justification: Gender disaggregated data available, Gender inclusion regarding access to seed and robust varieties is the focus in seed system development.
youth_justification: Youth-led seed businesses were officially registered as seed merchants in Kenya to produce certified seed.
capdev_justification: A general strong focus of several clusters on CapDev (see MEL module)
climate_justification: In Kenya and Malawi, potato production is taken to non-traditional agro-ecologies with robust varieties.

outcome_sumary: High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and disease resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha due to quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Satellite nursery production of potato rooted apical cuttings by private sector in Kenya and Uganda. Seed companies and NARS producing certified yam seeds in Ghana and Nigeria.
milestone_evidence: The apical cuttings technology continues to expand with small-scale nursery development to produce cuttings having progressed in 2020.  Breeder and Foundation seed of new improved cassava varieties produced by IITA and NRCRI semi-private seed entities in Nigeria. The YIIFSWA project has developed and promoted techniques for the multiplication of breeder seed yam using TIBs, foundation seed yam using AS and Hydroponic System, and certified seed yam using the Adaptive Yam Minisett Technique (AYMT).
gender_justification: Women are specifically targeted when forming framer groups for training and largely as a result of being more available and more enthusiastic to participate.
capdev_justification: Training in seed production
climate_justification: Seed produced of climate-smart varieties

outcome_sumary: High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and disease resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha due to quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Satellite nursery production of potato rooted apical cuttings by private sector in Kenya and Uganda. Seed companies and NARS producing certified yam seeds in Ghana and Nigeria.
milestone_evidence: The first release of cassava varieties from genomic selection occurred in Nigeria. Conventionally bred Cassava Brown Streak Disease (CBSD) and Cassava Mosaic Disease (CMD) resistant varieties were evaluated in Uganda, DRC, and Tanzania. Five CBSD resilient varieties have been officially released by the Tanzania Agricultural Research Institute in Tanzania.  In Asia, three virus-resistant potato varieties were registered in Georgia, and in Vietnam, in a public-private partnership, CIP and HZPC company are developing tropical varieties with processing quality.  IITA and the National Agricultural Research Organization extended joint banana breeding activities. 49 banana hybrids were highlighted, yielding bunch weights ≥17.0 kg. Significant progressive heterobeltiosis in cross-bred NARITA ‘Matooke’ banana hybrids was demonstrated. Genetic Gain estimates were calculated for population hybrid breeding in sweetpotato, showing impressive gains between 81% and 132% for storage root yield after o
gender_justification: Varieties developed include gender-preferred traits
capdev_justification: Varieties developed jointly with NARS partners
climate_justification: 50 Nutrition Community Scholars were trained to provide nutrition education to project beneficiaries [24533\, 13 extension staffs of Department of Agriculture and Extension and Prodipan were trained on saline tolerant potato variety cultivation

outcome_sumary: New Orange-Fleshed Sweetpotato (OFSP) varieties with high yields and good organoleptic properties released in Africa, including Solo Gold in Nigeria. Potato breeding lines biofortified for iron and zinc have been distributed to Ethiopia, Buthan, Kenya, Rwanda and India for evaluation. In Nigeria, cassava lines biofortified for pro-Vit A have been selected to be targeted for final release, having high carotenoid and high dry matter content. IITA plantain breeding program has incorporated high pro-VitA diploids from Papua New Guinea in the breeding strategy. Testing of high Pro-VItA banana varieties in DRC and Burundi identified several with consumer acceptability for subsequent dissemination.
milestone_evidence: Drought tolerance varieties for sweet potato in Mozambique, Malawi, and South Africa. Provitamin A carotenoid plantain varieties released in Ghana. Late blight resistant and drought tolerance potato varieties released in Kenya, Ethiopia, and Peru. Also, due to the nature variety release, this milestone is completed despite additional varieties will be released in 2021.
gender_justification: Much of the biofortification strategies are targeting women and young children.
youth_justification: Much of the biofortification strategies are targeting women and young children.
capdev_justification: Advanced clones have been already shared with National breeding programs and NARS for further validation and release and/or to be integrated in national breeding programs.

outcome_sumary: An automated phenotyping facility has been set up to screen banana genotypes for drought tolerance. Varieties are being released and further developed with resistances to diseases that will be affected by climate change. Potato varieties with increased heat tolerance have been tested and released in dry hot areas of India and heat tolerant lines have been identified in sweetpotato for inclusion in breeding programs. SMART targets for traits linked with enhanced resilience of RTB populations to climate shocks formulated and included in breeding programs. Increased resilience and food production in rice-potato agri-food systems in Asia.
milestone_evidence: Due to the nature variety release, this milestone is completed despite additional varieties will be released in 2021. Since 2010, 19 drought-tolerant OFSP cultivars have been released in Mozambique, 7 in Malawi, and 2 in South Africa.
capdev_justification: Advanced clones have been already shared with National breeding programs and NARS for further validation and release and/or to be integrated in national breeding programs.
climate_justification: Cassava varieties with resistance to both viruses integral to adaptation to climate change effects on these diseases. The advanced phenotyping facility will allow screening of the diversity in the banana accession collection for drought tolerance and other climatic stresses, under controlled conditions. Breeding for climate-smart potato varieties in Georgia [5767], Kenya [5744; 18443], Peru [14346; 18448] and Vietnam [17976; 17977].

outcome_sumary: Gender roles in seed systems and access to improved varieties studied in Uganda, Tanzania, Kenya, Georgia and South-East Asia. Gendered end-user preferences determined for main food products prepared from RTB crops in Africa to inform quality trait prioritization in breeding programs. G+ Tools for gender responsive breeding were piloted successfully with national partners, with multidisciplinary breeding teams working with cassava in Nigeria and sweetpotato in Uganda. The pilots created awareness and developed capacity in national breeding programs. Gender sensitive and inclusive protocols and guidelines developed, to be used to recruit a network of farmers for participatory varietal evaluation and selection.
milestone_evidence: A review on integrating gender in experimental auctions was conducted and a set of recommendations for collecting data on women's and men's willingness to pay studies for seed was proposed. Gender had a significant effect on the uptake of high-quality planting material (tissue-culture, TC, plantlets) for banana production in Central Uganda. Manual from toolkit shows auctions in Rwanda and Laos.

outcome_sumary: Regulatory frameworks for seed production under discussion in Kenya (potato), Vietnam (cassava and potato), Nigeria (cassava), Tanzania (cassava), Georgia (potato). Seed regulations for potato are being updated with seed regulatory bodies in Cameroon. Quality Declared Seed development of regulations starting in Cameroon, Malawi, Rwanda, Uganda. Seed potato production regulation policy approved by Georgia ministry of agriculture. National seed councils modernized with digital tools for seed quality assessment and certification in Nigeria and Ghana. National and sub-national potato strategies in Cameroon, Ethiopia and Kenya. Contribution to the new regulation promoted by the National Seed Authority in Peru to produce potato seeds.
milestone_evidence: Cassava seed standards launched by the Rwanda Standards Board to enhance the competitiveness of cassava products.  Tanzania passed into law seed certification standards for all classes of seed, from pre-basic to quality declared seed (QDS) for cassava, potato, and sweet potato. Ethiopian National Potato and Sweetpotato Strategy document prepared together with other government development strategies and programs. Distinctness, Uniformity, Stability (DUS), and Value for Cultivation and Use (VCU) test protocols for the homologation of new potato varieties in Cameroon supported by CIP.
capdev_justification: Several individual training involved in seed frameworks.
climate_justification: Seed management practices to control emerging diseases due to climate change (e.g. potato wart and purple top) are being implemented.

outcome_sumary: Research has focused on Single-Diseased Stem Removal (SDSR) for the control of Banana Xanthomonas Wilt (BXW), the use of beneficial microorganisms for the control of Fusarium. The use of AI-powered smartphone apps for the assessment of disease symptoms. These approaches will be integrated into Integrated Pest Management (IPM) packages for the control of these major banana diseasesThe knowledge gained on Cassava Brown Streak Disease (CBSD) incidence on local varieties under different sites will be used to select for suitable varieties to incorporate in CBSD management package. Several Pest Risk Analysis (PRA) documents have been developed but have not yet been adopted to implement policy decisions in target countries.
milestone_evidence: Pest management approaches disseminated and documented in international journals for countries in Latin America (Bolivia, Ecuador, Peru, Colombia), Sub-Saharan Africa (Cameroon, Nigeria, Benin) and South-East Asia (Thailand, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Indonesia, Myanmar, China).
capdev_justification: Extensive delivery of capacity development in integrated pest management (IPM)
climate_justification: Climate-resilient integrated pest management (IPM) solutions delivered

outcome_sumary: Virome data used to predict virus strains evolution; Foc Tropical Race 4 (TR4) spread assessed in South Asia and southern Africa; areas of Thailand affected by the Cassava Mosaic Disease (CMD) pandemic identified; enhanced modeling tools for banana bacterial wilt; survey for potato cyst nematode in Uganda. Extensive Fusarium surveys conducted in southern Africa and Asia to inform on current geographical spread, surveillance strategies, and mitigation efforts.In Banana Xanthomonas Wilt (BXW) affected landscapes, studies on crop diversification and sustainable intensification were carried out, with a special focus on drought and shade tolerant intercrops for enhanced biomass production and yield.
milestone_evidence: Nuru has been widely used across Africa to conduct surveillance of cassava disease and pest damage. PestDisPlace has been applied to support the monitoring of the CMD pandemic in SE Asia. Tumaini has been applied for AI-based detection of banana diseases.
gender_justification: Capacity development for Nuru has targeted women farmers
capdev_justification: Extensive training in Nuru during scaling out efforts
climate_justification: Nuru scaling focused on a climate-resilient root crop

outcome_sumary: Risk maps have been developed and shared with NARS to support surveillance. At the same time several training courses on the use of Insect Life Cycle Modeling (ILCYM) to generate risk maps have been performed.Effects of Climate Change on pest and disease dynamics and spread are being assessed and Pest Risk Assessment have been developed for specific Pest, Disease and country combinations.Models have progressively been developed and improved for various insect pests and recently insect vectored diseases using the ILCYM software, which has also undergone important improvements during the years. With these detailed risk maps have been generated.
milestone_evidence: Trainings have been performed in the use of Insect Life Cycle Modeling (ILCYM) software and the generation of insect life table data for NARS across various countries (a reference to the Capacity Development section). Risk maps have been generated and shared for Andean countries (Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador).
