capdev_justification: Training was an important element of this activity. Introduction and application of Insect Life Cycle Modeling (ILCYM) software for pest phenology modeling and risk assessments developed for advanced research institutions in Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia.
climate_justification: The software application predicts impacts of climate change

outcome_sumary: In Rwanda and Burundi gender roles have been characterized in relation to the production of four crops. Understanding the division of labor and decision-making in crop management may lead to designing better interventions targeted at improving efficiency in smallholder agriculture. Data from PlantVillage Nuru app has shown adoption by both male and female users.Both men and women National Plant Protect Organization (NPPO) officers have been trained in South-East Asian countries and are implementing standard surveillance and diagnostics protocols for Cassava Mosaic Disease (CMD). Materials that explain the importance of gender responsive approaches to disseminating technologies were produced.
milestone_evidence: In Southeast Asia, both men and women plant protection officers have been fundamental for the implemetantion of standard protocols at a regional level and these are documented in an online platform.
gender_justification: PlantVillage Nuru is being strongly promoted with women but also appeals strongly to men
youth_justification: Young people are playing a lead role in teaching farmers how to use Nuru
capdev_justification: Farmer level training and awareness raising are important elements of Nuru scale-out work

outcome_sumary: Plant Protection Center (PPC) of Laos, General Directorate of Agriculture (GDA) in Cambodia, Plant Protection Research Institute (PPRI) in Vietnam. Corporacion Colombiana de Investigacion Agropecuaria (AGROSAVIA) in Colombia for Cassava frogskin disease
milestone_evidence: Different activities developed to determine the state of the art and the incidence of the disease in the eastern part of Colombia in collaboration with the National Plant Protection Organization (NPPO).
capdev_justification: Training has been an important element of building the capabilities of monitoring networks
climate_justification: Training work also includes discussion about the anticipated impacts of climate change

outcome_sumary: Crop management and P&D management practices are developed in collaboration with national partners in the public sector, private sector and with non-governmental organizations. Capacities of partners are strengthened to enhance the uptake of the new technologies and practices and to facilitate their integration in their own extension programs.
milestone_evidence: Results summary: 1) ICT-based decision support tools to scale agronomic technologies and practices for cassava production developed by IITA in collaboration with the Federal University of Agriculture (Nigeria), National Root Crops Research Institute (Nigeria), University of Agriculture (Nigeria). 2) Management practice based on Single Diseased Stem Removal (SDSR) for quick and effective banana recovery in Xanthomonas wilt (XW) affected regions developed and disseminated in collaboration with Catholic Relief Service, Food and Agriculture Organization, Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Livestock (Congo DRC), National Agricultural Research Organization (Uganda), Plateforme Diobass au Kivu (Congo DRC).
capdev_justification: Training is central to the delivery of this milestone. Production, disease and pest management, quality management and certification trainings for farmers.
climate_justification: Integrated pest management (IPM) strategies trained have addressed issues related to the potential impacts of climate change

outcome_sumary: Processes and protocols developed and available for producers, processors, NARS to expand sales of cassava in several countries (Ghana, Democratic Republic of Congo, Nigeria). Evaluation of nutritional composition of RTB crops varieties and identification of critical biophysical traits, sensory attributes and consumer acceptance.
milestone_evidence: More than 4 processes and protocols developed and deposited in the public domain (journal publications) where producers, processors, NARS could access that will expand sales of cassava in several countries (Ghana, Democratic Republic of Congo, Nigeria).
gender_justification: Sweetpotato silage technology being scaled out and offering promising opportunities for women's income and job creation
youth_justification: Sweetpotato silage technology being disseminated by youth groups to trigger the interest of other youth to enter into this business venture
capdev_justification: Training is central to the delivery of this milestone. Development of effective dissemination of Biofortified Sweetpotato program training for key stakeholders.

outcome_sumary: Efficiencies and losses assessed for small sale processors.More efficient technologies disseminated in 3 countries and contributing to reduction of production costs.
milestone_evidence: Objective completed of disseminating more efficient technologies (flash drying; heat exchanger; dewatering press) and waste management options (high-quality cassava peels HQCP; cassava peels substrate for mushroom farming) in at least 3 countries (DR Congo, Nigeria, Ghana, Colombia).
capdev_justification: Training manuals developed and series of capacity development activities conducted to disseminate cassava processing innovations
climate_justification: Options for cassava drying assessed (for both roots and peels) with important long-term implications for climate change adaptation (in face of growing challenges for sun-drying) and mitigation (lower fuel consumption)

outcome_sumary: Post-harvest technologies assessed in 3 countries and piloted in 4 countries
milestone_evidence: A study of sweetpotato vine silage piloted for dairy cattle in Uganda was completed and findings published. Gender-responsive communication tools and approaches for scaling the Triple S Technology in Ethiopia and Ghana published. Ware potato storage practices of farmers and traders in Uganda and performance of improved ambient ware potato stores assessed.
gender_justification: Gender-responsive communication tools and approaches for scaling the Triple S Technology in Ethiopia. Sweetpotato silage offering opportunities for women's income and job creationand Ghana. Sweetpotato silage technology being scaled out and offering promising opportunities for women's income and job creation
youth_justification: Sweetpotato silage technology being disseminated by youth groups to trigger the interest of other youth to enter into this business venture
capdev_justification: Capacity development activities integrated into the innovation process to ensure responsiveness to end-user demand and facilitate uptake
climate_justification: Triple S technology suitable to maintain quality planting material during dry seasons and long dry spells

outcome_sumary: Sweetpotato purees study for inclusion in markers completed and entry points identified.
milestone_evidence: Aseptic Processing of Sweetpotato Purees Using a Continuous Flow Microwave System studied in Kenya.  Bioavailability found to be higher in potato and sweetpotato than other crops
gender_justification: Evidence provided of gender differences in iron absorption in regular and biofortified potato and sweetpotato
youth_justification: Innovation in processing contributing to higher retention of micro-nutrients and particularly important for children and young women in reproductive age
capdev_justification: Capacity development activities integrated into the development of innovative processing methods
climate_justification: Aseptic processing able to extend the shelf-life under ambient conditions

outcome_sumary: From 2017-2020 153 (PhD, MSc and BSc) individuals were trained of which 42% were women. For MSc and BSc degrees gender equity has been reached; in case of PhD students 30% are women scientists. In 2020 gender equity has progressed: 14 PhD students (79% women) and seven MSc students (86% women) were trained through FP 2 R&D activities.
milestone_evidence: More than 100+ students trained where 51% are women between MSc (80) and PhD (63) in intercropping systems, seed production system, and genetic improvement fields for cassava, banana, sweetpotato and potato.
gender_justification: Mandatory gender aspect as per Milestone definition
youth_justification: Majority of trained individuals are young scientists
capdev_justification: This is a CapDev Milestone
climate_justification: Several individual trainings  deal with climate change related topics e.g. seed degeneration, P&D occurrence, resilient varieties, user guide of impact network analysis (INA), potato purple top disease

outcome_sumary: As part of the RTB Scaling Fund and several bilateral projects strategies for the inclusion of RTB innovations in policies and programs executed by government agencies, NGOs and/or private sector are ongoing.
milestone_evidence: In 2020, RTB published three policy outcome stories that document how RTB work has influenced policy. Two cases are related to cassava seed system certification in Tanzania and Rwanda, and one case is related to the mainstreaming of biofortification in the African Union. The cases provide evidence of a critical step towards broader use and impact of RTB innovations.
capdev_justification: Inclusion of RTB innovations requires capacity development of government agencies, NGOs and private sector

outcome_sumary: Bilateral projects in Bangladesh, India, Georgia and Kenya targeted 50-100% of beneficiaries to be women.
milestone_evidence: Studies in Kenya and Bangladesh on understanding how the introduction and commercialization of orange-fleshed sweet potato have affected opportunities and constraints for smallholder sweet potato farmers, particularly women, and assess progress achieving increased utilization of improved orange fleshed sweetpotato (OFSP) and potato varieties by target households (HHs), especially to support and improve the nutrition of small children.
gender_justification: The studies includes Gender as key variable.

outcome_sumary: Whole farm productivity approaches have not implemented in 5 target countries as result of reduced (mapped) projects and partners support in applying the suggested schemes. The COVID-19 situation prevents to achieve this contribution in the remaining time of the project.
milestone_evidence: Limited influence on (mapped) projects and other national initiatives due to COVID-19. The remaining time of project implementation will not allow completing this milestone.

outcome_sumary: Nutrition approaches have not implemented in 5 target countries as result of reduced (mapped) projects and partners support in applying the suggested schemes. The COVID-19 situation prevents to achieve this contribution in the remaining time of the project.
milestone_evidence: Limited influence on (mapped) projects and other national initiatives due to COVID-19. The remaining time of project implementation will not allow completing this milestone.

outcome_sumary: Gender-differentiated perceptions and preferences understood and available to support interventions targeted to increase number of women and youth beneficiaries.
milestone_evidence: Objective completed of understanding the gender-differentiated perceptions and preferences of RTB food products (gari, attiéké, etc) in Nigeria, Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire
gender_justification: Gender differentiated preferences of farmers, processors, traders, and consumers identified for a wide range of RTB crops and products
youth_justification: Age-based differences in perceptions and preference preferences of farmers, processors, traders, and consumers identified for a wide range of RTB crops and products

outcome_sumary: The documentation of soil management practices have not progressed due to change in staff and COVID-19 situation.
milestone_evidence: Scientists in charge were not able to work on the paper due to changes in the staff. The paper will be developed during 2021 but publication will occur in 2022.

outcome_sumary: Opportunities and challenges for specific value chains' nodes identified and available to increase organizational development and capacity to innovate.
milestone_evidence: Studies and review papers on the integration of Fish, roots, tubers, and bananas in agri-food systems were explored. The opportunities for and constraints to integrated production, value-addition, and human consumption were highlighted based on the literature review and ground-truthing in Bangladesh. The studies used and adapted the system approaches to identify and analyze the opportunities and challenges at specific value chains' nodes.
gender_justification: ABS implementation contributes to strengthen fisherfolk's entrepreneurial capacities and establish micro-enterprises. Participants are mostly women
youth_justification: ABS helped identify emerging market opportunities which are being exploited mostly by young women targeted by IFAD large-scale investments
capdev_justification: ABS is a participatory action learning process that involves fisherfolk groups’ participation in value chains. As part of capacity strengthening, ABS comprises a series of group-based experiential learning activities over a production-marketing cycle while interacting with other chain actors and stakeholders.
climate_justification: ABS curriculum has been expanded over time to include climate change considerations in the choice of commodity and value chains to be prioritized

outcome_sumary: Iron bioavailability shown to be high in potato and sweetpotato. This provides evidence for the promotion of iron- biofortified potato and sweetpotato varieties and their development.
milestone_evidence: Due to COVID-19 awareness and advocacy activities to include RTB crops in nutrition programs have been postponed to 2021.
other_reason: Delay in delivering due to COVID-19 context

outcome_sumary: National partners are increasingly aware of the importance of understanding consumer demands
milestone_evidence: One of the RTB Golden Eggs is the G+ Breeding tools that provide an evidence-based protocol that is socially inclusive for customer and product profile development including trait prioritization. The tools have been used in various CGIAR programs including include: cassava in Nigeria, sweetpotato in Uganda, banana in Uganda, and beans in Kenya, and its further uptake and use in the CGIAR is being promoted currently.
gender_justification: The use of Gennovate and other gender-related tools enables more gender-responsive research and development planning and processes
capdev_justification: Capacity development is part of the use of Gennovate and other gender tools

outcome_sumary: Scaling Readiness team has been providing capacity development support through supporting RTB Scaling Fund Projects, providing on demand seminars and trainings, responding information requests from www.scalingreasdiness.org
milestone_evidence: Flagship 5 Clusters have supported and collaborated with a 15 MSc and 10 PhD students (where 52% are women) conducting their thesis research on Flagship 5 related themes and topics. This work has been carried out with international and target-country universities and research programs. Examples include the EVOCA programs led by Wageningen University and the RTB-mapped CIALCA program which develops the capacity of NARS scientists through PhD programs with Belgian Universities.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is part of the adoption and appropriate use of gender-responsive and other flagship tools and approaches

outcome_sumary: Scaling Readiness has become a part of CGIAR Stage Gating, Scaling Readiness has become an integral part of ILRI Impact at Scale Program, ICARDA has commissioned Scaling Readiness Assessments. Five Fund Projects (OFSP Puree, FlashDryer, AKILIMO, Tricot, ICT4BXW) have been supported to develop their scaling models and partnerships. As part of the RTB Scaling Fund, country-specific scaling strategies and partnerships have been developed to advance the scaling of RTB innovations.
milestone_evidence: Flagship 5 has been conducting a number of adoption/ impact studies covering a broad range of RTB crops (cassava, potato, banana, OFSP) and a broad range of RTB countries (Peru, Uganda, Rwanda). The studies have provided insights on the welfare and nutritional impacts of the adoption of RTB Innovations.
gender_justification: One study assesses the impact of a market-oriented gender-sensitive agriculture-health project on household food consumption and food security.
climate_justification: Scaling models are applied to climate change-related innovations

outcome_sumary: Training and support of smallholder seed multipliers in RTB crops is ongoing in more than 20 countries, of which a large proportion are women. Moreover, RTB seed value chains are contributing to improved yields from access to improved varieties with clean planting material and allowing the growth of product value chains. Socio-economical needs in Uganda and Tanzania better understood. RTB Gender-responsive seed system approaches are accepted by national and local partners. Various studies completed on gendered end-user preferences for processed products of RTB crops, providing insights of critical quality traits to be considered in breeding programs.
milestone_evidence: The apical cuttings technology expanded with small-scale nursery development to produce cuttings in 2020. In Kenya and Uganda, seven and five small-scale nurseries sold 198,418 and 26,227 cuttings at an approximate value of 20,000 and 2,600 USD to 943 and 39 farmers, respectively. Women-led seed businesses supported to produce apical cuttings and become seed merchants to produce certified seed in Kenya and Uganda. The  Yam Improvement for Income and Food Security in West Africa (YIIFSWA) project has developed and promoted techniques for the multiplication of breeder seed yam using temporary immersion bioreactor systems (TIBs), foundation seed yam using Hydroponic System, and certified seed yam using the Adaptive Yam Minisett Technique (AYMT).  A total of three hundred and six units of the Platform Temporary Immersion Bioreactor system has been provided to the National Agricultural Research Institutes for plantlets' laboratory production. Semi-Autotrophic Hydroponics (SAH) labs producin
gender_justification: Gender responsive technical training on seed yam production to enhance the capacity women in the yam sector, and modernizing the national seed councils in Ghana and Nigeria with digital tools for seed quality assessment
capdev_justification: NARES (National Root Crops Research Institute in Nigeria, Crop Research Institute in Ghana and private seed companies in Nigeria and Ghana) equipped with high ratio propagation tools for very rapid and quality breeder seed yam production, and the national seed councils in Ghana and Nigeria modernized their seed quality assessment capacity the with digital tools. NARES trained in setting up and managing SAH facilities for cassava plantlet production as nucleus seed.

outcome_sumary: Pre-breeding activities using CWR in cowpea, soybean, chickpea, pearl millet and pigeonpea resulted in identifying lines with abiotic and biotic stress tolerance. In addition, the focus was on the characterization and advancement of stacked (with multiple mode of action Bts) transgenic events for traits (such as Bt in pigeonpea, chickpea) for insect resistance and aflatoxin events in groundnut where natural diversity is not available.
milestone_evidence: Pre-breeding activities using crop wild relatives in cowpea, soybean, chickpea, pearl millet and pigeonpea resulted in identifying lines with abiotic and biotic stress tolerance. In addition, the focus was on the characterization and advancement of stacked (with multiple mode of action Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) ) transgenic events for traits (such as Bt in pigeonpea, chickpea) for insect resistance and aflatoxin events in groundnut where natural diversity is not available.
capdev_justification: Capacity development included in-team training of member scientists , presentations in virtual conferences.

outcome_sumary: SNP markers were deployed for high priority traits as per product profiles in GLDC crops resulting in more than 2.5 M marker datapoints. Molecular breeding lines were released in chickpea and groundnut in Asia and Africa. QC panels for breeding application were developed, validated and deployed in 5 GLDC crops.
milestone_evidence: Single nucleotide polymorphism markers were deployed for high priority traits as per product profiles in grain legume and dryland cereal (GLDC) crops resulting in more than 2.5 million marker data points. Molecular breeding lines were released in chickpea and groundnut in Asia and Africa. Quality check panels for breeding application were developed, validated and deployed in 5 GLDC crops.
capdev_justification: Capacity building of breeding line deployment partners in Asia and Africa, e.g Gene editing workshop, and Empowering young scientists with new skills to develop genomic-assisted climate-resilient crops both held at ICRISAT Hyderabad.

outcome_sumary: Data on GLDC crops research activities were loaded onto Integrated Breeding Platform (IBP), Breeding Management System (BMS) and Genomic Data Management System to manage genotypic and phenotypic data. QuickCrop, the second generation transformation achieved in sorghum and pearl millet and the expression constructs for gene editing applications were developed for targeting primary strigolactone pathway genes in two sorghum and one pearl millet line. Transformative RapidGen methodologies to accelerate breeding cycles in cowpea were developed using a range of 10 cowpea genotypes and overall, 4-6 generations may be taken in a year.
milestone_evidence: The data were loaded onto Dataverse and BMS. GLDC crops data can be accessed using a filter function with search variables.
capdev_justification: Capacity building was done around the integration of GLDC data into databases, and operation of the interface to retrieve data.

outcome_sumary: Data on GLDC crops research activities were loaded onto Integrated Breeding Platform (IBP), Breeding Management System (BMS) and Genomic Data Management System to manage genotypic and phenotypic data. QuickCrop, the second generation transformation achieved in sorghum and pearl millet and the expression constructs for gene editing applications were developed for targeting primary strigolactone pathway genes in two sorghum and one pearl millet line. Transformative RapidGen methodologies to accelerate breeding cycles in cowpea were developed using a range of 10 cowpea genotypes and overall, 4-6 generations may be taken in a year.
milestone_evidence: QuickCrop, the second generation transformation achieved in 2 GLDC crops (sorghum and pearl millet) and the expression constructs for gene editing applications were developed for targeting primary strigolactone pathway genes in two sorghum and one pearl millet line. Transformative RapidGen methodologies to accelerate breeding cycles in cowpea were developed using a range of 10 cowpea genotypes and overall, 4-6 generations may be taken in a year. For climate change related research, various activities under simulated temperature, CO2 and humidity were conducted to study population dynamics, life cycle of pathogens and host response in GLDC legumes.
capdev_justification: CapDev included training of breeders in the use of the new Rapid Generation Advance technology.

outcome_sumary: Scaling Readiness team has been providing capacity development support through supporting RTB Scaling Fund Projects, providing on demand seminars and trainings, responding information requests from www.scalingreasdiness.org
milestone_evidence: Flagship 5 Clusters have supported and collaborated with a 15 MSc and 10 PhD students (where 52% are women) conducting their thesis research on Flagship 5 related themes and topics. This work has been carried out with international and target-country universities and research programs. Examples include the EVOCA programs led by Wageningen University and the RTB-mapped CIALCA program which develops the capacity of NARS scientists through PhD programs with Belgian Universities.
gender_justification: Female trainees have been trained in agricultural extension, sustainable intensification, crop production, and pest management fields.
capdev_justification: Capacity development is part of the adoption and appropriate use of gender-responsive and other flagship tools and approaches

outcome_sumary: Efficiencies and losses assessed for small sale processors.More efficient technologies disseminated in 3 countries and contributing to reduction of production costs.
milestone_evidence: Objective completed of establishing efficiency baselines for 5 postharvest processing technologies used by SMEs in Nigeria, Benin, Cameroon.
gender_justification: Reduction of energy and water consumption in cassava processing primarily benefitting women who are the ones in charge of small-scale processing and firewood collection.
youth_justification: Reduction of energy and water consumption in cassava processing benefitting youth, either young female processors or young entrepreneurs
capdev_justification: Assessment of energy consumption and options for higher efficiency conducted jointly with private firms in order to enhance the likelihood of innovation uptake
climate_justification: Options for cassava drying assessed with important long-term implications for climate change adaptation (in face of growing challenges for sun-drying) and mitigation (lower fuel consumption)

outcome_sumary: In Rwanda and Burundi gender roles have been characterized in relation to the production of four crops. Understanding the division of labor and decision-making in crop management may lead to designing better interventions targeted at improving efficiency in smallholder agriculture. Data from PlantVillage Nuru app has shown adoption by both male and female users.Both men and women National Plant Protect Organization (NPPO) officers have been trained in South-East Asian countries and are implementing standard surveillance and diagnostics protocols for Cassava Mosaic Disease (CMD). Materials that explain the importance of gender responsive approaches to disseminating technologies were produced.
milestone_evidence: An article was published on gender perspectives in the management of pests and diseases in RTB crops as well as a FAQ sheet to support gender-responsive extension work. A Baseline study to evaluate gender dynamics in banana seed systems in Cameroon, Nigeria, and Benin and Lessons on gender-responsive approaches in banana seed systems management were completed in previous years.
gender_justification: This is a gender-focused activity

outcome_sumary: Risk maps have been developed and shared with NARS to support surveillance. At the same time several training courses on the use of Insect Life Cycle Modeling (ILCYM) to generate risk maps have been performed.Effects of Climate Change on pest and disease dynamics and spread are being assessed and Pest Risk Assessment have been developed for specific Pest, Disease and country combinations.Models have progressively been developed and improved for various insect pests and recently insect vectored diseases using the ILCYM software, which has also undergone important improvements during the years. With these detailed risk maps have been generated.
milestone_evidence: A new module called “Geographical simulation by point” was added to Insect Life Cycle Modeling (ILCYM) software. It allows to easily locate the estimated risk index values in georeferenced points and is linked to the temperature database. Update ILCYM with the most recent global climate data maps (2018 maps) and index-interpolater function.  Pest distribution and risk atlas for Africa focusing on potential global and regional distribution and abundance of agricultural and horticultural pests and associated biocontrol agents under current and future climates. Predicting climate-change-caused changes in global temperature on potato tuber moth Phthorimaea operculella (Zeller) distribution and abundance using phenology modeling and geographic information system (GIS) mapping.
capdev_justification: Training was an important element of this activity. Introduction and application of Insect Life Cycle Modeling (ILCYM) software for pest phenology modeling and risk assessments developed for advanced research institutions.

outcome_sumary: An automated phenotyping facility has been set up to screen banana genotypes for drought tolerance. Varieties are being released and further developed with resistances to diseases that will be affected by climate change. Potato varieties with increased heat tolerance have been tested and released in dry hot areas of India and heat tolerant lines have been identified in sweetpotato for inclusion in breeding programs. SMART targets for traits linked with enhanced resilience of RTB populations to climate shocks formulated and included in breeding programs. Increased resilience and food production in rice-potato agri-food systems in Asia.
milestone_evidence: Milestone completed despite the development of climate responsive breeding target is a continuous process. Hackathon convened by RTB Breeding Community of Practice evaluated market segments and product profiles, including agroecological zones.
capdev_justification: Training component for the development of product profiles.
climate_justification: Hand-held decision-making tools, which allows farmers to reduce to the number of sprays applied to control late blight.

outcome_sumary: Training and support of smallholder seed multipliers in RTB crops is ongoing in more than 20 countries, of which a large proportion are women. Moreover, RTB seed value chains are contributing to improved yields from access to improved varieties with clean planting material and allowing the growth of product value chains. Socio-economical needs in Uganda and Tanzania better understood. RTB Gender-responsive seed system approaches are accepted by national and local partners. Various studies completed on gendered end-user preferences for processed products of RTB crops, providing insights of critical quality traits to be considered in breeding programs.
milestone_evidence: The G+ multi stakeholder framework tool is validated. The results of a PVS study in pototato breeding suggests that women and men had the same three clonal preferences but with different internal ranking. Various studies completed on gendered end-user preferences for processed products of RTB crops, providing insights of critical quality traits to be considered in breeding programs. Results published in special issue if IJFST. A first marked intelligence on plantain end users was done in Nigeria. Dodo (fried plantains), boli (roasted plantains), boiled plantain, plantain with beans, and porridge were the most preferred food products identified in the study areas. Fruit size, fruit pulp texture (firmness/softness), colour and taste were identified as the most critical characteristics, with impact on quality of processed food products. Through Community Nutrition Scholars (CNS), especially women were targeted in Bangladesh for agriculture and nutrition training which has led to behavioral changes. For Uganda, it is being developed guidelines and research questions in the banana and sweetpotato seed systems, as well as Peru in potato seed systems.
gender_justification: Women are specifically targeted when forming framer groups for training and largely as a result of being more available and more enthusiastic to participate
capdev_justification: Agriculture and nutrition training which has led to behavioral changes

outcome_sumary: Platform for screening bananas for drought tolerance responses used to screen various genotypes showing different responses. Sweetpotato close wild relatives were screened for drought tolerance, using a platform to assay for short-term memory induction.
milestone_evidence: As an important part of the product profile development, the RTB Breeding Community of Practice (BCoP) organized an online hackathon to review the process of how the RTB center and NARS have defined the market segments and product profiles. In total 42 breeders, economists, gender specialists, and food technologists from 10 organizations and programs participated and reviewed four case studies in break-out groups. Groups also pointed out that the agroecological zones are a too broad concept to define market segments and need to be sub-divided according to different agricultural practices and climatic conditions.
gender_justification: Hackathon included discussions of integrating gender and breeding tools into product profiles
capdev_justification: Hackathon had a strong CapDev component, as participants shared experiences and provided feedback to breeding programs
climate_justification: Climate-resilient traits part of product profiles and some agro-ecological zones are arider

outcome_sumary: New Orange-Fleshed Sweetpotato (OFSP) varieties with high yields and good organoleptic properties released in Africa, including Solo Gold in Nigeria. Potato breeding lines biofortified for iron and zinc have been distributed to Ethiopia, Buthan, Kenya, Rwanda and India for evaluation. In Nigeria, cassava lines biofortified for pro-Vit A have been selected to be targeted for final release, having high carotenoid and high dry matter content. IITA plantain breeding program has incorporated high pro-VitA diploids from Papua New Guinea in the breeding strategy. Testing of high Pro-VItA banana varieties in DRC and Burundi identified several with consumer acceptability for subsequent dissemination.
milestone_evidence: Vit-A-rich orange-fleshed sweetpotato, cassava, and banana varieties already released in more than 10 countries. Yellow cassava lines are advancing with good b-carotene and dry matter content in Uganda and Zambia. Ongoing efforts to release further improved varieties and in more countries such as Malawi, Mozambique, Tanzania, Rwanda, Burundi, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ghana, Kenya
gender_justification: Nutrition components are an important part of traits to benefit women nutrition.
capdev_justification: Varieties developed jointly with NARS partners
climate_justification: Orange-fleshed sweetpotato (OFSP) varieties released with drought tolerance

outcome_sumary: Gender roles in seed systems and access to improved varieties studied in Uganda, Tanzania, Kenya, Georgia and South-East Asia. Gendered end-user preferences determined for main food products prepared from RTB crops in Africa to inform quality trait prioritization in breeding programs. G+ Tools for gender responsive breeding were piloted successfully with national partners, with multidisciplinary breeding teams working with cassava in Nigeria and sweetpotato in Uganda. The pilots created awareness and developed capacity in national breeding programs. Gender sensitive and inclusive protocols and guidelines developed, to be used to recruit a network of farmers for participatory varietal evaluation and selection.
milestone_evidence: In seed systems, gender was integrated into the toolbox for RTB Seed Systems  The multi-stakeholder framework tool was tested in Uganda and Georgia to identify gendered constraints and to develop context-specific approaches towards equitable seed systems. A review on integrating gender in experimental auctions was conducted and a set of recommendations for collecting data on women's and men's willingness to pay studies for seed was proposed. Gender had a significant effect on the uptake of high-quality planting material (tissue-culture, TC, plantlets) for banana production in Central Uganda. Disease pressure of banana bunchy top disease (BBTD) on banana production experienced in southern Cameroon may influence gendered access to resources upsetting resource access equity.  Research tools were also developed for the assessment of gender inequalities in access to and benefits derived from the cassava seed system in Tanzania. Two case studies were conducted to understand gendered access t
gender_justification: Studies look at Gender mainstreaming in root tuber and banana crops seed systems interventions

outcome_sumary: From 2017-2020 153 (PhD, MSc and BSc) individuals were trained of which 42% were women. For MSc and BSc degrees gender equity has been reached; in case of PhD students 30% are women scientists. In 2020 gender equity has progressed: 14 PhD students (79% women) and seven MSc students (86% women) were trained through FP 2 R&D activities.
milestone_evidence: More than 100+ students trained where 51% are women between MSc (80) and PhD (63) in intercropping systems, seed production system, and genetic improvement fields for cassava, banana, sweetpotato and potato.
gender_justification: Mandatory gender aspect as per Milestone definition
youth_justification: The majority of trained individuals are young scientists
capdev_justification: This is a CapDev Milestone
climate_justification: Several individual trainings  deal with climate change related topics e.g. seed degeneration, P&D occurrence, resilient varieties, user guide of impact network analysis (INA), potato purple top disease

outcome_sumary: Research has focused on Single-Diseased Stem Removal (SDSR) for the control of Banana Xanthomonas Wilt (BXW), the use of beneficial microorganisms for the control of Fusarium. The use of AI-powered smartphone apps for the assessment of disease symptoms. These approaches will be integrated into Integrated Pest Management (IPM) packages for the control of these major banana diseasesThe knowledge gained on Cassava Brown Streak Disease (CBSD) incidence on local varieties under different sites will be used to select for suitable varieties to incorporate in CBSD management package. Several Pest Risk Analysis (PRA) documents have been developed but have not yet been adopted to implement policy decisions in target countries.
milestone_evidence: Identical to proposal.Pest Risk Analysis (PRA) developed and shared with NARS. Working documents within cluster CC3.1.2.1 avaialable upon requests.
capdev_justification: Several training courses delivered on pest risk

outcome_sumary: Climate resilient HH options have not implemented in 5 target countries as result of reduced (mapped) projects applying the suggested approaches. The COVID-19 situation prevents to achieve this contribution in the remaining time of the project.
milestone_evidence: Milestone has not been reported by any of the Clusters
other_reason: Milestone has not been reported by any of the Clusters

outcome_sumary: Regulatory frameworks for seed production under discussion in Kenya (potato), Vietnam (cassava and potato), Nigeria (cassava), Tanzania (cassava), Georgia (potato). Seed regulations for potato are being updated with seed regulatory bodies in Cameroon. Quality Declared Seed development of regulations starting in Cameroon, Malawi, Rwanda, Uganda. Seed potato production regulation policy approved by Georgia ministry of agriculture. National seed councils modernized with digital tools for seed quality assessment and certification in Nigeria and Ghana. National and sub-national potato strategies in Cameroon, Ethiopia and Kenya. Contribution to the new regulation promoted by the National Seed Authority in Peru to produce potato seeds.
milestone_evidence: Tools and policy recommendations developed for East and West Africa for potato seed systems and for potato and cassava in Vietnam.  Regulatory frameworks still to be developed. Cross border seed potato trade harmonization in the East African community region under discussion. Protocols for detection and surveillance of potato bacterial wilt developed. Ethiopian National Potato and Sweetpotato Strategy document prepared together with other government development strategies and programs. Potato Seed System Roadmap for Taita Taveta County, Kenya developed. Policy options for advancing seed systems for vegetatively propagated crops in Vietnam.  Manual for Good Agricultural Practices for Field Multiplication of Seed Potato in Cameroon.
gender_justification: the multi-stakeholder framework was used to analyze banana and sweetpotato seed systems in Northern Uganda
capdev_justification: several individual trainings involved in seed frameworks (see CapDev MEL)
climate_justification: Seed management practices to control emgering diseases due to climate change (e.g. potato wart and purple top) are being implemented.

outcome_sumary: High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and disease resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha due to quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Satellite nursery production of potato rooted apical cuttings by private sector in Kenya and Uganda. Seed companies and NARS producing certified yam seeds in Ghana and Nigeria.
milestone_evidence:
In total 2,098 crosses made resulting in 3,485 germinated embryos across breeding sites in Uganda and Tanzania. IITA and NARO have now further extended their joint activities with evaluation trials and preliminary yield trials. Preliminary data highlights 49 hybrids of interest, which are yielding bunch weights ≥17.0 kg. 
A farmer preference ranking and consumer acceptability exercise has identified the most preferred NARITA hybrids for distribution. Yields were ~1.5-2 times higher than the most popular Matooke and had demonstrated resistance to target pests and diseases. Characterization and evaluation of the diversity within the banks' wild population, the ancestor of most edible cultivars showed drought tolerance and avoidance traits within the acuminata population.
gender_justification: Women are specifically targeted when forming framer groups for training and largely as a result of being more available and more enthusiastic to participate.
youth_justification: training of youth: Smeets, Bill. Understanding Water Deficit Response in Bananas: Screening Beneficial Traits in Wild Relatives by Phenotyping Root Properties, Leaf Emergence and Transpiration Dynamics.
capdev_justification: 3 students trained in 2020.
climate_justification: Impact of water deficit on bananas and plantain was researched

outcome_sumary: High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and disease resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha due to quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Satellite nursery production of potato rooted apical cuttings by private sector in Kenya and Uganda. Seed companies and NARS producing certified yam seeds in Ghana and Nigeria.
milestone_evidence: Sweetpotato varieties continuously released in East and South Africa with drought tolerance and high yields.  Trials have shown high yield increases and good consumer acceptability.  As these varieties increase in their adoption, the number of HH with increased yields will grow.

outcome_sumary: High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and disease resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha due to quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Satellite nursery production of potato rooted apical cuttings by private sector in Kenya and Uganda. Seed companies and NARS producing certified yam seeds in Ghana and Nigeria.
milestone_evidence: Increased availability of improved varieties of potato, cassava, and orange-fleshed sweetpotato, with strengthened seed multiplication and supply systems, and improved crop management practices in Malawi.  New potato varieties released in Rwanda after 30 years, with Rwanda Agriculture Board (RAB) producing quality early generation seed. National plan for improving seed potato in Georgia submitted. The apical cuttings technology continues to expand with small-scale nursery development to produce cuttings having progressed in 2020.  Breeder and Foundation seed of new improved cassava varieties produced by IITA and National Root Crops Research Institute (NRCRI), semi-private seed entities in Nigeria.
gender_justification: Packages include women producers as beneficiaries
capdev_justification: Seed produced with national partners
climate_justification: Some varieties are heat or drought tolerant. Heat-tolerant potatoes are being developed, and banana accessions are being screened for drought tolerance.

outcome_sumary: High yielding banana NARITA varieties have been selected based on taste and disease resistance. In Bangladesh, salt-tolerant potato varieties in demo trials showed 20-44% yield increases over local varieties. White guinea yam and water yam varieties with higher yields and good farmer acceptability were recommended for release in Nigeria. In Kenya, 11,000 potato farmers achieved yields of 21 t/ha due to quality seed and GAP technology package, from a baseline of 7.6 t/ha. Satellite nursery production of potato rooted apical cuttings by private sector in Kenya and Uganda. Seed companies and NARS producing certified yam seeds in Ghana and Nigeria.
milestone_evidence: Approaches and tools to better understand the causes and dynamics of seed degeneration have been developed and help in defining integrated seed systems strategies. Case studies have been published for sweetpotato in Uganda and for bananas in Peru, Uganda, Ghana, Ivory Coast, and in the Congo Basin.
capdev_justification: Manuals and online resources developed to help training on the use of tools
climate_justification: Seed degeneration has an interaction with climate change as pest and disease pressure are affected

outcome_sumary: An automated phenotyping facility has been set up to screen banana genotypes for drought tolerance. Varieties are being released and further developed with resistances to diseases that will be affected by climate change. Potato varieties with increased heat tolerance have been tested and released in dry hot areas of India and heat tolerant lines have been identified in sweetpotato for inclusion in breeding programs. SMART targets for traits linked with enhanced resilience of RTB populations to climate shocks formulated and included in breeding programs. Increased resilience and food production in rice-potato agri-food systems in Asia.
milestone_evidence: This milestone's nature is the development of breeding populations with improved resilience for future climates and it is a continuous activity, with new material being developed and incorporated into breeding programs continuously. this milestone is completed despite additional activities that will complete in 2021. In Kenya and Malawi, potato production is taken to non-traditional agro-ecologies with robust varieties. Under Quickgro project in Kenya and Malawi in partnership with James Hutton Institute evaluating short maturity, heat-tolerant potato varieties to enable farmers to battle changing climates and take potato production to non-traditional agro-ecologies.  Banana genotypes screened for drought tolerance under controlled conditions.  Sweetpotato wild relatives screened for drought tolerance to identify new sources for breeding programs. Cassava varieties with resistance to cassava mosaic disease (CMD) and cassava brown streak disease (CBSD) viruses being applied for release.
capdev_justification: Advanced clones have been already shared with National breeding programs and NARS for further validation and release and/or to be integrated in national breeding programs.
climate_justification: Main targets of breeding program are climate resilience traits

outcome_sumary: Virome data used to predict virus strains evolution; Foc Tropical Race 4 (TR4) spread assessed in South Asia and southern Africa; areas of Thailand affected by the Cassava Mosaic Disease (CMD) pandemic identified; enhanced modeling tools for banana bacterial wilt; survey for potato cyst nematode in Uganda. Extensive Fusarium surveys conducted in southern Africa and Asia to inform on current geographical spread, surveillance strategies, and mitigation efforts.In Banana Xanthomonas Wilt (BXW) affected landscapes, studies on crop diversification and sustainable intensification were carried out, with a special focus on drought and shade tolerant intercrops for enhanced biomass production and yield.
milestone_evidence: RTB is developing and promoting soil fertility management practices, water-efficient irrigation practices, weed management strategies together with digital decision support tools that may enhance the access of small-holder farmers to technical advice and valuable crop management knowledge. Examples of ongoing interventions are the African cassava agronomy initiative in Nigeria and Tanzania; Sustainable weed management technologies for cassava systems in Nigeria; Improved soil fertility management for sustainable intensification in potato-based systems in Ethiopia and Kenya; Taking integrated crop management to scale in highland banana systems in East Africa.
capdev_justification: Extensive training and awareness-raising for DSTs, including the introduction of topics into the school curriculum in Nigeria.
climate_justification: Targeting a climate resilient crop

outcome_sumary: Risk maps have been developed and shared with NARS to support surveillance. At the same time several training courses on the use of Insect Life Cycle Modeling (ILCYM) to generate risk maps have been performed.Effects of Climate Change on pest and disease dynamics and spread are being assessed and Pest Risk Assessment have been developed for specific Pest, Disease and country combinations.Models have progressively been developed and improved for various insect pests and recently insect vectored diseases using the ILCYM software, which has also undergone important improvements during the years. With these detailed risk maps have been generated.
milestone_evidence:
The following pest and disease risk assessments have been realized. However, they have not been adopted as official documents in relevant countries:
PRA for Banana Xanthomonas Wilt (BXW)
PRA: Pest risk analysis for Fusarium oxysporium f. sp. Cubense
PRA-Banana Aphid
PRA document for cassava green mite (Mononychellus tanajoa)
Pest Risk Analysis for Prodiplosis longifila for Andean region
Pest Risk Analysis for Prodiplosis longifila for SSA countries
Pest risk analysis for Tecia solanivora
Pest Risk Analysis for Tuta absoluta
capdev_justification: PRAs are designed for capacity strengthening purposes
climate_justification: PRAs anticipate future impacts of climate change

outcome_sumary: Crop management and P&D management practices are developed in collaboration with national partners in the public sector, private sector and with non-governmental organizations. Capacities of partners are strengthened to enhance the uptake of the new technologies and practices and to facilitate their integration in their own extension programs.
milestone_evidence: The capacity to perform pest risk has been strengthened for partners in SE Asia in response to the cassava mosaic disease (CMD) pandemic. This has resulted from the capacity development of national partners in Cambodia, Laos, Thailand, and Vietnam. The capacity of Latin American partners in Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru has been strengthened to respond to potato purple top, and that of the plant health services of Zanzibar and Tanzania has been improved for response to Fusarium Tropical Race 4.
gender_justification: Gender balance groups of trainees
youth_justification: Young people involved in the training and given extra encouragement through the webinar approach
capdev_justification: Training is central to the delivery of this milestone

outcome_sumary: Processes and protocols developed and available for producers, processors, NARS to expand sales of cassava in several countries (Ghana, Democratic Republic of Congo, Nigeria). Evaluation of nutritional composition of RTB crops varieties and identification of critical biophysical traits, sensory attributes and consumer acceptance.
milestone_evidence: The extensive evaluation of the rheology, textural and microstructural properties of yam products carried out. The nutritional composition analysis of RTB crops varieties and identifying critical biophysical traits, sensory attributes and consumer acceptance of RTBs were evaluated and technical reports developed with journal publications.
gender_justification: Biochemical and biophysical protocols for consumer traits that have also been evaluated for gender preferences. Women tend to rank consumer quality traits higher.
capdev_justification: SOP protocols have been jointly developed with NARS and capacities built for adoption, contributing to reduction of time needed for screening breeding material

outcome_sumary: Iron bioavailability shown to be high in potato and sweetpotato. This provides evidence for the promotion of iron- biofortified potato and sweetpotato varieties and their development.
milestone_evidence: Iron bioavailability shown to be higher in potato and sweetpotato than in other crops, with protocols developed and applied to assay iron bioavailability. SinnovaTek shipped a microwave processor to Kenya in 2020. The R&D and production facility was constructed and brought online under restrictive and difficult pandemic circumstances, but it is already well on its way to operating at full capacity. The continuous flow microwave sterilization and aseptic packaging enable superior nutrition and flavor quality for sweetpotato puree.
gender_justification: Iron biofortification especially important for women's nutrition in reproductive ages. Sweetpotato puree with extended shelf life makes it more available.
climate_justification: Transfer of microwave technology to Kenya

outcome_sumary: Post-harvest technologies assessed in 3 countries and piloted in 4 countries
milestone_evidence: This milestone has achieved piloting of technologies and management options for management of post-harvest losses and waste in 3 countries (Uganda, Nigeria, Colombia). Transformation of cassava peels, sweetpotato vines and damaged or poor-quality roots into animal and fish feed has been demonstrated as viable options to add value to waste and sub-products. In Nigeria, CRPs RTB and FISH are exploring strengthen collaboration for better integration of crop-fish agri-food systems.
capdev_justification: Training manuals developed and series of capacity development activities conducted to disseminate innovative ways to process cassava peels into animal feed and mushroom media
climate_justification: Processing cassava waste peels contributes to reduction of GHG emissions. Peel drying options being validated to address the growing challenges for sun-drying due toinvreasingly unpredictable weather

outcome_sumary: Scaling Readiness has become a part of CGIAR Stage Gating, Scaling Readiness has become an integral part of ILRI Impact at Scale Program, ICARDA has commissioned Scaling Readiness Assessments. Five Fund Projects (OFSP Puree, FlashDryer, AKILIMO, Tricot, ICT4BXW) have been supported to develop their scaling models and partnerships. As part of the RTB Scaling Fund, country-specific scaling strategies and partnerships have been developed to advance the scaling of RTB innovations.
milestone_evidence: As part of the Science of Scaling Special Issue and through various collaborations with other CRPs and the CGIAR System Office different scaling models (e.g. Scaling Readiness, Scaling Scan, Stage-gating) have been explored and their uniqueness and synergies have been assessed and documented.
gender_justification: Capacity development is part of the testing and use of scaling models. Training for scaling up agronomic practices to orange-fleshed sweet potato producers and cassava flash dryer at a small scale was carried out.
youth_justification: Scaling models consider age in innovation clients
capdev_justification: Capacity development is part of the testing and use of scaling models

outcome_sumary: The process innovations developed and/or deployed include speed breeding, multi-environment testing (MET), product profile design through multi-stakeholder engagement and optimizing the breeding schema of GLDC crop commodities.
milestone_evidence: High oil groundnut variety and forage cultivars of sorghum and millet with high digestibility (fodder quality) are released.
gender_justification: Pregnant women and young mothers who are in  most need of GLDC crop varieties with high nutritive values benefit from this milestone.
youth_justification: High nutrient value varieties target youth, adolescents in particular to augment micronutrient requirements.
capdev_justification: Multi-location tests and deployment of genotypes to partners organizations entailed capacity training activities.

outcome_sumary: Micronutrient-rich bean varieties with superior agronomic traits were developed and quality seeds disseminated by partners. 12 consumer-preferred bean varieties that are climate resilient were developed. Ethiopia released 4 climate-resilient, farmer-preferred and market-demanded varieties and Rwanda released 8 new farmer preferred HIB varieties [p. 21 CAC report)]
milestone_evidence: 12 consumer-preferred bean varieties that are climate resilient were developed. Ethiopia released 4 climate-resilient, farmer-preferred and market-demanded varieties and Rwanda released 8 new farmer preferred high-iron bean varieties.
gender_justification: Consumer preferences assessed that fed into variety development are gender-disaggregated.

outcome_sumary: Micronutrient-rich bean varieties with superior agronomic traits were developed and quality seeds disseminated by partners. 12 consumer-preferred bean varieties that are climate resilient were developed. Ethiopia released 4 climate-resilient, farmer-preferred and market-demanded varieties and Rwanda released 8 new farmer preferred HIB varieties [p. 21 CAC report)]
milestone_evidence: Micronutrient-rich bean varieties with superior agronomic traits were developed and quality seeds disseminated by partners.

outcome_sumary: Data from annual stakeholder questionnaire used to update breeding profiles have been applied by researchers and partners in Tanzania, Uganda, Ethiopia, Burundi, DRC, Rwanda, Zimbabwe and Malawi resulting in 11 product profiles updated by CIAT.. Seven ICT-based platforms to facilitate bean business actors were designed, piloted and promoted, especially for women farmers. Private and NGO partners were tapped on scaling up the bean platform and extending to processing efforts. Women and youth were particularly targeted to participate and benefit from bean business platforms to address gender gaps and train women and youth on entrepreneurship, business skills and value addition to generate bean products like bean flour.
milestone_evidence: Empowerment of women and youth to participate and benefit from bean business platforms were promoted. Empowerment strategies to address gender gaps included training of women and youth on entrepreneurship, business skills and value addition to generate bean products like bean flour (148 male, 372 female). Women, youth and men (1011) who are opinion leaders were integrated as change agents in the development and delivery of beans, dry bean products and nutrition information in the community.
gender_justification: Gender disaggregation of activity beneficiaries is accounted for.
youth_justification: This milestone caters also to young agri-preneurs and farmers who need capacity development greatly.
capdev_justification: The main aspect of this milestone is CapDev.

outcome_sumary: In Zimbabwe, a total of 53 new populations were advanced (29 for heat tolerance and 24 for drought tolerance). A total 38 progenies were also established F3 (7 progenies), F4 (16 progenies) and F5(15 families). These progresses align to development and wide testing of consumer preferred high yielding, nutritious, stress tolerant and environmentally friendly bush and climbing bean varieties resilient to climate change and variability.In breeding for heat tolerance, a genetic mapping population has been constructed composed of 302 interspecific accessions using the Vascular adhesion protein (VAP) 1 bridging genotype. These materials were sequenced using Genotyping-by-Sequencing (GBS). Currently the phenotyping cycle under heat stress conditions is over and association mapping analyses is being carried out to determine if these interspecific regions explain the observed heat tolerance. Two critical sensitive points in seed development were pinpointed, permitting focus on them in the breeding program. The results permit focusing of future work on heat tolerance in key developmental stages. Genes from Mesoamerican lines have improved heat tolerance in heat-tolerant Andean (HTA) lines, expressed in 3 sites. As in any breeding program, this objective continues but the initial success is significant and a milestone, moving genes across gene pools.Pan-Africa Bean Research Alliance (PABRA) developed and disseminated appropriate climate smart advisories to smallholder farmers for resilience in bean production. Five climate advisory information products delivered in Kenya and Tanzania. Innovative delivery systems for climate-resilient varieties, integrated crop management (ICM) practices and information were strengthened. Twenty-one seed enterprises were established in corridors for the delivery of climate-smart varieties in Rwanda, Uganda, Tanzania, Malawi, and Zimbabwe. Climate smart, environmental and gender friendly pre-and post-harvest integrated crop management practices were adapted and developed -- Conservation Agriculture (CA) in Zambia; mulching in Burundi; drought-tolerant varieties in Kenya, Zimbabwe, Uganda; timely planting and proper spacing in all countries and Solar bubble driers in Kenya, Burundi and Southern Tanzania
milestone_evidence: In consultation with USDA, another 3 markers for QTL were implemented to complement the bgm-1 major gene. This is being implemented through selection at Intertek and has made breeding for virus resistance much more efficient.

milestone_evidence:
PABRA developed and disseminated appropriate climate smart advisories to smallholder farmers for resilience in bean production. Five climate advisory information products delivered in Kenya (3) and Tanzania (2) based on national meteorological forecasts.
In Tanzania, the March - May forecast by the National Meteorological Department was released and shared with bean farmers via WhatsApp on 13 February.
gender_justification: Climate advisories enable women not just to participate more in farm decision making based on data, but also increase their capacity to make use of interventions.
climate_justification: This milestone makes use of advisory services to assist farmers in making farm decisions.

milestone_evidence: Two critical sensitive points in seed development were pinpointed, permitting focus on them in the breeding program. The results permit focusing of future work on heat tolerance in key developmental stages.
climate_justification: Breeding work aligned to this milestone is specifically designed to develop heat tolerance in bean vartieties.

climate_justification: Crop breeding to improve heat tolerance in beans is the main aspect of this milestone.

Climate smart, environmental and gender friendly pre-and post-harvest integrated crop management practices were adapted and developed -- Conservation Agriculture (CA) in Zambia; mulching in Burundi; drought-tolerant varieties in Kenya, Zimbabwe, Uganda; timely planting and proper spacing in all countries and Solar bubble driers in Kenya, Burundi and Southern Tanzania
milestone_evidence: A genetic mapping population has been constructed composed of 302 interspecific accessions using the VAP 1 bridging genotype. These materials were sequenced using GBS. Currently the phenotyping cycle under heat stress conditions is over and association mapping analyses is being carried out to determine if these interspecific regions  explain the observed heat tolerance.

outcome_sumary: In Zimbabwe, a total of 53 new populations were advanced (29 for heat tolerance and 24 for drought tolerance). A total 38 progenies were also established F3 (7 progenies), F4 (16 progenies) and F5(15 families). These progresses align to development and wide testing of consumer preferred high yielding, nutritious, stress tolerant and environmentally friendly bush and climbing bean varieties resilient to climate change and variability.In breeding for heat tolerance, a genetic mapping population has been constructed composed of 302 interspecific accessions using the Vascular adhesion protein (VAP) 1 bridging genotype. These materials were sequenced using Genotyping-by-Sequencing (GBS). Currently the phenotyping cycle under heat stress conditions is over and association mapping analyses is being carried out to determine if these interspecific regions explain the observed heat tolerance. Two critical sensitive points in seed development were pinpointed, permitting focus on them in the breeding program. The results permit focusing of future work on heat tolerance in key developmental stages. Genes from Mesoamerican lines have improved heat tolerance in heat-tolerant Andean (HTA) lines, expressed in 3 sites. As in any breeding program, this objective continues but the initial success is significant and a milestone, moving genes across gene pools.Pan-Africa Bean Research Alliance (PABRA) developed and disseminated appropriate climate smart advisories to smallholder farmers for resilience in bean production. Five climate advisory information products delivered in Kenya and Tanzania. Innovative delivery systems for climate-resilient varieties, integrated crop management (ICM) practices and information were strengthened. Climate smart, environmental and gender friendly pre-and post-harvest integrated crop management practices were adapted and developed -- Conservation Agriculture (CA) in Zambia; mulching in Burundi; drought-tolerant varieties in Kenya, Zimbabwe, Uganda; timely planting and proper spacing in all countries and Solar bubble driers in Kenya, Burundi and Southern Tanzania
milestone_evidence: A paper was published. Data suggests a general quantitative resistance toward root rot disease present in tropical germplasm.
climate_justification: As climate change can aggravate the frequency and intensity of pest and disease effects, breeding for these biotic stress addresses this gap.

outcome_sumary: Research was done and traits were evaluated. Results demonstrate the potential of genomic selection to increase genetic gain in common bean breeding. Prediction abilities improved when more phenotypic data was available and G × E could be accounted for. Furthermore, the developed models allowed us to predict genotypic performance under different environmental stresses. This will be a key factor in the development of common bean varieties adapted to future challenging conditions. More than 300 lines were distributed to partners in Latin America and the Caribbean partners resulting to selection of lines for further study.

This will be a key factor in the development of common bean varieties adapted to future challenging conditions.

milestone_evidence: More than 300 lines were distributed to partners in LAC. Data are being collected for analysis. Partners have selected lines for further study.
climate_justification: Genotypes shared with partners in Latin America and the Caribbean will be evaluated in a wide range of environments including varied climatic regimes.

climate_justification: Milestone`s includes in its main consideration climate change related management practices adoption,

outcome_sumary: Flagship 5 was not able to produce this outcome milestone due to the limited number of bilateral projects mapped to Cluster 5.2. The few projects mapped to Cluster 5.2 have not been specifically or significantly contributing or reporting to the outcome.
milestone_evidence: The limited engagement with funders prevented the development of specific initiatives.

outcome_sumary: Evaluations of co-management application in coastal fisheries progressed and are being used to inform improvements in policies and practice for co-management, and livelihood diversification at national, regional and global levels.Data collection and analysis was progressed through the global, collaborative Illuminating Hidden Harvests (IHH) research.Trade research was completed through an evaluation in Africa, with research positioned to influence policy in Malawi and Zambia. Global research progressed through a set of “Blue Food Assessment” papers being prepared for the UN Food Systems Summit in 2021.Progress was made in enabling adoption of improvements in fisheries co-management policies and practice, in the Pacific, Bangladesh and Myanmar. Adoption is taking place through direct engagement with policy makers and communities in FISH focal countries.Progress was made in enhancing visibility of small-scale fisheries in various policy initiatives, seeking to avoid marginalising small-holders and the food and nutrition security benefits they provide.Development of tools and approaches to “nutrition sensitive fisheries” made progress, but was extended to incorporate further work on nutrient values of inland fisheries and work on integration of nutrition into the FishBase.
milestone_evidence:
A four country meta-analysis and case study was completed (Bangladesh, Cambodia, Sri Lanka and Philippines) and is in press with FAO. Public event held to present main findings. 

Evaluations of Hilsa fisheries co-management and livelihood interventions complete in Bangladesh and Myanmar. An evaluation of investments in hilsa management in Myanmar demonstrated a 1:6 return on each dollar invested in management. 

Methodology for diagnoses and design of livelihood interventions is being applied with lessons from pilots in Timor and Solomon Islands and scaling in Pacific with regional partners.

FAO cooperation on small-scale fisheries evaluations highlighted in the Thirty-fourth Session of the FAO Committee on Fisheries.
gender_justification: Review examined whether, and how studies had dealt with gender
capdev_justification: Review and assessment focus on support capacities of partner organizations and stakeholders in small-scale fisheries.

outcome_sumary: Data from annual stakeholder questionnaire used to update breeding profiles have been applied by researchers and partners in Tanzania, Uganda, Ethiopia, Burundi, DRC, Rwanda, Zimbabwe and Malawi resulting in 11 product profiles updated by CIAT.. Seven ICT-based platforms to facilitate bean business actors were designed, piloted and promoted, especially for women farmers. Private and NGO partners were tapped on scaling up the bean platform and extending to processing efforts. Women and youth were particularly targeted to participate and benefit from bean business platforms to address gender gaps and train women and youth on entrepreneurship, business skills and value addition to generate bean products like bean flour.
milestone_evidence: Seven ICT-based platforms to facilitate bean business actors were designed, piloted and promoted, especially for women farmers: 2 in Ghana, 2 in Kenya within the EAREM corridor, 2 in Cameroon and 1 in Uganda. Were engaged with Eastern Agricultural Development Company Ltd (EADC) and Community Enterprises Development Organization (CEDO) on scaling up the bean platform and extending to processing efforts. Major off-takers were engaged to start organizing bean platforms in Zambia.
capdev_justification: PABRA has developed client-oriented e-resource manuals/tools for both training and information sharing which are useful in connecting with the network members including smallholder farmers and their organizations. PABRA will also continue facilitating and catalyzing digital business to business interactions targeting small and medium enterprises and peer mentoring.

milestone_evidence: PABRA continues to develop and widely test consumer preferred high yielding, nutritious, stress tolerant and environmentally friendly bush and climbing bean varieties resilient to climate change and variability. In Zimbabwe, a total of 53 new populations were advanced (29 for heat tolerance and 24 for drought tolerance). A total 38 progenies were established in September 2020 as follows: F3 (7 progenies), F4 (16 progenies) and F5(15 families) p. 37 CAC Annex
climate_justification: This milestone`s main aspect is breeding for stress tolerant and environmentally friendly bush and climbing bean varieties resilient to climate change and variability, in addition to accounting for consumer preference and nutritional value.

outcome_sumary: The process innovations developed and/or deployed include speed breeding, multi-environment testing (MET), product profile design through multi-stakeholder engagement and optimizing the breeding schema of GLDC crop commodities.
milestone_evidence: Early-maturing chickpea and soybean cultivars, drought-tolerant groundnut and chickpea cultivars in Malawi and India were commercialized.

milestone_evidence: Innovative delivery systems for climate-resilient varieties, ICM practices and information were strengthened. Twenty-one seed enterprises were established in corridors for the delivery of climate-smart varieties in Rwanda (8), Uganda (3), Tanzania (6), Malawi (2) and Zimbabwe (2). Nine  (42.8%) of seed enterprises are owned by women.
These have been completed for 8 countries: Tanzania, Uganda, Ethiopia, Burundi, DRC, Rwanda, Zimbabwe and Malawi. There are 11 product profiles done by CIAT.

outcome_sumary: Sweetpotato purees study for inclusion in markers completed and entry points identified.
milestone_evidence: Research in Rwanda demonstrated that OFSP purée can be an economically viable, vitamin A enhancing ingredient in commercially baked products. A study on the level of compliance to good manufacturing practices and food safety standards in Kenya showed that special attention to hygiene, microbial quality, and safety of OFSP purée is needed. Due to COVID-19 documentation of techniques and development of training material has been carried over to 2021.
other_reason: Delay in delivering due to COVID-19 context

outcome_sumary: New Orange-Fleshed Sweetpotato (OFSP) varieties with high yields and good organoleptic properties released in Africa, including Solo Gold in Nigeria. Potato breeding lines biofortified for iron and zinc have been distributed to Ethiopia, Buthan, Kenya, Rwanda and India for evaluation. In Nigeria, cassava lines biofortified for pro-Vit A have been selected to be targeted for final release, having high carotenoid and high dry matter content. IITA plantain breeding program has incorporated high pro-VitA diploids from Papua New Guinea in the breeding strategy. Testing of high Pro-VItA banana varieties in DRC and Burundi identified several with consumer acceptability for subsequent dissemination.
milestone_evidence: The national release committee in Nigeria recommended extending one additional year of multilocation trial and demonstration of yellow cassava varieties. In Nigeria,  33 genotypes selected from different advanced yield trials across several locations have been identified as potential pipeline genotypes targeted for the final release, having high carotenoid content and high dry matter content. Four plantain varieties close to being released in Tanzania. Also, milestone will be extended to 2021.
other_reason: Nutrient-rich varieties are still under evaluation.
gender_justification: Much of the biofortification strategies are targeting women and young children.
capdev_justification: Advanced clones have been already shared with National breeding programs and NARS for further validation and release and/or to be integrated into national breeding programs.
climate_justification: Potato varieties are also tolerant to abiotic stresses (heat and drought).

outcome_sumary: In Rwanda and Burundi gender roles have been characterized in relation to the production of four crops. Understanding the division of labor and decision-making in crop management may lead to designing better interventions targeted at improving efficiency in smallholder agriculture. Data from PlantVillage Nuru app has shown adoption by both male and female users.Both men and women National Plant Protect Organization (NPPO) officers have been trained in South-East Asian countries and are implementing standard surveillance and diagnostics protocols for Cassava Mosaic Disease (CMD). Materials that explain the importance of gender responsive approaches to disseminating technologies were produced.
milestone_evidence: A study was published describing gender roles in managing banana Xanthomonas wilt in Burundi. Two working papers were drafted describing men’s and women’s knowledge, practices, and attitudes to integrated pest management (IPM) in Laos and Cambodia.
gender_justification: This is a gender-focused activity
climate_justification: Examines also the influence of climate change on RTBs in Burundi and Rwanda
